Smith first floated the idea of a special prosecutor for the S&L crisis in a brief, little-noticed speech on the floor of the House on May 24. His resolution is the first public proposal for an independent counsel to investigate the debacle, which will cost U.S. taxpayers around $325 billion to cover losses to depositors of failed thrifts. If passed in its present form, the resolution wouldn't trigger the provisions of the independent counsel law, which requires the Justice Department to review such requests under certain conditions. In order to be mandatory under the law, the request for a special prosecutor would have to come from a majority of Democrats or Republicans on the House or Senate Judiciary committees. Independent counsels were called in most notably to investigate the Iran-Contra and Watergate scandals. The most recent appointment of a special prosecutor was to investigate allegations of fraud and abuse at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Smith's proposal ``sounds to me like it's a little off the mark,'' said Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett. He said special prosecutors, who are separate from the department, normally investigate high-ranking individuals in the executive branch who are suspected of wrongdoing. In the savings and loan case, the allegations concern members of Congress and individuals outside Washington, Tillett noted. ``I don't think we would have any problems prosecuting those people,'' he said. ``We ought to be able to pursue those cases pretty well on our own without calling in'' a special prosecutor. Several Democratic legislators have accused the Justice Department of dragging its feet in prosecuting S&L fraud cases. About 200 House Democrats recently signed a letter asking Bush to seek additional money for the department to pursue the cases.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested After Hitting Quayle with Sheaf of Papers
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf, ``''Quayle, who xxx to CORRECT Tuesday to Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle is shrugging off an incident in which a man shouting ``I have documents'' hurled a small sheaf of papers at him, knocking him in the head, officials said. Quayle, who was getting into his limousine outside a Capitol Hill office building Wednesday, was not hurt and the papers only grazed him, said his press secretary, David Beckwith. Mwenea Sikuzote, 42, of St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, was arrested and charged with assaulting the vice president, a felony that carries the possibility of a $10,000 fine and up to 10 years in prison upon conviction. ``The guy shouted `I have documents' and proceeded to throw same,'' Beckwith said. But the papers were not enough to inflict damage. Quayle was driven away by his Secret Service agents. One of the papers the man threw appeared to be a letter to President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said one official, but the contents weren't disclosed. ``The vice president is fine,'' Beckwith said. ``He inquired about what the guy's story was. He asked what his problem was but otherwise shrugged off the incident,'' and returned to his office to prepare for his afternoon schedule. Assaulting the president or vice president is a federal crime, a felony in the U.S. code. The man called to Quayle from about 20 feet away as the vice president was getting into the limousine outside the Hart Senate Office Building after a luncheon with senators, Beckwith said. Quayle looked up and the flying roll of papers glanced off his head after first striking the car, Secret Service spokesman Alan Cramer said. The Capitol police assist the Secret Service in blocking pedestrian traffic in situations involving the vice president's motorcade near the Capitol, Cramer said. ``This guy kind of broke through the ranks,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Crossing Point at Berlin Wall To Be Dismantled
DOC.TEXT: For decades, Checkpoint Charlie has been the best-known crossing through the now-crumbling Berlin Wall, a site of demonstrations against hard-line East German Communist leaders and daring dashes to freedom. On Wednesday, the U.S. military announced that the Cold War symbol _ a small building in the middle of a roadway _ will soon be dismantled. Until last year's peaceful revolution in East Germany, people seeking the release of relatives barred from joining them in the West held demonstrations at the checkpoint, some holding up protest signs for weeks. Frequently, East German guards photographed anyone they found suspicious. The checkpoint provided millions of visitors with the feeling they were witnessing something truly dangerous. ``You are leaving the American sector,'' reads a bold sign at Checkpoint Charlie. The warning is repeated in French and Russian. Tourists would simply strode by the checkpoint to the East German control stations 66 feet across the boundary line. In a drab building at the East German outpost, stern-faced guards would scrutinize passports. The clanging, metal doors _ opened by buzzers _ and the ceiling-mounted mirrors that let Communist guards check right down to people's feet were a chilling reminder of the differences between East and West. The crossing itself was designed for use by non-Germans. Occasionally, brave or foolhardy East Germans tried to flee through the maze of concrete and steel barriers set up by the Communists. Usually, East German guards or bullets stopped them. Sometimes it worked. In January 1986, East Berlin construction worker Andreas Bratke made what must have seemed the longest dash of his 23 years, sprinting through Checkpoint Charlie and into the West. Eight months later, Hans-Joachim Pofahl piled his girlfriend and her infant daughter into the front of a loaded gravel truck and barreled through the crossing and into the West in a blaze of Communist gunfire. Abutting the western side of the crossing is the Haus am Checkpoint Charlie museum _ rooms crammed with cars and other means used in daredevil escapes. Photographs document escapes by East Germans over the Berlin Wall, which was built in August 1961 to stem a westward exodus. Other crossings existed, but Checkpoint Charlie was No. 1 in the public's imagination, the crossing that became famous the world over. When the Berlin Wall was opened on Nov. 9, ecstatic East Germans ran, drove and shoved through Checkpoint Charlie on their way to the West _ for many, the first time in their lives. Despite the changes, troops of World War II allies France, Britain and the United States have continued to man the checkpoint. East Germans have also continued to check those entering and leaving East Berlin, and have not said what they will do with their buildings. But the economic and monetary union of the two Germanys is due on July 1, and all border checks are to end in less than a month.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Tax Increase Marks Death of California Tax Revolt
DOC.TEXT: The state that started the nation's tax revolt 12 years ago is taking down the barricades. Californians have voted to double their gasoline tax and raise billions for mass transit, schools and the poor. Fearful of ever growing traffic jams and eventual automotive gridlock, California voters agreed to shoulder an average of $60 a year per motorist in new taxes and approved Proposition 111 by a 52-to-48 percent margin Tuesday. Under the measure, the state gas tax will go from 9 to 18 cents per gallon, raising $15.5 billion for a 10-year freeway building and improvement program. In total dollars, it's the largest tax increase in California history. The measure came more than a decade after California's Proposition 13 started the national tax revolt. Conservatives in a dozen other states tried to copy California, and at least half succeeded. The tax revolt also was credited with helping establish the political climate that got Ronald Reagan elected in 1980. The chief sponsor of Proposition 111, conservative Republican Gov. George Deukmejian, insists it was not an assault on the tax revolt movement because it was a specific tax for a specific purpose _ relief of traffic congestion. ``There is no evidence in these results whatsoever to indicate that the public will now be supportive of a general tax increase where the revenues would go into the general fund for the purpose of expanding the size or scope of government,'' he said Wednesday. ``If there's a lesson to be learned from this it's that the public will support a specific increase in revenues provided they know exactly where that money is going to go. I don't see any other lesson to be learned as a result of this vote on Proposition 111.'' But others see the California vote quite differently. ``It really does end the tax revolt in California, and sends a message to Washington which I dislike intensely,'' said conservative economist Arthur Laffer, who helped win approval of the twin foundations of the California tax revolt _ the property tax-slashing Proposition 13 in 1978 and a lid on government spending the next year. In fact, despite Deukmejian's words, Proposition 111 does far more than raise taxes for highways and mass transit; it also eases the spending limit initiatives. U.S. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner said he was delighted with the vote. He said it validates the Bush adminstration's argument that voters are willing to raise taxes for highways and other transportation needs. California's gas tax ranks 47th in the nation, well below the national average of 15.8 cents a gallon. If other states' taxes stay the same, California will rank 23rd after Proposition 111 goes into full effect in five years. Proposition 111 was extremely popular in freeway-laced cities but soundly rejected in the most rural regions. Supporters said the economy, environment and quality of life were at stake in the vote, and the campaign played off the dramatic demonstration of the need for freeway improvements in the wake of recent California earthquakes. Voters also passed two bond measures, one a companion to Proposition 111 and the other sponsored by environmentalists, that will together provide nearly $3 billion for mass-transit rail construction throughout the state. The ballot carried five other bond measures _ the most bond funding for a single election in California history _ and voters approved them all. They provide $150 million to house the homeless and $2 billion to build prisons, make government buildings safer and upgrade schools and universities. The impetus for passage of the gasoline tax and rail bonds was the growing congestion on California's freeways. California's population has been increasing about 10 times faster than the capacity of its highways. As a result, the average freeway speed during rush hour has dropped in Los Angeles and other urban areas to about 20 mph. Deukmejian maintained that was costing Californians millions of dollars annually in wasted fuel and million of hours in wasted time.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Ethics Expert: Michigan May Become Assisted-Suicide Haven
With PM-Suicide Machine, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Jack Kevorkian's suicide machine has confronted Michigan legal authorities and lawmakers with the possibility their state will become a haven for death-by-choice. Kevorkian, a retired pathologist, said he did nothing illegal when Janet Adkins used his button-operated device to take her life Monday in his van 40 miles from Detroit. Alexander Capron, professor of law and medicine at the University of Southern California and chairman of Congress' biomedical ethics advisory committee, said Wednesday that Michigan may have no legal means to stop Kevorkian from helping someone else die. ``If the state decides that its present law doesn't prohibit this, the Legislature will have to decide whether they want Michigan to be the place that people come to get Kevorkianed,'' said Capron. Attorney General Frank Kelley acknowledged the laws of his state left Kevorkian's status unclear but said the doctor could become a test case. Because of where Mrs. Adkins died, the case is in the hands of Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson, who said a decision on whether to charge Kevorkian might not be made for up to two months. Thompson did, however, request a temporary restraining order preventing further use of Kevorkian's device in the county. Circuit Judge Alice Gilbert refused Wednesday to grant that request but set a hearing for Friday. Adkins, a 54-year-old Alzheimer's victim from Portland, Ore., died after Kevorkian attached her to his device and she pushed a button to inject herself with lethal drugs. Had Adkins used the device in her home state, Kevorkian could have gone to prison for 18 months or longer under a 1981 law. Helping someone commit suicide in Oregon is manslaughter, said Phil Lemman, spokesman for the state Department of Justice. Prosecutors cited two precedents in Michigan that could influence the Kevorkian case. In 1920, the state Supreme Court upheld the murder conviction of man who placed a bottle of poison within reach of his wife, who wanted to commit suicide, Thompson said. But the state Court of Appeals decided in 1983 that a man who gave a gun to a friend who used it to commit suicide shouldn't have been charged, he said. The appeals court said the high court in 1920 had gone too far in extending responsibility for murder to a second party, said James Shonkwiler, executive director of the Prosecuting Attorneys Association of Michigan. ``Murder, by statute, requires that the actor _ the accused _ is the instrument, the cause, of death,'' he said. ``There's an intervening step when the victim acts of his own free will. ``It is by no means clear that Dr. Kevorkian committed a crime,'' Shonkwiler said. ``You have to reach to get to that. The question is, whose will prevailed in the case _ his, or the patient's? That's not clear.''

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Soldier Found Guilty of Treason, Gets Life Sentence
DOC.TEXT: In the first case of a foreign resident being tried for espionage in West Germany, a former U.S. soldier has been sentenced to life in prison for passing NATO secrets to the East over a decade. The Rhineland Palatinate state court convicted former Army Sgt. 1st Class Clyde Lee Conrad, 43, of treason on Wednesday. It found that the Sebring, Ohio, native had passed classified material to the Hungarian and Czechoslovak secret services from 1975 through 1985, and received about $1.2 million for his efforts. Chief Judge Ferdinand Schuth said the former sergeant ``endangered the entire defense capability of the West.'' In reading the judgment, the judge said Conrad's motive for spying was ``pure greed.'' He said had war broken out, the information Conrad passed to the then-Soviet bloc countries ``could have led to a breakdown in the defenses of the Western alliance,'' and ``to capitulation and the use of nuclear weapons on German territory.'' Schuth sentenced Conrad to life imprisoment for spying for the Hungarians. He said Conrad was also guilty of spying for Czechoslovakia on a lesser scale, and sentenced him to four years in prison on that charge. Conrad had been in charge of the 8th Infantry's classified document center. Documents he had access to included NATO strategic war plans and other highly sensitive information. The prosecution in the trial, which began Jan. 18, said Conrad planned to continue spying for the Hungarians even after his discharge. Maj. Robin Higgins, a spokeswoman for the Pentagon in Washington, said she was unaware of the sentence and that the department would have no immediate comment. ABC News reported Wednesday that authorities were investigating another former U.S. Army sergeant, Roderick Ramsay, in connection with the Conrad case. It said Conrad had recruited Ramsay into the spy ring when both were stationed at the 8th Infantry Division in Bad Krueznach, 50 miles west of Frankfurt. The report, which quoted unidentified U.S. sources, said Ramsay had been talking with the FBI. It said the espionage ring had, among other things, smuggled computer parts from the United States to the East bloc via Canada. Conrad was arrested Aug. 23, 1988 on suspicion of heading a West German-based spy ring with Eastern contacts in Sweden and Vienna, Austria. He had spent 20 years in the Army, returing in September 1985, and had lived in West Germany since his discharge. Except for a period from September 1979 to November 1980, when he was based in the United States, Conrad served with the 8th Infantry in West Germany from 1975 until his discharge. He was in charge of the classified document center during the majority of his time with the unit. According to court records, Conrad was introduced to the Hungarian secret service in late autumn of 1975 by his supervisor in the 8th Infantry Division, former U.S. Army Sgt. 1st Class Zoltan Szabo. Szabo, who was convicted of espionage in Austria in 1989, received a 10-month suspended sentence. He identified for investigators some of the documents the court said Conrad sold to the Hungarians. Szabo provided the information against Conrad in a sworn statement to the court and did not come to West Germany for the trial. Two Hungarians, Sandor Kercsik and his brother, Imre, were described by the court as Conrad's main contacts. The two were arrested in 1988 in Sweden and admitted to being agents of the Hungarian secret police. They were sentenced to 18 months in prison for possessing NATO defense material. The Kercsik brothers also provided statements to the Rhineland Palatinate state court with evidence implicating Conrad.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Soviet Immigrants Living on Land Seized in 1967 War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to RESTORE first reference to survey. Picks up 6th pvs, `Although Israel ...' ^By EILEEN ALT POWELL
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 4,000 Soviet Jews are living on land Israel seized from Jordan in 1967, despite Israeli statements that the Soviet Jewish presence on occupied territory is minuscule. Still, a survey completed Wednesday indicated that the scope of the immigration to the occupied West Bank and Arab east Jerusalem is far short of the mass influx feared by Arab states. Movement to those areas constitutes only a small percentage of the 51,700 Jews who have arrived since the Soviet Union liberalized its emigration policies in the spring of 1989. The Israeli government said this week that just 318 Soviet immigrants have moved into the West Bank, seized from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. But the survey by The Associated Press indicated that in addition to those on the West Bank, more than 3,400 Soviets have moved to five suburbs of Arab east Jerusalem since 1989. Although Israel took east Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 war, it annexed it and does not consider the suburbs occupied territory. The issue of settling Soviet Jews on land captured in the 1967 war has become critical to the future flow of immigrants, projected to reach 20,000 a month this year. In response to pressure from Arab states, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last weekend threatened to limit exit permits for Soviet Jews if Israel does not heed appeals to keep Jews from the occupied areas. But the Soviet Union appears to have retracted that threat, a senior U.S. official said on condition of anonymity Wednesday. The official said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze had told Secretary of State James A. Baker III that Soviet emigration policy would not be altered. Israel's government says it has no policy of settling Soviet Jews on occupied territory. But Foreign Minister Moshe Arens told Parliament on Wednesday that the new immigrants are free to settle wherever they want, including the occupied lands. Arab leaders contend the flood of Soviet immigrants could ultimately displace the 1.7 million Palestinians who live in east Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza Strip. They say it might undercut Palestinian efforts to form an independent state. To date, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing government has given only figures for Jews living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. They say 10 percent have settled in Jerusalem, but refuse to give figures for how many are moving to annexed areas of the disputed capital. The Israeli Absorption Ministry said this week that 318 Soviet immigrants have moved to the West Bank, joining the 70,000 Jewish settlers. No Soviet Jews are known to be living in the Gaza Strip. Spot checks of settlements in the West Bank indicated the government figure was accurate. But the AP survey found 1,140 new Soviet immigrant families registered and received services at neighborhood community centers in five suburbs of Arab east Jerusalem in little more than a year. Based on government estimates that there are three to four people in each Soviet immigrant family, the total in Jerusalem translates to 3,420 to 4,560 immigrants in annexed areas. Absorption Ministry spokeswoman Ida Ben-Shitreet refused to confirm or deny the estimate. She said the ministry did not distinguish between immigrants settled in Jewish west Jerusalem or the Arab eastern sector because government policy is to consider Jerusalem a united city. City spokeswoman Bonnie Boxer said she believed the figure of up 4,560 immigrants in annexed areas of Jerusalem was ``too high.'' But she did not provide statistics. Earlier this year, President Bush upset Israeli officials when he restated the long-standing but infrequently expressed U.S. policy that views east Jerusalem as occupied land.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Rises, Dollar Dips
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index rose moderately today, while the dollar dipped after a seven-day rise against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 239.00 points, or 0.73 percent, closing at 33,192.50. The index rose 31.88 points Wednesday. Traders said market players were making arbitrage purchases in the spot market in an attempt to take profits by selling in the futures market today, the last day for June futures contracts. ``The market was at first very cautious because of the chance of heavy sales linked to the expiration of June contracts today, but the index remained strong as the morning gain reassured participants,'' said Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. But trading lacked direction, he added. Akihiro Sezaki, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., said many investors rolled their June futures over into September contracts. Trading was moderate, with first section volume estimated at 650 million shares, up from Wednesday's 600 million. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 152.55 yen, down 0.05 yen from Wednesday's close of 152.60 yen. It opened at 152.49 yen and ranged between 152.40 yen and 152.56 yen. Before today's dip, the dolar had gained 3.15 yen in seven trading days. ``The currency rates hardly moved in the absence of market-affecting news,'' said Mamoru Tabata, a dealer with the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. He said market players felt no immediate need to change positions with the dollar in the 152-153 yen range. ``Unless there is an announcement of changing U.S. monetary policies or the resignation of (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev, the dollar-yen rate would be stuck at the current level,'' Tabata said. About $2.88 billion changed hands in spot trading, down from $7.53 billion the previous day. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.94 points at 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT) from Wednesday's 87.89-point close. The yield was 6.980 percent, down from 6.990 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``On that blue dot, that's where everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever lived, lived out their life.'' _ Astronomer Carl Sagan, discussing a photograph taken by Voyager 1 that shows the Earth a blue dot in an ocean of black 3.8 billion miles away.

``It sets us back in our fight against ignorance, it slows our fight against discrimination, and it undercuts our fight against AIDS.'' _ Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., objecting to an amendment to a congressional bill that would deny food service workers with AIDS civil rights protection and allow them to be banned from handling food.

``I don't believe in kicking someone when they are down, so I have nothing to say about Donald Trump. ... Call me when he's back on his feet.'' _ Former New York City Mayor Edward Koch, no lover of Trump, refusing to join people gloating over the businessman's financial woes.

James W. Jackson Jr., writer-producer of the old PBS series ``Lowell Thomas Remembers,'' was killed Tuesday in an auto accident at age 66. Jackson worked on the acclaimed series during the 1970s. He was a sports editor for The Columbia Record and an announcer and promotion manager for WIS-TV in Columbia. In the mid-1970s, he was instrumental in helping the University of South Carolina get 20th Century-Fox's Movietonews library, valued at $60 million to $100 million. The library has footage from the old newsreels shown in movie theaters from 1919 to 1963.

Joe Loss, a favorite bandleader of Britain's royal family, died in a hospital Wednesday of kidney failure at age 80. Loss was fascinated by dance band music and at 20 became Britain's youngest band leader, playing at the Astoria Ballroom in Charing Cross Road in London. The Joe Loss Orchestra played many years on the cruise ship Queen Elizabeth II and entertained the royal family at Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle. His signature tune ``In the Mood,'' sold 1 million copies.

Neta Lohnes Frazier, an award-winning author, died June 2 at age 100. Of her 14 books for young readers published between 1947 and 1973, four received Junior Literary Guild awards. Most of her works were based on Pacific Northwest history, such as ``Stout-Hearted Seven.'' The story is about children orphaned when they lost their adoptive parents, missionaries Marcus and Narcissa Whitman, in the Whitman Massacre near what is now Walla Walla.

Rev. Vincent J. Hart, former president of St. Peter's College in Jersey City, N.J., died Tuesday at age 91. Hart was dean of studies at Georgetown University from 1931 to 1933. In 1943, Hart was appointed president of St. Peter's College, leaving in 1949. Hart then served as director of development at Fordham University until 1957. For 12 years he was director of the Jesuit Retre at House in Shrub Oak, N.Y.

Dr. John W. Alexander, who helped create New Jersey's first intensive care unit for newborns, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home. He was 71. In the late 1960s, Alexander established a unit for premature and critically ill newborns at Babies Hospital in Newark. He then went on to develop Children's Hospital of New Jersey in Newark. He also worked to get Orange's system of dividing school districts along racial lines abolished in the 1960s.

Joseph Barrett, a poet who taught at the University of Kentucky, died Tuesday at age 39. The cause of death was not immediately known. A West Viginia native, Barrett published a collection of poems, ``Roots Deep in Sand,'' in 1970 and followed it with ``Periods of Lucidity'' in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Pop Singer's Chest Pains Caused by Bruised Ribs
DOC.TEXT: Michael Jackson apparently bruised his ribs during a vigorous dance workout in his bedroom, causing the chest pains that put him in the hospital, his doctor says. Tests of Jackson's heart and lungs revealed no abnormalities, Dr. Mark Zatzkis, a cardiologist, said Wednesday in a statement. The singer should be released from St. Johns Hospital and Health Center this week, said Jackson spokesman Bob Jones. Jackson had complained of chest pains when he went to the hospital Sunday. He suffered costochondritis, or inflammation of the cartilage in the front part of the ribs, Zatzkis said. He apparently hurt himself during a two-hour solo dance session, his regular Sunday routine, at his Los Angeles home. Jackson demands to be left alone during the workout, ``and no one dares disturb him,'' Jones said. Later Wednesday, Jackson's brothers Jackie, Marlon and Randy arrived at the hospital to visit him. Security guards handed a man over to police for allegedly making threats against Jackson. Jacki Lee Adams, 28, was arrested after saying he was going to kill the singer, said Sgt. John Meile. Adams was booked for investigation of giving false information to police, trespassing and threatening bodily harm.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Vows to `Crack Some Heads' if Backers Try Racial Politics
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Jesse Helms warned he will ``crack some heads'' if his backers try to make race an issue in his re-election bid against Harvey Gantt, North Carolina Democrats' first black Senate nominee. ``Race is a non-issue. I told my folks here, and I told my folks in Raleigh, that some heads will be cracked if anything is done that even appears to be racist. Now what y'all call racist is one thing,'' Helms was quoted as saying at a press briefing in Washington on Wednesday by The News and Observer of Raleigh. Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte, won a runoff Tuesday against prosecutor Michael Easley for the right to challenge Helms. Regarding his opponent, Helms said: ``I've never met Mr. Gantt. I did him right many favors when he was mayor of Charlotte, which are a matter of record. As far as I know, he's a nice man. I wish him well _ but not too well.''

DOC.HEAD: Shining Path Rebels Have Formed New Urban Front, Garcia Says
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path rebels have formed a new front to push their insurgency into Lima and other coastal urban areas, President Alan Garcia said after two powerful car bombs exploded within blocks of the Government Palace. Garcia spoke Wednesday in an atmosphere of stepped up rebel attacks in Lima and a series of weekend raids around the capital that resulted in the seizure of five Shining Path safe houses and 31 arrests. The president, who leaves office July 28, said the newly formed People's Defense Revolutionary Movement, is the ``urban, metropolitan organ of the Shining Path.'' The Maoist-inspired Shining Path operates in at least half of Peru, especially in the mountains and jungle, but has had little success in expanding to coastal cities. At least 18,500 people have been killed in political violence related to the decade-old insurgency, which was launched in the Andean highlands. The Shining Path draws much of its support from indigenous peoples resentful of the economic and political dominance in the country of 22 million of descendants of European immigrants. The wave of violence comes four days before a presidential runoff that pits novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, a free-market activist, against centrist agricultural engineer Alberto Fujimori. The Shining Path has called on voters to boycott Sunday's vote and threatened election day ``armed strikes'' in Andean cities. In one of the guerrilla safehouses raided in an upper-class Lima suburb, police found tons of Shining Path documents and propaganda. They also found personal possessions that apparently belonged to Shining Path leader Abimael Guzman. Garcia said he believed the raids proved that ``the chief of terrorism actively participates'' in Shining Path operations. Guzman went underground in 1979 and, over the years, there have been numerous rumors he was dead. The raids also proved that the new urban front has been formed, Garcia said: ``The people who were captured were essential to the new movement.'' Two people were injured in the car bombings near the Government Palace on Tuesday night and Wednesday and Garcia called the upsurge in urban violence a ``desperate response'' to the weekend raids. In other violence Wednesday in Lima, a city of 6 million, four rebels armed with machine guns took over a neighborhood electoral office. They forced the electoral workers outside and set fire to the office. Firefighters said the blaze destroyed most of the documents in the building, including identification for electoral workers. Guerrillas blew up at least three high-tension power pylons Tuesday night, blacking out parts of the capital and other coastal cities where most of Peru's 22 million people live. In pre-dawn attacks Wednesday, guerrillas threw gasoline bombs at a city bus and at a stove factory owned by a senator-elect of Fujimori's Change 90 party, according to police. Tuesday's car bomb went off behind Lima's Roman Catholic cathedral, which faces the main plaza where the Government Palace is located. Police said the cathedral was not damaged, but one passerby was wounded. Operating out of its stronghold in Ayacucho, the Shining Path has spread throughout Peru's highlands since it launched its armed insurgency in May 1980. The movement, which seeks to impose a peasant-worker state, also controls much of Peru's jungle. Efforts to move into Lima's sprawling shantytowns, however, have been countered by strong police crackdowns.

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact Gathers to Debate United Germany, Summit
DOC.TEXT: Warsaw Pact leaders gathered in Moscow today to debate the consequences of a united Germany and address the future of their military alliance in a Europe where a new security order is expected to emerge. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said Tuesday that the Pact would seek a ``transformation'' at the meeting. On the eve of the gathering, Hungary's prime minister said he would tell Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Warsaw Pact is outmoded. ``We intend to make it clear that the Warsaw Pact as a political organization, reflecting confrontation in Europe, is outdated,'' Prime Minister Jozsef Antall said in Budapest. Antall has said he wishes to take his country out of the seven-member Warsaw Pact, but will not make any such move without the consent of all of the pact countries. The alliance was formed in 1955 under Soviet domination, but last year's democratic upheaval in Poland, Hungary, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Romania and Bulgaria ended longtime subservience to Moscow. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have even called for a united Germany to be a member of the NATO alliance, which the Soviets oppose. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said the Warsaw Pact leaders would discuss ``the problems of the all-European structure, disarmament, and strengthening security on the continent, the further cooperation of the members of the Warsaw Pact.'' It added said ``great attention'' would be given to the question of a united Germany, and the integration of the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in a new all-European security structure. Tass said Gorbachev would report on his summit with President Bush and in Washington last week. The Warsaw Pact meeting includes political and military leaders as well as foreign ministers of the member countries. Gorbachev and Bush did not settle their differences over a united Germany's military allegiance. The U.S. president _ and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany _ want the new Germany to be in the Western military alliance. Continuing efforts to settle the differences, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Shevardnadze met in Copenhagen just days after the summit. Baker presented a nine-point package aimed at easing Soviet worries about a united Germany. In turn, he said the Soviet Union had made a new proposal. He did not elaborate. Among the Warsaw Pact leaders attending the conference is East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maziere, who will then travel to Washington for talks.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Works Out School-Finance Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: The Legislature gave final approval to a $528 million school finance package the governor promises to sign, ending months of wrangling over how to meet a court over to steer more money to poor districts. ``I think it's a great step forward. We made some very significant changes in the way we're going to do business in public education in the state of Texas,'' Republican Gov. Bill Clements said Wednesday. In bills passed Tuesday and Wednesday, the House and Senate approved education reforms, budget cuts, fund transfers and a quarter-cent boost in the state sales tax, now 6 cents on the dollar, to help pay for the package. Clements killed two previous plans because they relied on a half-cent increase. But he said he agreed to the quarter-cent increase as a compromise and to fend off the prospect of a court-written funding plan. A judge had previously assigned a court master to write a plan if the Legislature failed to do so. The governor said he is optimistic the tax increase will be rescinded in next year's session. The overhaul became necessary when the state Supreme Court in October declared Texas' school-finance system unconstitutional because of big disparities in spending between rich and poor districts in the 3.1 million-student system. As in most states, schools in Texas are supported primarily by local property taxes. ``I think that what we have passed here and what we have agreed upon will more than satisfy the courts,'' Clements said. ``I think this will lay it to rest.'' Courts have struck down school finance systems in a dozen states in recent years. The others are Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. The Democratic-controlled Legislature has been meeting since February, holding four special sessions on school-finance reform. The $528 million would be pumped into the $13.5 billion-a-year school finance system in the upcoming academic year. Among other things, the package would increase testing of students and give the governor authority to appoint the state education commissioner. The commissioner now is appointed by the state Board of Education. Some lawmakers said the legislation does not go far enough to meet the Supreme Court order. ``Members, we will be back. ... Don't fool yourself. We haven't resolved the issue,'' said Rep. Gregory Luna, a Democrat.

DOC.HEAD: Donations to Help Kidnapped Peorian Coming from Throughout Country
DOC.TEXT: Nursing homes held bake sales and waitresses donated their tips to help raise the $60,000 ransom demanded by Colombian kidnappers holding a former Peoria man more than a month. Donations to help free Scott Heimdal, 27, came in from across the country after his parents, Roy and Marge Heimdal, appealed for help. ``We sat at the kitchen table last night and cried,'' Mrs. Heimdal said Wednesday. ``We just couldn't believe the generosity of total strangers.'' The captors had demanded $1.2 million for Heimdal's release but later lowered the figure. They have threatened to kill him unless the money is delivered to their jungle hideout by Monday. Mrs. Heimdal said $17,000 had come in by late Wednesday to a bank that set up a trust fund, and more than $900 was donated at their home. ``All the waitresses at Jumer's Restaurant donated their tips. Nursing homes have been holding bake sales. A collection was taken up at the Peoria Chiefs baseball game last night,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ``And people have been putting envelopes inside our door with money. They're trying to help save our son's life.'' Heimdal, who headed a dredging operation for a gold mining company in Ecuador, was kidnapped along the Colombian border April 28 by a Maoist guerilla group known as the Popular Liberation Army, said the U.S. Embassy in Quito, Ecuador. State Department spokesman Dave Denny said Wednesday the family was advised not to pay any ransom, in keeping with U.S. policy, ``but families are free to do what they must do.'' The Heimdals took their appeal to the public because their life savings were wiped out seven years ago when Mrs. Heimdal was seriously injured in an accident with a drunken driver.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Expected to End State of Emergency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Speech scheduled at 8:30 a.m EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Most leading newspapers today quoted government officials as saying President F.W. de Klerk would likely end the four-year-old state of emergency in an address to Parliament later in the day. The emergency laws, which include some of the harshest restrictions on political activity ever imposed by South Africa's white rulers, must be renewed by midnight Friday if they are to remain in effect. Beeld, an Afrikaans-language newspaper with strong ties to the government, said the only decision yet to be made was whether the emergency would be lifted totally or partially. The African National Congress and other leading anti-apartheid groups have made the repeal of the emergency one of their preconditions for full-scale negotiations with the government on a new constitution. Most English-language newspapers quoted government sources as saying the emergency decree would be totally lifted. They said the government would rely on previous security legislation passed by Parliament to control unrest and political violence. Most papers based their predictions on Wednesday's six-hour Cabinet meeting, at which the emergency was discussed at length. The Star, the nation's largest daily, said there were ``strong indications that the Cabinet decided ... to end the emergency.'' The Citizen, a pro-government Johannesburg newspaper, said: ``Government sources indicated the end of the state of emergency in its entirety would be more in line with with Mr. De Klerk's moves to normalize South African society as soon as possible than a partial lifting of the emergency.'' Many of the emergency regulations are duplicated in existing legislation, but the emergency decree allowed the government and police to bypass the courts in detaining people without trial, banning political activity, suspending newspapers and censoring public speech. The emergency decree also protected police against prosecution. De Klerk has said he would lift the state of emergency if authorities were confident they could control violence, particularly in the northeastern province of Natal, where more than 500 blacks died in factional fighting in the first three months of this year. Business Day in Johannesburg said senior government officials expected de Klerk to announce that violence in Natal would be dealt with under the existing Public Safety Act. The act enables the minister of law and order to declare the province an unrest area. Some newspapers said that ending the state of emergency at this time could be seen as an opportunity to undermine ANC leader Nelson Mandela's calls for continued sanctions against South Africa. Mandela is on a six-week trip to Europe, North America and Africa. He was scheduled to meet with French President Francois Mitterrand in Paris at about the same time de Klerk was to address Parliament. Business Day quoted Mandela as saying in a French television interview Monday: ``If France reduces sanctions, then the South African government will slow down the rhythm of change.'' Business Day said, ``Mitterrand indicated in talks with De Klerk last month that he would be willing to call for a reassesment of (European Community) policy towards South Africa if the emergency was lifted, political prisoners released and exiles allowed to return.'' ``If they lift it the situation will become chaotic,'' said Moolman Mentz, spokesman for the pro-apartheid Conservative Party. ``They couldn't cope with the violence even with the state of emergency because they were not applying it. Our view is the government is trying to appease everybody.''

DOC.HEAD: Eight Dangle from Bridge to Protest Battleship Arrival
DOC.TEXT: Eight anti-nuclear protesters were arrested for dangling from a bridge in an unsuccessful effort to prevent the battleship New Jersey from entering the Columbia River. The Greenpeace protesters used climbing equipment to attach themselves to the 205-foot-high, 4{-mile-long bridge Wednesday. Each held a banner that read ``Nuclear Free Seas.'' They lowered themselves as much as 50 feet but remained a safe height above the battleship, police said. They climbed back up and were charged with criminal trespass, said state police Lt. Bob Pendleton. He said the eight would remain in jail pending federal charges of violating the safety zone around the ship. Greenpeace spokeswoman Cynthia Rust said group succeeded in getting across its message that nuclear missiles it believes are aboard the New Jersey are endangering the people of Oregon and Washington. The Navy does not say whether its ships are carrying nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Missing After Norwegian Freighter, Japanese Fishing Boat Collide
DOC.TEXT: Eleven Japanese fishermen were missing after their boat collided with a Norwegian freighter and sank today off the island of Miyake-jima, authorities said. A Maritime Safety Agency agency official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said four Japanese fishermen were rescued after the ship sank. It was not immediately known how many fishermen were on aboard the ship, the official said. He said the two ships, the 10,986-ton Nopal Cherry of Lorentzen Shipping Co. of Norway and the Yugen-maru, collided about 50 miles east of Miyake-jima, which is about 100 miles south of Tokyo. The official said no other details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Lower Midwest; Hot Weather in Southwest.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms were over the mid-Mississippi and Ohio valleys early today, and light rain dampened parts of the East, central Plains and Pacific Northwest. Extreme heat lingered in the desert Southwest and southern Plains. Temperatures were expected to hit 110 degrees today in Arizona. Thunderstorms Wednesday spawned nine tornadoes in Colorado, five in Kentucky and three in Indiana, the National Weather Service said. Heavy thunderstorms were expected today in eastern Kansas, northern Arkansas and Missouri. Isolated thunderstorms were likely in Florida, and thunderstorms, some severe, were expected in parts of the Midwest. Thunderstorms with winds gusting into the high 60s and low 70s uprooted trees Wednesday in parts of Kentucky and Tenneesse. Low atmospheric pressure in the Dakotas was expected to draw moisture from the central Plains and Mississippi Valley and create thunderstorms in southern Minnesota and the eastern Dakotas. There were showers early today in Philadelphia and the along the New England coast. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. Skies were fair across much of the southwestern and south-central United States. The high for the nation Wednesday was 109 degrees at Wink, Texas. Other reports at 5 a.m. EDT: _East: Albany, N.Y., 66 cloudy; Atlanta 75 cloudy; Boston 60 showers; Buffalo 58 foggy; Charleston, S.C., 73 hazy; Chattanooga 69 fair; Cleveland 64 foggy; Detroit 58 fair; Hatteras 74 fair; Jacksonville 71 fair; Key West 83 cloudy; Knoxville 68 fair; Macon 73 fair; Miami 79 fair; New York 59 foggy; Philadelphia 69 foggy; Pittsburgh 65 foggy; Portland, Maine 53 rain; Richmond 70 hazy; Tampa 74 foggy; Washington, D.C., 72 partly cloudy. _Central: Birmingham 76 fair; Bismarck 53 partly cloudy; Denver 59 fair; Des Moines 55 fair; Fort Worth 78 partly cloudy; Indianapolis 64 foggy; Kansas City 68 cloudy; Little Rock 75 fair; Louisville 66 thunderstorm; Memphis 77 fair; Nashville 71 fair; New Orleans 76 fair; North Platte 58 cloudy; Oklahoma City 77 windy; Omaha 60 partly cloudy; Rapid City 58 partly cloudy; St. Louis 68 thunderstorm; Minneapolis-St. Paul 56 partly cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 44 fair; San Antonio 79 partly cloudy. _West: Albuquerque 66 fair; Anchorage 52 partly cloudy; Boise 57 cloudy; Casper 52 fair; Fairbanks 53 fair; Great Falls 50 cloudy; Honolulu 76 fair; Las Vegas 78 fair; Los Angeles 62 fair; Medford 49 fair; Pendleton 52 partly cloudy; Phoenix 85 partly cloudy; Portland, Ore., 55 cloudy; Reno 53 fair; Salt Lake City 57 fair; San Diego 63 foggy; San Francisco 57 fair; Seattle 51 fair; Spokane 50 partly cloudy. _International: Calgary 48 partly cloudy; Montreal 48 foggy; Ottawa 55 foggy; Regina 48 fair; Toronto 55 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 54 fair; San Juan 75 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Falls Sharply, Dollar Rises
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices fell sharply in Europe this morning, touching a four-year low in London. The dollar rose in moderate trading. In early London dealings, gold fell briefly to $351.50, its lowest level since July 1986. The movement was a carry over of Asian selling after the Sydney market took gold through $355, a key chart level, dealers said. The move below that chart level, which has been anticipated for weeks, came on the back of Australian producer selling in what was essentially a thin market, they said. Gold's fall, however, continued through Asian dealings and into early European trading. Gold rebounded briefly to $355 on a flurry of Middle East buying orders at the day's low, dealers said. But apparent profit-taking by Middle East investors, along with fears that large Arab players in the gold market would move to push bullion lower again, brought fresh selling into the market. ``It was just a matter of time before it broke $355,'' a Zurich dealer said. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $353.50 a troy ounce, down from $359.50 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $353.25. In Zurich, the bid price was $352.25, down from $358.60 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $5.75 to close at a bid $355.67. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.99 a troy ounce from Wednesday's $5.085. Foreign exchange traders said the U.S. currency was in good demand, though dominated by political considerations rather than new economic data. Traders identified uncertainty about unrest in the Soviet Union and about the impact of German monetary union as the two major themes boosting the dollar. Investors also were reassured by indications from Federal Reserve officials that U.S. interest rates would probably maintain current levels, dealers said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.05 yen to a closing 152.55 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 152.67 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6935 West German marks, up from 1.6870 _1.4381 Swiss francs, up from 1.4280 _5.7088 French francs, up from 5.6870 _1.9005 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8980 _1,245.50 Italian lire, up from 1,241.00 _$1.1700 Canadian, down from $1.1723 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6860, compared with $1.6880 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Explorers Reach World War II Bomber Buried in Greenland Icecap
DOC.TEXT: Explorers bored a 250-foot shaft through the Greenland icecap to a B-17 bomber buried since World War II, said a sponsor who was awaiting word today of their findings. ``They're going to try to enlarge the hole to get into a hatch,'' Pat Epps, president of the Greenland Expedition Society, said Wednesday. One plan was to use hot water from the thermal borer that cut through the Arctic ice to enlarge the bottom of the shaft. If that doesn't work, ``somebody has to go down there with electric chain saws and carve around the airplane,'' Epps said. Epps, who had been on the icecap with the expedition until last week, heard by radio from Greenland on Wednesday morning that the expedition succeeded in reaching the plane. The bomber is one of two B-17s and six twin-engine, P-38 Lightning fighters that crash-landed when they ran out of fuel after being decoyed by false radio transmissions from German submarines while en route to Europe in 1942. Epps and Atlanta architect Richard Taylor formed an expedition to find and salvage the planes. This year, the third consecutive year the men flew to the icecap, a team led by Taylor used a thermal borer to drill the 42-inch diameter shaft to the B-17 named Big Stoop. A second team, led by Angelo Pizzagalli of Burlington, Vt., used a huge auger to bore a hole 16 feet in diameter toward a P-38. Epps, who hopes to fly one of the P-38s off the icecap, said plans call for getting all six fighters out by Sept. 1. The eight planes crash-landed July 15, 1942. Their crews camped in one of the B-17s for nine days until rescuers arrived on dog sleds. In the early 1970s, Col. Carl Rudder, one of the P-38 pilots, mentioned the planes to Roy Degan, a commercial airline pilot who brought the idea of an Arctic expedition to Epps. The explorers eventually obtained search and salvage rights from Denmark, which administers Greenland. In 1988, the society found the aircraft using low-frequency subsurface radar. Last year, expedition members drilled down to the B-17 and brought back poker chip-size pieces of its skin. Epps estimated his group will have spent $800,000 to $1 million by Sept. 1, financed by fund raising and Rolls Ltd., Pizzagalli's non-profit corporation in Vermont.

DOC.HEAD: Nest Built in Missile Launcher Augurs Well, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The prophet Isaiah spoke of beating swords into plowshares, but it took a bird to turn a missile-launcher into a home. The Air Force is cutting up 443 land-based cruise missiles, many of which have been deployed in Europe, as part of the Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces Treaty. The treaty lets Soviet inspectors verify the destruction, which they were doing Wednesday at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base. ``And lo and behold, in one of the transporter erector launchers a bird had built a nest and was sitting on its eggs,'' said Air Force Lt. Col. Robert Yablonski, who headed the American On-Site Inspection Agency team escorting the Soviets. ``And I think that's a good sign for us, it's a good sign for peace, it's a good sign of the cooperative effort between our two sides in building strategic stability in a world that will be peaceful.'' In all, 268 Air Force missiles and 83 launchers have been eliminated, all at Davis-Monthan, since October 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Grabs Spotlight With Controversial Euthanasia Views
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th graf, ``Everyone is ...,'' to CORRECT place of interview; picks up 14th graf, ``The state ...' Subs next-to-last graf, ``Unable to ...,'' to CORRECT when Kevorkian did paintings.
DOC.TEXT: State medical regulators have joined prosecutors in investigating Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the suicide-machine inventor treading the line separating outsider from outlaw. The Department of Licensing and Regulation launched a probe Wednesday of the 62-year-old retired pathologist who hooked an Alzheimer's victim to the drug-injecting apparatus and let her take her life with the press of a button. ``Our role is to gather the facts and evidence and determine what occurred,'' said Mary MacDowell, director of the department's Health Investigation Division. Evidence of a violation of regulations would be referred to the state Board of Medicine, which could reprimand Kevorkian or lift his license, MacDowell said. Meanwhile, Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson has not decided whether to charge Kevorkian with a crime in the death Monday of Janet Adkins. Attorney General Frank Kelley acknowledged the state has no clear-cut law against assisting in a suicide. State Police impounded the suicide machine, but Circuit Judge Alice Gilbert on Wednesday denied Thompson's request for an order barring further use of the device. The judge set another hearing for Friday. Kevorkian, who scorns the medical mainstream as too timid, defended the machine amid the fierce legal and ethical debate its use has stirred. He said a duplicate device could be built within days, but he did not say whether he has arranged other suicides. ``What I'm doing is absolutely ethical,'' Kevorkian said Wednesday on ABC's ``Nightline.'' ``Of course it's audacious, but somebody has to do it. Doctors weren't going to tell anybody, and patients out there want it.'' Mrs. Adkins, 54, had been diagnosed a year ago with Alzheimer's, an incurable disease that leads to progressive deterioration of the brain, and had traveled 2,000 miles from her home in Portland, Ore., to die through the use of Kevorkian's machine. Having read about the device, ``She thought that sounded like a very, very humane and painless way to end her life,'' her husband, Ronald Adkins, said on ``Nightline.'' Kevorkian drove with Mrs. Adkins to a park and attached her to the electric-powered device in the back of his van. Mrs. Adkins pressed a button that delivered chemicals that stopped her heart. Death came within minutes, Kevorkian said. Kevorkian said he offered his device at no cost and would do so for anyone else wanting him to help them die. ``Everyone says to me, `Hey, you're taking on yourself like God.' Well, then, come on and do something,'' he said in an interview on a plaza bench outside city hall in the Detroit suburb of Royal Oak. ``If it's legal, let me do it. If it's illegal, stop me.'' The state Medical Board never has disciplined Kevorkian, MacDowell said. But his support of doctor-assisted euthanasia is only one aspect of a medical career that has placed him well outside the mainstream of his profession. He has advocated medical experimentation on death-row inmates and the use of cadavers' blood in transfusions. Known to friends as ``Dr. Death,'' he scorns the medical community, which he said is cowed by the influence of religion. In 1988, Kevorkian asked the Hemlock Society, which advocates the right to death on demand, to refer terminally ill members to a center he wanted to open in California, founder and executive director Derek Humphry said. ``I persuaded him not to take up in California,'' Humphry said from the Netherlands, where he was presiding over an international convention on right-to-die issues. ``We didn't want to be involved in lawbreaking.'' The Pontiac native received his medical degree in 1952 from the University of Michigan. Colleagues said he was a medical maverick by the time he completed his residency in 1958. ``He's a loner,'' said Dr. Murray Levin, an internal medicine specialist in Bloomfield Hills. ``He's dropped out of medical circles as far as I know. It bothers me why a guy so competent ... is retired.'' ``He's always been a free thinker,'' said Dr. Gerald Abrams, a former classmate of Kevorkian's and now a professor of pathology at the University of Michigan medical school. ``He always impressed us as being very bright, very sincere. His aren't exactly mainstream ideas.'' Kevorkian worked from 1959 to 1966 at Pontiac General Hospital, then operated a diagnostic clinic in Southfield for three years. From 1969 to 1976, he was laboratory director at Saratoga General Hospital in Detroit, then worked at several small hospitals in the Los Angeles area before returning to Michigan. Unable to find work within a medical community hostile to his views, Kevorkian said, he retired in 1982 to study ethics, write articles for European medical and law journals. His friends recalled the surrealistic oil paintings he produced about 15 years ago with medical themes _ and titles like ``Nausea,'' ``Fever'' and ``Coma.'' ``They're pretty powerful,'' Kevorkian said. ``They're not great art, but they've got a lot of impact. I like to shake people up.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Agrees to Allow Reassignment of Food Workers with AIDS.
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 1st graf to make clear the Senate vote is conditional, and that the final language subject to a House-Senate conference
DOC.TEXT: Food service workers with AIDS would be denied the full protection of civil rights legislation for the disabled under an amendment endorsed by both houses of Congress. By a voice vote Wednesday, the Senate agreed to instruct its negotiators reconciling House and Senate versions of the Americans with Disabilities Act to accept the amendment in the House-passed version of the bill. The Senate passed the bill last September by a 76-8 vote. The House passed it, 403-20, last month. Although non-binding, the motion by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., reflected the Senate's attitude toward the amendment. Backed by the restaurant industry, the amendment provides the only exemption for any group of disabled people. Under the amendment, employers in food industries such as restaurants and supermarkets could reassign workers infected with the AIDS virus to areas where they would not be near food. The only other group exempted from the protections of the bill is people _ such as pedophiles or pyromaniacs _ whose mental condition leads to criminal behavior. The Americans with Disabilities Act would grant the same rights to the estimated 43 million disabled Americans that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 gave to blacks and other minorities. Opponents of the AIDS amendment argued that it flies in the face of medical evidence about how the fatal disease is spread. Supporters said restaurants would lose customers if they found out a chef or other employee had AIDS. ``It sets us back in our fight against ignorance, it slows our fight against discrimination, and it undercuts our fight against AIDS,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. AIDS is spread by intimate sexual contact, use of contaminated hypodermic needles, and use of contaminated blood products, according to medical authorities. Homosexual men and intravenous drug users have been the main victims. Helms called the belief that AIDS is spread in limited ways ``conventional wisdom,'' and added: ``You try telling that to John Q. Public.'' The bill does not protect homosexuals or active drug users. Even without the amendment, it doesn't protect anyone whose disease poses a serious risk of contagion. The chief sponsors of the bill, Rep. Steny H. Hoyer, D-Md., and Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said the amendment had been the only serious difference between the House and Senate versions of the bill. Although the voice vote means no individual senator's vote is known, the Senate had voted 53-40 to reject an earlier motion by Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, to kill Helms' motion.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Boy's Death Ruled Accidental
DOC.TEXT: The death of a 6-year-old boy whose disappearance spurred a citywide search has been ruled an accident. Matthew Roberts suffocated after he locked himself in the storage compartment of a station wagon, officials said Wednesday. The medical examiner's office said the boy likely climbed into the 18-by-18-by-12-inch compartment the day he disappeared, said Police Chief Caleb Chandler. Matthew disappeared from his home May 8. His body was found May 23 when someone noticed a strong odor coming from the station wagon parked in the family's driveway. About 10,000 people of Clovis' 25,000 residents joined the search for the boy. ``We accept the results from the medical examiner's office,'' Geoff Roberts, Matthew's father, said Wednesday. ``We know our little boy just fell asleep without suffering. It doesn't bring him back, but it eases our mind.'' General Motors Corp. recalled the cars in 1979 because the self-latching compartment was considered dangerous to children. The owner of the vehicle, a friend of the Roberts, has said he didn't know the car had been recalled.

DOC.HEAD: List of Major Emergency Regulations
DOC.TEXT: The police and some Cabinet ministers have had wide restrictive powers under the 4-year-old national state of emergency. But many of the regulations have not uniformly been enforced since President F.W. de Klerk came to power in August. Many of the powers granted to police under the emergency regulations already existed in security laws. However, the emergency decree bypassed the courts, and granted police indemnity from prosecution for any action they took ``in good faith'' under the emergency. Here are some of the actions police and government ministers have taken under the national emergency declared by former President P.W. Botha on June 12, 1986: _More than 30,000 people, most of them black, were detained for varying lengths of time without being charged with a crime. Some were held for nearly three years. Some were as young as 11 years old. _Police did not have to tell inquiring relatives or lawyers whether they had a missing person in detention, or give any information about a detainee to anyone. _Newspapers were prohibited from reporting the names of detainees without police permission, and it was illegal for anyone, including freed detainees, to describe the circumstances of detention. _When they were released, the government could restrict former detainees to their homes, prohibit them from working, meeting with other people or participating in political activity, although they had never been charged or convicted of a crime. _Police, without warrants, could search any person, building or vehicle and seize anything they wanted. _Security officers could prohibit anyone from carrying out ``any activities or acts whatsoever.'' _More than 20 organizations were banned. _Several newspapers were temporarily suspended from publication. _Journalists were prohibited from being within sight of any political unrest and were immediately arrested if spotted by police. Tape recordings and film were seized without warrants. _Journalists were prohibited from reporting about any police activity in connection with unrest unless police gave their permission. Local newspapers were prohibited from indicating whether news articles had been censored by the emergency regulations. _Certain T-shirts with slogans were made illegal. Police confiscated political banners, flags and pamphlets under the emergency regulations even though they were not prohibited under any law passed by Parliament. _All outdoor political rallies and demonstrations were banned at one time. _Police issued regulations for funerals, limiting the number of mourners, designating who could speak, setting the time and place for the burials. _The government banned ``subversive statements'' from being uttered or reported. Calls for boycotts, strikes of foreign sanctions; statements which might undermine the morale of the military; and at one time, any call for the release of detainees, were defined as subversive.

DOC.HEAD: Flood's Legacy: Mud, Snakes, Spiders and Mold on Mud Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, ``Residents are ...,'' to CORRECT ``since'' to ``after.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: The layers of mud on the floors, bathroom fixtures and walls are not the only legacy of a week of record flooding along the Trinity River. There are the snakes, fire ants and huge furry spiders. And there's the oppressive odor of mold and dead fish. ``I used to be fussy, but now ...,'' Janet Messenger said, her voice trailing off as she surveyed the damp floor, buckled walls and ripped tile of her home on aptly named Mud Street. ``We've had a lot of good times here. It's kind of sad. I don't think we're going to stay.'' Her husband, Charles, gets so upset about their plight he won't even talk about it. Residents are trying to put their lives back together almost two weeks after the water began receding on the Trinity just below the Lake Livingston Dam in southeastern Texas. When torrential rain in early May filled Lake Livingston to record levels, the dam gates were opened wider than ever, flooding bottom land downstream. The river crested 30 feet above flood stage at nearby Liberty on May 25. On Wednesday, the river was still 4 feet above the flood mark at Liberty, which is about 70 miles northeast of Houston. Thirteen deaths were blamed on storms and flooding in northern Texas that also extended into Louisiana and Oklahoma. No deaths or injuries were blamed on the floods along the lower Trinity. But lives were uprooted. ``It's a mess,'' said Dorothy Harrington, who measured more than 6{ feet of water in her house. ``A lot of people are selling out. But we can't afford to and nobody's going to buy it anyway.'' Her husband, Tom, used a scraper to remove inches of mud caked in their garage. She scrubbed sinks and bathtubs in a race against fuzzy green splotches of mold that thrive in the steamy climate. In their front yard, a picnic table, a fence, a squirrel feeder high off the ground and a sign with their name and address were covered with grass, leaves and dirt left behind when the water receded. The retired couple rescued the dangling sign, wiped it off and hung it properly. ``I start one place and end up doing something else,'' Mrs. Harrington said during a break in her cleaning. Water was in the homes of the Camilla Twin Harbors subdivision, adjacent to the dam, for seven days. What many residents wait for now is a visit from someone from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which doles out government aid. John Pencavage, a FEMA agent who verifies claims, said he has been in Texas since early May and expects to remain for several more weeks. He says he wore out a camera taking pictures of damage and hasn't had time to replace it. ``This is home for me _ all I've got left,'' Henry Prlka told Pencavage. Eight feet of water left Prlka's air conditioner broken, his telephone packed with mud and the white ceiling of his mobile home green with mold. ``I'm leaving this time,'' he said. ``It's terrible what's happened to us.'' As of this week, FEMA had received 4,848 applications for aid from Texas families and businesses, spokesman George Burgess said. FEMA also had provided 2,168 families with more than $1.5 million in temporary housing money and 538 families with $1.68 million in grants for emergency aid or repairs not otherwise covered by the Red Cross or insurance. Lonnie Trotti promised to remain and ``float out another one.'' ``It's funny, sad, aggravating, heartbreaking,'' said Trotti, who put his house on stilts after a flood a year ago and still got water this time. ``But I do have a trailer. I can rebuild. And I've still got a place to go fishing.''

DOC.HEAD: Ailing High School Graduate Dies Hours After Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Even during the last hours of his life, Aaron Shoreys didn't give up on his goal of walking across an auditorium stage to claim the high school diploma that meant so much. But in the end, the heart disease he fought all his life made him too weak and he had to go home, where he later died in his mother's arms. ``He wanted that diploma, he wanted to graduate so bad and he was so sick,'' said Jane Shoreys, who had watched and waited with her son for 15 months for a heart-lung transplant that never came. ``He never really said anything but I knew in my heart that it was close to the end _ he was just so weak _ and I think he knew it, too,'' she said. Mrs. Shoreys said her son's determination to graduate never wavered, even though he was too ill to attend graduation rehearsal Monday morning. ``In the afternoon, he said he had to go. He was in line ready to get his diploma when the music started and he just became too weak and we had to take him home.'' The 18-year-old's death was tempered for his family by the fulfillment of his dream to finish high school. ``It was a huge achievement to be able to get his four years done in high school. He did finish on time and he was a good student,'' Mrs. Shoreys said. ``He had a lousy body, but a really good mind.'' ``I'm glad that we got 18 years,'' said his sister, Michelle. ``We were happy about (the graduation). Unfortunately, we weren't able to see him walk down the aisle.'' The flag at Doherty High School was at half-staff Wednesday. Two days earlier, Principal Pasquale Quitadamo had expected to hand Shoreys his diploma. The principal said few in the audience realized why Shoreys didn't show up. ``He was a fighter. He tried his best,'' the principal said. ``If this was what was meant to be, he certainly had to be happy about completing his four years.'' Mrs. Shoreys said her son opened his graduation presents Monday night. At about 2 a.m. Tuesday, ``He called me and I went in and he died,'' she said. Born with a congenital heart defect that also affected his lungs, Shoreys had been on a waiting list for a heart-lung transplant, said his physician, Dr. Allan Goldblatt. ``If there's some sense to his tragic death, it is to bring to the people of this country an understanding that there must be so many Aaron Shoreys who are missing out on the opportunity for a potential future and that opportunity is not going to be available without more organ donors,'' Goldblatt said. Mrs. Shoreys said she and her husband, Peter, agreed to donate any of their son's usable organs. His corneas have been transplanted, she said. ``It would make Aaron very happy,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Census Count Reaches 90 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Census has counted 91 percent of American households, the bureau reported today. The national head count is now entering the home stretch, said bureau director Barbara Bryant. Census takers are still going door-to-door seeking those people who have not yet been counted. The effort is expected to continue at least through the end of June and mop-up activities are likely to continue through August. The first official report on the nation's population is due Dec. 31. The census is mandated by the Constitution every 10 years. The numbers are used to reapportion seats in Congress and to distribute billions of dollars in federal money. Here is a state-by-state list of the percentage of households that have been counted:

DOC.HEAD: Summit Meeting Most Closely Followed News of Month
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was the most closely followed news story of the month, but not among Americans under 30, the Times Mirror Center for People & the Press reported today. The center, which makes monthly studies of how much attention people pay to events in the news, said the Bush-Gorbachev summit was followed ``very closely'' by 38 percent of the American people, making it the top story among those included in the survey. Among persons under age 30, however, only 26 percent paid particular attention to the summit news. The favored story among that group was the flooding in Texas and other Southwestern states, which was followed ``very closely'' by 29 percent. In the overall ratings, the Washington summit far outdrew the Bush-Gorbachev meeting off the coast of Malta in December, which was followed very closely by 21 percent. The Washington summit drew very close attention from 35 percent of people aged 30 to 49. Among those 50 and older, it held the attention of 49 percent. Overall, 34 percent said they followed the Southwestern floods very closely, putting it second to the summit in news interest. Next came the tensions between Moscow and the Baltic republics, at 21 percent; news of the budget summit and the savings and loan scandal, each at 18 percent; racial tensions in New York City, 17 percent; renewed Palestinian rioting, 11 percent; and the elections in Romania, 6 percent. The survey results are based on telephone interviews conducted under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associates among 1,231 adults from June 1-4. Times Mirror said the results are subject to an error of plus or minus 3 percentage points because of sampling and other random effects. The center is a research arm of Times Mirror, which publishes the Los Angeles Times and other newspapers and has other publishing and broadcasting interests.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstration in Kirghiz Capital; Death Toll Rises to 48
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more from Bakatin on mobs at border, clashes; details from Frunze official. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people armed with spears, stones and guns are massing along the border between the Central Asian republics of Kirghizia and Uzbekistan, seeking to avenge the 48 people who have died in ethnic warfare, a top Soviet official said today. Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin told lawmakers in Moscow that the violence, which began three days ago in one town in Kirghizia, had spilled over to Uzbekistan and spread to five regions in Kirghizia. A state of emergency was declared today in Frunze, the capital of Kirghizia, where one person died from a beating, cars were destroyed and thousands of people surrounded Communist Party and government buildings, an official said. They demanded the resignation of the republic's leaders and urged Kirghiz to unite and strike back at Uzbeks, the Tass news agency said. ``Kirghiz, unite!'' and ``Kirghiz to Osh!'' they chanted, referring to the frontier town 195 miles to the south, where the fighting flared Monday over a land dispute, Tass reported. The unrest has been the latest in a series of ethnic outbreaks fueled by poverty or political conflict that have occurred in the more permissive political climate of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's 5-year tenure. The conflicts, especially a bitter feud between Armenia and Azerbaijan in the Caucusus, have claimed hundreds of lives and forced tens of thousands of people to flee their homes in the face of attacks by rival ethnic groups. An estimated 2,000 Uzbeks tried to cross the border from their republic to fight in Osh, but security forces stopped them and sealed all roads between Uzbekistan and Kirghizia, the unofficial Interfax news agency reported. A state of emergency and curfew are in effect in Osh, with troops patrolling the streets and sealing off the city. Overnight in Frunze, security forces fired warning shots to disperse groups of students who ``committed acts of hooliganism,'' damaging a children's hospital, a cloth factory and a market, Tass reported. A state of emergency and curfew were declared in Frunze, where more than 4,000 angry students rallied in the center of the city and demanded a chance to fight Uzbeks, said Ivan V. Pavlov, a department head on the city's party executive committee. Participants at the rally also gave leaders of the republic three days to resign, Tass said. Militia units held back the crowds. A shopkeeper from the bazaar died today from a beating he received the day before, said Pavlov, the city party official. He said no further deaths were reported today but that angry crowds had destroyed 34 cars and several buses. Bakatin, the top Soviet law enforcement official, told parliament that thousands of ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks were ``standing at the ready, striving to avenge wrongdoings.'' He said violence had been reported in Uzbekistan and had spread to five regions in Kirghizia, but he did not identify the sites. Bakatin said the ``local clashes may develop into conflict between the two republics,'' Tass said. ``The militia cannot handle inter-ethnic conflicts, particularly in the kindling of cave-dwelling and medieval nationalism,'' Bakatin said in a speech to the Soviet of Nationalities, one of two houses of the Soviet parliament. Tass's English-language service left out Bakatin's reference to ``cave-dwelling and medieval,'' which were carried on its Russian wires. The Uzbeks and the Kirghiz are predominantly Sunni Moslem ethnic groups that speak different Turkic dialects. Soviet Central Asia, with high levels of poverty and unemployment, has been hit repeatedly by violence since Gorbachev began to relax central controls. The country's worsening economic crisis has hit the region particularly hard. In the fighting at Osh since Saturday, 48 people have been killed, 11 of them in the previous 24 hours, and 333 injured, including 42 ``law and order personnel'' _ 39 militiamen and three soldiers, Bakatin said. Security forces ``stood between the warring bands of Kirghiz and Uzbeks,'' said Bakatin, adding that 1,500 regular army soldiers, 900 Interior Ministry militia and troops, and 450 troops under the KGB border guard were trying to keep order in Osh. The fighting was triggered by the distribution of land for individual houses in Osh, a heavily populated area along the twisting border between Uzbekistan and Kirghizia, Bakatin said. He blamed the dispute on ``folly, self-conceit and a bureaucratic approach to the division of land where the interests of one nationality were ignored,'' but gave no further details.
