The area is closed to Western correspondents and official accounts of the unrest and the death toll have been sketchy.

DOC.HEAD: Pay Phones Take Technical Step Back To Combat Drug Deals
DOC.TEXT: Pay phones in an inner-city park are going low-tech to combat drug dealers who rely on push-button models. Modern telephones in MacArthur Park will be replaced with rotary dial phones under a City Council plan adopted unanimously Wednesday. The older style phones cannot activate most pagers used by the dealers. Similar steps were taken in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area in April. The Police Department was charged with overseeing the plan that includes asking pay telephone companies to install lighting and bar incoming calls at phones in high-crime areas. Drug dealers like beepers because they can be used on the street and because some fear telephone taps, police say. Customers call dealers and can leave phone numbers anonymously. Dealers often send suppliers numbers of the pay phones where they are or use pre-arranged number codes to set up drug deliveries. MacArthur Park is a sprawling landmark west of downtown where tourists can rent paddle boats. In recent years, it has attracted homeless people and the dealers. Representatives of Pacific Bell and Pacific Coin have pledged cooperation in the effort to disconnect drug dealers.

DOC.HEAD: New Cabinet Will Take Tougher Measures Against Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has agreed to take tougher measures against the Palestinian uprising in an effort to draw key far-right factions into a coalition government, a right-wing party official said today. Shamir, who heads the right-wing Likud bloc, also has promised his new coalition would allocate more money for enlarging the Jewish settlements in the occupied lands, the daily Maariv reported. The reports came amid feverish attempts by Likud to overcome feuds among eight potential coalition partners by a deadline of Friday, when Shamir's mandate to form a government expires. Shamir's spokesman, Avi Pazner, declined to comment on the reports of tougher steps against the uprising or more money for settlements. ``When we announce the government tomorrow, we will aso announce the policy guidelines,'' he said. Pazner described Shamir as being close to forming a right-wing coalition. The prime minister's confidence was bolstered today when Labor member Efraim Gur announced he would defect to the Likud. That would give Shamir 62 votes, if he gets all eight religious and right-wing parties. If he fails to form a government, Israel could be forced to hold early national elections. Ultra-Orthodox religious parties that would be key to forming the Cabinet reportedly were demanding more government jobs before agreeing to back a Likud-led coalition. The uncertainty prompted President Chaim Herzog to intervene Wednesday and ask Shamir and Shimon Peres, leader of the left-of-center Labor Party, to meet and consider building another joint coalition like the one that collapsed March 15. By this morning Peres had agreed to the meeting but Shamir failed to respond, said Herzog's spokesman, Giora Pordes. Israel Television said Herzog's call for another unity coalition had been prompted by a flood of letters he received in the last week from Israeli citizens worried about the continuing political void. The collapse of the government in March came in a parliamentary vote of no confidence after Likud refused to go along with Labor demands that Israel agree to a U.S.-proposed first meeting with Palestinian representatives. Peres then failed in a 35-day bid to form a left-leaning coalition. Herzog subsequently gave Shamir a mandate to try on April 27. His time runs out on Friday evening. Danny Dayan, secretary-general of the far-right Tehiya Party, said that to meet the deadline, Shamir agreed to hard-line action against the intefadeh, the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising, and to steps to increase the population of the 130 Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Dayan denied there was an agreement on giving more money to settlements. But he said his party would insist on that once a government was installed. Dayan, reached by telephone, also said ``the policy guidelines will say that measures will be taken to end the intefadeh,'' but that the agreement did not detail what measures were involved. Untra-right leaders have been demanding such steps as expelling Arab stone-throwers from the occupied territories and destroying more homes of terror suspects. Such steps could further strain ties with the United States, which already has complained about the harsh moves taken by Israel to put down the revolt against occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Major Developments During the 1986-90 National State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the major political developments in South Africa during the 4-year-old state of emergency that was lifted in three of the country's four provinces Thursday: _June 12, 1986: President P.W. Botha imposes the emergency amid growing black unrest that has left hundreds dead. Thousands of activists are detained without trial within days. The African National Congress begins an urban bombing campaign. _July 1, 1986: The government repeals the Pass Laws, which required blacks to have an identity document and permission to be in white areas. _Nov. 5, 1987: The government frees African National Congress leader Govan Mbeki after 23 years in prison. The government says his release is trial run for the freeing of other anti-apartheid leaders such as Nelson Mandela. One month later the government places tight restrictions on the 77-year-old Mbeki. _Feb. 24, 1988: The government effectively bans 17 opposition groups, including the United Democratic Front, the largest legal anti-apartheid organization at the time. _January 1989: Some 1,000 detainees go on a hunger strike demanding to be put on trial or released. Hundreds are released over a period of several weeks. _Jan. 18, 1989: Botha suffers a stroke. He returns to work several weeks later, but gives up his post as leader of the governing National Party. F.W. de Klerk becomes party leader and heir apparent to Botha. _July 5, 1989: Botha meets with Mandela, the jailed African National Congress leader, for a brief talk. _Aug. 14, 1989: After disputes with his Cabinet, Botha resigns. De Klerk assumes power. _Sept. 6, 1989: De Klerk's National Party wins white parliamentary elections. Some 20 blacks are killed in clashes with security forces the same day. De Klerk launches a series of reforms such as allowing peaceful demonstrations and opening segregated beaches to all races. _Oct. 15, 1989: Six African National Congress leaders imprisoned for more than 25 years, including Walter Sisulu, are released. Two weeks later, the first legal ANC rally in 30 years draws 70,000 blacks in the Soweto township outside Johannesburg. _Feb. 2, 1990: De Klerk legalizes the ANC and more than 60 additional opposition groups, suspends the death penalty, eases emergency restrictions, announces Mandela will be released shortly. _Feb. 11: Mandela is freed after more than 27 years in prison, receives tumultuous welcomes in rallies in the country's major cities. _May 2-4: The ANC and the government hold their first talks. They agree to work together to end violence and negotiate a new constitution that would end white domination and bring blacks into the national government. _June 7: President F.W. de Klerk ends the national state of emergency, but keeps emergency rules in effect in violence-torn Natal province.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Leaves Engine Running, Train Taken on 2-Mile Joyride
DOC.TEXT: A train engineer figured it was safe to leave his engine running while stopped in a railyard, but returned to find empty tracks. Someone took the train on a two-mile joyride. The ride ended when the train ran out of track Wednesday. The culprit escaped; no injuries or damage were reported. Engineer C.L. Keibaugh left the CSX freight train engine running, but hid controls needed to get it going again, police said. The train-taker apparently found the controls. ``I imagine whoever left it felt it was perfectly secure,'' said county police Sgt. Daniel Nowack. The train never got going very fast and came to rest when track ran out, with the engine's two front wheels coming to rest in gravel, he said. Whoever rolled off with the train jumped off somewhere along the line, police said. Andrea Just, a CSX spokeswoman, said she was unaware of any company policies prohibiting crews from leaving trains in rail yards with the engines running. ``I think it's more a matter of common sense prevailing,'' she said. The engine and cars were valued in police reports at $2 million, but most were empty, Nowack said.

DOC.HEAD: Johnson Resigns as Vice Chairman of Federal Reserve
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New material throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Manuel H. Johnson, who as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve helped steer the nation's monetary policy for the past 3{ years, announced his resignation today to return to academic life. Johnson, 41, was appointed to the Fed by President Reagan on Feb. 7, 1986, and became vice chairman on Aug. 4 of that year. He said his resignation would be effective Aug. 3 at the end of his term as vice chairman. His term on the central bank would have ended Aug. 21, 2000. There was no immediate comment from the White House on a successor. As Fed vice chairman, Johnson helped steer monetary policy through the last half of the nation's longest peacetime economic expansion. For more than a year, the central bank has sought to stem inflation by keeping a tight grip on credit without tipping the economy into a recession. The result _ continued, but slow economic growth _ has become known as the ``soft landing.'' ``I am extremely proud to have played a part in the unprecedented period of sustained economic growth and low inflation that has characterized the decade of the 1980s and continues into the 1990s,'' Johnson said in his letter of resignation to President Bush. ``Although there are still major issues to be addressed as this country moves ahead, I feel optimistic about our future. Indeed, part of my reasoning for leaving at this time is the confidence I have in my colleagues at the Federal Reserve and in the economic team you have assembled in your administration,'' he continued. Johnson said he plans to return to George Mason University in Washington's Virginia suburbs and assume the Koch Chair in international economics and become director of the Center for Global Market Studies. ``I deeply regret, but understand, Manley Johnson's decision,'' Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan said in a statement. ``The vice chairman and I have been an effective team. I'll miss him.'' The Fed is the nation's central bank whose primary responsibility is monetary policy. Its Federal Open Market Committee actually makes the key decisions affecting the cost and availability of money and credit. The Fed is run by a seven-member board of governors, headquartered in Washington, and a nationwide network of 12 district banks. The governors are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate to serve 14-year terms. The newest member, former assistant Treasury secretary David Mullins, was confirmed by the Senate last month, bringing the board to full strength. Johnson, 41, served as an assistant secretary and deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury prior to his Fed appointment. As a Treasury official, Johnson was responsible for formulating economic policy initiatives and developing the administration's economic forecast for the budget. He also was instrumental in designing the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 and the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Born in Troy, Ala., Johnson was a graduate of Troy State University and received masters and doctoral degrees in economics from Florida State University. From 1977 to 1981, Johnson taught graduate economics at George Mason University in suburban Fairfax, Va., where he holds a full professorship. He and his wife have two children.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Demand Falls During 1980s
DOC.TEXT: U.S. doctors cut back their use of donated blood for transfusions during the 1980s, apparently because of fear of passing on AIDS, according to a study released today. The study found that transfusions of whole blood and red cells totaled 9.9 million pints in 1980, reached a peak of 12.2 million pints in 1986 and have declined since then. During the same period, people have sharply increased the practice of setting aside their own blood for use during operations. The study, directed by Dr. Douglas M. Surgenor of the Center for Blood Research in Boston, was based on a survey of about 5,800 hospitals and blood centers. It was published in today's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine. Among the findings: _Transfusions of whole blood and red cells fell to 11.6 million pints in 1987 and continued to decline in 1988, the last year of the survey. _Transfusions of blood plasma dropped almost 9 percent during the decade. _Donations of autologous blood _ the practice of setting aside blood for one's own use _ increased from 30,000 pints in 1982 to 397,000 pints in 1987. _The supply of blood donated for others was unchanged between 1986 and 1988. The researchers attributed the changes to fear of passing on the AIDS virus through transfusions. The chance of catching the disease from a transfusion has been slight since blood banks began screening for the virus in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Damages Guest Bedroom at Palm Beach Estate
With PM-Trump
DOC.TEXT: Fire heavily damaged a guest bedroom today in the 118-room Mar-a-Lago mansion owned by real estate tycoon Donald Trump in this tony resort town, the fire chief said. A member of the household staff called the 911 emergency line at 8:08 a.m. to report the fire in a two-story guest wing attached to the main building at the historic oceanfront estate, said Fire Chief Ken Elmore. About 15 firefighters put the fire out in about 15 minutes, before flames could spread beyond the bedroom and attached bathroom, Elmore said. No one was injured. The fire caused no structural damage, but smoke spread to several other bedrooms in the wing, Elmore said. He had no estimate of the dollar loss. Elmore said he didn't know whether any Trumps were home, but said no one had been staying in the guest bedroom. ``The cause of the fire is undetermined,'' he said. ``We don't have any reason to believe that it's suspicious at this time.'' The 58-bedroom mansion is located on a 17-acre strip of land between the Atlantic Ocean and the Intracoastal Waterway. Trump bought the 64-year-old Mar-a-Lago, Spanish for sea to lake, in 1985 for $7 million. The coral-colored home is one of about 130 in this island community bearing a historical designation.

DOC.HEAD: Students, Workers Protest; Lawmakers Debate Jobless Threat
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of students rallied in front of Parliament today, and workers blocked a main street leading to the city as East German lawmakers debated ways to head off widespread unemployment. University students demanded that the stipends they receive for attending school be increased as the nation merges its economy with West Germany's as part of the process of German unification. The group marched around the Parliament building and staged a sit-in at its entrance, but there were no major incidents. Education Minister Hans Joachim Meyer came outside to speak to the group of several thousands students and said the government would consider their demands. But he also referred to East Germany's ``difficult financial situation.'' About 10 students got inside the Parliament building while lawmakers were meeting, unfurled a banner from the spectator gallery and threw leaflets to the floor below. They were led away without incident. About 3,000 students and teachers in the southern city of Chemnitz also staged a demonstration, the government news agency ADN said. The broad agreement merging the German economies and social institutions contains no details about the stipends that students received for attending school. Meanwhile, electronics industry workers from the outlying city of Teltow blocked for about an hour a main thoroughfare connecting Berlin with the city of Potsdam, ADN said. The workers were demanding protection from unemployment. The electronics industry is expected to be among those that suffer the most from competition from the West. Many East Germans already are buying radios and other sophisiticated electronics appliances from Western manufacturers. Experts estimate that up to 4 million East Germans may lose their jobs as the nation's industries are forced to compete with more efficient Western companies. Lawmakers debated measures to ease the transition to a free market, including a government plan to set up retraining centers for workers likely to lose their jobs. Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl said the government will discuss the possibility of closing down large sections of industies to conduct massive retraining programs. But he said this would be done against the backdrop of the ``hopeless situation'' in the microelectronics, auto, and shoe industries in the industrial cities of the South, where many giant, outmoded industries are expected to fail. In the West German capital, Bonn, an opposition lawmaker warned of serious problems this autumn with East Germany's system of vocational and technical schools. Social Democrat Gert Weisskirchen said industries in East Germany may have to cancel between 20,000 and 30,000 training contracts for students being groomed for skilled jobs in factories. He said up to 60,000 students may not be able to find work in their fields after their training is complete this year.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Urges Barry to Plea Bargain, Declare He Won't Run Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 3, Talk of, to update with four more prospective jurors questioned.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson is injecting himself into Mayor Marion Barry's battle over drug charges, saying prosecutors should revive plea bargain talks to ``spare all of us the pain'' of a racially divisive trial. Barry is ``open to a negotiated process,'' Jackson said. He urged Barry to promise he won't seek re-election and urged prosecutors to spare the mayor a prison sentence. Talk of a possible plea bargain dominated public discussion of Barry's cocaine and perjury trial as the process of selecting a jury went into a fourth day today. Sixteen people were added Wednesday to bring the jury pool to 25. Four more prospective jurors were questioned this morning. The mayor and prosecutors are at an impasse over the prosecution's insistence that he plead guilty to one of the three felony charges against him, said a source close to the Barry camp who insisted on anonymity. If he pleaded guilty to a felony, Barry might face prison and would have to resign his office. ``The mayor obviously does not want to resign. The mayor obviously does not want to go to jail,'' Jackson said in an interview. Various reports have said Barry may be willing to plead guilty to misdemeanor drug possession charges if he could finish out the last few months of his term. But Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, told reporters during a break in Wednesday's court proceedings: ``Are there talks ongoing now? No.'' Mundy disclosed he had spoken with Jackson about the trial, but wouldn't comment on those discussions. Jackson and Walter Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's delegate to Congress, apparently had not succeeded in persuading prosecutors to reopen plea bargain talks. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said Tuesday it would be inappropriate to meet with a third party on a criminal matter and had no comment on Jackson's latest remarks. Sources close to the prosecution, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it would be extremely unlikely that Stephens would meet with Jackson. Barry is facing three felony charges of perjury, 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and one count of conspiracy. He's accused of smoking crack cocaine in an FBI sting Jan. 18 and possessing cocaine at other times and lying about it to a federal grand jury. Fauntroy, himself a mayoral candidate, called a news conference to remind reporters he had earlier appealed to Barry and prosecutors to ``spare the city and the nation the agony of a trial.'' Jackson, who until now has not spoken extensively about the drug charges, urged Barry to declare he won't run again and prosecutors to seek a settlement. ``I would hope that both of them could work out an agreement honorably and within the law short of a full-blown, long, nasty, divisive trial, to spare all of us that pain,'' Jackson said. In a separate television interview, Jackson said the debate over Barry's troubles has become ``very Republican-Democrat, very black-white; it's very nasty.'' ``I would hope that the mayor would determine he would not run again ... and would really challenge the Justice Department to work out some settlement process,'' he told WUSA-TV. Most of the 16 jurors added to the pool Wednesday said they were somewhat familiar with the case. They included one man who worried his family could face threats if his name was made public and a woman who said race ``had a lot to do with'' the investigation of the black mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Brings Victims in Pellet-Gun Shootings Face-to-Face with Attackers
DOC.TEXT: A man shot in the back during a pellet-gun shooting spree says his attackers would have faced harsher penalties if they lived by frontier rules. ``In the old days, in the West, people like you would have been hung,'' Clyde Lehman said Wednesday in a face-to-face meeting with his attackers called by Judge John Bozza. Four men pleaded guilty in the string of drive-by shootings with pellet guns that wounded 19 people last year. Kevin Trost, 19; Thomas K. Craig, 19; and Mark Smith, 20; face a maximum 112 years in prison at their sentencing Friday. William Peyton, 18, faces a 30-year term in connection with one shooting. He will be sentenced later this month. The judge called victims and the four men together to hear from both sides before determining the attackers' sentences. Three apologized and asked for mercy, but Peyton remained silent. One of the attackers said the shootings were ``a prank that went too far.'' Victim Frank Polenta said the four couldn't be charged with discrimination. ``You shot at men and women, young and old, black and white. You hit all neighborhoods,'' he said. ``You caused needless and senseless pain, not only to your victims but to your parents.'' Helen Howell said her hand swelled to twice its normal size after the drive-by shooting and told the judge how her wedding band had to be cut from her finger in a hospital emergency room. ``What you did changed my life emotionally and physically,'' she told her attacker. ``I'm sorry for your parents and your teachers, but I'm not sorry for you.''

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Runs Aground; 260,000 Gallons of Fuel Leak Into Channel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with Coast Guard saying the tanker's hull was ruptured, CLARIFIES that capacity for ruptured tank, not entire tanker. Picks up 7th graf, `Absorbent booms....'.
DOC.TEXT: An oil tanker ran aground in a waterway between New York and New Jersey early today, rupturing its hull and leaking about 260,000 gallons of heavy oil into the shipping channel, the Coast Guard said. The waterway was closed to marine traffic and oil was washing ashore. The 811-foot tanker Nautilus ran aground at about 5:15 a.m. and began leaking No. 6 heating oil into the Kill Van Kull waterway, said Petty Officer Jim McGranachan. Oil was pumped out of the leaking tank, and the leak stopped by midmorning when the remaining oil fell below the rupture, said Lt. Cmdr. Paul A. Milligan. Officials said they didn't know how much oil was aboard the tanker, which is owned by the British Nautilus Motor Tanker Co. of London. The ruptured tank has a capacity of 1.2 million gallons. Absorbent booms were set out to contain the spill and other cleanup crews were called in, McGranachan said. The Kill Van Kull and the Arthur Kill, a second shipping channel between New Jersey and Staten Island, N.Y., have been the scenes of several major oil spills this year. On Jan. 1-2, 567,000 gallons of oil leaked into the Arthur Kill from a ruptured Exxon underwater pipeline. On Feb. 28, 30,000 gallons of heating oil spilled into the Kill Van Kull from a barge anchored in Bayonne. A day later, nearly 4,000 gallons of heavy crude oil spilled into the Arthur Kill at Exxon's refinery in Linden. About a week later, more than 100,000 gallons of heating oil was dumped in the Arthur Kill near Linden from a barge that exploded and caught fire.

DOC.HEAD: Mentally Disabled Man Hit By Car While Doing Push-ups in Street
DOC.TEXT: A mentally disabled man was seriously injured when pranksters paid him a few dollars to do push-ups in the middle of a street and a car struck him, police said. The Erie County district attorney's office was determining whether it could file charges against the pranksters, said Sheriff Thomas F. Higgins, uncle of the victim, Michael Gilliland. Gilliland, 29, suffered two broken legs, a collapsed lung, serious head injuries and a possibly ruptured spleen, said his mother, Joan Archer. He may be hospitalized up to six months as a result of Sunday's accident, she said. ``It just shocks me. He would never do this to himself,'' Mrs. Archer said. ``He's the most likable person, and he's very naive and gullible, and he takes everything in good faith.'' Higgins said the pranksters, whose names have not been released, had been taunting Gilliland. ``They just mocked him and made a fool out of him,'' the sheriff said. ``Those two individuals have to be the two biggest lowlifes. They didn't even warn him. They must have seen the car coming.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Gay Violence Pervasive in 1989, Report Shows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 2nd graf, The report, with 2 new grafs to include news conference quotoe.
DOC.TEXT: Acts of violence, vandalism and harassment against gay people were widespread again last year, but new anti-hate-crime laws offer hope the trend can be reversed, according to a report released today. The report was presented at a news conference by the National Gay & Lesbian Task Force, along with civil rights, law enforcement and congressional leaders. ``Hate crimes exist because the narrow-minded and mean-spirited among us have judged some of their fellow citizens to be less deserving of respect than themselves,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. ``The more that we bring these crimes to light, the less tolerable they will be.'' The fifth annual survey of anti-gay violence in the United States, recounts 7,031 such incidents in 1989. They ranged from verbal harassment to homicide, and were documented by 119 organizations and individuals in 40 states and the District of Columbia. ``Last year, the nation's lesbian and gay community celebrated the 20th anniversary of the Stonewall riots, which sparked the modern gay rights movement,'' said Kevin Berrill, author of the report. ``Although we have made remarkable strides toward freedom since Stonewall, we remain a community under siege, battling an epidemic of bigotry and violence.'' In June 1968, patrons rioted at the Stonewall, a gay bar in New York's Greenwich Village, when police tried to raid it. The data for the survey came from questionnaires sent to 650 gay activists and organizations nationwide. The task force acknowledged its methods were unscientific, and noted that more than half the groups that responded in 1988 did not do so in 1989. However, the survey gives a broad look at the prevalence of anti-gay harassment and violence. Of the total incidents reported last year, approximately two-thirds, were acts of verbal harassment, the report said. Of the remaining 2,322 incidents, 34 percent were physical assaults; 31 percent were threats of violence; 17 percent were acts of vandalism; 14 percent were police abuse; 3 percent were homicides; and 1 percent were arson or other victimization. Nineteen percent occurred on college campuses, revealing ``dangerous intolerance and prejudice that threatens an academic environment of enlightenment,'' Berrill said. Fifteen percent were classified by local groups as AIDS-related, indicating that some people continue to use the disease as a justification for anti-gay prejudice and violence, the report said. But the report pointed to laws passed in 1989 and 1990 aimed at curbing bias crimes, including those against gay people. On April 23, 1990, President Bush signed the Hate Crimes Statistics Act, which requires the federal government to collect data on crimes based on race, religion, sexual orientation and ethnicity. The report called this ``an historic victory for the nation's gay and lesbian community.'' Hate crimes laws with anti-gay provisions also recently passed in: California, Connecticut, the District of Columbia, Iowa, Minnesota, New Hampshire, Oregon, Vermont, Atlanta, Burlington, Iowa; Montgomery County, Md.; and St. Louis, according to the report. For the most part, states reporting the highest number of anti-gay incidents were those without hate crime laws that included homosexuals, the report found. States with the highest number of documented episodes were: North Carolina, 1,204; Texas, 997; California, 563; Illinois, 529; and Ohio, 387. Overall, 1989's total of 7,031 episodes is slightly lower than the 7,248 reported in 1988, the report noted. It added, however, ``Given the many factors that affect annual totals and the relatively minor difference between 1989 and 1988 figures, it is not possible to accurately gauge whether the problem increased or decreased last year.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Said To Be More Optimistic on Germany Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Baker briefing NATO allies on Soviet position, Thatcher saying NATO needs new role. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has shifted to a more encouraging stand on NATO membership for a unified Germany, U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was quoted as telling Western allies today. Baker privately briefed NATO foreign ministers who began a two-day meeting at this resort on Scotland's rugged west coast. The ministers are seeking a new strategy for the western military alliance as the Cold War draws to an end. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said nuclear weapons and U.S. forces remain essential in Europe. She also told the meeting of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization at a luxury hotel in Turnberry that the Western military alliance should assume a more political role. The meeting is the third in a series held this spring to try to map out a new strategy for NATO in an era of reduced East-West tensions. Leaders of the 16 nations meet in London next month to formally begin work on NATO's future. West Germany is a member of NATO, but East Germany is part of the crumbling Warsaw Pact led by Moscow. NATO wants the new Central European state to remain in the Western alliance, but the Kremlin has balked at the idea. U.S. officials said Baker reported on his recent talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in the Danish capital, Copenhagen. A senior official of a NATO delegation, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Baker indicated to the allies that ``the Soviets were much more encouraging than at the summit'' last week in Washington between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``They have many concerns, but they are looking at more things to do'' to make NATO membership for a unified Germany more acceptable, the official said. ``It's more of a change in spirit.'' Baker brought with him to the current meeting a Soviet proposal for an accord that would help ease Moscow's concerns about a unified Germany belonging to NATO, but he told reporters Wednesday that he was ``not at liberty to get into the details'' of the Soviet plan. Baker and his West German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, were reported to be optimistic that the West would reach agreement with the Kremlin on the military status of the new German state. ``Both indicated optimism ... that the Soviets would ultimately come along with this,'' said a British official who also requested anonymity. Mrs. Thatcher said NATO ``needs to be more imaginative and work on a bigger canvas... Politically, NATO no longer has a clear front-line in Europe.'' ``With the spread of sophisticated weapons and military technology to areas like the Middle East, potential threats to NATO may originate from outside Europe,'' she said, calling for U.S. forces and nuclear weapons to stay put. Mrs. Thatcher reiterated her vision of a ``grand alliance'' across Europe, based on a strengthened role for the 35-nation East-West Conference on European Security and Cooperation. It comprises all European nations except Albania, as well as the United States and Canada. ``This is the time to create a new European order, an order for a Europe which is undivided, free and at peace,'' NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner told the NATO meeting. He said the alliance must adapt to last year's fall of hard-line Communist governments in Eastern Europe. ``If we want to be able to meet the challenge of change, we have to change ourselves,'' he said. The Warsaw Pact has been unraveling since the political upheavals in Eastern Europe. Hungary and Czechoslovakia, once staunch members, have demanded the removal of Red Army troops from their soil.

DOC.HEAD: Some Changes in Legal Situation With The Lifting of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: Without the national state of emergency, the government still has wide powers under its security laws to restrict political activity. By using the law and the courts, government ministers and the police force can take most of the actions which the 4-year-old emergency regulations allowed. But there are some changes in the three provinces where President F.W. de Klerk ordered the emergency ended: _People detained without trial, or whose freedom of activity is restricted, can challenge the action in court. Under the emergency, judges' discretion was generally limited to determining whether a particular action was covered by the emergency decree. The decree said police were empowered to take ``any action'' and to tell anyone to do anything. _Police no longer have automatic immunity from prosecution for actions they take ``in good faith'' in an unrest situation. _The power of the police to conduct warrantless searches and seizures is reduced but not eliminated. _Police commissioners can no longer make sweeping bans on all rallies, marches or public gatherings in their region. They have to obtain a magistrate's order to halt specific activities. However, the minister of law and order still has power under the law to declare any region an ``unrest area'' and impose emergency regulations within it. _Police lose their power to place restrictions on funerals in black townships and to prohibit the display of certain slogans. _Government ministers can no longer seize newspapers or suspend them at will. They can still halt newspaper publication, but must go through legal procedures and their action can be challenged in court. _Police cannot order journalists or community workers away from an unrest area merely by invoking ``emergency regulations.'' They can still issue such orders but must have a legal reason.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Say Superpowers Should Cut Warheads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 7 grafs new with arms negotiator comments; deletes pvs 7th graf as outdated; picks up 2nd graf pvs, The book
DOC.TEXT: The superpowers may complete a treaty on 30 percent cuts in long-range nuclear weapons as early as November, a senior U.S. negotiator said today. Linton Brooks, deputy head of the U.S. delegation to the Geneva negotiations, told reporters he was confident the treaty would be finished by the end of the year, a target affirmed at last week's summit by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``I think it's possible to do it ... as early as sometime in November,'' Brooks said. The three major areas of disagreement are on limits to Soviet modernization of the SS-18 ballistic missile, constraints on the Soviet Backfire bomber and ways of limiting sales of long-range missiles to third countries. Brooks said the negotiators, who return to the bargaining table in Geneva on Monday, also have a lot of work left on details of an inspection regime for the treaty. Even as the superpowers are approaching the end of eight years of negotiations on this landmark treaty, some critics are saying the U.S.-Soviet approach to reducing offensive nuclear weapons is becoming outdated. On Wednesday, U.S. and Soviet scientists released a jointly published book that said future nuclear arms accords should provide for the destruction of warheads, not just the missiles or other vehicles that deliver them. The book, ``Reversing the Arms Race,'' by the Federation of American Scientists and the Committee of Soviet Scientists for Global Security, also said the superpowers could cut the number of strategic nuclear weapons to less than 2,000 on each side without creating an incentive to launch a preemptive first strike. The U.S.-Soviet treaty nearing completion at the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks in Geneva calls for a 30 percent reduction in strategic, or long-range, nuclear weapons, to 6,000 on each side. The START treaty as drafted would not require the elimination of any warheads, nor was there any such requirement in the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces treaty that banned all U.S. and Soviet land-based missiles of medium range. The START and INF treaties require destruction of missiles and missile launchers, but put no restrictions on removing the fissionable material from the warheads and reusing it in other weapons not covered by the treaties. Allowing warheads from treaty-prohibited weapons to be reused has not been a major drawback during an era in which both superpowers have tens of thousands of nuclear weapons, the scientists said. But it will become a problem in guarding against treaty cheating if future arms deals cut arsenals to minimal levels. The scientist groups also said that for warhead dismantlement to be effective, the superpowers should agree to halt production of new fissionable materials, including plutonium, tritium and enriched uranium, used in warheads. Congress is increasingly interested in pursuing a U.S.-Soviet agreement to halt nuclear materials production, but the Bush administration is opposed. The scientist groups noted that both Moscow and Washington already have had to reduce their nuclear materials production because of safety problems in manufacturing. Just this week new evidence emerged to indicate that problems at a key U.S. weapons plant are more serious than previously believed.

DOC.HEAD: One of West Germany's Most Wanted Terrorist Suspects is Captured
DOC.TEXT: One of West Germany's most wanted terrorist suspects, linked to the slayings of a prominent banker and a wealthy industrialist, has been captured, officials said today. Susanne Albrecht, 39, a member of the notorious Red Army Faction terrorist group, was captured Wednesday afternoon in front of her apartment in East Berlin, East Germany's interior minister said. The minister, Peter-Michael Diestel, said Albrecht had been living in East Berlin for the past 10 years under an assumed name and was married to an East German. Albrecht is accused of killing Juergen Ponto, former head of West Germany's Dresdner Bank, outside his home in July 1977 in the West German city of Oberursel, just north of Frankfurt. Albrecht was an acquaintance of the Ponto family. She is also wanted in connection with the kidnapping and killing of West German industrialist Hanns Martin Schleyer. Schleyer, the president of West Germany's Employers and Trade Association, was kidnapped on Sept. 5 1977, when two of his bodyguards were cut down in a hail of bullets on a Cologne street. He was held by the Red Army Faction for six weeks before being slain. The Red Army Faction, a spinoff of the Baader-Meinhof gang, got its start with a series of arson and bombing attacks, mainly against U.S. military targets, in what it said was retaliation for the war in Vietnam. It later broadened its attacks, staging bombings and slayings of West German industrial and banking leaders. About 25 Red Army Faction members are still being sought. The West German Interior Ministry says there are also about 250 sympathizers who provide hideouts and other support for gang members. The latest attack claimed by the Red Army Faction was bombing death of banker Alfred Herrhausen on Nov. 30. Herrhausen, 59, was head of Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest commercial bank. He was killed when a bomb was detonated under his armored car as he was being driven to work from his home in Bad Homburg, 12 miles north of Frankfurt. In October 1977, a group of Palestinian terrorists hijacked a Lufthansa plane to Mogadishu, Somalia, and demanded the release of jailed terrorists belonging to the Baader-Meinhof group. The hijackers were overpowered by a West German anti-terrorist unit on Oct. 18, 1977, after the plane landed in Mogadishu. The pilot of the plane was shot and killed, but 89 passengers and crew were freed safely. Of the terrorists, four were shot and killed and a fifth terrorist was wounded. A Palestinian, Soraya Ansari, was later tried and sentenced to 20 years in prison. Hours after the raid on the plane, convicted terrorists Andreas Baader, Gudrin Ensslin and Jan-Carl Raspe were found shot to death in their prison cells in Stammheim prison in Stuttgart. Officials said they had committed suicide. Schleyer was found shot to death in the trunk of a car in Mulhausen, France, near the border with West Germany, a short time later. Ulrike Meinhof, who along with Andreas Baader led the Baader-Meinhof gang of the late 1960s, had hanged herself a year earlier in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Census Takers Take a Hike Over Pay Dispute
DOC.TEXT: On-schedule census workers staged a sickout today to protest a $2-an-hour raise given to census takers in other parts of the country where the head count is lagging. Seventy-five of about 100 day-shift office workers called in sick with the flu, but most said they will be better by Friday, said Arlin Violetta, district census manager. ``They're calling it the $2-bill blue flu,'' he said. The sickout affected only Michigan's Upper Peninsula, where the census count is on schedule. ``I'm sure it was in protest to wage increases across the country that we did not get,'' Violetta said. ``I think it's just showing a point that if you're doing a rotten job with the census, you'll get a raise. If you do a good job, you get a slap in the face.'' Many of the office workers who called in sick earn $4.50 an hour, compared with clerks in some districts who earn $7 an hour. Violetta said the raises went only to field workers. Though office workers were not affected, the ones in the Upper Peninsula decided to protest anyway. The raises went to regions that are farthest behind in taking the national population count, where recruiting and retaining workers has been troublesome. ``Our people went in on skis and snowshoes,'' he said. ``We had a snowstorm May 10, and yet we got our job done.'' Anger over the raises might prompt some sickout participants to quit altogether, he said. His workers have completed their first door-to-door survey and were scheduled to begin followup field work within two weeks. Violetta said he needs to hire 400 new field workers; the sickout was likely to slow that process. ``I feel bad for my people and I'll stand behind them to the end. I don't think they're being treated fairly,'' he said. The census bureau on Wednesday announced pay hikes from between 50 cents and $2 an hour in locations where it has had problems attracting staff. Before the pay hikes, census workers were paid between $5 and $8 an hour depending on local wage rates and staff needs. The raises went to workers in New York, Boston, Atlanta, the Washington, D.C., suburbs, Kansas City, San Diego, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Charlotte, N.C., and Arizona.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Crime Bill
Hispanics Concentrate in Urban Areas in a Few States
DOC.TEXT: Like other immigrant groups before them, America's Hispanics are clustering in cities in a few states and tend to marry one another, a Census Bureau report released Thursday shows. More than 90 percent of the nation's 20 million Hispanics live in urban areas, and nearly nine of 10 reside in just nine states, the bureau said. The study of the nation's Hispanics found that they seek each other out to form families. Some 85 percent of Hispanic husbands married Latino women and 82 percent of Hispanic wives wed Latin men. The report, ``The Hispanic Population in the United States,'' found: _There were 20,076,000 Hispanics in the United States as of March 1989. That's up 38.9 percent since 1980. In the same period, the nation's population increased 9.5 percent. _About 92 percent of Hispanic households were in urban areas, compared with 73 percent of non-Hispanics. _The poverty rate among Hispanics was 23.7 percent; it was 9.4 percent for others. _Only 42 percent of Hispanic households live in homes they own or are buying, compared with 66 percent for non-Hispanics. _Some 82 percent of Hispanics had a phone in their home, compared with 94 percent of non-Hispanics. _Mexicans were the largest and fastest growing group of His PMs

Democrats on the Senate Agriculture Committee say legislation to halt export of pesticides that can't be sold in the United States will help American farmers. ``By stopping the export of banned and unregistered pesticides, we will level the playing field for our producers,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the committee. ``Both domestic and foreign farmers will be treated the same.'' The committee inserted the ban Wednesday in its version of the 1990 farm bill, under protest from ranking Republican Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana and other GOP members on the committee. Lugar said he didn't think the provision belonged in the legislation that establishes the government's agricultural policy for the next five years. Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., said the legislation could lead to loss of jobs at chemical companies that may decide to do their manufacturing abroad. He also said, ``If we phase companies out, it would take other companies very little time to gear up.'' Jay Vroom, president of the National Agricultural Chemicals Association, said his organization would continue to try to get the committee to change certain provisions of the bill. He said proposed restrictions on experimentation with chemicals would be detrimental to U.S. scientific discovery. ``We could be shooting ourselves in the foot,'' Vroom said. ``Some companies will move research plants to Europe where the likelihood is better of moving products around the world unfettered during experimentation on crops.'' He said many of the unregistered chemicals sold abroad that would be banned from export are awaiting approval by the Environmental Protection Agency, which has a backlog. Thus, they could eventually be registered here, he said. Other chemicals don't pass the zero tolerance laws in the United States for residue, but do pass pesticide regulations in other countries, Vroom said. Leahy said that no part of the farm bill generated more mail to his office than this one. ``At a time when we are toughening our standards at home, we need to do more about imports with hazardous pesticides,'' he said. ``Because the Food and Drug Administration waives through virtually all imported food without inspection, these chemicals often end up on America's dinner tables.'' About 25 percent of the fruits and vegetables consumed in the United States come from abroad. Many of the chemicals that have been banned for health reasons were quite effective in eliminating pests and increasing crop yields. ``Foreign farmers are able to use made-in-the-USA chemicals that our farmers cannot,'' said Leahy. ``We effectively penalize U.S. farmers and growers for using safe pesticides and obeying the law.''

U.S. food processors and processing-equipment makers took a few steps closer to converting the Soviet Union to the capitalistic system during a conference this week. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher signed an agreement Wednesday with the Soviet Union that promises that federal officials will work with the Soviets to find ways to adapt the U.S. food making and distribution system to their country. Vladilen Nikitin, the Soviet equivalent to the U.S. agriculture secretary, said the agreement was a small step, ``but everything starts with a small step.'' ``For you, it's a key if you want to participate in the strengthening of our economy,'' he said through an interpreter. The pact was signed on the last day of a three-day conference sponsored by the Food Processing Machinery & Supplies Association and the National Food Processors Association. Mosbacher said the pact was unprecedented and a start toward expanding trade between the two superpowers. ``We are the two largest industrialized nations in the world,'' said Mosbacher. ``We have one-third of the world's GNP (gross national product). But we do only a tiny fraction of world trade.'' John Cady, president of the food processors association, said barriers are beginning to come down, although Americans are concerned about getting paid for business with the Soviets. Soviet currency is of almost no value in the world market, leaving those companies doing business in the Soviet Union to either accept products in exchange or wait for long-term gains after the economy there improves. ``We have to understand when companies invest, it's not going to be a three-year turnaround, but probably eight to 10 years,'' said Cady. He said Nikitin was a powerful official in the Soviet government and would smooth the way for American business. U.S. businessmen at the conference had complained earlier of complications in dealing with the Soviet bureaucracy.

Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., wants to put his agricultural marketing reform legislation into the 1990 farm bill. The measure would modify the Agriculture Department's grading standards of fruit and vegetables by including flavor, sugar content and nutritional value as grading criteria. The current system of some produce relies solely on its exterior appearance with no regard for the quality of the fruit or vegetable, Fowler said. Sometimes pesticides are used to enhance the looks of produce when external appearance is irrelevant, such as in fruits or vegetables used by juice makers. ``Both consumers and farmers will benefit from this amendment,'' Fowler said Wednesday. ``Consumers will be eating healthier food with less pesticides and farmers will be reducing their costs by spending less money on pesticides.''

DOC.HEAD: N.Y. Church Member Spots Alleged Embezzler _ in New Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Investigators were...', to CLARIFY that Womer was spotted in a store. SUBS graf 12th graf, `He moved...', to ADD that Womer was retired and wife managed a store.
DOC.TEXT: A New York woman's trip to this arts center has led to the arrest of her church's former treasurer who was accused of embezzling $267,000 after he vanished eight years ago. Clyde Womer, 67, was in Taos County Jail today, awaiting his return to New York where he faces six counts of grand larceny. Womer waived extradtion during an appearance Wednesday before Magistrate Betty Gonzales. After Womer disappeared in 1982, $267,000 was discovered missing from the treasury of Christ Episcopal Church in Suffern, northwest of New York City. Rockland County District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz in New York said Womer had persuaded members of the church to invest money in liquid accounts, which he controlled. Womer then looted the church accounts, depositing the money in his own bank account, Gribetz said. Investigators were unable to trace Womer until last month, when a church member told police she had seen him in a store and spoken to him in Taos, where she attended a crafts fair. The woman said that she did not let on she suspected the man was Womer, but that he had volunteered he knew people in Rockland County. ``The odds of finding him in Taos, New Mexico, are one in a million or one in a billion,'' said Gribetz. Suffern detective Sgt. Leo J. Costa and a priest from the church identified Womer, who had taken a new name, Gribetz said. Womer was arrested Monday night. ``I didn't steal any money,'' Womer said as he left court. ``I didn't know I was a fugitive from justice 'til Monday,'' he said. ``I didn't know there were warrants for my arrest. I want to get back to New York as quickly as possible to clear my name.'' Womer said he changed his name for ``personal reasons.'' He moved to Taos in 1983 and in 1984 married Betty Sutton, who manages a J.C. Penney store. He was retired. Gribetz said Womer left his wife, Harriet, and five children in New York. Sutton said Womer told her his former wife had died of cancer. ``This is the last thing I would have thought,'' she said. ``You never think something like this will happen to you.'' Harriet Womer, according to Costa, lives in Colorado Springs, Colo., about 200 miles north of Taos. He said she was in the process of filing papers to declare her husband dead so she could receive Social Security payments. Womer's assets were seized, Gribetz said, adding that he could not list them.

DOC.HEAD: Year-Old Cease-fire Violated in Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: A year-old cease-fire between the government and Tamil rebels was violated Thursday when insurgents opened fire on army trucks in the northeast, police and residents said. One corporal was killed and at least 10 soldiers were injured in the gunfight at Nedunkeri village, about 160 miles northeast of Colombo, said police in the area. At least six rebels were injured when the army returned fire, according to the officials who were contacted by telephone and spoke on condition of anonymity. It was the most serious confrontation since the Tamil Tigers accepted a government invitation to start talks and declared a unilateral cease-fire in May 1989. A military commander of the Tamil Tiger rebels said members of his group opened fire when the army convoy refused to stop at a checkpoint manned by the rebels. Suresh, the commander, said in a telephone interview that the Tigers did not suffer any casualties. He uses only one name. The Tamil Tigers have been at the forefront of the Tamils' 7-year-old war for an independent nation in northern and eastern Sri Lanka. After last year's cease-fire, they started negotiating with the government for autonomy in the predominantly Tamil region. At least 11,000 people have died in the war, including 1,100 Indian soldiers who were sent to the country to put down the Tamil rebellion. The last Indian soldiers left Sri Lanka in March, and the Tigers began sharing law and order duties with Sri Lankan soldiers and policemen. But there have been strains in the relationship. Newspapers accuse the rebels of assaulting policemen, levying illegal taxes and blocking roads. The Tigers say the government has stepped up military movement and may be gearing up for another bout of fighting. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claim they are discriminated against by Sinhalese, who form 75 percent of the population and dominate the army and government.

DOC.HEAD: Older Americans More Closely Follow Summit News
DOC.TEXT: The older you are the more attention you probably paid to the Bush-Gorbachev summit last week, judging from a report released Thursday. The Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press said President Bush's meetings with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington and at Camp David were followed ``very closely'' by 38 percent of Americans. The center makes monthly reports of how closely people follow news events. Among persons under age 30, however, only 26 percent paid especially close attention to summit news. More younger people _ 29 percent of them _ followed the flooding in Texas and other Southwestern states very closely. The summit drew very close attention from 35 percent of those age 30 to 49. Among those 50 and older, it held the attention of 49 percent. Overall, the summit far out drew the Bush-Gorbachev meeting off the coast of Malta in December, which 21 percent followed very closely. It was the most closely followed story of the month, with the Southwestern floods in second place at 34 percent. Next came the tensions between Moscow and the Soviet Union's Baltic republics, at 21 percent; news of the budget summit and the savings and loan scandal, each at 18 percent; racial tensions in New York City, 17 percent; renewed Palestinian rioting, 11 percent; and the elections in Romania, 6 percent. The survey results are based on telephone interviews with 1,231 adults conducted from June 1-4 under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associates. Times Mirror said the results are subject to an error of plus or minus 3 percent because of sampling and other random effects. The center is a research arm of Times Mirror, which publishes the Los Angeles Times and other newspapers and has other publishing and broadcasting interests.

DOC.HEAD: American Killed in the Central Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified men stabbed an elderly American to death in his home in the central Philippines, U.S. officials said Thursday. Kathleen Manalo, a spokeswoman for the U.S. consulate office in Cebu, identified the victim as Joseph Barber, 72, a longtime resident of the Philippines. Barber was killed June 1 in his home in Palo, 360 miles southeast of Manila, Ms. Manalo said. Ms. Manalo said she received the report on the killing from military authorities and that there were no further details. Barber was married to a Filipino. It was unknown who may have been behind the slaying of Barber, the seventh American killed this year in the Philippines. One day after Barber's murder, a U.S. sailor was stabbed to death in an apparent robbery in his home outside the U.S.-run Subic Bay naval station, northwest of Manila. Five other American servicemen and civilians have been killed this year. Their slayings have been blamed on the communist New People's Army, which opposes the U.S. military presence in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage's Daughter Appeals for His Release
DOC.TEXT: The daughter of American hostage Terry Andersoan-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah is the umbrella for extremist factions holding most of the hostages. Musawi's statement to the communist Voice of the People radio station echoed a declaration by Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Wednesday. Rafsanjani urged the United States to press for the release of Arabs held in Israeli jails and Shiite Moslem convicts in Kuwait in return for Iran's help in gaining the freedom of the Western captives. Two American educators, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, were released by their pro-Iranian kidnappers in Lebanon in April at Tehran's bidding. Iran said Washington should make a gesture in return. An-Nahar and several other newspapers published an appeal from the International Committee of the Red Cross for the release of two of its employees, Elio Erriquez and Emanuel Christen. ``The ICRC, dismayed by the abduction that targeted two members of a purely humanitarian organization, demands their immediate release and requests help from those capable of doing so,'' the Arabic-language statement said. Christen, 33, and Erriquez, 24, were kidnapped near the southern port city of Sidon on Oct. 6. No group has claimed responsibility. The two worked for the Red Cross orthopedic center in Sidon, which provided people with artificial limbs.

DOC.HEAD: White House Calls De Klerk Move Sign of Progress
DOC.TEXT: The White House today called the lifting of the state of emergency in most of South Africa a sign of ``the remarkable progress'' made in recent months in the white-minority-ruled country. It said the move by South African President F.W. de Klerk to lift the 4-year-old state of emergency removes a major obstacle to talks with the opposition African National Congress aimed at ending apartheid. ``We look forward to the early beginning of a negotiating process,'' deputy White House press secretary Alixe Glen told reporters flying aboard Air Force One with President Bush to a speaking engagement in Milwaukee. ``We welcome the announcement of the ending of the state of emergency in South Africa, except in Natal. This is another significant step toward creating a climate conducive to negotiations that will lead to a democratic, non-racial South Africa,'' she said. The announcement ``builds on earlier decisions by President de Klerk to release Nelson Mandela and certain other political prisoners, to unban the ANC and other organizations and to permit free political debate to take place in South Africa,'' she said. ``Much work remains to be done by all sides. The issue of the remaining political prisoners needs to be resolved. The continuing climate of violence and intimidation must be transformed. The senseless killings in Natal Province must end. ``However, we are encouraged by the remarkable progress that has been made in recent months. With this latest move, the government has moved to meet almost all of the opposition's requirements to enter into negotiations.'' Mandela, the deputy president of the ANC who was freed from prison after 27 years last February, is scheduled to visit the White House on June 25. Bush has also invited de Klerk to Washington. He is expected to come at a later date that has not yet been set.

DOC.HEAD: After 72 Tries, Councilors Still Can't Pick New Member
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-two times they voted. And 72 times the result was the same: Frustrated city councilors wound up deadlocked in their attempt to elect a fellow council member in a special election. Each vote to choose between Selden Hannah and Bernard Veno was followed by a familiar refrain: ``Veno 6, Hannah 6.'' The councilors tried unsuccessfully into the wee hours Wednesday to fill a seat vacated by Councilor Ronald Laurion's death. Hannah and Veno beat a third candidate in the first vote, but choosing between the two left the council stymied until the meeting was recessed at 2 a.m. The first portent of problems came when the council decided, after four fruitless secret ballots, to take care of the rest of the agenda before picking their new colleague. They returned to the voting at 11 p.m. Tuesday. After the 15th ballot, Councilor Chuck Grassie commended his fellow members for helping the city's recycling effort as soda cans began lining up on the table. After the 20th ballot, City Solicitor Danford Wensley suggested a sure-fire way to break the deadlock _ a duel. After the 27th ballot, a motion was made to send a newspaper reporter to get doughnuts. The motion failed. Later tallies ran into trouble as one weary councilor turned in a blank ballot and another count turned up too many votes. Councilor Dan Moynihan said the record for the greatest number of ballots cast was 104, set in the 1920s. The council will have another chance to break the record June 12, when it plans to resume voting on Veno and Hannah. The first order of business that evening, however, is a review of the entire city budget.

DOC.HEAD: Millionaire Polo Player Gets Three Months for Tax Violations
DOC.TEXT: A millionaire polo player who once entertained the Duke and Duchess of York was sentenced today to three months in federal prison and ordered to pay a $200,000 fine for tax violations. Peter M. Brant, 43, pleaded guilty in April to misdemeanor charges of putting his household servants on his company payroll and using company credit cards to buy jewelry, clothing and antiques for his family. ``I accept the responsibility for the mess that occurred,'' a contrite Brant told U.S. District Judge T.F. Gilroy Daly, who imposed a sentence of one year in prison suspended after 90 days. Brant also received five years probation, during which he must perform at least 500 hours of community service. Brant rushed from the courtroom with his wife after sentencing and refused to talked with reporters. He must surrender by July 16. Federal prosecutors alleged that Brant and members of his family charged more than $1.5 million in personal expenses to his newsprint companies from 1981 to 1984. Brant's cousin and business partner, Joseph Allen of New York, and their two newsprint companies, The Bato Co. Inc. and its subsidiary, Riviere du Loup Newsprint Ltd., also pleaded guilty to tax charges. Daly fined each company a total of $1 million, the maximum. Brant, who owns a 1,500-acre estate and is an avid horseman, is a top-rated polo player and established the Greenwich Polo Club Inc. in 1983. In 1987, he played host there to Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson, the Duke and Duchess of York, in their first trip to America after their wedding. As part of a plea agreement, Brant had already agreed to pay $250,000 in taxes owed the federal government and a $125,000 civil fraud penalty. U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy Jr. said the government believes Brant may owe still more in taxes. Allen, 48, pleaded guilty to the same criminal charges as Brant, misdemeanor charges of willful failure to maintain records and conspiracy. The government alleged Allen and family members charged more than $500,000 in personal expenses to Bato and RDL from 1981 to 1984. The Bato Co. and RDL Newsprint also pleaded guilty to two felony charges of filing false tax returns in 1983 to 1984. Bato claimed more than $1 million in improper business deductions and RDL claimed more than $200,000 in improper deductions, the government said. Brant and his wife also have other business interests, including Brant Publications, which publishes Antiques, Art In America, Interview and The Thoroughbred Record.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Sees Shift Away From Production Priorities On National Forests
DOC.TEXT: A shift from timber production will mean a higher priority over the next five years for recreation and wildlife habitats in national forest management, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yuetter said Thursday. Yeutter and U.S. Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson unveiled a long-term plan for forest and range land resources, calling for greater environmental sensitivity and a better balance among multiple uses of public lands. The secretary said production levels will be reduced in areas where timber and mineral production and livestock grazing cannot be accomplished in an ``environmentally acceptable manner.'' ``We are looking at multiple-use management from a new perspective,'' Yeutter said during a news conference at the Agriculture Department. ``This plan calls for some reductions in timber harvests and livestock range grazing in order to enhance and protect the ecological balances there,'' he said. President Bush, in a formal statement to Congress, called the blueprint an ``ambitious program'' that ``strongly renews my commitment to multiple-use management.'' The plan, which the Agriculture Department is required to present to Congress every five years under the Resources Planning Act of 1974, was hailed by at least one environmental group for placing greater emphasis on fishing and wildlife habitats. ``In the past they had a telescope on trees period. Much of the emphasis has been on timber and forest products,'' Trout Unlimited Executive Director Robert L. Herbst said. Leaders of the timber industry condemned the report during a Tuesday news conference, saying the projections are worthless because they ignore such critical factors as the anticipated listing of the rare northern spotted owl as a threatened species. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is to decide by June 23 whether to declare the owl as threatened, a move congressmen in the Pacific Northwest say would result logging bans across large sections of the region. Yeutter acknowledged the industry's concern that the RPA proposal will have to be altered to take the owl into consideration if it is listed under the Endangered Species Act, but he said that will not be done until a formal announcement is made on the owl's status. ``We're not going to do an RPA on the basis of hypotheticals,'' he said. Robertson added that timber-based communities should understand also that the owl listing could carry significant impacts not accounted for in the RPA report. ``There's no question we're going to have to provide more protection for the spotted owl... even if it's not listed,'' Robertson said. Timber harvests on national forest lands, which averaged 12.2 billion board feet from 1983-88, will fall to about 10.8 billion board feet by 1995 then begin to grow slowly again to about 12 billion board feet by 2040, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Orangutan Unscrews Bolts And Escapes Cage at K.C. Zoo
DOC.TEXT: A 127-pound orangutan escaped from its cage by unscrewing four large bolts. Visitors at Kansas City Zoo's Great Ape House screamed, but no one was hurt during the animal's brief dash to freedom Wednesday, zoo officials said. ``You've got all these women pushing kids in strollers trying to get out of there,'' said Beth Cooper, who was in the building with her husband and two toddlers. ``It was kind of funny.'' The zoo's public relations director, Jori Glazer, said no one was injured and the female orangutan, named Cheyenne, was only out of her glass cage about 20 minutes. The 18-year-old ape, who's been caged since 1983, was tranquilized by a veterinarian and back in her cage Wednesday evening. Mrs. Cooper said about a dozen people were in the ape house when they noticed Cheyenne prodding at the window of her cage. ``She unscrewed the bolts and just pushed the glass away,'' Mrs. Cooper said. ``She must have been working on it quite awhile to get them out. They are huge bolts.'' Mrs. Glazer such an escape had never occurred before at the 30-year-old circular ape house. She said Cheyenne was never out of zoo keepers' sights and no one was in danger, adding: ``Of course, we moved all the people to the other side of the zoo. With any wild animal, you never know.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Ends State of Emergency, But Mandela Says Keep Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 graf after 10th pvs, `The African...' to UPDATE with White House comment. Pickup 11th pvs, `De Klerk said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk today lifted the 4-year-old state of emergency in most of the country and challenged black nationalist leaders to respond to his government's reforms. De Klerk's decision to end repressive emergency measures removes a major obstacle to negotiations with the African National Congress on ending apartheid and giving the black majority a voice in the government. ``I have decided to announce there will no longer be a general countrywide state of emergency, but that henceforth it will exist in Natal (province) only'' de Klerk said in a speech to Parliament. Black factional fighting in the southeastern province of Natal has left about 500 people dead since the first of the year. The president also announced that as a goodwill gesture he was releasing 48 prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes. Members of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party burst into laughter when de Klerk began his speech to Parliament by saying he had received a mandate from white voters for reform. ``We are on the threshold of the real negotiation process and the time has come for other important role players to do their bit,'' de Klerk said. ``In particular, the ANC must now stop vacillating.'' Many of the emergency regulations are duplicated in existing legislation. However, without the regulations, police will no longer have immunity from prosecution for any action they take in an unrest situation. Police commissioners lose their power to impose sweeping bans on public gatherings. They will have to prove the necessity of each restriction in court. Police will lose their control over funerals in black townships. Government will not be able to suspend or seize newspapers at will. Police once again will need warrants for most searches and seizures. The African National Congress has said the lifting of the emergency, the release of prisoners and the return of exiles are the main obstacles to full negotiation on a new constitution. The White House called the lifting of the state of emergency in most of South Africa a sign of ``the remarkable progress.'' ``We look forward to the early beginning of a negotiating process,'' deputy White House press secretary Alixe Glen told reporters flying aboard Air Force One with President Bush to a speaking engagement in Milwaukee. ``This is another significant step toward creating a climate conducive to negotiations that will lead to a democratic, non-racial South Africa.'' De Klerk said his government has accepted a joint program on those major issues worked out last month by mid-level officials on both sides. He said he is ready to implement it, but the ANC has said it will not have a response until July 10. De Klerk says he wants the new constitution to allow the country's 28 million blacks to share power with the 5 million whites. The president today reiterated his call for an end to international sanctions against his government. In Paris, ANC leader Nelson Mandela called de Klerk's move ``a victory for the people,'' but he urged the West to maintain the economic sanctions. Some South African newspapers have said that by ending the emergency now de Klerk could be trying to undermine Mandela as he tours the world calling for continued sanctions. The emergency laws, which included some of the harshest restrictions on political activity ever imposed by South Africa's white rulers, had to be renewed by midnight Friday if they were to remain in effect for another year. More than 30,000 activists, almost all of them black, have been detained without trial for varying lengths of time during the emergency. Others went into hiding. About 300 remain in detention now. Most of the country's leading newspapers had predicted de Klerk would lift the decree during his speech to lawmakers. A six-hour Cabinet meeting was held Wednesday at which the emergency was discussed at length. De Klerk's predecessor, P.W. Botha, declared the nationwide emergency on June 12, 1986, in a bid to quell mounting black unrest. De Klerk had nullified some of the emergency restrictions as part of a series of reforms implemented since he assumed power in August. He also has released scores of detainees and long-term political prisoners. But de Klerk said today the violence in Natal province ``cannot be countered with the ordinary laws of the land.'' The ANC has acknowledged that the violence there is worse than in other parts of the country. While he has not called for a continued state of emergency there, Mandela has suggested that the government use the full force of its military and police to stop the killing. The main combatants in Natal are supporters of the African National Congress and members of the conservative Zulu organization, Inkatha. An estimated 6,000 blacks have died in the past four years, 4,000 of them in black-on-black violence in Natal. But scores have been killed in clashes with police, including more than 30 deaths in recent months. Mandela, on a six-week trip to Europe, North America and Africa, conferred with French officials today. The lifting of the emergency decree ``is what we have fought for since the emergency was declared (in June 1986),'' Mandela told journalists. ``But it doesn't change my mind'' regarding the need for sanctions. In pressuring for an end to apartheid, the United States and other countries have restricted trade with and investment in South Africa. Mandela was freed in February after more than 27 years in South African prisons. He and de Klerk have held preliminary negotiations aimed at clearing away obstacles for formal talks. In his speech today, de Klerk again challenged Mandela to stop advocating continued guerrilla activity. De Klerk criticized Mandela's statement in Botswana earlier this week that the ANC approves of ``organized, disciplined violence'' against chosen targets. On two other major issues, de Klerk held out the prospect of reforms soon. He said the government is considering changing security legislation that ``could possibly inhibit the free conduct of peaceful politics.'' He also said the government has ``started to act'' on allowing thousands of exiles to return home. The ANC says it has more than 15,000 exiled members. Anticipating de Klerk's announcement, Conservative spokesman Moolman Metnz said beforehand that lifting the emergency would cause chaos. ``They couldn't cope with the violence even with the state of emergency because they were not applying it. Our view is the government is trying to appease everybody.''

DOC.HEAD: House Votes To Override Bush Amtrak Veto
DOC.TEXT: The House voted 294-123 today to override President Bush's veto of a bill authorizing $2 billion for Amtrak and increasing government power over freight railroad acquisitions. The override measure went to the Senate, where the vote was expected to be closer. A two-thirds vote of both houses is required to turn back a presidential veto. Congress has failed to override all 10 previous Bush vetoes. Bush has said he would support Amtrak funding, unlike former President Reagan, but objected to increased power to be given the Interstate Commerce Commission, calling it ``a step backward for the entire rail industry.'' Democrats argued that the ICC already has power over sale of a portion of a railroad or sale of more than one railroad to investors outside the industry but has decided it cannot scrutinize sale of a whole railroad. House GOP Leader Bob Michel of Illinois introduced a bill today before the veto vote that contained all of the provisions of the Amtrak legislation except for the ICC section. ``The president is committed to an adequate passenger rail service,'' Michel told the House, adding that Bush would not veto the new measure. The veto has had affected daily train operations because the railroad is working with money that Congress already had appropriated. The bill envisions more than $2 billion going to Amtrak through Sept. 30, 1992. Actual amounts will be determined when Congress appropriates the money. The veto had threatened plans for a commuter line between Washington, D.C., and its Northern Virginia suburbs. It contained technical provisions necessary for the project to begin. The measure also contained a provision that would save Amtrak $16 million over two years in unemployment insurance payments for railroad workers.

DOC.HEAD: Transit Authority to Relax Ban on Baby Strollers in Subways
DOC.TEXT: First came love. Then came marriage. Then came the couple with a baby carriage, only transit officials wouldn't let them on the subway with it. After parents threw a tantrum, the ban was lifted Wednesday. ``The TA loves children,'' Transit Authority President Alan Kiepper said in announcing that strollers will be allowed in the system starting Monday. ``Hurrah, hurrah,'' said Andy Breslau, a spokesman for Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger, who lead a ``stroll-in'' with parents to protest the ban.
