Strollers have been a no-no in the subway system for some time, but officials began enforcing it recently. ``We applaud the president's reconsideration and urge him to remove whatever barriers there are to parents and their children using and enjoying public transportation,'' Breslau said. Ed Barbini, a spokesman for state Attorney General Robert Abrams, said Kiepper's office had asked to meet with Abrams on Monday after the attorney general threatened to sue. ``We never met,'' Barbini said. ``That's probably the most successful type meeting you can have in government: when the issue is resolved before you sit down at the table.'' Kiepper said he had not been influenced by the threat or stroll-in. ``I don't feel pressured in all of this. We made a calm reassessment,'' Kiepper said. He added that because of ramps and stairways in the subway, ``If strollers do come onto the system, they need to be handled with great care.''

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Hearings to Begin Next Week
DOC.TEXT: The two top Senate Ethics Committee members said today there has been no plea bargaining with Sen. Dave Durenberger in his financial misconduct case and declared the panel is ready to begin public hearings next week. About 200 potential witnesses have been contacted for the panel's first trial-like hearings since 1981, but not all are likely to testify in the proceedings that begin Tuesday, according to Committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala. and Vice Chairman Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H. Durenberger, R-Minn. has refused in recent weeks to comment on the case, which will determine whether his actions broke Senate rules. The senator has appeared before the committee twice in closed session, but ``there has been no plea bargaining,'' Heflin told a news conference. ``There's been no plea bargaining here whatsoever,'' Rudman added. ``We're not in the nature of trading.'' Durenberger had touched off speculation of plea bargaining when he said last month that he had been talking informally with the committee and that the hearing date served as a deadline for reaching a settlement in the case. The committee previously announced it found ``substantial credible evidence'' of financial wrongdoing by Durenberger, who previously admitted mistakes in judgment. Some of the allegations cover transactions from 1983 to 1989, relating to a Minneapolis condominium that Durenberger partly owned _ and for which he received Senate reimbursements. Other charges are connected to money collected by Durenberger in promoting two books he wrote and his acceptance of free limousine rides. These alleged violations took place in 1985 and 1986. A number of facts in the case are not in dispute, and Heflin said ``the issue of intent is one issue that may be involved, among many.'' The senators said Durenberger and his attorney, Jim Hamilton _ and committee special counsel Robert Bennett _ could file an agreement that certain events took place, thus negating the need for some testimony. ``This is not an easy case,'' Rudman said, adding, ``There is not the kind of tension that you may think.'' When the hearings are completed, the special counsel will make a report to the panel, and the committee would then make recommendations to the Senate. If there's a conviction for breaking the rules, the committee could recommend punishment ranging from a reprimand to expulsion _ although the latter is not likely.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Nasser's Son, Terror Suspect, Released on Bail
LaserPhoto CAI1
DOC.TEXT: The son of late President Gamal Abdel Nasser pleaded innocent Thursday to a series of terrorist attacks that killed two Israeli diplomats and wounded six Israelis and two Americans. Khaled Abdel Nasser, 40, was freed on bail following the court hearing. He wore a dark gray suit and white shirt and sat calmly inside a barred defendant's cage during most of the session. Nasser, who could be hanged if convicted, returned Wednesday night from abroad. Judge Emad el-Din Ismail of the state security court set bail at $1,858 and ordered him not to leave Egypt until his trial ends. ``I trust the justice of the Egyptian judiciary,'' Nasser said afterward, refusing further comment. The court session was adjourned until Saturday. Nasser and 19 others are accused of four attacks against Israeli and American diplomats, one a year between 1984 and 1987. Prosecutors are demanding death sentences for the late president's son and 10 others. The other nine, charged with complicity, face prison terms of up to 25 years. One is Nasser's cousin and the late president's nephew, a physician accused of treating a wounded gunman without informing authorities. In Egypt, defendants are listed according to the seriousness of their alleged crimes, and Khaled Abdel Nasser is the second accused in this case. He and the others facing possible capital punishment are charged with forming a terrorist group called ``Egypt's Revolution'' and financing it with money and military support from Libya. Nasser fled Egypt on Sept. 11, 1987, and made his way to Yugoslavia by the time the indictment was announced in February 1988. Nasser was arrested immediately upon his return to Cairo on Wednesday night. He told police at Cairo International Airport he returned ``to prove my innocence.'' Nasser's charismatic father headed a military group that seized power and ousted King Farouk in July 1952. His ideas on Arab unity and nationhood became immensely popular throughout the Arab world. He died of a heart attack in 1970. Nasser's lawyer, Ahmed el-Khawaga, said the prosecution's main evidence against Nasser is a confession made by another defendant. The prosecutor, Abdel-Meguid Mahmoud, objected to bail, citing Nasser's flight from prosecution for so many months. Bail is not generally granted when such serious charges are involved. Defense lawyer el-Khawaga denied any deal had been made prior to Nasser's return. He said Nasser made the decision on his own.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Apologizes for Former Regime's Support of China Crackdown
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0570 for all needing to remove garble.
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers on Thursday praised Chinese demonstrators for inspiring East Germany's own peaceful revolution and apologized for a resolution supporting last year's violent crackdown in Beijing. East Germany's Parliament, which was elected March 18 in the nation's first free elections, passed by a voice vote a declaration meant to erase the former Communist government's support of the Chinese crackdown. ``The first freely elected Parliament ... regrets the former declaration. The Parliament members remember the victims with profound sorrow,'' the declaration said. The former Communist-controlled Parliament pasng a declaration June 8, 1989, that expressed support for the Chinese government's military attack on protesters in Beijing. The old resolution was passed four days after troops rolled through Beijing and into the capital's Tiananmen Square, killing hundreds and perhaps thousands of people. The declaration approved Thursday drew parallels to China's thwarted democracy movement and East Germany's own revolt, which began with protests in the middle of last year and grew to mass demonstrations by the fall. The unrest toppled the government of Erich Honecker in October and forced open the Berlin Wall in November. Several German news reports since then have said East Germany's hard-liners had considered a ``Chinese solution'' to the mass demonstrations. ``In awareness that the courageous beginning of the Beijing demonstrators bestowed in the GDR the essential impulses for the young democracy movement ... and in knowledge that in October 1989 there was a danger of a similar fate, the members of Parliament express hope that also in China there will be democratic developments,'' the Parliament declaration said.

DOC.HEAD: Nurse Asks U.S. Government Help for My Lai Clinic
DOC.TEXT: An American nurse on Thursday asked Washington to fly in supplies for a hospital she built in My Lai, the village where U.S. troops committed their worst atrocity of the Vietnam War. Three weeks ago, Cherie Clark and her private International Mission of Hope inaugurated the two-story hospital at My Lai, where soldiers of Charlie Company shot hundreds of villagers to death in 1968. But the hospital remains an empty building. The $300,000 of medical supplies needed to open it are in Atlanta and Portland, and the cost of privately transporting them to Vietnam is too high, said Ms. Clark, of Denver. Ms. Clark, a volunteer nurse in Vietnam during the war, said Washington has agreed in principle to take the supplies along when space is available on its aircraft going to Hanoi, Vietnam's capital. But it gave no commitment and no supplies have gone thus far, she said. The U.S. government has embargoed all trade and official aid to Vietnam since the war ended in 1975. ``We're saying to the U.S. government: Give us a break this time. Fly the supplies here. The people are suffering all sorts of ailments,'' Ms. Clark said in an interview in Ho Chi Minh City, where she has an office. Ms. Clark said more than half the children in the My Lai area, about 340 miles northeast of Ho Chi Minh City, are malnourished. She said villagers wept at the inauguration of the hospital, built by about 100 local laborers on the spot where the U.S. helicopters landed on the bloody day in March 1968. The handful of survivors recalled how they lay under heaps of bodies, she said. ``The old men were looking at us, and the kids were holding me and they wouldn't let go,'' Ms. Clark said. ``We wanted to bring health care to them,'' she said. ``We wanted them to know that there were different kinds of Americans, that some care even though it was 20 years ago. ``They say they cannot forgive, but they love the new Americans who have come back,'' she said. On March 16, 1968, Charlie Company's first platoon led by Lt. William L. Calley Jr. killed at least 175 Vietnamese men, women and children at My Lai, according to the 1970 report of a U.S. Army inquiry. A plaque in the village is inscribed with the names of 504 men, women and children Vietnamese officials say died there. Calley was the only soldier convicted for the massacre at a court-martial in March 1971. He was sentenced to life imprisonment. Following a public outcry, then-President Richard Nixon reduced his sentence to 20 years, and Calley actually served just three years under house arrest before his conviction was overturned by a federal judge. The United States withdrew from Vietnam in 1973. In April 1975, the South Vietnam government it backed fell to Communist forces from the north. After Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978, Washington reaffirmed the embargo and the withholding of diplomatic relations with Hanoi. It says that will change only with a political resolution of the continuing Cambodian war. The work of Ms. Clark and other private citizens was eased after the United States in 1987 pledged to facilitate non-government humanitarian aid to Vietnam, in exchange for cooperation on resolving the status of about 1,800 missing U.S. soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: State Lawmaker Announces Run For GOP Governor Nomination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT ``dozen'' to ``half a dozen.''
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. Nyla Murphy today filed for the GOP gubernatorial nomination, saying she believed Republicans should have a choice in the primary. The field of Republican candidates has dwindled from more than half a dozen to just rancher Mary Mead. That brought accusations that GOP ``power brokers'' were behind Mead's campaign and had successfully discouraged all other contenders for the nomination. ``I call them king makers. I guess I should say queen makers,'' said Murphy. ``... I think there are some money powers, money brokers, behind the opponent's candidacy.'' A 12-year member of the House of Representatives, the 59-year-old Murphy from Casper said she was approached about two weeks ago to oppose Mead, and that after mulling the idea for about a week decided to enter the race. The state representative refrained from directly attacking Mead, saying she knew little about her. Mead, 54, was an unsuccessful candidate for state senator in the 1970s and is a former president of the Wyoming Heritage Society. She is the daughter of Cliff Hansen, a former Wyoming governor and U.S. senator in the 1970s. Democratic Gov. Mike Sullivan is seeking a second term, and is opposed by Ron Suds Clingman, a first-time gubernatorial candidate.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Refuses to Break Crime Bill Filibuster
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with sponsors call for bipartisan negotiations; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Senate failed today to break a filibuster against an anti-crime bill that included curbs on semiautomatic weapons, and sponsors called for negotiations to save the measure from being scuttled. The vote was 57-37 in favor of imposing a time limit on debate _ six short of the 60 votes needed. ``The only way we're really likely to get a bill is if we can enter into negotiations,'' Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., told the Senate. The action represented a victory for the National Rifle Association, which opposed the measure's gun provisions. The bill also includes provisions instituting the death penalty for 30 federal crimes and is designed to end delays of up to a decade in carrying out executions. It also would allow courts to consider evidence gathered with flawed warrants in some cases. Democratic leaders said debating each of 300 amendments waiting in the hopper would fuel a filibuster with endless delays. They said in advance of the vote that failure to impose a 30-hour time limit would kill the bill. Biden, chairman of the Judiciary Committee and the measure's floor manager, took the floor minutes after the vote and declared that it had been ``do or die time for the crime bill and it just died.'' Within two hours, however, Biden returned to say he was ``confident our staffs can literally in a matter of an hour or so bring to a resolution all the remaining issues.'' ``I feel we can reach an agreement on one or two other provisions and pass this bill,'' said Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., one of the measure's handful of Republican supporters. `` ... I think we can work it out.'' On the roll call, 11 Republicans joined 46 Democrats in voting for a time limit. Seven Democrats and 30 Republicans opposed it. Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas urged the Senate to push ahead with action on the bill even without a limit on debate. ``This is an important bill,'' he declared. ``... If we want a crime bill, the majority can have one.'' Biden blamed the National Rifle Association for the surge of amendments. The gun group had been widely expected to win a Senate battle two weeks ago to drop restrictions on semiautomatic assault weapons. In a surprise move, the Senate rejected a move to drop the curbs. Biden said the NRA hoped to block final action on the bill by encouraging lawmakers to let debate flow on indefinitely. The campaign to curb such weapons began in January 1989 after a deranged man with an assault rifle opened fire on a Stockton, Calif., school yard, leaving five youngsters dead and 30 other persons hurt. The NRA as well as federal firearms experts say, however, that the so-called assault weapons differ only in their military styling from normal semiautomatic hunting rifles with their traditional brown wooden stocks. NRA lobbyist David Conover said Wednesday the group sent out ``targeted alerts to half a dozen to eight states, to a portion of our membership in each state,'' urging them to press senators to vote against shutting off debate. He stressed the political dividends lawmakers see in keeping alive a death penalty measure with voters aroused over the issue.

DOC.HEAD: No. 2 at Federal Reserve Announces Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Nickname `Manley' in penultimate graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Manuel H. Johnson unexpectedly announced his resignation Thursday from the No. 2 job at the Federal Reserve, creating a key opening at an agency often criticized by the Bush administration for keeping interest rates too high. Johnson, 41, said he planned to return to an academic career. The Aug. 3 departure will give President Bush the chance to make another appointment to the seven-member board that directs the nation's monetary policy. The administration at various times in past months has been openly critical of the Fed's efforts to restrain inflation by keeping interest rates high. There was a published report in March quoting an unnamed Bush adviser as saying the president was ``mad as hell'' with Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and would not reappoint him as chairman. Bush later insisted there was ``no bubbling war'' with Greenspan, but left the clear impression he would like to see more aggressive action on the part of the Fed to lower interest rates. Analysts said it was likely that Bush would appoint someone to the Fed who would be more amenable to the administration's pleas for lower interest rates. ``This administration has been jawboning the Fed on and off for some time for a looser monetary policy,'' said Kenneth Guenther of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``They want lower interest rates because they don't want the economy moving into a recession.'' Fed officials have been pursuing a ``soft-landing'' approach for the economy in which interest rates are used to slow growth enough to ease inflationary pressures but not enough to tip the country into a recession. Many analysts believe that approach is working and that the Fed is unlikely to change course even with a new vice chairman appointed by Bush. ``The Fed isn't closely divided now where one vote in either direction would make much of a difference,'' said Lyle Gramley, a former Fed governor and now chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association. The administration had no immediate comment on Johnson's departure. The president will have the opportunity to either name someone new to the board and designate that person as vice chairman or select one of the other governors as vice chairman while appointing someone else to fill Johnson's board term, which runs until Aug. 21, 2000. There was speculation that David Mullins, appointed to the Fed earlier this year, might be considered for the vice chairman's job. Mullins, one of the authors of the savings and loan bailout legislation, had been a top assistant to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Johnson was appointed to the Fed by President Reagan on Feb. 7, 1986, and was elevated to vice chairman six months later. He said his resignation would be effective at the end of his four-year term as vice chairman. ``I am extremely proud to have played a part in the unprecedented period of sustained economic growth and low inflation that has characterized the decade of the 1980s and continues into the 1990s,'' Johnson said in his letter of resignation. Johnson said he planned to return to George Mason University in Washington's Virginia suburbs and assume the Koch Chair in international economics and become director of the Center for Global Market Studies. He was a professor at the school in 1981 when he was selected to join the economics team assembled by then-Treasury Secretary Donald Regan in Reagan's first term. ``I deeply regret, but understand, Manley Johnson's decision,'' Greenspan said in a statement. ``The vice chairman and I have been an effective team. I'll miss him.'' The Fed, the nation's central bank headquartered in Washington, is run by the board of governors and a nationwide network of 12 district banks. The governors are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate to serve 14-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Fishermen Missing After Boat Collides With Freighter
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese fishing boat collided with a Norwegian tanker, broke in two and sank Thursday, and 11 of its crewmen were missing, authorities said. Fumio Ichinosawa, an official of the Maritime Safety Agency, Japan's coast guard, said four Japanese fishermen were rescued by the Norwegian ship Nopal Cherry. He said 15 fishermen were aboard the Yugen-maru when it collided with the Nopal Cherry about 50 miles east of the island of Miyake-jima. The island is 100 miles south of Tokyo. He said the Nopal Cherry suffered no major damage and none of its 20 Filipino crewmen was reported injured.

DOC.HEAD: President Praises Gorbachev as Remarkable Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 2, Bush made, to show remarks delivered; Subs grafs 7-8 to make quotes as delivered.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, in his first speech since the superpower summit, today praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as ``a remarkable man'' helping to usher in a new era in U.S.-Soviet relations. Bush made the remarks at a Republican luncheon here for Gov. Tommy Thompson on the first stop of a four-state Midwestern swing by the president to raise money for GOP candidates. En route to Milwaukee on Air Force One, a White House statement welcomed the lifting of the 4-year-old state of emergency in most of South Africa. ``We welcome the announcement,'' said deputy press secretary Alixe Glen. ``This is another significant step toward creating a climate conducive to negotiations that will lead to a democratic, non-racial South Africa.'' But even as Bush shifted his attention to domestic politics, he was looking back at what he called ``a very productive Washington summit.'' Bush ran down a list of arms and trade agreements that he and Gorbachev signed. He said even on the tough issues that the summit did not solve, such as German membership in NATO and the future of the Baltic states, they made progress with the candor of their discussions. ``Of course we have differences ... I want to see Lithuania have its freedom. We are committed to self-determfination for the Baltic states. Although I ... am pleased that the emigration of Soviet Jews is at an all-time high, I want to see unfettered emigration,'' he said. ``We have differences on Cuba and, for now, on a united Germany in NATO and on many other issues as well,'' added Bush. ``But as I chatted informally with President Gorbachev at Camp David, I kept thinking that this new Soviet leader, committed to reform and openness, is indeed a remarkable man,'' he said. He praised the Soviet leader ``for the forthright spirit in which he addressed every issue on the table, and I take it as proof that we have indeed entered a new era in our relations with the Soviet Union.'' Bush also had stops planned in Illinois, Iowa and Nebraska today and Friday to campaign for U.S. Senate and gubernatorial contenders. In both Wisconsin and Iowa, the thorny issue of abortion promises to figure prominently in the November campaigns. Thompson is considered in strong shape in a well-funded re-election bid against four-term Democratic Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus. After the Milwaukee luncheon, Bush was heading to Chicago to put his prestige behind one of the GOP's top-priority governor's races _ Secretary of State Jim Edgar's bid against Democratic state Attorney General Neil Hartigan to succeed outgoing Republican Gov. James R. Thompson. The party hopes the president's campaign efforts in Illinois also will provide a boost to Rep. Lynn Martin's tough battle against incumbent Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. As is the White House custom of combining public events with political trips _ with the taxpayers paying for the presidential events and the Republican Party sharing costs for political portions _ Bush also had a series of education and other policy-oriented appearances. The White House is planning increasingly frequent campaign trips for Bush as the November election nears. ``This is the type of thing the president will do a lot of,'' said a national party official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The best thing the president can do now is to provide material resources for these candidates,'' by appearing at high-priced fund-raisers. On Wednesday, the president met with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo to discuss Roh's talks in San Francisco with Gorbachev after the Soviet leader left Washington on Sunday. When he returns to Washington on Friday night, Bush will host West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl for further post-summit consultations. On Friday, Bush will be in Des Moines for incumbent Gov. Terry Branstad, who will be feted at a $150-a-ticket breakfast, and also benefit from a $2,000-per-person private gathering with Bush. Abortion has emerged as an issue in Branstad's forthcoming race against House Speaker Don Avenson, selected by Democrats on Tuesday as their nominee, as well as in the state's Senate contest. Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin is pro-choice, and his Republican challenger, Rep. Tom Tauke, is anti-abortion. Avenson credited his pro-choice position for his victory over an anti-abortion primary opponent and said he will campaign on the issue against Branstad as well. In Wisconsin, Democrat Loftus said he also plans to make abortion an issue against Thompson. Loftus claims Thompson has been unsympathetic to feminist causes. Thompson endorses abortion in cases of incest, rape and when the mother's life is threatened. He also supported a proposal that would have required unemancipated girls under 18 to have the consent of at least one parent or a judge before obtaining an abortion. Bush has made a point as president of opening the doors of the GOP to both pro-choice and anti-abortion backers. He opposes abortion except in cases of rape, incest or threat to the mother's life. From Iowa, Bush goes to Nebraska for an Omaha luncheon for Senate contender Hal Daub, recruited by the Republicans to take on two-term incumbent James Exon. Daub, a former congressman, lost his bid for the GOP nomination against former Sen. David Karnes in the state's last Senate election.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim to Have Killed 1,870 Government Troops
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels claimed Thursday they had killed 1,870 government troops in two days of fighting early this week near a strategic town north of the capital. The Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, in a clandestine broadcast, said 1,990 soldiers were wounded in the battles south of Dessie, the heavily defended capital of Wollo province. The front is a combined force of the Tigre People's Liberation Front and the Ethiopian People's Democratic Movement, a much smaller group. The broadcast, monitored in Kenya's capital, Nairobi, said the fighting took place Sunday and Monday about 90 miles north of Addis Ababa. Both the rebels and President Mengistu Haile Mariam's government claimed victories in the same area last week. It was impossible to verify either claim because the war zone is generally inaccessible to journalists and other independent witnesses. If the rebels' claim Thursday is true, the insurgents would be only six miles south of Dessie. The town is at the junction of a major road northeast to Ethiopia's Red Sea port of Assab. Dessie is also the main depot for emergency food being distributed to famine victims in Wollo and Tigre provinces. The food is trucked from Assab, the only port in government hands since rebels captured Massawa in February. The Eritreans are fighting a three-decade war for the independence of Ethiopia's northermost province of Eritrea. The Tigreans have been fighting for 15 years seeking Mengistu's ouster and the establishment of a hard-line Marxist state. They took control of Tigre province early last year.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Homemaking a `High-Risk' Job
DOC.TEXT: Displaced homemakers often face poverty and limited job opportunities, a private group said Thursday. ``If you choose homemaking, you're choosing a very high-risk occupation,'' said Jill Miller, executive director of the National Displaced Homemakers Network. Women forced to seek jobs outside the home after spending years as full-time homemakers often lack training and have to take part-time, seasonal jobs, Miller said. The number of displaced homemakers rose 12 percent over the past decade, from 13.9 million in 1980 to 15.6 million in 1989, according to a report by the Washington-based group based on Census Bureau figures. Displaced homemakers are women whose main job was homemaking, but who lost their key source of income through widowhood, divorce, separation or because a spouse suffered disability or long-term unemployment. ``We are penalizing (homemakers) and leaving them high and dry when they make that choice,'' she said, noting that other workers are eligible for unemployment benefits. Nearly three in five displaced homemakers were living near or below the poverty level, the report said. About one in five, or 3 million American women, are living in households with other families, it said. The group said there were 22 million American married women in 1989 who were full-time homemakers.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE Amtrak ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Official Foresees Accord on `Wide Window' to Space Defense Work
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and United States may agree this year on an experimental program for increasing each side's observation of the other's anti-missile defense work, a senior U.S. negotiator said Thursday. David Smith, chief U.S. delegate to the Geneva negotiations on defense and space, told reporters such an accord was possible as early as this year. But he saw little likelihood of completing a formal treaty on the use of space-based defenses against strategic ballistic missiles within the next two years. He said there was no official target date for completing the Defense and Space Treaty, which, in the U.S. view, would govern a gradual transition by both countries from offensive to defensive means of deterring nuclear war. But the Soviets don't accept that concept, saying it would lead to a new, more expensive, more dangerous and unpredictable arms race in space. Smith said the experimental program, as proposed by the United States, would be an important sign of progress in the Geneva talks, which have been bogged down lately. The United States has proposed an executive agreement on ``predictability measures'' designed to build confidence in both Washington and Moscow that neither side is trying to conceal its intentions in researching space-based dcist running hard in Arkansas and a charismatic ex-Klan leader seeking to represent Louisiana in the U.S. Senate. While mainstream candidates denounce the extremist views, some civil rights officials voice concern. They see a fearful trend in the candidacies of J.B. Stoner and Ralph Forbes, who seek nominations for lieutenant governor in Georgia and Arkansas, and are especially troubled by David Duke's run for the Senate in Louisiana. ``This is part of a new strategy that the white supremacists have developed ... to work within the electoral system while at the same time building their underground operation,'' says Eva Sears of the Center for Democratic Renewal, an Atlanta-based organization that monitors the Ku Klux Klan and similar groups. The Klan has elected members to Congress and to many state offices in the past, but those who watch white supremacists say their strategies have evolved and the stakes have gone up. ``What's new is the extent of the support that they're getting,'' says Irwin Suall of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in New York. ``Financial support, votes,'' Suall continues, ``the amount seems to be sufficient to take them out of the category of fringe candidate.'' Duke, who left the Klan to lead the National Association for the Advancement of White People, has reported receiving nearly $600,000 in donations to his campaign for the GOP nomination for the seat now held by Sen. Bennett Johnston. Duke insists he's now merely a champion of whites' civil rights, not a white supremacist. Forbes, a former American Nazi leader, won 46 percent of the vote in last month's primary for the GOP nomination for Arkansas lieutenant governor. A runoff is set for Tuesday. ``The numbers that Ralph Forbes polled ... will be used time and time and time again to show that people do sympathize with the views of white supremacists,'' says Pat Clark, who heads Klanwatch, a monitoring group in Montgomery, Ala. The balloting figures will become ``a recruiting tool,'' she says. ``It's not necessary always to have a definite victory, in the sense of being elected.'' Indeed, victory often has been elusive since the Klan's electoral successes of the 1920s, when, as University of Florida history professor David Chalmers puts it, ``the Ku Klux Klan elected senators and governors literally from Maine to California.'' Even President Warren Harding agreed to be sworn in as a KKK member in a White House ceremony, according to another scholar, Wyn Craig Wade, in his Klan history, ``The Fiery Cross.'' But at that time, the Klan was at its height, with an estimated 5 million members. Now, monitoring groups say, there are perhaps 5,000 KKK members and 17,000 or so Americans who belong to other racist organizations. That's part of the reason why some thought Duke's 1989 victory on his third try for a seat in the Louisiana Legislature was significant. It ``propelled people to think, `OK, now we've seen it be successful; let's try it once more.' We've definitely seen more people jump on the bandwagon,'' says Ms. Clark. ``It was the first time they've been able to successfully elect people to office since the demise of Jim Crow in the 1960s,'' says Leonard Zeskind, research director of the Center for Democratic Renewal. ``These guys ran for office before ... but they never had this kind of strategy _ of being a hardcore white supremacist and passing yourself off as a right-to-lifer ... or anti-affirmative action.'' Duke, in a telephone inteview from Baton Rouge, says he's been misunderstood and maligned, but he agrees with civil rights officials that a victory in the U.S. Senate race Oct. 6 would reverberate far beyond Louisiana. ``I think a Senate victory would send a message to elected officials across America that they've got to start listening to the majority,'' Duke says.``When I'm elected with my admittedly controversial background, it's going to make it easier for other people to begin to talk about the issues that I'm speaking about.'' Asked about photos of himself in Nazi garb, Duke dismisses them as part of a ``college stunt'' when he picketed a left-wing campus speaker. Asked about statements attributed to him in his own NAAWP News _ such as, ``The media is dominated by Jews ... not good Americans'' and ``North Americans and Europeans are like islands of light in a hungry and backward Third World Sea.'' _ Duke says now, ``I believe in freedom. ... I don't believe in forced integration and I also don't believe in forced segregation. ... I believe in less government.'' Asked about his leadership of a Klan group, he notes that was 12 years ago. ``I think I have a right to change and develop just like anybody else,'' he says. He adds that many of his views differ from those of Forbes, who was once his campaign manager, and of Stoner. Forbes, running against a black candidate in the runoff, recently reiterated his belief that ``racial separation is ultimately the right answer.'' A minister, Forbes cites the Bible in support of his views. His runoff opponent, Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris, speculates that Forbes might have placed first in the primary because, although he wasn't well-known, he had better name recognition than his two opponents and his name was listed first on the ballot. His former membership in the Nazi Party also was not widely known among voters. As for Stoner, who served a prison term for bombing a black church in Alabama in 1958, his anti-black and anti-Semitic campaign rhetoric has prompted some fellow Democratic candidates to threaten to boycott joint appearances. Analysts give Stoner no chance of winning in the July 17 primary, but say racist candidates may tap into a backlash among some white voters. Wayne Parent, a professor of political science at Louisiana State University who has followed Duke's career, says he and other candidates represent ``the remnants of George Wallace-ism'' and hope to take advantage of voter resentment of changes in society brought on by the civil rights movement. Duke has been denied official Republican sanction, ``but as far as making those Republicans turn to the right, he seems to have had some success,'' Parent says, ``because his message is selling better than people thought.'' Jane Hardisty, director of the Cambridge, Mass.-based Political Research Associates, which studies the political right wing, says white supremacists have devoted themselves to politics more seriously since a series of arrests in the 1980s ``effectively set back the violent approach as the medium for the message.'' Voiced by politicians who carry no guns and wear no robes, the message still has a waiting audience, she says. ``If you're in a position where your standard of living is falling, you have job insecurity that you didn't use to have, you're looking for an explanation for that,'' Ms. Hardisty says. ``And they're providing a fairly simple, easy scapegoat _ blame it on some specific group, the Jews or the blacks, whoever.'' Resentment among the electorate and the increasing sophistication of white supremacist candidates make a formidable combination that is hard to disentangle, says Ms. Sears of the Center for Democratic Renewal: ``If you had a big fire, how much of it was the dry wood and how much was the gasoline?''

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Rips Colorado Farm Town, Injures at Least 12
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with crews clearing debris today, other details. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Crews using bulldozers, dump trucks and front-end loaders today began clearing away the debris left by a tornado that devastated this farming community's commercial strip and a trailer park. Twelve people were injured, but warning sirens apparently averted more serious casualties. Lincoln County sheriff's deputies and other public safety employees conducted a house-to-house search today; afterward, they said they believed every resident was accounted for. Officials estimated that the twister damaged 90 percent of the downtown district and more than half the residences of this eastern Colorado plains town. One grain silo was flattened like a beer can. Most of the town's structures were twisted masses of metal and wood, and several railroad cars were overturned. The sirens wailed for 10 minutes before the twister struck Wednesday night, giving residents time to take shelter, officials and survivors said. Gov. Roy Romer, who flew to the shattered town on a National Guard helicopter early today, said he would seek a federal disaster declaration. ``The business district is 50 to 75 percent destroyed,'' he said, adding that damage was likely to run into the tens of millions. The town, 80 miles east of Denver, is known for helping blizzard-stranded travelers forced off Interstate 70. It was without water, but limited electricity and telephone service were reported restored by late morning, officials said. National Guardsmen brought bedding, food and other supplies. The town hall, a bank, a supermarket, a video store and a nightclub were destroyed along Main Street. Most of the businesses were closed at the time; 10 people in the nightclub were saved by taking refuge in the bar's cooler, a witness said. Three guests at the Lariat Hotel piled into their bathtub and pulled a mattress over themselves after the sirens went off. ``We were doing a lot of praying in that bathtub,'' said David Thomas, 27. The tornado tore their room apart. ``It felt like somebody just reached down and squeezed your whole body. My eardrums were coming out,'' Thomas said. Most of the 20 to 25 homes at a trailer park on the edge of town were damaged or destroyed, resident Bernard Goetz said. ``It's a lot of havoc, a lot of destruction, a lot of homes gone out there,'' Goetz said. Two people were hospitalized; one was reported in serious but stable condition with a fractured pelvis. The tornado spun out of thunderstorms that swept the plains east of Denver with heavy rain and baseball-size hail. The National Weather Service said nine other tornadoes touched down on the plains. In eastern El Paso County, two people were trapped in a mobile home for about two hours after it was hit by a tornado late Wednesday, Sgt. Dean Kelsey said. Both were hospitalized in Colorado Springs.

DOC.HEAD: Pizza Man Threatened With Snapping Turtle, Robbed of $50
DOC.TEXT: Where were the crime-fighting, pepperoni pizza-munching Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles when Domino's delivery man Troy Brewer really needed them? After all, they may have known his alleged hard-shelled attacker. Brewer said he was at a pay phone when he was robbbed by a pair of thieves armed with a snapping turtle. ``That sucker was going to bite me,'' he said. ``They put him right up to my face.'' The toothsome turtle didn't nip the flustered pizza delivery man, but those wielding the turtle got away with his money pouch containing about $50, he said. ```Don't move or you're gonna get bit,''' Brewer said robbers told him. Brewer, a college student who works in Balch Springs, filed a police complaint in Dallas because he said Tuesday night's robbery occurred just inside the city limits. Balch Springs Assistant Police Chief B.W. Smith said it was first robbery at turtle-point he's ever heard of. ``I suppose if he said it happened, I guess it did. Personally, I just can't see somebody holding somebody up with a turtle,'' he said. Brewer said he was still shaken a day later: ``It was a big, huge, ugly turtle.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Swashbuckling leading man Harrison Ford is donating the bullwhip he used in his ``Indiana Jones'' movies to help raise funds for a new archaeology studies building, organizers said Thursday. ``He brought archaeology alive for the general public,'' said Cathy Giangrande, organizer of the Institute of Archaeology's fund-raising drive. Ford has made three films playing the role of adventurous archaeology professor Indiana Jones for director Steven Spielberg. Ford's bullwhip will be sold with other film and entertainment memorabilia at Christie's auction house in December. ``We don't know what it will fetch. Christie's said the price depends on who goes to the sale and how badly two or more bidders might want it,'' Ms. Giangrande said. The fund-raising effort is to raise $6.7 million for the new building at the archaeology institute located at University College, part of London University.

Rep. John Conyers got hitched this week in a wedding so private that his chief of staff claimed to know nothing about it. According to the marriage license, his wife was born in 1964 _ the same year the 61-year-old Conyers won his first congressional election, the Detroit Free Press reported Thursday. Records at the Wayne County Clerk's Office show he married Monica Ann Esters, 25, of Detroit. Records also indicated the marriage Monday was Conyers' first. ``Why would he have gotten married? What are people saying? What's the scuttlebutt?'' Julian Epstein, Conyers' chief of staff in Washington, asked Wednesday when queried about the wedding. Conyers spokeswoman Leslie Kaufman said Thursday she would not confirm or deny the reported marriage. ``It's his personal life. He's not discussing it,'' she said.

Actor Robby Benson, whose six-figure earnings at the University of South Carolina stirred controversy, is being wooed to remain in the Palmetto State. The State Development Board and Columbia College are working on a package deal to keep the actor and filmmaker in the state. The board that works to attract business and industry into the state, unanimously approved contract negotiations with Benson on Wednesday. But Isabel M. Hill, head of the Development Board's film office, said talks with Benson had not moved past ``very cursory initial contact.'' Officials asked Benson and his wife, singer-actress Karla DeVito, if they would consider staying in South Carolina, possibly to teach at Columbia College and help bring movie producers to the state, she said. Benson was caught up in negative publicity surrounding University of South Carolina President James B. Holderman, who resigned last week amid reports of lavish spending. Among spending criticized was the $158,367 in salary and living expenses the school paid Benson over the past two years. Benson taught filmmaking there and made the movie ``Modern Love'' in Columbia, using students and local professionals. The actor of such films as ``Tribute,'' ``One on One'' and ``The Chosen'' could not be reached for comment, but he said last week he resigned ``the second Dr. Holderman did'' and that he would be moving to Los Angeles this month.

Onetime New York City limousine king William Fugazy was ordered to pay billionaire John Kluge $46.6 million for lying about the car company's worth before selling it. A Manhattan jury decided Wednesday in favor of Kluge and awarded him more than $15.5 million in damages. Under the state's civil racketeering law, the award was tripled by U.S. District Judge Robert Carter. Kluge, owner of Metromedia Co., bought Fugazy Express car service in 1985 and sued two years later, claiming Fugazy lied about the company's finances. Fugazy, who said he would appeal, accused Kluge of mismanaging the company into bankruptcy. He said he remained mystified by the suit. ``He and I were friends,'' Fugazy said. ``I guess that's the way it goes. I don't know what he was mad at.'' Metromedia attorney Arnold Wadler called the verdict ``fabulous'' and said Kluge was ``very satisfied.'' Kluge already has been awarded $4 million in damages from other lawsuits stemming from the sale.

DOC.HEAD: Dogs Gather at Greenwich Lawn Party To Celebrate Birthday
With AM-Doggie Domiciles, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Whoever coined the phrase ``It's a dog's life'' probably had no idea just how good it could be. Max Felberbaum, a tuxedo-clad bichon frise, certainly does. The dog was one of an elite group of party animals who gathered Wednesday for a lawn party in this upscale suburb. Unruffled by his trip from Manhattan, Max joined Sparky Duberstein, Bibi Walker and several other close friends _ all the same breed _ at the first birthday party of Bonnie and Clyde Frankel. While their masters sipped champaign and nibbled turkey sandwiches, the dogs savored meatball-shaped morsels on baked biscuits and heart-shaped cookies. A cake resembling a bone took a few wallops from a hammer to convert into bite-sized portions. President Bush's Aunt Mary Walker, who accompanied her dog, Bibi, pronounced the event a success. ``Well, it was just perfectly lovely. I've never been to a party like this before,'' she said. ``It's a really wonderful idea. It's so adorable.'' Some dogs arrived in limousines, and at least one wore what appeared to be a diamond-studded collar. ``Of course it's real,'' a guest remarked. Barbara Frankel, the hostess, admitted that some might find the gathering odd. ``You can imagine my friends think I'm certifiable, but it makes me happy,'' she said. As for next year's party, Bambi Felberbaum, Max's master, said: ``I think for the second anniversary we'll have to fly them to Paris. It's very chic to bring your dog to a restaurant in Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Electrical Stimulation Devices No Better for Back Pain Than Placebo
DOC.TEXT: Lower back pain is better remedied by a good stretch than expensive electronic gadgetry, according to a study published Thursday The results of the study indicate that widely used transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, or TENS, appears to be no more effective than a placebo, said Dr. Richard A. Deyo, lead author of the study published in the New England Journal of Medicine. ``It appeared to do nothing in our study. It was a resounding negative result,'' the University of Washington researcher told reporters Wednesday. A major manufacturer of the devices, Empi Corp. of St. Paul, Minn., criticized the study, saying the 30-day length was not long enough. ``Other studies done over a longer time frame have reinforced our belief that TENS devices are an effective, low-cost alternative to narcotic drug therapy and surgery for many pain sufferers,'' Donald Maurer, Empi chairman, said. TENS units _ about the size of a personal cassette player _ are carried on the belt. They include wires with electrodes placed on the skin in the area of pain. Deyo said they cost about $500 and have been used for about 20 years. He said use of TENS resulted from the belief that counterstimulation of the nervous system could modify perception of pain, like rubbing a bump on the head. It was later believed that TENS' low-frequency, high-amplitude electrical stimulation could raise the level of opiatelike substances, endorphins, in the spinal fluid. But little clinical evidence existed on the machines' effectiveness. The researchers, who also included doctors at the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, ran clinical tests using 145 patients with chronic back pain from 1985 to 1987 in San Antonio. They were broken into four groups: TENS plus exercise, TENS alone, exercise with sham TENS, and sham TENS alone. All four groups reported significant improvement after two and four weeks of participation, but had relapsed by the two-month follow-up. ``There were no clinically important or statistically significant differences in any outcome between the subjects receiving true TENS and those receiving sham TENS,'' the study concluded. ``By contrast, the analysis of the effects of exercise showed an advantage of exercise in several outcomes,'' including reduction in reported frequency of pain. Deyo's advice: ``Try exercise first, and be persistent.'' He said those working at exercise to help chronic back pain should expect no quick fixes but should see improvements over time. He also advised against surgery for muscle-oriented pain, and against powerful medications. He said TENS may be effective for acute pain or pain in other parts of the body. But he said he hoped the research would prompt others to study the TENS' effectiveness. The study said Americans spend $13 billion each year on lower back pain treatments. Athough no estimate of national expenditures for TENS is available, Deyo said the Veterans Administration in 1986 spent $2 million to purchase them. Deyo is director of health services research and development at the Seattle Veterans Affairs Medical Center as well as a University of Washington associate professor of medicine and health services. He said he expected a ``public relations-type'' assault against the study, adding that a half-dozen manufacturers of TENS devices do business in the United States. Others involved in the study included Dr. Nicholas Walsh, chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine Rehabilitation at the University of Texas; Dr. Donald Martin at the University of Washington; and Drs. Lawrence Schoenfeld and Somayaji Ramamurthy at the University of Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Lifting of National State of Emergency Brings Praise, Criticism
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk's lifting of the national state of emergency was welcomed Thursday by world leaders but drew some domestic criticism for going too far _ or not far enough. The African National Congress, the black nationalist group that has spearheaded the anti-apartheid movement, called the government actions ``half measures.'' Right-wing whites, on the other hand, intensified their criticisms of de Klerk. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar called de Klerk's move a ``positive development,'' and the White House hailed the move as a sign of ``the remarkable progress'' being made in South Africa. De Klerk lifted the 4-year-old emergency in most of the country but retained the rules in violence-torn Natal province and the Zulu homeland. ANC leader Walter Sisulu said the state of emergency had done nothing to stop the fighting in Natal. Sisulu told a news conference that if de Klerk wants to create the right climate for negotiations on ending apartheid, the emergency should be lifted in the troubled eastern province as well. ``We are not asking for half measures,'' Sisulu said. ``What we have asked for is to clear the atmosphere to negotiations. That was not done.'' Sisulu said Natal violence could be eased with the lifting of the state of emergency and ``by the government taking positive steps to prevent police brutality in the area.'' In Paris, ANC leader Nelson Mandela also criticized the decision to retain the state of emergency in Natal. He also said it was still too early to end international sanctions against South Africa. Still, he called the lifting of the state of emergency a ``victory for the people ... both black and white.'' About 4,000 blacks have died in violence in Natal during the past four years. The main combatants are supporters of the ANC and members of Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi, who heads the Zulu homeland government, said it was ``lamentably tragic'' that the emergency remained in force in Natal. ``I find it politically altogether unacceptable that I ... who was among the first to declare his readiness to negotiate, now finds himself locked into an emergency-ridden region,'' Buthelezi said. The ANC also wants the government to repeal security laws that still allow detention without trial even though the emergency decree has been lifted. ``Anyone of us in this room can be detained now,'' said ANC official Mohammed Valli Moosa, who was detained three times during the emergency. ``The de facto situation on the ground, in the townships doesn't really change.'' Meanwhile, the pro-apartheid Conservative Party said the end of the emergency would lead to chaos elsewhere in the country. ``They (the government) couldn't cope with the violence even with the state of emergency because they were not applying it,'' said Moolman Mentz, a spokesman for the Conservatives. ``Our view is the government is trying to appease everybody.'' The South African Chamber of Business praised de Klerk's action, calling it ``an important step toward national reconciliation.'' It said stability was essential for business and investment in South Africa. De Klerk wants to work out a new constitution with opposition groups that will lead to power-sharing between the 5 million whites and 28 million blacks, who currently have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Gay Violence Widespread in 1989, Report Shows
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina led the nation in acts of violence, vandalism and harassment against homosexuals in 1989, a year during which such episodes were prevalent nationwide, according to a survey of gay organizations. A total of 7,031 incidents of anti-gay violence or harassment occurred last year in 40 states and the District of Columbia, according to the report, ``Anti-Gay Violence, Victimization & Defamation in 1989.'' Of those, 1,204 took place in North Carolina, the survey found. ``These attacks occurred in a context of widespread violence against Jews, people of color and women,'' said Kevin Berrill, the report's author and director of the anti-violence project at the National Gay & Lesbian Task Force. He cited the death of Yusuf Hawkins, a black youth killed by whites in Brooklyn, N.Y.; the firebombing of the San Diego Jewish Times; the beating death of an Asian in Raleigh, N.C.; and racist bombings in Birmingham, Ala., and Savannah, Ga., that killed a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer. ``Hate crimes exist because the narrow-minded and mean-spirited among us have judged some of their fellow citizens to be less deserving of respect than themselves,'' Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., said at a news conference to release the report. ``The more that we bring these crimes to light, the less tolerable they will be.'' Berrill said anti-gay violence remains largely hidden. He said gay people should report such crimes. He also called on more states to pass hate crimes laws similar to the federal Hate Crimes Statistics Act, signed in April by President Bush. The report said hate crime laws with anti-gay provisions recently passed in California, Connecticut, the District of Columbia, Iowa, Minnesota, New Hampshire, Oregon and Vermont. They also were adopted in Atlanta, Burlington, Iowa; Montgomery County, Md.; and St. Louis, the report said. In Durham, N.C., Jill Duvall, executive director of Gay & Lesbian Health Project, said she believed anti-gay incidents were on the rise in part because of AIDS backlash. Nevertheless, she said, many of the crimes go unreported in North Carolina because of the state's sodomy law. ``Gay people are afraid to go to local police because of treatment in the past. There have been people that have gone to police stations that have been told they are breaking a felony'' statute, she said. The data for the survey came from questionnaires sent to 650 gay activists and organizations nationwide. The task force acknowledged its methods were unscientific, and noted that more than half the groups that responded in 1988 did not do so in 1989. However, the survey is designed to give a broad look at the prevalence of anti-gay incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Urges Continued Sanctions Despite End of State of Emergency
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Black leader Nelson Mandela said Thursday that easing sanctions as a reward for the near-total lifting of South Africa's state of emergency would be ``a stab in the back'' for the anti-apartheid movement. Mandela, in Paris on the first stop of a six-week international trip, said President F.W. de Klerk's decision to lift the emergency in all but one province was ``a victory for all the people, black and white.'' But asked at a news conference if South Africa's government should be rewarded by an easing of economic sanctions, Mandela replied: ``That would be a grave mistake. It would be regarded by the people of South Africa as a stab in back.'' Mandela also expressed regret that the emergency remained in force in Natal province, where black political factions have been battling. One of the main purposes of Mandela's trip to Europe, the United States and Canada is to urge Western leaders to maintain sanctions despite de Klerk's reforms. The 71-year-old African National Congress leader, freed in February after more than 27 years in prison, said French President Francois Mitterrand assured him during private talks that France would keep its sanctions in place. ``He made an unequivocal statement that the French government supports sanctions until fundamental, irreversible changes take place'' in South Africa, Mandela told scores of journalists covering his first visit to France. According to French officials, Mandela urged Mitterrand during their 30-minute meeting to lobby other European leaders to keep existing sanctions in effect. Mandela and de Klerk have held preliminary negotiations aimed at clearing away obstacles, including the state of emergency, so that formal talks can begin on a new constitution that would extend political rights to the black majority. During a meeting with Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac, a former premier, Mandela said a new South African Constitution should not entrench special legal protection for the white minority. ``Nowhere in Europe does one find this idea that the rights of a particular minority must be safeguarded,'' Mandela said. ``Our position is that what's good for Europe is good for us.'' Mandela also met Thursday with Georges Marchais, secretary-general of the French Communist Party, and with Premier Michel Rocard. On Wednesday evening, Mitterrand and his wife, Danielle, joined Mandela and his wife, Winnie, at an outdoor concert held in Mandela's honor at the Place du Trocadero, across the Seine River from the Eiffel Tower. The two couples stood shoulder to shoulder in the rain as an ensemble of 100 white-jacketed violinists played ``God Bless Africa,'' the anthem of the anti-apartheid movement. Mandela _ making his third and most extensive foreign trip since his release from prison _ visits Switzerland next, followed by West Germany, Italy, Canada, the United States, Ireland and Great Britain, as well as several African countries. He returns home July 18, his 72nd birthday. De Klerk, since taking office in August, has moved to dismantle several segregation laws, lifted a 30-year ban on the African National Congress and freed dozens of jailed ANC members, including 48 on Thursday. Mandela, however, contends that foreign pressure should be maintained because de Klerk's government has not yet addressed the black majority's basic demand of a one-person, one-vote political system. De Klerk visted Mitterrand and other Western Euorpean leaders during a nine-nation, 18-day trip last month. Mitterrand told de Klerk the status of sanctions would be discussed at a European Community summit meeting in Dublin, Ireland on June 25-26.

DOC.HEAD: Pennies in the Wishing Well
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS 1st graf to change shaky to beleaguered; ADDS two grafs to include Trump almost slipping by photographers.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY17, NY18
DOC.TEXT: Ivana Trump contributed her two cents Thursday to save her husband's beleaguered empire. ``Hopefully it will bring us good luck,'' Mrs. Trump said with a smile as she tossed her pennies into the newly restored fountain outside the Plaza Hotel, which Trump owns and she runs. ``It can't get much worse.'' The Donald was one of the leading contributors to the privately financed restoration of the Pulitzer Fountain and Grand Army Plaza at the southeast corner of Central Park. Mrs. Trump appeared unannounced at the dedication ceremony to accept a small plaque on her husband's behalf. Asked how her husband was doing in light of his highly publicized cash-flow problems, Mrs. Trump replied, ``I don't know. You'll have to ask him.'' On Wednesday, she released a statement saying that despite their recent marital problems, she planned to ``stand beside him through thick or thin and for better or worse.'' A few blocks down Fifth Avenue on Thursday, Trump almost managed to slip by photographers staking out Trump Tower after someone called news organizations saying he would offer to buy the Trump Shuttle for $1. Trump got into a limousine and sped off.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Study of 25 Percent Force Cut Not A Budget Offer
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney next week will give budget negotiators a ``thumbnail sketch'' showing the effect various defense cut proposals will have on the armed services, his spokesman said Thursday. ``It's to help them focus ... on the budget debate,'' said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. ``It is not a budget offer, it's not a recipe, it's not a plan'' for reductions in the nation's armed forces. Cheney's study will begin with a look at a possible 25 percent reduction in the armed forces over the next five fiscal years, Williams said. He also will outline the effects of the far deeper defense spending cuts sought by the House and Senate. The 25 percent force cut, Williams said, would be the kind of ``ballpark reduction'' that Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have been speaking about over the long term as the defense budget is reduced. The Pentagon ``may well end up making those reductions in the force'' over the years given the current drive to reduce spending, Williams said, adding that such decisions had not been made. Defense experts on Capitol Hill have complained for months about ``blanks'' in Cheney's fiscal 1991 budget, pressing him to come up with long-term spending needs so lawmakers can make decisions about the administration's $303.3 billion spending proposal. Cheney met Wednesday with White House and congressional budget negotiators who are trying to limit next year's budget deficit. They said later that the report would produce figures to be used for bargaining _ but was not an indication that such a cut was inevitable. After that session, Cheney said he was sticking to the administration's proposal to spend $303.3 billion for the military in fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. That's a slight increase over the 1990 budget. Under the House-passed budget, defense spending would be limited to $295.4 billion, while the Senate Budget Committee has approved a $293.9 billion level. Cheney's report will examine a 25 percent reduction in forces, ``not a 25 percent reduction in budget,'' Williams said. ``It's intended to be a kind of a thumbnail sketch of the possible outcome of the department's current six-year defense plan reviews,'' he said. Budget negotiators want to limit next year's budget deficit to $64 billion, the target set by the Gramm-Rudman law. The sessions so far have focused on technical issues, and actual bargaining is at least a week away. The administration says that unless steps are taken, that shortfall could be as high as $206 billion this year. Failure to come within $10 billion of the Gramm-Rudman target will trigger automatic, across-the-board spending cuts in defense and most domestic programs.

DOC.HEAD: Red Army Terrorist Suspect Captured in East Berlin
DOC.TEXT: Authorities caught one of the most notorious terrorist suspects in West German history and said Thursday she lived for years as a homemaker in East Germany, perhaps with the approval of the old Communist regime. East German authorities arrested Susanne Albrecht, 39, in front of her apartment in East Berlin on Wednesday, ending a 13-year hunt for a woman believed to be a key member of the leftist Red Army Faction. The Red Army Faction is blamed for assassinations and arson and bombing attacks in West Germany since the 1970s. The latest attack in November killed the country's leading banker. Miss Albrecht has been accused in the 1977 slaying of Juergen Ponto, the head of Dresdner Bank _ West Germany's second-largest. She also has been linked to the kidnapping and murder that year of wealthy industrialist Hanns Martin Schleyer. Miss Albrecht did not resist arrest and was unarmed, Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel said. She produced her identification, which had the phony name of Ingrid Jaeger, he said. She also had a special travel visa that allowed her more travel freedom than other East Germans under the former Communist regime, he said. Diestel said Miss Albrecht had been a resident of East Berlin for the past 10 years and was married to an East German man. He said she had a child who apparently was born in East Berlin. She had been employed for the last two years as a laboratory worker in another country but maintained a residence in East Berlin, Diestel said. Chief Detective Wolfgang Pauleit told reporters he presumed that she was on vacation from her job and returned because she wanted to be in East Germany for the economic union with West Germany. Diestel would not give the age or gender of Miss Albrecht's child or details about her husband, nor would he identify the country in which she had been working. The West German tabloid Bild, in a report made available in advance of publication Friday, said Miss Albrecht had been in the Soviet Union and was an operative for East Germany's former secret police. The newspaper gave no attribution. It said she was exposed when the vast files of the former secret police network were examined by the country's new democratic government. There has been much speculation about the wealth of information in the 6 million secret police files, and whether there is proof that the former Communist government sponsored leftist terrorism. Diestel said there was no evidence Miss Albrecht worked for the secret police. But he said he could not rule out the possibility that she was living in East Germany with the approval or knowledge of the hard-line Communist government, which was ousted amid massive pro-democracy protests in October. The Red Army Faction got its start with a series of arson and bombing attacks in the early 1970s. Most were aimed at the U.S. military for American involvement in Vietnam. About 25 Red Army Faction members were still being sought up to the time of Albrecht's arrest. The latest attack claimed by the Red Army Faction was the Nov. 30 bombing death of Alfred Herrhausen, head of Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest commercial bank. He was killed when a bomb was detonated under his armored car as he was being driven to work.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Labels Animal Rights Activists `Terrorists'
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top health official portrayed animal rights activists Thursday as ``terrorists'' and said their tactics jeopardize the future of disease-curing experiments. ``Animal research has saved millions of human lives,'' said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. ``It is an integral part of mankind's striving for the betterment of humanity.'' ``I am saddened and a bit angry that we have to put up with major disruptions to science by so-called animal activists who are, in fact, nothing more than animal rights terrorists,'' he said. Animal rights activists, who plan to march Sunday in the nation's capital, responded that Sullivan's remarks were ``appalling.'' They said he was ignoring the continuing exploitation of laboratory animals that suffer needlessly while alternative, non animal testing methods are available. Sullivan was joined at a news conference by officials from the Association of American Medical Colleges; actor David Birney, who is a national spokesman for the American Diabetes Association; Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn.; and parents of children who have benefited from medical procedures that evolved from animal experiments. Also participating were representatives of the beef, dairy, poultry and other industries dependent on animals. Sullivan said that ``virtually everyone agrees that unnecessary animal research or the cruel use of animals is wrong.'' He added, however, that the federal government has in place regulations that ensure that research animals are treated humanely ``and that we do everything possible to reduce any pain or discomfort'' that results from experiments. He said cruel treatment of animals by research scientists was ``very rare.'' Birney, who played the role of a doctor on the television series ``St. Elsewhere,'' ticked off a list of medical advances that have resulted from animal research, including insulin for diabetics, antibiotics, organ transplants, drug therapies and skin grafts. ``Without animal research, many of us in this room would be dead,'' he said. Len Koch, chairman of the Incurably Ill for Animal research, said the activists used ``lies, distortion and misinformation,'' to wage a sophisticated campaign that is costing taxpayers millions of dollars. Medical schools are spending about $6 million a year for damage to labs attacked by animal rights protesters and additional security to prevent further disruption of their experiments, said Dr. L. Thompson Bowles, an official of the Association of American Medical Colleges. The annual cost to the federal government is about $12 million, said Dr. Frederick Goodwin, administrator of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration. Rep. Weber said the issue is not about cruelty to animals but about abuse and harassment of scientists conducting lifesaving experiments. Animal rights groups constitute ``a strong, growing, powerful political movement,'' he said. ``There is no political movement in my judgment that more directly threatens the health and quality of life of the American people in the 1990s than the animal rights movement.'' But Ingrid Newkirk, national director of the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said statements by Sullivan the others were ``appalling ... an attempt to gloss over all the exposes of terrible cruelties, fraud and unnecessary use of animals'' in research. ``I am morally opposed to the exploitation of any individual or group of individuals who cannot fight for themselves,'' she said. ``And so I believe there is always a way if you look to get information without using animals.'' Neal Barnard, president of the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, said Sullivan was wrong in claiming animal abuse in labs was rare. He pointed as an example to a $2.1 million Army study in which 700 cats were shot in the head with bullets, and a surgical company's practice of killing dogs to train its salespeople how to use surgical staples. ``We are still dealing with the outer crust of cruelty and waste,'' Barnard said. ``I would encourage (Sullivan) to deal with the ugly cases that are still there.'' Barnard said that among the alternatives to animal testing are experiments in which cultures of human cells are grown in the laboratory. Tests on these cells, though still imperfect, are faster and more appropriate than testing with animals, he said. ``I'm concerned that Dr. Sullivan isn't thinking,'' he said. ``I don't think he's looked at the opportunities for improvement.''

DOC.HEAD: Some High-Tech Trade Restrictions Being Lifted for Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Officials from 17 Western nations agreed Thursday to lift export restrictions on some high-technology products and opened the way for preferential treatment for East European nations previously denied access to Western technology. The Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls _ known as COCOM _ agreed to delete 30 of 116 items from its restricted list effective July 1, U.S. officials said. This will make the items available to all nations, including the Soviet Union. COCOM will seek to eliminate eight more items by mid-August and reduce restricted items to a ``core list'' of highly strategic items by the end of the year. Delegates at the two-day meeting also agreed that East European countries that adopt ``appropriate safeguards'' could become eligible for preferential treatment. ``We believe these countries are future candidates for deletion from the COCOM list of proscribed destinations,'' a U.S. statement said. Allan Wendt, senior State Department representative for strategic technology policy, said Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia would likely be the first to benefit from a preferred status with the group. East Germany, pending full political unification with West Germany, will benefit from a ``greatly reduced list'' of export controls and improved licensing protections, officials said. West Germany's Economics Ministry said the COCOM decisions amounted to freeing ``all essential technologies for East Germany.'' ``What we are doing is rewriting the COCOM controls from scratch,'' said Wendt, who headed the U.S. delegation. ``It's a tabla rasa approach.'' The moves effectively modernize COCOM, which sets and oversees export restrictions on Western technology with possible military application. They also give a boost to the effort by East European nations to modernize their economies. The decisions ``basically allow Eastern Europe to engage in modernization across the board,'' said Dennis Kloske, undersecretary of commerce for export administration and a member of the U.S. delegation. Machine tools, telecommunications and computer equipment _ which account for the bulk of COCOM cases _ are the ``bricks and mortars'' of modern economic society, Kloske said. The move to free access to a higher level of telecommunications equipment came at the initiative of the United States, U.S. officials said. Members of the U.S. delegation estimated that in reducing COCOM's list of controlled items about $45 billion of U.S. exports alone were eliminated from the licensing process. Among the safeguards required for nations like Poland, Hungary or Czechoslovakia are guarantees the technology will be limited to civilian use and that there will be no intelligence cooperation with the Soviet Union aimed at diverting the technology in question, Wendt said. Kloske said the moves amounted to a ``basic removal of 50 percent of our licensing caseload.'' President Bush called May 2 for modernization of COCOM following the dramatic moves toward democratization in Eastern Europe. All COCOM members _ the NATO alliance minus Iceland, plus Australia and Japan _ were pressing for decontrols.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From De Klerk's Speech
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from President F.W. de Klerk's speech Thursday to Parliament, in which he announced the lifting of the state of emergency in three of the country's four provinces: There are today few or no restrictions on political activities in our country ... Many organizations including the ANC, have now been stripped of the mythological status which they previously enjoyed. They now have to defend their policies in the open marketplace of ideas. ... I announced (in April) a number of practical steps which the government would take to strengthen the maintenance of law and order, particularly in Natal. Those steps are, generally speaking, indicating positive results. ... I have decided to announce that there will no longer be a general countrywide state of emergency, but that henceforth it will exist in Natal only. ... The increasing phenomenon in Natal of violence among blacks, which has led to the destruction of human life and property and has assumed shocking proportions, as well as the exceptionally high level of intimidation that exists there, must still be countered by the strongest means available. ... The government's decision (to lift the emergency) has nothing to do with pressure from any quarter or with any wish to gain political capital. We do not, and have never, regarded the state of emergency as a political pawn. Nonetheless, the net result of the lifting of the state of emergency is that one of the main stumbling blocks has been removed. ... The government is already looking at aspects of security legislation which could possibly inhibit the free conduct of peaceful politics and which, because of the reduction in the violent onslaught on the existing order, might no longer be necessary. ... Communication lines between the South African police and ANC leaders have in the meantime also been established so that violence and intimidation could be monitored and countered right down to local level. ... We are not only talking. We are actually implementing in rapid succession the steps we have envisaged. The process of building a new South Africa has become irreversible. We are on the threshhold of the real negotiation process and the time has come for other important role players to do their bit. In particular, the ANC must now stop vacillating. ... How can (ANC calls for peace) be reconciled with Mr. (Nelson) Mandela's statement June 2 that: `The only sort of violence which we accept is organized violence in the form of armed activity which is properly controlled and where the target is carefully selected.' ... Exactly what targets has the ANC in mind? The same police force which protected him and his colleagues during their recent visit to Cape Town? The departments of the ministers with whom he and his colleagues were discussing in the need for peaceful solutions? Their political opponents in the homelands? ... Let bygones be bygones. Let us forget real or imagined injustices of the past and create a new future for our children, free from mistrust, prejudice and hatred and domination. ...

DOC.HEAD: Hostage's Wife Says She's Not Bitter
With AM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: The wife of U.S. hostage Thomas Sutherland, who marks his fifth year in captivity Saturday, said she does not bear a grudge against his Shiite Moslem kidnappers. ``I don't feel bitter.
