It doesn't do you any good ... to feel bitter,'' Jean Sutherland said in an interview at her office on the campus of the American University of Beirut. Mrs. Sutherland, 56, lives and works at the campus in Moslem west Beirut, continuing the work she and her husband were doing before he was kidnapped June 9, 1985. ``Tom and I are just ordinary people who came here to do a job. The job is still there and we're still doing it and we just have to hang tough as long as we have to,'' she said. ``I was just determined that the continuity should go ahead, that there shouldn't be changes,'' she added. ``This has been tremendously rewarding for me.'' Scottish-born Sutherland, 59, of Fort Collins, Colo., is the second longest-held hostage in Lebanon. He was dean of agriculture at the university when he was kidnapped on the airport highway a few minutes after he returned from a visit to the United States. In addition to Sutherland, 15 other Westerners are missing in Lebanon, including five Americans. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, is the longest held. Anderson was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, the pro-Iranian Shiite group that holds Sutherland, has never issued a photo of him. The only word on his welfare has come from former hostages who had been held with him. Mrs. Sutherland, a tall woman with short, dark gray hair, never loses her smile even when she talks about the pain of her husband's captivity. She is known among her colleagues as a strong, determined woman who spends most of her time at work, teaching English for beginners. In her free time she jogs, plays tennis and walks. Mrs. Sutherland said she has not changed anything in her house since her husband was abducted. ``If Tom walked through the door today, the house would look just as though he left yesterday. Maybe that's part of what you do to make do and keep going. In our situation, I never count days or hours or weeks or years,'' she said. Mrs. Sutherland described the house, on campus and overlooking the Mediterranean, as ``very welcoming. It's something that refreshes the spirit. ``There's so much activity on the campus green that even if I'm at home on my own I never feel alone,'' she said. The Sutherlands have three daughters, Ann, 32; Kit, 30; and Joan, 26. They all live and work in the United States. Sutherland has never seen his only granddaughter, Simone, 3. She was born to Ann after his abduction. Mrs. Sutherland has a gardener _ ``one of my luxuries'' _ who tends the flowering trees, jasmin and gardenias. She moves freely around Beirut, doing her shopping and going out to dinner without feeling afraid. ``People are really nice to me. Nobody has ever threatened me. I never feel it,'' she said. ``People live under such awful conditions here and you're really at essence, you're down to the basics. What you find is that people come together and interact. ``Human relationships become the most precious thing you've got.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Continue Search for Child Labor Violations
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators who found 15,000 violations of child labor laws during a three-day nationwide sweep in March followed with a surprise one-day effort this week, the Labor Department said Thursday. The nearly 1,000 enforcement officials who fanned out across the country Wednesday did not immediately report the number of violations they uncovered at nearly 1,900 businesses, the department said. During the March sweep, agents visited mostly fast-food restaurants, grocery stores and other service businesses that employ large numbers of youngsters. This week's effort was broadened to include agriculture workers and the garment industry, officials said. ``We're trying to see if the problem is pervasive or if it is just in the metropolitan areas,'' said Johanna Schneider, a Labor Department spokesman. The majority of the alleged violations uncovered in March involved firms in which 14- and 15-year-olds worked more hours or later at night during the school week than allowed under federal law. But there were also hundreds of youngsters, mostly 16- and 17-year-olds, who were performing dangerous tasks or using hazardous equipment such as power-driven meat-slicing machinery, dough mixers and paper-balers. Of the 3,900 businesses visited in March, nearly half were in apparent violation of child labor laws, officials said. After the March blitz, investigators first reported 7,000 violations, but the total rose to 15,500 after further reviews of payroll records, the Labor Department said. Fines stemming from the March sweep are expected to total $5 million, up from the original estimate of $1.8 million in fines, the agency said. Last year, the Labor Department's wage and hour division, which enforces child labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act, found 22,508 minors to be illegally employed, an all-time high. Fines totaling $2.7 million were assessed during all of 1989. On Friday, a House panel will continue hearings into child labor violations. Those scheduled to testify include parents of youngsters killed on the job. Officials from Burger King, McDonald's and Domino's pizza are also scheduled to appear. Federal law forbids 14- and 15-year-olds from working more than three hours on a school day or 18 hours in a week during the school year. Eight hours is permitted on weekend days and 40-hour weeks are permitted in summer and during vacations. Youngsters under 14 are prohibited from working in all but a few exempt jobs, such as newspaper delivery workers.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Borrowing Slows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out just $584 million more in consumer credit than they paid off in April, a sharp slowdown resulting from slackened demand for new automobiles, the government said Thursday. The Federal Reserve said consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.0 percent, down from a 4.0 percent growth rate the previous month. Consumers, who account for about two-thirds of all economic activity, have been selective in their buying recently as the economy slowed because of the Fed's tight-credit policy designed to stem inflation. Spending on services generally continues to be brisk, but expenditures for big-ticket goods that are purchased with loans have flagged. Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York, said consumers are becoming less interested in taking on new debt both because of the amount they already hold and because of high interest rates. In a possible reflection of future spending, the Conference Board reported on Monday that its index of consumer confidence dropped to 106.7 in May from 107.3 in April. Some analysts question whether the Fed report accurately reflects the amount of consumer debt since people have other ways of borrowing, such as home equity loans, that are not included in the survey. Automobile loans in April fell $2.5 billion, a 10.3 percent annual rate of decline, after gaining 7.5 percent in March. Automakers had reported a sharp drop in sales in April, a trend that began in the final quarter of last year and continued in May. Credit card debt increased by a brisk $2.4 billion, an annual rate of 14.0 percent, after rising 10.2 percent the previous month. But Benz said much of the gain was due to Easter sales and does not represent a trend. ``You'll probably see it pull back down the road,'' he said. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $735 million, a 4.3 percent annual rate, after falling 6.9 percent in March. Borrowing for mobile homes was off $8 million, a 0.4 percent annual rate of decline, after gaining 4.1 percent a month earlier. ``This supports what we were looking for in terms of the construction sector, that there is a lot of weakness not only in the commercial but in the residential sector as well,'' Benz said. Manufacturing and housing have been the sectors of the economy hardest hit by the Fed's tight-money policy. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of April at $720.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Votes to Slash Additional Funds for Moscow Embassy
DOC.TEXT: A Senate panel voted Thursday to slash an administration request for additional money to tear down and rebuild the new U.S. Embassy in Moscow, which is riddled with electronic listening devices. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 15-0 for an amendment offered by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the $270 million figure the State Department had asked for the coming year to $50 million. The vote was largely symbolic because it came on legislation that is unlikely to be enacted into law. However, it illustrated the continuing controversy over what to do with the eight-story structure, suffused with Soviet listening technology, on which the government already has spent $60 million. Both Democrats and Republicans on the panel, arguing in support of Moynihan's move, said it would be a waste to tear down an nearly completed building that could be used for other purposes for which Soviet eavesdropping would not be a problem. Moynihan argued that the $50 million he left in the bill would be enough to complete the compromised chancery building and construct a smaller building elsewhere in the Embassy compound to house sensitive intelligence and other secret operations. That idea is vigorously opposed by the State Department, which wants to tear the chancery down to its foundation and rebuild it for its originally planned use as the primary office building for the complex. Intelligence experts, including the Senate Intelligence Committee, have endorsed that approach as the only secure one. The House Foreign Affairs Committee, in a separate version of the legislation, has included the full $270 million but left open the question of whether it would be spent on a new building or reconstructing the present one. The skirmish over the Embassy building came on a measure sought by the administration that also would authorize spending $474 million to pay past-due dues to the United Nations. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., signaled that if the measure comes to the Senate floor he would seek to delete that money from the bill. In addition, the measure included a series of add-ons, most from Democrats, to address pet concerns. The provisions included $7.4 million sought by Moynihan to control sea lampreys and zebra mussels in the Great Lakes.

DOC.HEAD: Eagleburger Meets With Chinese Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: A top State Department official met Thursday with China's ambassador amid reports that China has helped Libya develop chemical weapons. Richard Boucher, the department's spokesman, said he didn't know whether Lawrence Eagleburger, the deputy secretary of state, planned to bring up the issue of chemical weapons in his talks with Chinese Ambassador Zhu Qizhen. However, Boucher said, ``We have met with the Chinese recently on the subject of chemical weapons proliferation.'' Eagleburger, who is the State Department's No. 2 man and runs the agency in Baker's absence, traveled twice to China last year on secret missions in the aftermath of China's crackdown on pro-democracy dissidents. Eagleburger accompanied National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft on the trips. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon said on Capitol Hill Wednesday that ``there have been some indications'' the Chinese are involved with chemical weapons. ``We have expressed our concerns to the Chinese at a very high level,'' he said. Boucher refused to elaborate on the reports, but a congressional source, who spoke only on condition that he not be identified, said there were reports that China may be selling chemicals to Libya.

DOC.HEAD: Toddler Killed in Tornado Laid to Rest
With AM-Tornado Warning
LaserPhoto XBED1
DOC.TEXT: A toddler ripped from his mother's arms by a tornado was laid to rest Thursday with his teddy bear sharing his blue metal coffin. ``Today we are in grief, we are in sorrow, we are in a comforting state to the family because this child left us in the morning hours of life,'' the Rev. Elliott Perry said in his eulogy for 15-month-old Benjamin R. Ray. ``But God is not in the business of sorrow. God is in the business of comfort.'' Tim and Donna Ray were trying to carry their four children into the back bedroom of their mobile home when the tornado hit Saturday night. The twister demolished the trailer and ripped Benjamin and his sisters from their parents' grasp. Benjamin was the only Bedford resident among 10 Indiana residents killed during weekend storms that swept through Indiana. Before the service began, Ray stood before the casket on crutches with his sister, Kelli Jaggers. He suffered a broken left leg in the storm. Mrs. Ray, her face still gashed and bruised, was nearby. The Rays' oldest child, Jenny, 7, remained in stable condition at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, where she was being treated for severe head injuries. At the funeral were 6-year-old Abby, who was released from the hospital Thursday, and 3-year-old Melissa, who was released earlier in the week. Along with the teddy bear, a white handkerchief on little Benjamin's body was embroidered with the words, ``Thank heaven for little boys.'' A blue satin pillow on top of the casket read, ``Brother.'' After having three daughters, the Rays continued to have children because they wanted a son, said the children's great aunt, Geneva Speer. ``They had three girls and wanted a boy so bad,'' she said. ``They really couldn't afford to have all them kids, but they kept having them until they got them a boy.''

DOC.HEAD: British Official Urges U.S. to Stay Active in Middle East
With AM-NATO
DOC.TEXT: Britain's foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, said Thursday ``a tremor of danger'' was running through the Middle East and urged the United States to try to bring peace to the troubled region. Hurd said he discussed his anxieties about the Middle East with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III at a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Turnberry, about 50 miles southwest of Glasgow. The foreign secretary said he urged Baker to maintain his interest in the peace process and ``found he remained actively interested, which is crucial.'' Hurd termed an attempt by Palestinian gunmen on May 30 to infiltrate a Tel Aviv beach ``clearly a reverse for the Palestinians.'' He told reporters, ``The tremor of danger running through the area is clear.'' ``The peace process has taken a step backwards in the last few weeks. It is important it should not be lost.'' The United States has denounced the raid, which Israel foiled. Baker has not said whether U.S. talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which began in December 1988 after PLO chief Yasser Arafat renounced terrorism, would be continued. Hurd recently returned from a trip to the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Bipartisan Aviation Funding Bill Introduced In House
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of a House committee introduced a bipartisan bill Thursday to pay for improvements in the nation's air travel system without tax increases or fees proposed by the Bush administration. The plan by the Democratic and Republican leadership of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee calls for spending $17.7 billion over the next two fiscal years, which is close to what President Bush has requested. But a large share of the money would come from the Aviation Trust Fund, which has accumulated $7.6 billion from passenger fees and other tax revenue. Bush wants new airport passenger fees and increased federal ticket taxes and taxes on aviation fuel. The House aviation subcommittee is scheduled to take up the bill June 14. ``We are proposing to authorize this funding that will benefit all airline passengers without a federal tax increase,'' said Rep. Glenn M. Anderson, D-Calif., committee chairman. Other bill sponsors include the committee's ranking Republican, Rep. Paul Hammerschmidt of Arkansas, along with the chairman and ranking minority member of the aviation subcommittee, Reps. James L. Oberstar, D-Minn., and William F. Clinger Jr., R-Pa. Oberstar said the measure would reduce money in the trust fund to $1.2 billion by fiscal 1995. ``We see no ned for a federal tax increase for aviation while we have a $7.6 billion surplus in the trust fund,'' Oberstar said. He said the committee's plan envisions expansion of the nation's aviation capacity through ``airport development, modernization of the air traffic control system and improved system operations.'' The bill would authorize $1.8 billion in fiscal 1991 and $1.9 billion in fiscal 1992 for the airport improvement program and $2.5 billion in 1991 and $3 billion in 1992 for aviation facilities and equipment. It also would authorize $4.1 billion for operation in 1991, about half of which would come from the trust fund. In fiscal 1992, that would increase to $4.4 billion. The bill would eliminate penalty clauses applying to the trust fund that are designed to ensure that the greater share of the fund be spent for capital improvements rather than operation of the Federal Aviation Administration. The clauses limit the proportion of funding that can go to operations.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Companies Join Soviets to Improve Health Care
DOC.TEXT: A group of U.S. health-care companies have joined Soviet officials to create a program that will share technology and research to improve care for children in both countries. Officials of Children's Health System Inc., based in Norfolk, Va., said Thursday the agreement with the Soviet Ministry of Health would help meet that country's needs for medical supplies, drugs, technology and advanced training. The agreement was signed last month in Moscow, where two Eastern Virginia Medical School pediatricians who represented Children's Health System toured Moscow's leading pediatric hospitals. Drs. Raymond D. Adelman and Rebecca L. Byrd said the Soviet facilities were 10 to 15 years out of date and in urgent need of medical supplies, equipment and drugs. U.S. physicians, Adelman said, will benefit by learning about some of the new techniques and procedures the Soviets have perfected. About 90 percent of the patients in Soviet pediatric hospitals would be treated as outpatients in the U.S. health care system. However, because of a shortage of medical specialists and services in many areas of the Soviet Union, children must travel hundreds of miles for appropriate care. One public health problem facing the Soviets is that many families refuse to have their children immunized because of the possibility they will contract AIDS, Byrd said. Unlike the United States where disposable syringes are used, Soviet physicians use reusable syringes, which if not sterilized can transmit blood-borne diseases, she said. The exchange, to be funded with donations from corporations and foundations, will begin in September and will start with a few physicians and other health care professionals in each country, Adelman said. He said the Soviet health care system cannot improve dramatically without adequate supplies of medical equipment and improvement in basic technology. The exchange program, called the US-USSR Children's Health Center, will work with Soviet authorities to facilitate the sale of American medical supplies, drugs and technologies, he said. The Children's Health System network is anchored by Children's Hospital of The King's Daughters, a non-profit, specialized pediatric hospital in Norfolk.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Playboy Model Guilty of Tax Evasion
DOC.TEXT: A former Playboy model was convicted Thursday of failing to pay taxes on almost $400,000 she got from an elderly millionaire who allegedly paid her and her twin sister for companionship or sex. The jury deliberated about 3{ hours before finding Leigh Ann Conley, 35, guilty on four misdemeanor counts of failing to file federal income tax returns on about $398,000. The conviction came a month after her twin, Lynnette Harris, was found guilty of evading taxes on $686,000 she received from the same suburban Milwaukee businessman, the late David Kritzik of Shorewood. The identical blonde twins appeared nude in Playboy magazine and in two films, ``I, the Jury,'' and ``Sorceress'' before joining three other young women in befriending Kritzik, who died last summer at age 89. In Ms. Harris' trial, the government alleged the money she received from Kritzik was in exchange for sex. In Ms. Conley's case, prosecutors charged she accepted the money in exchange for her companionship rather than for sex. Ms. Conley, who could be sentenced to four years in prison and fined $325,000, said she believed the jury in her trial was ``totally biased because of my sister's case. I couldn't get a fair trial.'' Defense attorney Aaron Starobin said Thursday's verdict would be appealed. ``My feeling is the hype this case received made it very difficult for the jury to separate the law and facts from the emotion,'' Starobin said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Mel Johnson, the prosecutor in both cases, said he was satisfied with the verdicts. U.S. District Judge Thomas Curran scheduled sentencing for Ms. Conley for Aug. 29. Ms. Harris, who is to be sentenced July 25, could receive a maximum of 12 years in prison and fines totaling $625,000. The guilty verdict in her case also will be appealed, her lawyer said. In closing arguments, Johnson described Kritzik as a millionaire who ``craved the company of young women and was willing to pay for it. He wanted a relationship with Ms. Conley, he paid for it and he got it.'' ``There isn't one single witness the government brought that said they could show there was a service contract,'' Starobin said. ``There was a good relationship, a happy relationship for both of them. He wanted her to be happy, and he had the ability.'' He argued the money was given as a gift and did not constitute income. The prosecution countered that Kritzik never designated the money as a gift on his tax forms. Kritzik founded General Merchandise Co. in the 1930s. The company grew to become one of the largest mail order companies in the world. He sold the company to J.C. Penny Co. in 1962 for $11 million.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Say Veterans Waiting Too Long for Assistance
DOC.TEXT: Veterans are waiting months for wheelchairs, artificial limbs or even eyeglasses because veterans hospitals must borrow money from medical device accounts to meet other costs, according to congressional testimony Thursday. The diversion is necessary because of chronic funding shortages in VA hospitals, witnesses told the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee. The committee has been examining the Veterans Affairs Department's prosthetics and rehabilitation programs for months, conducting its own investigation. Prosthetics is the term for a wide range of medical devices, including artificial limbs, wheelchairs, bathtub grab bars, canes for the blind, glasses and hearing aids, and such basic items as stump socks. Close to 1 million of the nation's 28 million veterans receive prosthetic devices from the VA at a cost of $100 million each year. Veterans receive them because of injuries received during military service. Poor veterans may receive them even though the disability wasn't acquired as a result of service. According to Thursday's testimony, management of the program is fragmented. One of the problems is that the directors of the VA's 172 medical centers control local spending. Witnesses inside and outside of the VA pointed to a lack of centralized funding, a lack of cost accounting, overpayments of up to $1,000 for local purchases, and a lack of inventory control at local hospitals as well as the VA's central supply depot in Denver. Local medical directors ``are trying to make everything happen'' with limited funds, forcing them to juggle accounts, said Frederick Downs Jr., VA's director of prosthetics and sensory aids services. Local veterans tend not to complain too loudly for fear of getting even less service, so they resort to making small purchases on their own, he said. ``They just want to get by.'' But veterans groups said there are real problems: _The blind rehabilitation center at Westhaven, Conn., has more than 200 veterans on its waiting list; _The Minneapolis medical center has only $36,000 in its prosthetics account for the rest of the fiscal year because $276,000 was diverted for operating shortfalls; _Veterans are waiting up to three months for hearing aids and wheelchairs, 60 days for a simple pair of eyeglasses, the American Legion says. The VA's Inspector General, Renald P. Morani, said the District of Columbia medical center spent $2,300 for a brace that could have been obtained for less than $1,400. Morani's office has conducted numerous audits of the prosthetics programs and is currently undertaking a new one. Deputy VA Secretary Anthony J. Principi acknowledged problems and said the VA would undertake immediate steps to correct problems outlined by a management task force. He also plans to form an advisory committee.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Secretary Meets Separately With Both Sides in Greyhound Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole has met with both sides in the three-month-old Greyhound strike but has no plans to intervene in the dispute, now tied up in bankruptcy courts, a Labor Department spokeswoman said Thursday. Mrs. Dole met Thursday with Edward M. Strait, president of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. Last week, the labor secretary met with Fred Currey, chairman of Greyhound Lines Inc., at Currey's request, said Dale Tate, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Dole. ``It was basically a courtesy call,'' Ms. Tate said of Currey's meeting with Mrs. Dole. Union leaders representing the 6,300 striking drivers were invited following the Currey visit, Ms. Tate said. It was an informational session like the Currey meeting, she said. Mrs. Dole does not plan to intervene but is keeping on top of any progress being made by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Ms. Tate said. Bargaining talks have not been held since early May. Last year, Mrs. Dole won praise from organized labor when she appointed a ``super mediator'' to help settle the bitter Pittston coal strike affecting Appalachia miners. Greyhound, which lost $56 million in the first three months of 1990, filed for court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws on Monday so that buses can continue operating through the peak summer season. On Thursday in Brownsville, Texas, a bankruptcy judge gave the bus line permission to keep paying operating expenses so buses could keep rolling. He also ordered the establishment of a creditors' committee in time for a second hearing June 28.

DOC.HEAD: Foretich: Should Have Abandoned Custody Battle Long Ago
DOC.TEXT: A father accused of sexual abuse in one of the nation's longest and most highly publicized child custody battles said Thursday he should have ``backed away'' from the bitter fight years ago. ``I would frankly like nothing more than to de-escalate the fight,'' Eric Foretich said in an interview on radio station WFIR. Foretich, speaking from his office in Falls Church, Va., said he opposes his former wife Elizabeth Morgan's attempt to gain custody of their daughter, but has filed no formal custody request for the girl himself. Ms. Morgan spent more than two years in prison in Washington rather than surrender their daughter, Hilary, for court-ordered visits with Foretich. Ms. Morgan accused Foretich of sexually abusing the girl. Foretich denies the charge in the custody battle that began when the girl, now 7, was a toddler. ``Sexual abuse has become the nuclear bomb in child custody cases,'' Foretich said in the radio interview. ``When allegations are made against a man, some fathers will back away and give up just because the allegation is enough to taint their life and livlihood.'' ``I wish I had backed away a long time ago, because it has not really helped my practice or my daughter, either,'' said Foretich, who is an oral surgeon. Hilary lives in New Zealand with her maternal grandparents. Ms. Morgan has filed for permanent residency and custody there. ``I am not going to subject my daughter to another media go-around, to litigation in New Zealand that would be purposeless,'' Foretich said. Foretich has said he would continue to fight his wife's custody petition in the New Zealand courts because it would deny him access to the girl. ``I would like nothing more than for her to have the chance to be a child again. If that means I see less of her I can accept that very painful decision on my part,'' Foretich said. ``I just don't see how it's in her interests to have her whole life encumbered by this.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Prosecutor: Jilted Girlfriend Plotted Rival's Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4 and 6 to CORRECT that victim was Lisa Chiaski, sted Bill Buss, editing to conform
DOC.TEXT: A young beauty queen charged with strangling a woman in a jealous rage plotted the killing because she was obsessed by her love for a dairy farmer, a prosecutor told jurors Thursday. In opening arguments, District Attorney Greg Grau said he'll prove Lori Esker planned a ``mission of secrecy'' when she left her college campus to confront a former classmate who she thought had stolen her boyfriend. Ms. Esker, a 20-year-old student at University of Wisconsin-River Falls, is on trial on a murder charge in the death of Lisa Cihaski. If convicted, she faces a mandatory sentence of life in prison. Grau contends that Ms. Esker strangled Ms. Cihaski with a belt on Sept. 20 in a motel parking lot near Wausau. Ms. Esker, who was named Marathon County Dairy Princess in June 1989, resigned her title after she was charged in October. Grau said the plot was based on Ms. Esker's love for 25-year-old Bill Buss, an Eland dairy farmer. The two dated for about a year before Buss ended the relationship last summer, Grau said. Buss then began dating Ms. Cihaski, 21, of Birnamwood, and friends said the couple were soon to become engaged. Grau said he would prove Ms. Esker ``had a near obsession with trying to get Bill Buss back,'' including making repeated sexual advances, in the months before Ms. Cihaski was slain. ``He (Buss) is going to tell you he resisted those advances despite her persistence,'' the prosecutor said. ``Ladies and gentlemen I think the evidence will show that on September 20 Lori Esker left River Falls, Wisconsin, on a mission of secrecy.'' Jurors were selected from Forest County, about 100 miles from Wasau, because of pretrial publicity. According to court records, Ms. Esker told investigators she grabbed a belt and strangled Ms. Cihaski as the two argued in a car about Buss. She said she was acting in self-defense. Ms. Esker, a junior at the university majoring in agricultural journalism, was free and staying at her parents' dairy farm after the family put up $100,000 in property as bail.

DOC.HEAD: Partial Pricetag of Romania's Earthquake: $25 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Eugen in graf 10 is correct.
DOC.TEXT: Romania must spend more than $25 million for emergency repairs from last week's earthquake that killed 14 people and injured about 1,000 across central and eastern Europe, an official said Thursday. The government also appealed for foreign help in making this earthquake-prone country better equipped to handle temblors. Mihai Grigoriu, a top official in the Economy Ministry, said last week's quake carved a trail of damage through 14 of Romania's 40 counties, including the capital city of Bucharest. Grigoriu said experts started examining the damaged buildings in Romania and noticed most older structures that were damaged in major quakes in 1977 and 1986 were also battered by the latest temblor. The earthquake and its aftershocks May 30-31 did major damage at 400 schools, 200 hospitals, as well as many city halls in Bucharest and other communities across this Balkan nation of 23 million people, Grigoriu said. The Uppsala Seismological Center in Sweden said the quake was centered about 63 miles under the Earth, causing tremors to be felt in Bulgaria, Soviet Moldavia, Yugoslavia and Turkey. It registered up to 6.8 on the Richter scale. Apart from damage to buildings, Romania's $25 million loss also includes export goods such as tons of wood, glass and tiles, Grigoriu told The Associated Press. ``We could have well exported these materials to the West or to Asia for hard currency,'' he said. Officials have given no estimate for costs other than urgently needed repairs. Although no buildings collapsed, chunks of concrete fell from high-rise buildings on virtually every street in the capital. In the city above the earthquake's epicenter, Focsani, about 190 miles northeast of Bucharest, 500 apartments were damaged, and people were evacuated from four blocks of apartment buildings, Grigoriu said. Eugen Ionescu, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, told a news conference Thursday the Romanian government would accept offers from other governments or international groups on improving its ability to handle earthquakes. Romania has a long history of damaging earthquakes, with three or four major quakes a century, according to official statistics. More than 1,500 Romanians died in the 1977 quake. The government has asked local groups in Romania to make up a list of pre-World War II buildings at high risk of collapsing in the next major quake. Officials will then decide on the demolition of those buildings that ``are not worth any more money invested or are not worth being repaired,'' Grigoriu said.

DOC.HEAD: ConAgra To Buy Beatrice Co.
DOC.TEXT: ConAgra Inc. has agreed to buy Beatrice Co. for $1.34 billion in cash and stock, the two food giants announced Thursday. The deal completes the breakup and sale of Beatrice _ owner of such brand names as Hunt's, Wesson and and Reddi-Wip _ by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Kohlberg Kravis, bought Beatrice, then a major part of a huge foods and consumer products conglomerate, in 1986 for $6.1 billion in what was then the biggest leveraged buyout ever. The term leveraged buyout refers to purchasing a company with borrowed cash; corporations bought in this way often are broken up and sold to repay the loan and make a profit. Since the buyout, Beatrice has sold off most of its businesses, but still retains such well-known food brands as Hunt's, Wesson, Manwich, Peter Pan, Snack Pak, Swiss Miss, La Choy, Swift Premium, Butterball, Eckrich, and Reddi-Wip. ConAgra, an Omaha-based diversified food company with annual sales of more than $15 billion, sells fozen foods with such labels as Healthy Choice, Banquet, Morton, and Chun King, as well as Armour processed meats and Country Pride chicken products. ConAgra also sells fertilizer, animal feed and farm chemicals. ConAgra last year lost a bidding war for poultry processor Holly Farms Corp. to Tyson Foods Inc. The Beatrice sale will be completed after federal government review. The deal calls for ConAgra to buy Beatrice for $11.50 per share from Kohlberg Kravis partnerships and management investors. Beatrice would have 123.44 million shares outstanding, assuming all outstanding warrants for purchase of Beatrice shares are exercised. The transaction would include approximately $626 million in cash and $710 million in ConAgra stock. Henry Kravis, a founding partner of Kohlberg Kravis, said: ``Four years ago, together with new management of Beatrice, we began the process of reshaping Beatrice from a diverse conglomerate into a focused and more profitable food company. ... Today's announcement marks the successful completion of this process.'' Beatrice formerly was one of the nation's biggest food and consumer products conglomerates, owning product lines that included Coca-Cola bottlers, Hunt-Wesson foods, Swift-Eckrich meats, Stiffel lamps, Samsonite luggage, Tropicana juices, Max Factor cosmetics and the Avis car rental agency. After the buyout, Beatrice began selling most of its businesses in order to pay off the buyout debt and generate a return for investors who put up money for the deal. For example, Avis was sold to a group led by its employees; Tropicana to Seagram Co. Ltd.; Beatrice's international food businesses to the investment firm TLC International; and a score of other companies to a group led by former Beatrice Chairman Donald P. Kelly.

DOC.HEAD: Prison for Poindexter Would Be `Fundamentally Wrong,' Lawyer Says
DOC.TEXT: It ``would be fundamentally unjust'' to imprison John M. Poindexter for lying about the Iran-Contra affair, the former national security adviser's lawyer argued in court papers filed Thursday. Defense attorney Richard Beckler, responding to a prosecution request that Poindexter receive a prison term, urged U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene to consider Poindexter's lengthy service as a Navy officer and ``the suffering he has endured'' since the Iran-Contra affair became public 3{ years ago. Poindexter, 53, a retired Navy rear admiral, is scheduled to be sentenced Monday on five felony convictions of conspiracy, making false statements to Congress and obstructing congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair. He was found guilty of lying to Congress by denying the existence of a covert operation to arm the Nicaraguan Contras and to conceal U.S. involvement in an Israeli shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran in 1985. Poindexter, who served as President Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until revelations about the Iran-Contra affair forced his resignation in November 1986, faces up to 25 years in prison and as much as $1.25 million in fines. Independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh's request for imprisonment was ``made without the slightest reference to John Poindexter's lifelong career of service to his country and to his community,'' said the sentencing memo bearing Beckler's signature. ``It is made without consideration of the heavy punishment that the more than three-year `Iran-Contra' investigation has already visited upon John Poindexter and his family,'' Beckler said. Iran-Contra prosecutors earlier this week told Greene that the sentence ``must include a period of incarceration'' because the ``diet of lies'' Poindexter fed Congress ``did violence to this nation's fundamental principles of government.'' Prosecutors said imprisoning Poindexter would ``warn other high-ranking public officials that criminal violations of the public trust will result in more than mere loss of public employment.'' But Beckler said the prosecution ``well knows that John Poindexter has suffered far more than `mere loss of public employment.''' ``He has lost a bright and promising career in the United States Navy, he has endured the public ridicule of the Congress and the media, and he has suffered financial hardship.'' ``Most painful of all, he has been convicted,'' Beckler said. The sentencing memo quoted from letters to the court attesting to Poindexter's moral character from Admiral James L. Holloway III, former chief of Naval Operations, as well as Ronald H. Haines, acting Episcopal bishop of Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Trouble Erupts for Perpich Only Two Days After Gorbachev Visit
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rudy Perpich had only two days to savor the euphoria of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit. Now he's facing accusations from the Bush Administration of behaving ``very badly'' because the state's two Republican senators were barred from a luncheon for the Soviet president. On top of that, he's grappling with questions about sexual harassment lawsuits against his former chief of staff. Perpich faces a tough endorsement fight at the state Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party convention on Saturday, but his campaign is predicting victory over his challenger, former Commerce Commissioner Mike Hatch. ``The (Gorbachev) visit went well and the governor did a nice job and that's what people are going to remember,'' campaign Chairman John Stanoch said Thursday. A 60 percent majority is required for endorsement, and it's widely expected that several ballots will be needed to determine a winner. Perpich, who's seeking an unprecedented fourth term, and Hatch say they will run in the Sept. 11 primary regardless of who's endorsed. Perpich moved quickly to make the most of Gorbachev's Sunday visit, which the governor said provided the greatest day of his political career. Film of the visit will be used in campaign commercials, Stanoch said Monday. But mid-week, Perpich was confronted with the news that one of his former secretaries and another woman had filed lawsuits alleging sexual harassment by Terry Montgomery, Perpich's former right-hand man. The suits filed in Hennepin County District Court say Karen Ehrisman and Gayle Treloar left their jobs at the state-funded Greater Minnesota Corp., a rural development agency, because of the alleged sexual harassment. Ehrisman, a secretary to Perpich for nearly five years, alleges harassment by Montgomery at the agency and while she was the governor's secretary. Montgomery was Perpich's chief of staff in 1977 and 1978 and from 1983 through August 1987, when he became head of the rural development agency. He resigned as agency president in December after a 22-year-old woman seeking an internship accused him of making sexual advances. Those charges were dropped in March after the agency paid the woman $130,000. The Bush Administration's complaint that Sens. Rudy Boschwitz and Dave Durenberger were left out of the Gorbachev luncheon was raised Wednesday by White House protocol chief Joseph Reed. ``It was my understanding with Governor Perpich that they were to be invited. As far as I'm concerned he reneged on that understanding,'' Reed told reporters at he White House. Perpich said he had never agreed to invite the senators and complained the Gorbachev visit was now being marred by ``petty politics.'' The governor accused Boschwitz of working to sabotage the visit, an allegation the senator denied. Stanoch said Wednesday's developments are no concern heading into the party convention. ``I think that any delegate who is concerned about either issue is going to have an opportunity to discuss it with the governor,'' he said Thursday. Still, Hatch pointed to the sexual harassment lawsuit as a potential issue. ``These are very serious charges and fairness dictates that the courts determine if they are justified,'' he said. ``However, clearly, if they are justified, the governor has a tremendous accountability problem.'' Despite this week's ups and downs, Hatch expressed concern about the lingering effects of Gorbachev's visit. ``There's no doubt about it. This Gorbachev visit threw a hand grenade into events,'' Hatch said. ``We don't know what the outcome of that will be. We do know that up until two, three weeks ago ... we were substantially ahead.'' No new campaign ads appeared this week, and both campaigns said they were devoting their attention in the last days before the convention to working with delegates individually. Hatch, 42, was appointed state commerce commissioner in 1983 by Perpich after a two-year stint as party chairman. He has maintained close relations with party regulars, while Perpich, 61, regularly ignores party affairs. Hatch said he has 53 percent of the committed delegates, but 110 uncommitted delegates hold the key. There are 1,383 delegates who will cast 1,261 votes because some delegates have a half-vote and some a two-thirds vote.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Call South Africa's Lifting Of Emergency Good First Step
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials and political activists praised the end of the state of emergency in South Africa on Thursday but said the action doesn't warrant the removal of U.S. sanctions. The White House said the move by South African President F.W. de Klerk was a sign of ``the remarkable progress'' made by the white-minority government. De Klerk ended a 4-year-old national state of emergency in all but the nation's Natal Province. The policy imposed some of the government's harshest political restrictions on the country's black-majority population. ``This is another significant step toward creating a climate conducive to negotiations that will lead to a democratic, non-racial South Africa,'' said Deputy White House Press Secretary Alixe Glen. It ``is a long overdue and important step which will help pave the way to end the brutal system of apartheid,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., the prime sponsor of the 1986 Anti-Apartheid Act. The legislation barred landing rights in the United States to South African Airways, banned U.S. import of South African uranium and coal and prohibited new U.S. investments and bank loans in the racially segregated country. ``Apartheid is still in place,'' Kennedy said, adding, ``This is no time for the United States or any other nation to lift any sanctions.'' ``It's an important step forward but it clearly does not meet the requirements of the lifting of sanctions,'' echoed Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif, chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. At the State Department, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher noted that the Bush administration cannot legally modify U.S. sanctions against South Africa until certain conditions are met. The law says the restrictions would be lifted automatically if President Bush reported to Congress that the South African government satisfied specific conditions for ending them. The law requires the South African government to repeal the state of emergency nationwide and free black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela as it did last February. Additionally, the government must release all other political prisoners, legalize opposition political parties and their activities and enter into good-faith negotiation with representative black leaders without preconditions. The South African government also must repeal the Group Areas Act and the Population Registration Act which restrict the movement and residence of non-whites to comply U.S. preconditions. Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, a group that lobbies on concerns of Africa and the Caribbean, commended the action but called it ``a tiny measure.'' ``It is a little late and all too small considering the distance that must be traveled in a very short space of time,'' he added. Robinson said the move was conspicuously timed to coincide with a 13-nation trip by Mandela that will include a meeting with Bush in Washington on June 25 and ``designed to purchase relief from the painful Western sanctions.'' De Klerk also is expected meet with Bush at a later date that has not yet been set.

DOC.HEAD: `If You Want to be President, Learn to Read'
With MILWAUKEE-dated AM-Bush, Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, here to boost Republican candidates, stopped at Farnsworth Elementary School, where he read to a group of children and told them afterward, ``If you want to be president, learn to read.'' As for his time in the White House, Bush told the children: ``I like it a lot. They've got good food there,'' He said being president is ``not all hard work'' and told the students he and his wife, Barbara, like to play with their dog, Millie, after he finishes work. One child asked how many rooms are in the White House. ``That's a good question,'' Bush answered, quessing that the Executive Mansion has about 10 bedrooms. He told the children to have their parents and grandparents read to them. After he read to the youngsters, they applauded. Bush then asked: ``You really like it or are you just saying that?''

DOC.HEAD: Fire Damages Guest Bedroom at Palm Beach Estate
With AM-Trump Casinos, AM-People-Ivana Trump
DOC.TEXT: A guest bedroom in billionaire Donald Trump's mansion was gutted by fire Thursday, but there was no structural damage to the oceanside estate, fire officials said. ``The cause of the fire is undetermined,'' said Fire Chief Ken Elmore. ``We don't have any reason to believe that it's suspicious at this time.'' A member of the household staff at the 118-room Mar-a-Lago mansion called the 911 emergency line shortly after 8 a.m. to report the fire in a two-story guest wing attached to the main building, said Elmore. About 15 firefighters put the fire out in about 15 minutes, before flames could spread beyond the bedroom and attached bathroom, Elmore said. No one was injured. Elmore said no one had been staying in the guest bedroom. Smoke spread to several other bedrooms in the wing, Elmore said. He had no estimate of the dollar loss. The 58-bedroom mansion is on a 17-acre strip of land between the Atlantic Ocean and the Intracoastal Waterway. Trump bought the 64-year-old Mar-a-Lago, Spanish for ``sea to lake,'' in 1985 for $7 million from the Post Foundation. The coral-colored home is one of about 130 in this island community bearing a historical designation.

DOC.HEAD: 500,000 Attend Opposition Rally, 300,000 at Ruling Socialist Rally
DOC.TEXT: Up to a half-million opposition backers Thursday staged the capital's largest rally ever, chanting and singing three days before the country's first free elections in nearly 60 years. The ruling Socialist Party, formerly the Communists, mounted a nearby election rally in downtown Sofia that attracted at least 300,000 people, rally organizers said. A police cordon prevented any clashes between the two groups. During the opposition rally by the Union of Democratic Forces, people thronged along one mile of Lenin Boulevard, where four stages were set up for speakers, singers and other performers. The crowd also spilled into many side streets in a sea of swaying blue opposition pennants and banners. ``I have been born in Sofia, I have lived in Sofia, but I have never seen the like,'' said one demonstrator. Participants in a crowd estimated at 400,000 to 500,000 shouted ``Victory, Victory!'' and ``Down with the CP,'' the initials of the now-renamed Communist Party, throughout the nearly five-hour rally. Messages of support from foreign leaders, including Polish Solidarity chief Lech Walesa and U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., were greeted with loud clapping and cheering. ``The UDF must win, otherwise there will be no real life, because otherwise we would find ourselves even deeper in the morass,'' said Nina Galobova, a student in her early 20s, using the initials of the opposition alliance. ``What we are still lacking is democracy and a system that will show to the world that we are worthy of its respect,'' UDF chairman Zhelju Zhelev told the cheering crowd. He said Sunday's election ``will decide whether Bulgaria will join Europe and the world or will remain stifled in its own narrow confines.'' It will be this country's first free polling since 1932. East Germany, Hungary, and Romania have held free national elections in recent months after last year's wave of democratic revolutions. During the Socialist rally, demonstrators shouted ``We are many!'' and ``We shall win!'' Party chief Alexander Lilov, Premier Andrei Lukanov and Defense Minister Dobri Dzhurov all spoke to the crowd. Those leaders, along with President Petar Mladenov, are believed to have played a leading role in ousting longtime Communist leader Todor Zhivkov last year. Lilov claimed the Socialist Party has built back up to 1 million members after new people were admitted the last few weeks. ``The elections will confirm the party as the most influential political force in the country,'' he declared. All three speakers attacked the opposition alliance, saying it had tried to negate everything ``that has been created in the last 45 years'' under Communism. At a late-night news conference, Lukanov said that even if his party wins more than 50 percent of Sunday's vote, ``I refuse to head a one-party government.'' Socialist officials have said a coalition government is needed to lead Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Presents Social Security Plan at Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., tried to sell his plan to cut Social Security taxes to high-level budget negotiators Thursday but got a mixed reaction, participants said. Moynihan visited the sixth session of private budget talks between Bush administration officials and congressional leaders. The bargainers spent most of the day discussing the possibility of cutting federal benefit programs in order to reduce the budget deficit, with their discussions focusing on technical issues. No offers were exchanged. Moynihan has proposed rolling back the 7.65 percent levy workers pay to the retirement system. He argues that Social Security builds a surplus of tens of billions of dollars every year, money that is used to shrink the apparent size of the deficit. The plan has attracted the attention of tax-conscious politicians. Some Democrats say it would be wise for the party to support a tax cut, while others, joined by Republicans, say it would drive the government's red ink even deeper. Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said there was ``not as much positive support'' for Moynihan's plan among negotiators as he had thought there might be. He predicted the plan ``has little chance of passing'' Congress. But Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said he believed the proposal could be approved by lawmakers. ``We have to factor that in. The Moynihan proposal could be a reality,'' Sasser said. Participants said that the negotiators expressed little enthusiasm for cutting benefit programs, which include Social Security, Medicare and payments to farmers. White House budget director Richard Darman said that the chairmen of congressional committees who oversee those programs attended Thursday's session and opposed spending cuts. ``If we were to come to a consensus around what they were suggesting, we'd be moving in the wrong direction,'' Darman said.

DOC.HEAD: Library of Congress to Resume Poetry Awards
DOC.TEXT: The Library of Congress announced Friday it will award a national poetry prize in October, resuming a tradition halted more than 40 years ago in a controversy over the library's award of a prize to interned American poet Ezra Pound. The new Rebekah Johnson Bobbit National Prize for Poetry is named after President Lyndon B. Johnson's sister, who met her future husband while working in the library's cataloguing department in the 1930s. The $10,000 prize will honor the best book of American poetry published in the preceding two years. The funds will come from a trust created by Mrs. Bobbitt's family in her memory. A three-member jury will select the 1990 winner in mid-September from nominations submitted by publishers. The Bobbitt Prize will be the first poetry prize given by the library since it awarded the 1948 Bollingen Prize to Pound for his ``Pisan Cantos.'' Afterward, Congress prohibited the library from granting awards or prizes. Pound was an admirer of the late Italian dictator Benito Mussolini and broadcast Fascist propaganda to the United States during World War II. He was arrested for treason after the war and was judged insane in 1946. He spent 12 years in a Washington mental hospital until he was released in 1958 and returned to Italy. He died in 1972. At the request of Librarian of Congress James H. Billington, Congress reversed its ban two years ago. ``With this award, the United States once again joins Great Britain, France and other countries in honoring poetry by presenting a prize on behalf of the nation,'' a library statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Would Create Strike Force
DOC.TEXT: Three Democratic members of the Senate Banking Committee introduced legislation Thursday that would create a Justice Department strike force to attack fraud at savings and loans and other financial institutions. The bill, written by Sens. Alan Dixon of Illinois, Tim Wirth of Colorado and Bob Graham of Florida, would establish a Financial Services Crime Division, headed by an assistant attorney general As part of S&L legislation enacted in August, the Bush administration earmarked an additional $50 million to pursue S&L fraud. It's hiring 368 new employees, including 202 FBI agents and 120 prosecutors, to staff teams in 27 cities. Doug Tillett, a spokesman for the Justice Department, said the strike force proposal ``on the face of it, appears to be a duplication of effort.'' However, Democrats point to a backlog of 2,300 uninvestigated cases of suspected fraud, each involving a loss of more than $100,000, as evidence the administration needs to intensify its effort. ``These numbers are astounding and cannot be ignored,'' Wirth said Democrats also fault the administration for not seeking the full $75 million in anti-fraud money authorized by the S&L bill. ``This country is being robbed blind and the thieves are getting away scot-free,'' Dixon said. Tillett said in the past two years Justice has obtained 51 convictions of S&L executives from its Dallas office, adding: ``I think it's wrong to suggest the department is doing nothing. We're working very hard.'' He said the department would not shy from asking Congress for more money, if needed. On April 30, the Senate, by a 50-48 vote, rejected a proposal to divert $30 million from promoting tourism in Panama to fighting S&L fraud. Cosponsors of the strike force bill, all Democrats, are Sens. Paul Simon of Illinois, Richard Bryan of Nevada, John Kerry of Massachusetts, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island.

DOC.HEAD: Alzheimer's Difficult to Diagnose, Doctors Say
With AM-Netherlands-Euthanasia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Alzheimer's disease diagnosis is absolute only after an autopsy, experts said Thursday in the wake of the doctor-assisted suicide of a woman who had been told she had the incurable illness. ``The difficulty in some cases is that it may be misdiagnosed,'' said Michelle Manning, deputy director of the Alzheimer's Association's Detroit-area chapter. As many as 80 diseases can appear to be Alzheimer's, which affects up to 4 million people, most of them elderly, Manning said. Alzheimer's is a degenerative brain and nerve disorder that robs people of their memories, abilities to function and eventually their lives. A new spotlight has focused on Alzheimer's since Monday, when Dr. Jack Kevorkian of suburban Royal Oak hooked Janet Adkins, 54, to a machine and watched her die as she pressed a button that pumped heart-stopping chemicals into her system. Kevorkian had driven with Mrs. Adkins, of Portland, Ore., to a park outside Detroit and attached her to the electric-powered device in the back of his van. Kevorkian said she was dead within minutes after she pressed the button. Mrs. Adkins, who had despaired after being told a year ago she had Alzheimer's, had read of Kevorkian's device and ``thought that sounded like a very, very humane and painless way to end her life,'' said her husband, Ronald. Michigan State Police seized Kevorkian's van and suicide device after he reported Mrs. Adkins' death Monday. Prosecutors planned to seek an injunction to stop Kevorkian from using the device again at a Friday hearing in Oakland County Circuit Court. The Medical Examiner's Office refused to release results of Mrs. Adkins' autopsy Thursday. The prosecutor's office did not return several calls. Ronald Adkins said Thursday that the autopsy, which his wife had requested, had not been completed. Medical experts said extensive tests must be conducted when a person is suspected of having Alzheimer's. But the diagnosis isn't definite until brain tissue is examined under a microscope, they said. ``It's always called probable Alzheimer's disease. That's probable in capital letters,'' said Dr. Creighton Phelps, vice president of medical and scientific affairs for the Chicago-based Alzheimer's Association. ``The criteria fordefinite diagnosis is after death,'' he said. A probable diagnosis is usually between 80 percent and 90 percent accurate, he said. A possible diagnosis is about 70 percent accurate. Tests include memory checks, brain scans and spinal taps. Physicians also interview the patient's family about changes in behavior, Phelps said. Symptoms include memory loss, confusion, difficulty in judgment, changes in mood and personality and loss of bodily functions. In the final stages, a patient may be as helpless as a newborn, unable to recognize relatives. Dr. Norman Foster, professor of neurology at the University of Michigan, base for the Michigan Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, said it takes at least a week, and often a month, to check brain tissue under a microscope for the tangled clumps of cells common in Alzheimer's patients. Foster said physicians usually call on counselors in Alzheimer's cases. ``The physicians are not really prepared to handle all the legal, social and economic ramifications by this illness,'' Foster said. Alzheimer's support groups were shaken at the news of Kevorkian's machine. ``We have a number of services available that would hopefully prevent this kind of decision from taking place,'' said Manning of the support group here. ``We would hope that they explore other avenues.'' Foster said: ``People with Alzheimer's shouldn't feel so hopeless. ... There's lots of things they can do. We don't promise an instant cure but we're attacking this disease.'' Advances in testing are encouraging, said Robert P. Lisak, Wayne State University neurology chairman and chief neurologist at Detroit Medical Center and Harper Hospital. The newest test measures a protein believed associated with Alzheimer's. A study in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association said the protein can be used as a model for a diagnostic test in spinal fluid. ``Breakthroughs don't come like a bolt out of the blue,'' Lisak said. ``No one person is going to make a sudden discovery. Modern science builds on it. ``At this point, you want to make sure it's not something treatable and then you can kind of say it's probably Alzheimer's.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Absolves Soldier in Journalist Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A jury has absolved an army private in the killing of a TV journalist, but colleagues of the slain soundman on Thursday accused troops of pressuring frightened jurors to find the soldier innocent. Others called it another failure of the Salvadoran judicial system to punish the military, which has been blamed for thousands of summary executions, kidnappings and torture of suspected government opponents the past decade. President Alfredo Cristiani acknowledged Thursday the presence of 30 soldiers at the brief deliberations Wednesday might have swayed the jury in what high-ranking military authorities had called an ``open and shut case'' against Pvt. Jose Orellana. The members of Orellana's unit, the elite Arce battalion, entered the courthouse in the eastern provincial capital of San Miguel as the jury began deliberating. The five-member jury then found Orellana innocent of murdering Channel 12 soundman Mauricio Pineda at a military roadblock during 1989 elections. Marcos Antonio Guevara, who covered the trial for Channel 12, said the jurors were afraid of the soldiers. ``They were telling the jury in so many words that if they delivered a guilty verdict, they would have to contend with the Arce battalion,'' he said. ``The jurors live there. They leave the court alone and have their skins to think about.'' Referring to the soldiers' presence, Cristiani told a news confernce: ``It could have had an effect. Certainly, in many cases, the reaching of a decision completely free from outside influence is difficult.'' The prosecution said it would appeal. Channel 12 news director Narciso Castillo said the absence of the defendant at the trial and the intimidating presence of soldiers at the courthouse was grounds for overturning the verdict. Pineda was shot at a military roadblock March 19, 1989. He was part of a crew in a pickup truck covering that day's nationwide presidential and legislative elections. Two other journalists were killed and another was seriously wounded during the election weekend. One died in a cross-fire during combat between leftist rebels and government troops. The other was killed by air force paratroopers at a roadblock near the capital. His colleague was seriously wounded in the same incident. The paratroopers have yet to go to trial. El Salvador's highest ranking military authorities admitted Orellana fired on the Channel 12 pickup without provocation or justification. They said the case was the most open-and-shut of the slayings of the journalists during the elections. Raul Beltran, a Salvadoran journalist next to Pineda when he was shot, said of the verdict, ``This kind of justice is disappointing.'' Though the armed forces have been blamed for thousands of executions, kidnappings and torture in the 10-year-old civil war against leftist guerrillas, no officer has been convicted _ or even tried _ for a crime of human rights abuse. Four officers, including a colonel, are among eight army men charged with murder in the Nov. 16 slaying of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. According to testimony from those charged, the priests were killed by a unit of the elite U.S.-trained Atlacatl battalion. Atlacatl's commander, Col. Oscar Leon Linares, on Wednesday bade farewell to his troops before leaving for a new post. Leon was promoted June 1 to military commander of Morazan Province. According to testimony, the Jesuits _ widely respected academics _ were killed because many high-ranking army officers considered them guerrilla ideologues. Far from mentioning the Jesuit massacre as a black mark on the Atlacatl record and cautioning his troops against repetition of such action, Leon told them in his speech: ``You must remember that in front of us we have a terrorist combatant ... but behind that combatant there are intelligent sectors that use any kind of calumny and other tricks to gain ground.''

DOC.HEAD: President Gets Plan to Trim Nicaraguan Army
DOC.TEXT: Army chief Humberto Ortega on Thursday presented President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro with a plan to trim and reorganize Nicaragua's armed forces, the largest in Central America. Mrs. Chamorro's campaign pledge to cut the armed forces helped her defeat Gen. Ortega's brother, former President Daniel Ortega, in an election Feb. 25. Although Ortega's Sandinista government never gave official figures on the size of the military, it was acknowledged to be the largest in the region. After Mrs. Chamorro banned reserve duty and ended the draft, about 50,000 soldiers were left on active duty. A one-paragraph army communique gave no details of the plan, but government sources who demanded anonymity said it outlined the eventual reduction of 20,000 soldiers from the armed forces. Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said Mrs. Chamorro had no comment on the proposal. The army communique said Gen. Ortega presented Mrs. Chamorro with ``the document that contains the general plan of reduction and restructuring of the Sandinista People's Army.'' The communique said Gen. Ortega has fulfilled ``her instructions of April 25 in her speech to the nation.'' Mrs. Chamorro said in the inaugural speech that she would order Gen. Ortega to devise a plan to trim the fighting machine he had spent a decade building with Soviet help. She also announced she was taking over Gen. Ortega's post as defense minister. Although the army still bears the name of the revolutionary party Mrs. Chamorro ousted in the election, a transition protocol with the Sandinistas obliged the officer corps to give up party positions. In return, Mrs. Chamorro promised to respect ``the integrity and professionalism'' of the army. Ortega gave up his post as one of the nine members of the Sandinista National Directorate, which had run Nicaragua since 1979. But Mrs. Chamorro's decision to let him remain as armed forces commander drove a wedge between her and the 14-party United National Opposition coalition that helped bring her to power. The United States backed Mrs. Chamorro and the Contra rebels that fought the Sandinistas.

DOC.HEAD: Power Plant Shut Down by Safety Systems
DOC.TEXT: The Ignalnia nuclear power plant in northeastern Lithuania was shut down by its automatic safety system for unknown reasons Thursday, the Washington office of the Lithuanian Information Center said. The plant uses the same reactor design as used at Chernobyl which exploded in the world's worst nuclear accident four years ago. The center, quoting a statement issued by the Lithuanian Supreme Council in Vilnius, said operations of the plant will be halted for at least two days while the reasons for the shutdown are investigated. The information center said the incident throws a new burden on Lithuania's energy production facilities already strained by a partial Soviet fuel embargo. The statement by the Lithuanian Supreme Council said the Ignalina plant lost power at 10:52 a.m. local time and added: ``During the course of normal functioning of the second reactor, for reasons unapparent for the time being, the shutdown system of the reactor became activated.'' ``Now the entire workload of electrical energy must be transfered to the regional electrical plant which is almost completely depleted of emergency fuel resources,'' the statement said. The statement quoted Lithuanian Energy Minister Leonas Asmantas as saying sabotage was not suspected. The partial fuel embargo was imposed by the Kremlin to pressure the Lithuanian parliament to suspend its March 11 declaration of independence. The Lithuanian Information Center said that as of May 28 the embargo had caused a 25 percent reduction in electrical power production in the Baltic republic. The Ignalia site has two 1,500-megawatt reactors, and it was not clear from the statement if both were in operation when the plant was shut down. The reactors are the graphite-moderated, water-cooled designed designated ``RBMK'' in the Soviet union, one of which ran out of control and exploded at Chernobyl on April 26, 1986, killing 31 people and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of people because of the dispersion of highly radioactive material over thousands of square miles. The safety systems at Chernobyl were disconnected at the time for unauthorized experiments.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Urges NATO to Keep Its A-Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to ADD British reservations about exchanging assurances, Warsaw Pact meeting. Picks up graf 10 pvs, `The allies...'
DOC.TEXT: NATO on Thursday took a fresh look at its future in a Europe of receding East-West tensions, and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher urged members to hold onto ``sufficient nuclear weapons and the means of delivering them.'' Yet Mrs. Thatcher, on her way to Moscow to see President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, concluded Europe faces a ``new situation created by Soviet troop withdrawals'' and the prospect of a new agreement to reduce U.S. and Soviet conventional forces. Secretary of State James A. Baker III reported he found the Soviet attitude about enrolling a unified Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ``much more encouraging'' since Gorbachev held summit talks in Washington last week with President Bush. He told foreign ministers from 15 Western nations that the shift was ``more of a change of spirit'' than anything Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said to him specifically at their meeting Tuesday night in Copenhagen, Denmark. Baker made his comments during a private session. They were disclosed by a senior official. As the allies met, leaders of the Warsaw Pact indicated they would reshape their own alliance from a military to a political body and declared the ``enemy image'' of the East and West a thing of the past. In Moscow, the Warsaw Pact leaders announced their ``readiness for constructive cooperation'' with NATO and said they favored the creation of a new ``all-European security system and the creation of a single Europe of peace and cooperation,'' without artificial barriers and ``ideological hostility.'' Despite earlier reports that Hungary might want to pull out of the alliance, Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Kvitsinsky of the Soviet Union said ``there wasn't a single statement made relating to a wish to quit the Warsaw Treaty Organization.'' No agreement was reported at the Moscow session on Western proposals for making a united Germany part of NATO. The allies reaffirmed their commitment to NATO membership for the unified Germany and also to ``try to meet the legitimate needs of the Soviet government so they don't feel isolated,'' a senior U.S. official said later Wednesday. ``The Soviet Union has to get over the idea of seeing NATO as an enemy and see NATO as a partner,'' said the official, who briefed American reporters under rules guaranteeing he would not be identified. Earlier, a British official said his government had ``difficulties'' with the idea of exchanges with a faltering Soviet-led alliance. It would be ``life after death'' for the Warsaw Pact, he said. The allies said the changes in Europe required a strategic review of troop levels, weaponry and the conditions for using them, according to the U.S. official. A more upbeat account came from the Italian foreign minister, Gianni de Michelis. He said Baker and West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who also met with Shevardnadze in Copenhagen, ``told us they are optimistic, that the role of a unified Germany in NATO will not be a problem in negotiations with the Soviet Union.'' But, he said, Moscow wanted to know ``what kind of NATO will Germany belong to?'' The two-day meeting at a resort in Turnberry, on Scotland's rugged west coast, is the third in a series held this spring to try to map out a new strategy for NATO. The members meet in London next month to formally begin work on NATO's future. Mrs. Thatcher, in her speech, insisted on the allies keeping nuclear weapons. ``We must retain sufficient nuclear weapons, and the means of delivering them, to meet our long-term security needs,'' she said. ``Our job, as ministers responsible for our countries' defense and security, is to take the long view.'' However, in an apparent ad lib at the end of her speech, Mrs. Thatcher assured Moscow that NATO did not threaten the Soviet Union. ``NATO has never attacked anyone,'' she said. Baker told the allies, in a statement made public later, that ``we can and should be prepared to meet reasonable Soviet concerns.'' But, Baker said, ``we cannot acquiesce in an effort to block a full return to German sovereignty or to use ostensible security concerns over Germany as a surrogate for weakening the alliance.'' Baker told the allies that the defense of Europe primarily will remain in NATO's hands. ``NATO will remain an important contributor to the legitimacy and stability of the new Europe, although its functions and capabilities will evolve with the new times of changing challenges,'' he said. The Soviets have been resisting the U.S. demand for NATO membership for a unified Germany, suggesting instead their powerful neighbor be in the Warsaw Pact as well. Shevardnadze, meanwhile, proposed to Baker that the two alliances adopt some measures to guard against a revival of German militarism. Baker offered the Soviet official a nine-point package of assurances, including a promise that the merger of East Germany with West Germany would not lead to demands to recover territory lost at the end of World War II. He also assured Shevardnadze that NATO would revise its strategy to reflect the lessening of East-West tensions and take on more of a political mission. West Germany's Genscher said the Soviets were interested in NATO changing into more of a political structure and engaging the Warsaw Pact in ``confidence-building measures and cooperation,'' West German sources said. Genscher informed the allies West Germany may not hold elections scheduled for December. A senior official of another NATO delegation said unification is moving so quickly that combined elections may be held in East and West Germany by mid-January.

DOC.HEAD: New Patriarch Elected to Head Russian Orthodox Church
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS six grafs of background, byline.
DOC.TEXT: An ethnic Estonian considered a strong backer of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms was elected the new Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church and its following of tens of millions on Thursday. Metropolitan Alexi of Leningrad and Novgorod won election in a secret ballot, said Anna Generalova, a church spokeswoman. Alexi, 61, takes the helm of the church at a time when decades of Soviet government repression are being lifted and interest in religion is growing. A church council of 330 members chose him as successor to Patriarch Pimen, who died May 3 at age 79. He won despite predictions that many would consider him an inappropriate leader because he is of Baltic, rather than Russian, descent. In his pre-election program published by a church journal, he backed traditional church positions and spoke out in support of Gorbachev's reforms, saying they could improve both the material and spiritual lives of believers. He also pledged to work to solve ecological problems, according to Keston College, a British-based organization that closely follows events in the Russian Orthodox Church. Alexi runs the prestigious Leningrad diocese and has been responsible for the Russian Orthodox Church in Estonia as well. He was one of several clergymen elected last year as a deputy to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies. The meeting of the Local Council, which includes clergymen, monks and some laymen, was held at the Trinity-St. Sergius Monastery in Zagorsk, northeast of Moscow. It was closed to the press, but Soviet TV showed scores of bearded bishops in their flat-topped black or white mitres and flowing robes gathered at rows of flower-bedecked tables as the meeting began. In choosing Alexi, the council passed over a top cleric in the forefront of a bitter dispute with Ukrainian Catholics and another candidate considered a probable compromise candidate. He comes to power when Russian Orthodoxy is being virtually reborn in the Soviet Union. So many churches have been returned to religious authorities to be restored and reopened that observers say the church is strapped for money. A law guaranteeing freedom of conscience is slowly working its way throughout the Soviet legislature, raising hopes that decades of the officially atheist state's repression of religion are coming to an end. After the Bolsheviks took power in 1917, they deprived the church of all legal rights and imprisoned or executed thousands of priests. The church leadership decided to conform to the state, and it survived despite savage persecution under Stalin and suppression under subsequent governments. The number of Russian Orthodox worshipers is estimated at 20 million to 45 million.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Jack Lemmon Honored for His Understanding of Seasoned Citizens
DOC.TEXT: Actor Jack Lemmon was honored by the Jewish Homes for the Aging for his sensitive portrayal of an elderly man in the movie ``Dad.'' The non-profit Jewish Homes for the Aging of Greater Los Angeles presented its Rose Media Achievement Award to the Oscar-winning actor during a dinner Tuesday night at the Four Seasons Hotel.
