In the father-son picture co-starring Ted Danson, Lemmon portrayed an old man dying of cancer who reconciles with his son and grandson. ``This award, coming from you people who care for the aging, means a great deal to me because only a few roles can do more than spark good reviews by also bring into people's hearts a feeling of closeness or an emotion from within their own lives,'' Lemmon said during the ceremony. ``That is the greatest satisfaction for an actor.'' He won a best actor Academy Award for the 1973 film ``Save the Tiger'' and claimed best supporting actor honors for the 1955 film ``Mister Roberts.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Again in Plains; Sunny in West, Southeast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0697 to CORRECT coding.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms again pounded the central Plains and the middle Mississippi Valley, producing locally heavy rains and some severe weather Thursday, while skies were partly sunny to sunny across much of the West and Southeast. Around Louisville, thunderstorms produced four tornadoes, and in southern Indiana and northern Kentucky golf ball-size hail fell. Thunderstorms in the lower Missouri Valley created a tornado near Riverton, Iowa, and produced dime-size hail at Frankfort, Kan., and golf ball-size hail at Omaha, Neb. Showers and thunderstorms extended through parts of Nebraska, Iowa, Missouri, Illinois Oklahoma, Missouri, Tennessee and North Carolina on Thursday afternoon. Thunderstorms in the nation's midsection soaked some areas, particularly in northern Missouri which was deluged with more than six inches of rain. The Spirit of Saint Louis Airport in St. Louis reported 2.94 inches of in a six-hour period, and Mexico, Mo., was doused with more than three inches in a two-hour period Thursday morning. Elsewhere, showers and thunderstorms formed over New England, Florida and along the central Gulf coast. A few showers fell in the northern Rockies and the northern Plains. Strong southerly winds prevailed across the southern Plains and lower Mississippi Valley, and strong northwesterly winds ushered cooler air into the Northeast. Temperatures were in the 80s and 90s in the Southeast and south-central parts of the country, with readings approaching the 100-degree mark in the southern Plains; 60s and 70s across the north-central and northeastern states; 50s and 60s in the Pacific Northwest and the northern Rockies. Readings soared into the 90s and above 100 degrees in the desert Southwest. The nation's low Thursday was 33 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Doe Says Rebels Will Take Liberian Capital `Over My Dead Body'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with residents, diplomats reporting heavy fighting near airport. Pickup 10th pvs, `A Nigerian...' INSERTS 1 graf after 25th pvs `On Wednesday' to UPDATE with newspaper saying slain rebel leader from Massachusetts.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: Rebels and government troops battled with rockets, mortars and automatic weapons in heavy fighting Thursday on the huge Firestone rubber plantation 25 miles outside Monrovia, refugees and diplomats reported. Fighting was also reported at Robertsfield International Airport, which adjoins the 120,000-acre, U.S.-managed plantation. The diplomats and refugees said the government forces appeared to be mounting an offensive to retake the rubber plantation, the world's largest, captured by the rebels earlier this week. People who fled the fighting reported seeing at least one unit of 50 government reinforcements moving toward the battle site. President Samuel Doe dug in at his oceanside executive mansion and was quoted as telling a U.S. diplomat on Thursday that the rebels would take this capital city of 400,000 people ``over my dead body.'' In Washington, the State Department said Thursday that ``due to the potential threat to lives, all Americans are strongly advised to depart Liberia immediately.'' It said U.S. officials had arranged special commercial flights. The department put the total number of Americans still in Liberia as nearly 2,000. U.S. and British naval ships are off Liberia to assist in any evacuation. West Germany was preparing to evacuate about 100 German citizens and 100 other West Europeans, the Foreign Ministry in Bonn said Thursday. There was shooting and the sound of shells falling near Robertsfield Airport, residents of the area and diplomats said. The plantation is operated by Bridgestone-Firestone, Inc., an Akron, Ohio-based subsidiary of Japan's Bridgestone company. A Nigerian government official said in Lagos, the Nigerian capital, on Thursday that Doe would be welcome if he wished to go to Nigeria. Doe denied in a statement he was seeking asylum. He said he asked no one to seek asylum on his behalf and has ``no intention to leave or abandon the country in the face of the crisis.'' Doe took power in this West African nation of 2.5 million in a bloody coup in 1980. The rebels, led by former Doe aide Charles Taylor, accuse his administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. American officials said Washington had been quietly asking several African countries whether they would be willing to provide Doe with a safe haven if he is forced to flee. In London, Amnesty International, the international human rights organization, said the two warring sides were killing non-combatants and prisoners and asked them to stop. Hundreds of rebel and government supporters have been killed in Liberia in nearly six months since the rebel forces began their march toward Monrovia. Most of the 1,000 Liberians known to have died were killed by government troops. Ethnic differences complicate the uprising. The civil war has pitted Mandingos and Krahns, who support Doe, against the Gio and Mano. About half the Liberian soldiers have deserted since the fighting began Dec. 24, reducing the army to 3,000 to 4,000 men _ about the same size as rebel forces, according to diplomats. Official sources said that in recent fighting, rebels ambushed an army checkpoint less than 10 miles from Monrovia and wounded three soldiers. At least four Cabinet ministers live in that area, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. It was the closest yet to Monrovia that any fighting has been reported. Doe was quoted by a European diplomat as telling a U.S. diplomat the rebels would have to go ``over my dead body'' to take Monrovia. A Doe request for U.S. military aid was turned down. On Wednesday, Information Minister Emmanuel Bouwier and rebel forces reported that U.S.-trained rebel commander Elmer Johnson was killed in combat, but gave no details. Johnson, 31, had a Massachusetts driver's license with an address at an apartment complex in Quincy, just south of Boston, a newspaper reported. The Patriot Ledger of Quincy quoted neighbors as saying they were surprised Johnson, whom they considered mild-mannered, would be involved in violence. Refugees reaching Monrovia said rebels killed dozens of Krahn and Mandingo civilians in their advance toward Monrovia, which is suffering from widespread food shortages. A Mandingo woman said rebels burst into a mosque in her town and opened fire on people who spoke the Mandingo dialect. ``They just shot the people,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Likud Appears on Verge of Forming Israeli Government
DOC.TEXT: Likud officials announced Thursday they were close to forming a right-wing coalition government but conceded that a key ultra-Orthodox religious party was still holding out. Their statements came after a party official said caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir had agreed to take tougher measures against the Palestinian uprising in an effort to draw important far-right factions into a coalition. Shamir, who heads the rightist Likud bloc, also has promised his new coalition would allocate more money for enlarging the Jewish settlements in the occupied lands, the daily Maariv reported. The United States opposes new settlements, saying they are an obstacle to peace. Ariel Sharon, chairman of the Likud Central Committee, said Thursday that Likud had succeeded in garnering a 62-vote majority coalition in the 120-member parliament. He said he would convene the Likud's governing committee on Sunday to approve the new coalition. Shamir was expected to tell President Chaim Herzog on Friday morning he succeeded in mustering enough seats for a majority coalition, just hours before his deadline to form a government expires, Likud officials said. However, the officials conceded they had not received a final pledge of support from the Shas party, an ultra-Orthodox group. David Magen, a Likud minister, told Israel television they were waiting to receive a positive answer from Shas but said he was optimistic it would agree to participate in the government. In a related development, protesters demanding electoral reform clashed with police outside the prime minister's office, shouting they wanted an end to what they called ``political extortion.'' No injured were reported. Feverish attempts to overcome feuds lasted into the night, with Likud offering more government jobs to ultra-Orthodox religious parties whose support is crucial for forming the Cabinet. Labor Party officials greeted the likelihood of a Likud-led coalition government with caution, but one Labor leader said such a right-wing government would reduce world support for the Jewish state. ``This will be a right-wing extremist government, a tragic government for Israel,'' Labor Party Chairman Micha Harish said on Israel TV. Head of the Government Press and a member of Likud, Yossi Olmert, told The Associated Press ``it is very, very likely'' Shamir will tell the president he has formed a government. He added it was ``almost certain'' Shas would join. The Shas Party was instrumental in bringing down Shamir's unity government on March 15, when it abstained from a Labor-led vote of no confidence over Likud's refusal to agree to a U.S.-proposed meeting with Palestinian representatives. Labor leader Shimon Peres then failed in a 35-day bid to form a left-of-center coalition. On April 27, Herzog gave Shamir a mandate to try to form a government. Danny Dayan, secretary-general of the far-right Tehiya Party, said earlier Thursday that Shamir had agreed to hard-line action against the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising to meet his deadline for shaping a government. Dayan, reached by telephone, said ``the policy guidelines will say that measures will be taken to end the intefadeh,'' or uprising. However, he said the agreement did not detail what measures were involved. Untra-right leaders have been demanding such steps as expelling Arab stone-throwers from the occupied territories and destroying more homes of terror suspects. Across the street from the coalition dealings in Shamir's office, police used force to disperse about 200 protesters calling for an end to the use of political posts and public funds to lure defectors to cross party lines and woo religious factions. No injuries or arrests were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti To Hold General Elections
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Haiti will hold its first free elections in 186 years by October and the voting will be supervised by international observers, the electoral council said Thursday. Council President Jean-Robert Sabalat told a news conference the exact date will be announced next week after a new electoral bill is submitted to President Ertha-Pascal Trouillot, Haiti's provisional leader. Balloting will be held for local office, seats in parliament, and for the presidency, he added. The news conference marked the first public appearance of the nine-member independent electoral body since it was formed May 2. Sabalat said the elections had the president's total support and the ``collaboration'' of the army. Seventeen candidates have announced for the presidency. The United States granted this impoverished Caribbean island nation $5.4 million in electoral assistance last month. Sabalat said Haiti was also counting on financial aid from the Caribbean Economic Community, the United Nations and the Organization of American States. Ms. Pascal-Trouillot was sworn in March 13 after Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril fled to exile amid widespread protests against his military government in this nation of about 5.3 million. Haiti, the first republic of former slaves, gained independence from France in 1804 and has since been governed mostly by repressive military rulers. On Nov. 29, 1987, Haiti's first free general elections were canceled after thugs in collusion with the army killed at least 34 voters at the polls.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan's Bhutto Rules Out Martial Law in Sind Province
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto on Thursday ruled out martial law in her home province in southern Pakistan, where more than 400 people have died in ethnic violence in the past month. She also accused opposition parties of trying to stir up trouble in Sindh province for their own selfish interests. Her government is under pressure to declare martial law to halt bloodshed between native Sindhis and Moslem Indian immigrants known as Mohajirs. Pakistan has spent 25 years of its 43-year history under military rule. Ms. Bhutto, whose father was overthrown in a military coup in 1977 and executed two years later, said Thursday, ``No patriot could talk of martial law in the country. Only those elements who had benefited directly or indirectly are talking of martial law. They are trying in vain.'' Last week she called out the army to help the Sindh government restore peace. But critics and supporters agree the problem must be solved politically, not militarily. The Mohajirs make up the better-educated middle-class in the province's cities. Sindhis complain the Mohajirs monopolize the best jobs and take the most valuable land. The Mohajir Qami Movement blames Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, the party in power in the province, for the chaos. The movement is vital to any settlement. It represents Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan following the 1947 partition of the subcontinent.

DOC.HEAD: Warning Sirens Saved Lives in Devastated Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Limon is pronounced LIE-mon. With AM-Tornado Boy
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DX3, DX7, DX11, DX12; LaserColor DX12
DOC.TEXT: Block after devastated block of this farming town told Thursday of the visit by a tornado. But siren blasts gave the 1,800 residents here precious minutes to take shelter, and none was killed. Three guests at the Lariat Hotel piled into a bathtub and pulled a mattress over them when the tornado siren sounded at dusk Wednesday. ``We were doing a lot of praying in that bathtub,'' said David Thomas, who shared the cramped quarters with Arley Boston and Carl Riley. The tornado tore their room apart. ``It felt like somebody just reached down and squeezed your whole body. My eardrums were coming out,'' Thomas said. Town Clerk Teresa O'Dwyer said she ran to Town Hall when the siren sounded and put the town records in the vault. Minutes later, the tornado ripped the front off the building. As residents began picking up the pieces Thursday, officials toured this town about 80 miles southeast of Denver. Streets were cluttered with metal, wood and other debris left by the tornado that hopscotched down Main Street shortly after 8 p.m., yanking down walls and roofs, overturning rail cars and smashing a grain silo as if it were a soda can. Business owners stood guard against looters, and dozens of police patrolled. Among the devastation, people marveled that no one died. ``We're lucky to be alive,'' said Angie Spencer, cradling her cat in her arms as she surveyed what was left of her house. ``We went underneath the house and under a crawlspace and it sounded like an earthquake. We just heard everything rumbling and ripping and when we got out, everything was gone.'' Gov. Roy Romer estimated damage between $20 million and $40 million. He said about 90 percent of the businesses and government offices were damaged or destroyed, and about half the town's 750 homes. Romer said he would seek federal disaster aid for the town. At least 12 people were injured, but just two remained hospitalized Thursday, one in fair condition and one listed as stable. Lincoln County Sheriff Leroy Yowell was driving down Main Street when he saw the tornado looming behind him. ``It was huge,'' he said. ``We drove to the east edge of town and hid behind a building until it passed.'' Yowell and other residents alerted the Colorado State Patrol, which sounded the civil defense siren, giving people five to six minutes' warning the tornado was headed their way. The tornado moved through town from south to northeast in a wide ``S.'' While some residents complained the siren was drowned out by hail, many credited the warning system with saving lives. Some said they hadn't even needed it. ``You could hear it coming and when the glass started tinkling, we all ran for the basement. I don't know why somebody didn't get killed,'' said Russ Covington, a Lincoln County commissioner. The tornado halted water, electricity and telephones, but crews restored at least limited supplies of all three services Thursday. Relief efforts were launched by state and federal agencies. A makeshift grocery store was set up in the high school. Len Boulas, an operations officer with the state Division of Emergency Services, said a final damage assessment would take two to three days. The American Red Cross fed about 2,000 storm victims, volunteers and cleanup workers Thursday, and helped concerned relatives find loved ones. The Limon tornado was one of at least nine reported to the National Weather Service Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Balks at Curbs on Crime Bill Debate, Sponsors Seek Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 5th graf bgng: After caucusing ... to UPDATE that two sides met and agreed to pursue plan next week.
DOC.TEXT: Senate supporters of a wide-ranging crime bill with curbs on semiautomatic assault weapons scrambled to save the measure Thursday after efforts to stop a filibuster fell short. ``I think we can work it out,'' Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., said after senators of both parties called for a compromise version shorn of a number of the troublesome provisions. Republicans were weighing a plan to retain the bill's provisions to put curbs on nine semiautomatic assault weapons, overhaul the criminal appeals system, establish the death penalty for 30 federal offenses and fine-tune money laundering laws. Under the plan, the bill would be stripped of provisions to allow courts to consider evidence gathered with flawed warrants and to set up an organized crime and drug division in the Justice Department. After caucusing on the scheme _ which also would allow 12 amendments on each side _ Republican leaders walked down the hall and met with their Democratic counterparts but emerged without any commitments. The two sides did agree to explore the proposal next week. Democratic leaders blamed pressure from the National Rifle Association for the Senate's refusal to limit debate on the current version. They first pronounced the bill dead after the Senate voted 57-37 in favor of limiting debate, three votes short of the number needed. But then after an overture from Thurmond they called for talks aimed at reaching such a compromise. ``The only way we're really likely to get a bill is if we can enter into negotiations,'' said Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del. Much of the discussion of the bill has focused on its ban on the manufacture or importation of nine kinds of semiautomatic assault rifles, but it contains other significant provisions as well. The legislation contains remnants of President Bush's crime program, sent to Capitol Hill a year ago, but has been largely rewritten since then and few of its provisions now find favor with the administration. Under various provisions: _ The death penalty would be established for 30 specific federal crimes. _ Courts would be able to consider evidence gathered with flawed warrants in some case. _ An end would be sought to long delays _ up to a decade in some cases _ in carrying out executions. Democratic leaders said they needed to limit debate because of 300 pending amendments that could delay passage indefinitely. The time limit sought by Democratic leaders would have squeezed action on all amendments and the overall bill into 30 hours. On the roll call, 11 Republicans joined 46 Democrats in voting for a time limit. Seven Democrats and 30 Republicans opposed it. That gave bill sponsors three more votes than they gained Tuesday when they made their first run at a time limit but still not enough. Biden blamed the NRA for the proliferation of amendments. ``The NRA says this bill they want to kill because it contains guns,'' he declared. Indeed, in the days before the vote the NRA sent messages from Executive Director Wayne LaPierre to gun owners in eight states, urging them to put pressure on their senators. One mailed to South Dakota ripped into Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., saying the gun provisions had survived in an earlier skirmish by one vote. ``Tom Daschle betrayed every honest gun owner in South Dakota by voting for it ... because Daschle bought the big anti-gun media lie that gun control equals crime control'' and ``has now joined Ted Kennedy and the national gun ban crowd ...'' It urged gun owners to call Daschle's offices in Aberdeen, Rapid City and Sioux Falls and provided the phone numbers. Messages with the names of other senators and similar accusations were mailed into a number of other states. Daschle responded by telling South Dakotans that ``as a hunter and a gun owner, I am against gun control period.'' ``Let's be realistic,'' he said. ``Taking a couple of very small steps to try to deal with the drug killers who use these assault weapons is not going to hurt a single, law abiding South Dakota sportsman.'' Also, Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell said he had received phone calls because of a letter sent to Maine gun owners by the NRA. ``They have certainly been critical of me in the past,'' he said, though he added that he has generally supported their stands. ``Many of their statements have been false and misleading,'' he said. However, some lawmakers who voted against cutting short debate scoffed at the notion that fear of NRA retaliation at re-election time was the reason. ``It wasn't in my case _ I'm leaving here,'' said retiring Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H. He said was against the measure because its ``habeas corpus'' provisions designed to end delays in carrying out executions were not written properly. NRA lobbyist David Conover said in an interview Wednesday that ``we weren't out in the halls ... but we had mail out, which I think most people would say is our most effective way of communicating.'' He said the gun group's members may have grown complacent prior to a vote two weeks ago in which the Senate narrowly rejected a move to strip gun curbs out of the bill. He said that action created ``renewed energy among NRA members and gun owners.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Gorbachev a `Remarkable Man'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf, bgng: Of the xxx to UPDATE with detail on Lithuanian demonstrators in Chicago; note that embargoed material in grafs 6-7 has now been released.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, on a political tour of the Midwest Thursday, called Mikhail Gorbachev a ``remarkable man'' and said the Soviet president's forthright summit manner proves there is a ``new era'' in U.S.-Soviet relations. ``Of course, we have differences,'' said Bush, specifying Lithuanian self-determination, the emigration rights of Soviet Jews, a unified Germany as a NATO member and the continued totalitarian regime in Cuba. ``These aren't questions that can be solved simply, or in a single summit,'' Bush told a fundraising luncheon for Wisconsin Gov. Tommy Thompson. Bush summarized the outcome of a ``very productive summit'' as he began a two-day speaking trip on behalf of GOP Senate and gubernatorial candidates. He later flew to Illinois, and from there was headed to Iowa and Nebraska. In Chicago, Bush told a Republican fundraising event, ``I believe last week's summit can alter history.'' Of the long-term grain agreement that he and Gorbachev signed, which should increase U.S. grain sales to the Soviet Union by one million tons annually, Bush said, ``It will bring bread to Soviet consumers and business to the farmers of Illinois.'' Several hundred people carrying Lithuanian and other Baltic states flags demonstrated outside the Chicago hotel where Bush spoke. The president took note of the demonstrators in his speech, telling his audience the protesters were ``all decent and honorable people.'' The president said he, too, supports the self-determination rights of citizens of the Baltic republics. ``There's no difference between us at all on that,'' he said. Meanwhile, the White House hailed the decision by South African President F.W. de Klerk to lift a four-year-old state of emergency, calling the move ``another significant step toward creating a climate conducive to negotiations that will lead to a democratic, non-racial South Africa.'' The statement, issued by deputy White House press secretary Alixe Glen aboard Air Force One en route to Milwaukee, said the announcement ``builds on earlier decisions by President de Klerk'' toward more open and free political debate. Bush has invited both de Klerk and freed black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela to the White House. Mandela will visit on June 25, de Klerk at a later, yet to-be-announced date. ``Much work remains to be done by all sides,'' the White House statement continued. ``However, we are encouraged by the remarkable progress that has been made in recent months. ... We look forward to the early beginning of a negotiating process,'' it added. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher noted that the administration cannot legally modify U.S. sanctions against South Africa until certain conditions are met. Boucher said U.S. law requires that the state of emergency be lifted, among other measures, before the sanctions can be eased. Left unanswered for the time being, he said, is the impact on the legislation of the de Klerk's decision to lift the state of emergency in all but one province, Natal. Boucher added that the lifting of the sanctions must also await the release of all political prisoners in South Africa. ``This has not yet happened,'' he said. Bush, in his first speech since the superpower summit that ended Sunday, told his Milwaukee audience, ``As I chatted informally with President Gorbachev at Camp David, I kept thinking that this new Soviet leader, committed to reform and openness, is indeed a remarkable man.'' ``I'm grateful to Mr. Gorbachev for the forthright spirit in which he addressed every issue on the table,'' Bush said. ``And I take it as proof that we have indeed entered a new era in our relations with the USSR.'' Bush listed progress toward an agreement to limit nuclear missiles, a cutback in chemical weapons stockpiles, an agreement on nuclear testing and pacts on trade and grain sales as the key accomplishments of last week's meetings. Overall, Bush said, ``It was a good summit.'' Bush said his administration's top trade priority is to conclude international trade talks by year's end. The United States is seeking the removal of European farm export subsidies over 10 years at the talks, which have been underway in Geneva for nearly two years. ``And let me tell you: any trade agreement we sign will be an agreement that's good for the American farmer,'' he said. Gov. Thompson, an early supporter of Bush's 1988 presidential campaign, is waging a well-funded re-election bid against four-term Democratic Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus. After Milwaukee, Bush was travelling to Chicago to lend support to the Illinois gubernatorial candidacy of Republican Secretary of State Jim Edgar, who is battling Democratic state Attorney General Neil Hartigan to succeed outgoing Gov. James R. Thompson, a Republican. The party hopes the president's campaign efforts in Illinois also will help Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., in her battle against incumbent Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. Bush also was to speak to a group of students at a Chicago elementary school and participate in a National Literacy Week program. On Friday, Bush will be in Des Moines for incumbent Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad. He will also appear at an Omaha luncheon for GOP Senate contender Hal Daub, who is challenging Democratic incumbent Sen. James Exon, R-Neb.

DOC.HEAD: New Type Vaccine Elicits Desired Response
DOC.TEXT: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University have shown that a candidate vaccine produced by genetic engineering fights the virus that produces AIDS, according to a report published Thursday. The vaccine uses gene-splicing techniques to produce a chain of proteins mimicking a portion of the surface of the the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the cause of AIDS. Vaccines against viruses usually are made of the whole virus, crippled so that it cannot cause the disease in question, or killed virus. Writing in Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Johns Hopkins team said, ``although the induction of virus-specific ... (virus-fighting) responses is traditionally associated with attenuated live-virus vaccines, our results demonstrate that envelope protein subunit vaccines, which have greater inherent simplicity and safety, may also induce'' the desired activity. The candidate vaccine was injected into eight volunteers four times over 18 months _ an initial injection followed by three boosters. At the end of 18 months, three of the eight had developed a response in which the cells of their immune systems attacked the HIV virus and the cells it infected. They did so without attacking the so-called ``innocent bystander'' uninfected cells of the immune system, a major problem in AIDS research. The test vaccine is a long way from being shown to be a possible weapon against AIDS. Further clinical tests, which could take years to complete, must be conducted before the vaccine could be used. Other vaccines also are being tested at other labs in which portions of the AIDS virus proteins are being used to try to trigger an immune response. The Johns Hopkins team was led by Rimas J. Orentas of the Baltimore institution's department of pharmacology and molecular sciences and included James E.K. Hildreth, Eugene Obah, Michael Polydefkis, Gale E. Smith, Mary Lou Clements and Robert F. Siliciano.

DOC.HEAD: Annual Meeting May Spotlight Frustration Over Declining Influence
DOC.TEXT: The National Rifle Association opens its annual convention in an unfriendly state Friday, hoping to restore its influence after losses in membership and legislative defeats across the country. An estimated 20,000 members will attend the convention in California, which last year bucked the gun lobby and passed legislation banning more than 50 types of military-style assault rifles. The organization _ which also has suffered legislative defeats in California, New Jersey, Maryland and Florida _ won at least a temporary victory Thursday when the U.S. Senate failed to stop a filibuster on a broad anti-crime bill with new restrictions on semiautomatic weapons. Democratic leaders, blaming the NRA for their failure, at first decided the bill was dead, then sought a compromise to revive the measure. NRA lobbyist James J. Baker claimed the Senate action showed the NRA retains some legislative clout. ``We've lost some battles. The war is far from over,'' Baker said. ``You look at the votes in the United States Senate this morning and I think that gives you the proof that you need based on the fact that they decided a crime bill that contains a semiautomatic firearms bill would not go forward.'' NRA leaders expect to hear complaints about about the organization's legislative defeats, and have scheduled a meeting Saturday to field questions from the rank and file about them. ``I think there's a great deal of frustration among the membership based on a very tough year,'' Baker said. ``...I think that you're going to see that frustration played out at the annual membership meeting.'' The convention comes at a crucial time in the history of the 2.8 million-member organization. Along with legislative defeats, the NRA has lost support among law enforcement and has lost 240,000 members in four years. Baker attributed some of the membership loss to a $10 increase in dues in recent years. Opponents of the NRA see a badly damaged organization. ``The National Rifle Association has suffered enormous losses,'' said Luis Tolley, western director of Handgun Control Inc. ``Over the last 12 months you're looking at the worst period in the NRA's existence.'' The NRA faces divisions in its own ranks between members who feel the group has gone too far and members who want the NRA to push harder against gun control. One of the NRA's biggest losses was in the California Legislature last year when lawmakers passed and Republican Gov. George Deukmejian signed a bill banning many kinds of assault rifles. The bill was introduced after five children were slain and 29 others were wounded in a schoolyard by a man with an assault rifle. The man, Patrick Purdy, killed himself at the end of the Jan. 17, 1989, attack in Stockton. California also now requires a 15-day waiting period for the purchase of rifles and shotguns. Elsewhere, Maryland voters approved a referendum in 1988 that bans sale and manufacture of cheap handguns known as Saturday night specials. This year in New Jersey, Gov. James Florio signed what he called the nation's strongest ban on sale and possession of assault weapons. One NRA problem in fighting gun controls has been loss of support among police. Los Angeles County Sheriff Sherman Block and Los Angeles Police Chief Darryl Gates speak in favor of legislation banning assault weapons. Gun control advocates say the NRA has gone too far in its lobbying. ``Five or 10 years ago you wouldn't have seen the police doing what they're doing now,'' said Tolley. ``The NRA has gone off the deep end.'' Baker acknowledged that loss of law enforcement groups hurt but he contends the NRA has only lost support among police leadership groups. ``By and large, the rank and file law enforcement officers, the officer that walks the beat, that comes into contact with the criminal element in this country, supports the position that gun control laws do not do anything to deter criminals,'' he said. The convention features vendors pushing shotguns, handguns, bullets, crossbows, bulletproof vests, air guns, boots and camouflage jackets.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Major Says Chief Salvadoran Investigator Impeded Jesuit Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army major testified the Salvadoran colonel heading the inquiry into the murder of six Jesuit priests knew who was responsible weeks before he told senior authorities, the Supreme Court reported Thursday. The court also confirmed that military log books considered key evidence in the case were burned by one of the defendants, on orders from a higher officer. A court communique said that Judge Ricardo Zamora, who is investigating the Jesuit slayings, formally included as evidence a sworn declaration from the major. It did not name the major, but he has been identified as Eric Buckland, who until January was part of the U.S. Military Group here. Buckland told the same thing to a U.S. congressional commission studying the Jesuit slayings. The commission's report was released April 30. Buckland's testimony gained significance for being formally included as evidence. He testified that Col. Carlos Aviles told him Dec. 20 of the involvement of Col. Guillermo Benavides in the massacre of the Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter. The eight were killed before dawn Nov. 16 on the campus of Central American University, where the Jesuits taught. Buckland said Aviles based his assertion on a conversation with another Salvadoran colonel, Ivan Lopez y Lopez. Lopez y Lopez had been told by Col. Manuel Rivas, the head of the U.S.-funded Special Investigative Unit investigating the massacre, said Buckland in his statement. According to this version, Benavides admitted his involvement to Rivas, asking the investigating colonel, ``What can you do to help me?'' According to Buckland's version of events, at least three Salvadoran colonels _ Aviles, Lopez y Lopez and Rivas _ lied to U.S. and Salvadoran authorities looking into the killing of the Jesuits. Aviles has denied telling Buckland about any conversation between Benavides and Rivas and has been called by Zamora to provide sworn testimony. Both Aviles and Buckland took lie detector tests in January. According to the U.S. congressional commission, ``The polygraph results indicated some deception in both cases.'' In conversations with members of the congressional commission, Rivas and Lopez y Lopez denied Buckland's allegations. Both refused to take lie detector tests. After being briefed by Rivas' investigative unit, President Alfredo Cristiani announced Jan. 7 that military personnel were involved in the Jesuits' massacre. On Jan. 13, he said Benavides, three lieutenants and five other soldiers had been charged in the crime. One, a private, is a fugitive. The Supreme Court confirmed the 1989 log books of the Military College, where the unit that killed the Jesuits was temporarily based, were burned by Lt. Rene Mendoza in mid-December. Mendoza is a defendant in the murder case. The court communique said Mendoza testified he burned the books on orders from then-Maj. Camilo Hernandez, who then was subdirector of the Military College .

DOC.HEAD: 65 Candles for Mrs. Bush
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 10-11: ``President Bush,'' with the president's remarks; collapses last two grafs into one graf to remove redundancies
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush, on the eve of her 65th birthday, said Thursday that she ``couldn't care less'' about the milestone. ``I had a very good week, and I plan to have a great week next week, too,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``I felt all of America had a great week last week,'' she said, reflecting on the recent superpower summit. Mrs. Bush spent part of Thursday in a salute to 25 local children who read hundreds of books to raise money for the March of Dimes. As she left the event at The Washington Post, a reporter asked her feelings on turning 65. ``Ohhhhhh!'' she groaned, as if hammered by a verbal blow. But she quickly added with a laugh: ``I couldn't care less. No, I have no feelings about it.'' Mrs. Bush is coming off the most celebrated event of her 14-plus months in the White House: last Friday's nationally televised address to the Wellesley graduates, some of whom had questioned the wisdom of honoring the president's homemaker wife. But her witty address, a mixture of disarming humor and candid advice about not letting careers crowd out family, charmed the women graduates, who gave a tumultuous welcome to both Mrs. Bush and Raisa Gorbachev. Afterward, they were cheered by crowds in the town of Wellesley and a park in Boston, as Mrs. Bush took her guest arm-in-arm on a quick sightseeing tour of the city. ``I was really proud of the Wellesley girls and Boston,'' she said. ``I was really proud that we could show Raisa that kind of (welcome). The only problem was she wanted to thank each one personally.'' President Bush, in a fund-raising speech in Chicago, let everyone know Thursday night he had not forgotten his wife's birthday. He said he was just on the phone ``to tomorrow's birthday girl, the one who did so well at Wellesley.'' He said he had called British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to discuss last week's summit conference with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev: ``But she didn't want to talk about the Gorbachev summit. She wanted to talk _ because she'd seen live on television over there, she'd seen Barbara Bush speaking at Wellesley. So I was very proud of her assessment of what went on.'' Mrs. Bush draped ribbons around the necks of the schoolchildren dubbed the local March of Dimes' ``reading champions.'' The top reader was Nicholas Daly, 9, of Beltsville, Md., who read 435 books in a single month. Nicholas said the reading marathon left him little time for video games or television. The 4th grader said his favorite book was ``The Paper Crane.'' The 25 youngsters read more than 6,000 books and raised $1,200 for the March of Dimes fight against birth defects. Overall, 800 children taking part in the contest raised more than $14,000, which will be used for a campaign to encourage women to avoid drugs, alcohol and cigarettes during pregnancy. Friday is not only Mrs. Bush's birthday, but also National Read Aloud Day. Mrs. Bush will mark that event by reading aloud to children on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' and later by reading to second-graders at a library in suburban District Heights, Md. President Bush 66 turns Tuesday. He will return Friday evening to the White House, where the Bushes plan a private dinner for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

DOC.HEAD: Former Church Treasurer Denies Wrongdoing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with interview with Womer, others. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of absconding eight years ago with $267,000 from his New York church said Thursday he left because of ``industrial espionage,'' and hadn't stolen anything. ``I didn't know I was a fugitive until Monday night,'' said Clyde M. Womer, 67, in a rambling interview at the Taos County Jail. Womer disappeared from Rockland County north of New York City in January 1982, leaving behind a wife and five children. A few days later, $267,000 was discovered missing from the Christ Episcopalian Church of Ramapo, N.Y., of which he was treasurer. He was arrested Monday. He has lived in Taos since 1983, known as Lawrence Howard ``Howie'' Krantz, a quiet, friendly retired man who sometimes helped build fixtures in the local J.C. Penney store managed by the woman he married in 1984. Womer acknowledged having transferred money from church accounts to his own bank accounts in New York. But he said the transfers were not theft, and said he had had reasons for making them, which he could not discuss. He told a story that he acknowledged ``sounds screwy,'' about a chemical manufacturing process he developed and sold _ he wouldn't say to whom. He referred to ``industrial espionage'' and said he had been advised to leave Suffern and change his name _ he wouldn't say by whom. He said Lawrence Krantz is the name of his son-in-law from his first marriage. He said he came to New Mexico with around $300,000 in cash from selling the chemical process. Womer said he felt all right about leaving his first wife and children because after years of commuting into New York City, he had become estranged from them. He said he committed only two crimes: applying for a New Mexico driver's license under a name that wasn't his own, and marrying again. He called it ``plain, pure stupidity'' not to have told his second wife, Betty Sutton, who he really was. ``I'm sorry for the hurt that I've caused other people,'' he said. Sutton refused to be interviewed Thursday, saying only, ``I've had a bomb dropped this week.'' She said Wednesday she was aware the man she knew as Krantz had been married before and had five children, but said she was told his first wife died of cancer. ``This is the last thing I would have thought,'' she said. ``You never think something like this will happen to you.'' The Rev. John Andrews, rector of the New York church, said he had had personality conflicts with Womer and wanted him relieved as treasurer, but hadn't known money was missing. Andrews, who came here to identify Womer, said he tried to talk with him but Womer turned his back. Suffern police detective Sgt. Leo Costa, who also came here to identify Womer, said Wednesday that Womer's first wife, Harriet, now lives in Colorado Springs, Colo., and that their children are grown. He said she was ``pretty upset when she learned he was married in New Mexico.'' Costa said Mrs. Womer had been filing papers to declare her husband dead so she could get Social Security payments. Andrews said Mrs. Womer was in the Taos J.C. Penney store a year ago while on vacation but hadn't knowingly seen her husband. Last month, a vacationing member of the New York church spotted Womer in the store and tipped authorities. Womer waived extradition to New York, where he faces three counts each of second- and third-degree grand larceny. He is to be escorted there Friday and arraigned Monday. Rockland County District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz said Womer, an investment adviser and small business entrepreneur, persuaded church members to put funds into liquid accounts which he controlled. Womer then ``systematically looted'' the church accounts, depositing the money in his own account, Gribetz said. He said Womer withdrew the money $5,000 at a time from New York City banks and transferred it to banks in Albuquerque. He said Womer's assets were seized, but could not list them.

DOC.HEAD: More Names of Alleged Nazi War Criminals Submitted to Government
DOC.TEXT: Nazi hunters on Thursday submitted the names of nine more alleged war criminals living in Britain to the government and protested a House of Lords vote that killed a bill to prosecute such suspects. Efraim Zuroff, coordinator of the Simon Wiesenthal Center's Nazi War Crimes Center in Jerusalem, said he ``emphasized our sense of frustration and disappointment with what has happened to the bill'' when he provided the latest names to the Home Office. ``We talked about the possibilities of deportation, denaturalization and extradition,'' said Zuroff, who came to London to see the House of Lords vote Tuesday. He said the Wiesenthal Center, which is based in Los Angeles, wants to make sure if the bill is not reintroduced, ``there will be some alternative so these people are not granted a safe haven in Britain.'' Britain is the only World War II ally without laws to prosecute suspected war criminals. The government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had backed the bill, which was also passed by a large majority in the lower, elected House of Commons. Government officials could force the proposal through the unelected House of Lords by reintroducing it in the fall, but they have not yet announced their decision. The nine new names bring the total number of alleged war criminals living in Britain to 136. The failed bill followed an inquiry by a government-appointed commission that said there was enough evidence to prosecute three suspects for murder and investigate 124 others. A Home Office spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Thursday the latest names were received, but the government can investigate no further without a law allowing prosecution. Zuroff said names of alleged war criminals came from testimony of survivors in Lithuanian Jewish communities where nearly 250,000 Jews were killed during World War II. He added that more names were likely to result from further research in Israel. About 6 million Jews were killed in the Holocaust.

DOC.HEAD: Family Waits While City Scrambles To Raise Ransom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 8th graf pvs, `The kidnappers...,' to UPDATE with photo of missing man shown in Ecuador. SUBS 15th graf pvs, `About ...,' to UPDATE that $35,000 raised sted $21,000.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto QTO1
DOC.TEXT: A middle-aged woman with a wad of dollar bills in her hand hesitated Thursday before knocking on the door of a white-frame bungalow adorned with yellow ribbons and balloons. Inside, Roy and Marge Heimdal huddled with their two daughters as friends and strangers alike scrambled to gather the $60,000 ransom they hope will save the Heimdal's 27-year-old son, Scott, from South American kidnappers. ``This is for your son,'' the woman said as she quickly the money. ``Can I get your name?'' Heimdal, 52, asked the woman. ``It doesn't matter,'' she responded. The Heimdals hoped to wire the money to Ecuador by Friday in order to make the kidnapper's Monday deadline. The money will be given to an unidentified intermediary who will carry it into the jungles along the Ecuador-Colombia border, where their son, Scott, disappeared April 28. Scott Heimdal, an engineer for a gold-mining company near Quito, Ecuador, was traveling by boat when it was ambushed by Maoist insurgents who killed the boat pilot, wounded a passenger, and kidnapped Heimdal and an Ecuadoran student. The kidnappers subsequently released the student with two letters written by Heimdal, one to his family and the other to his company Iminco Co. The letters' contents were not revealed. The kidnappers have several several photographs of Heimdal to prove he was alive. One of them, shown to reporters Thursday by Jeffrey Fino, manager of the mining company that employs Heimdal, shows the captive sitting down, encircled by several armed men. The elder Heimdal said the photo appeared similar to pictures the family had seen previously. U.S. and Ecuadoran officials refused to comment on negotiations between the kidnappers and family. A U.S. diplomatic source said Heimdal was in Colombian territory. ``We assume that his life is in danger,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mrs. Heimdal, 47, said the kidnappers, reportedly members of a Colombian guerrilla group known as the Popular Liberation Army, have threatened to ``show us where his body is'' unless they get paid. ``It's not easy to strip your soul in front of the whole country,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ``We're trying to keep our dignity. But we had no other way to save our son than to go public like this. Our fear is so big right now.'' On Wednesday, State Department spokesman Dave Denny said the family was advised not to pay any ransom, in keeping with U.S. policy, ``but families are free to do what they must do.'' Since the Heimdals went public, the people of Peoria and elsewhere have been offering help. ``I've been following their story in the paper,'' said Oscar Boehl, who delivered a few dollars in his pickup truck. ``This is the kind of story that gets anybody. Or it should. I'm not wealthy, but everyone can kick in a few bucks. Every little bit helps.'' Steakhouses, taverns and sandwich shops have joined the cause to raise ransom money. Nursing homes have held bake sales and waitresses have donated their tips. About $35,000 had been raised by Thursday night, the missing man's father said. For the Heimdals, the kidnapping is just the most recent in a string of personal problems. In 1981, when Peoria's economy plunged into deep recession, Heimdal was forced to leave the real estate business, his line of work since 1969. The family moved to Chetek, Wis., opening a cabinet business and flower shop. Then in 1983 Mrs. Heimdal was critically injured in a wreck with a drunken driver. She suffered head and back injuries, and memory loss. Her injuries required her to be hospitalized for most of two years. Medical bills surpassed $300,000 and when their insurance ran out, the family was forced to sell everything to pay the bills. ``I can't remember my kids as babies and my speech was affected,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ``We sold everything and moved back to Peoria in 1988.'' Heimdal still works in the cabinet business and Mrs. Heimdal is active in Mothers Against Drunk Driving. The family maintains faith that their son will return home safely. ``My dream is coming home on a plane with Scott and being met at the Peoria airport by hundreds of people and all of them holding yellow ribbons,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ``Scott belongs to this community now. They are fighting for his life, just like we are.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korean President Leaves For Home
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo left Honolulu Thursday afternoon for Seoul as he wound up his historic trip to the United States. On Monday, Roh held groundbreaking talks with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev in San Francisco. Then, he flew to Washington to brief President Bush on the talks aimed at reducing tensions between North and South Korea. Roh spent about 18 hours in Hawaii relaxing from his high-level diplomatic contacts with the two superpower leaders. About 100 men, women and children from Hawaii's Korean community were on hand at Hickam Air Force Base for Roh's departure. Many of the women were dressed in hanboks, traditional Korean dresses.

DOC.HEAD: Fake Indian Pictographs Washed From Cavern Walls
DOC.TEXT: About 100 fake pictographs were removed from the fragile limestone walls of a Mojave Desert cavern once used by American Indians for religious ceremonies, authorities said. ``The work has been completed and there is no damage,'' said Larry Cermak, chief of the Mojave District of the state Department of Parks and Recreation, which manages the Mitchell Caverns Natural Preserve. An artist working with film director Oliver Stone painted the fake pictographs for a scene in ``The Doors,'' an upcoming movie about rock legend Jim Morrison. Actor Val Kilmer, portraying Morrison, wanders about the 250-foot-long Tecopa Cave in a hallucinatory state and meets a holy man. The scene called for Morrison to study Indian pictographs. State parks officials required the artist to use a powdery substance that could be vacuumed off afterward. But someone apparently used water in the process, causing the substance to seep into the limestone, authorities said. Mitchell Caverns, about 35 miles west of Needles, is known for its spectacular stalagmite, stalactite and other mineral formations created several million years ago. About 10,000 people visit the caves each year. For 500 years, the caves were used by the Chemehuevi Indians for shelter and ceremonial purposes. Needles is near the California-Arizona border, about 225 miles east of downtown Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Watson Becomes Nation's First Pregnant Police Chief of Major City
DOC.TEXT: Houston Police Chief Elizabeth Watson, the nation's first woman chief of a major city, once again made history when she announced she is pregnant. Mrs. Watson, 40, said Wednesday she and her husband, Sgt. Robert Watson, ar expecting their third child Dec. 12. The Watsons have a daughter, Susan, 9, and a son, Mark, 4. Mrs. Watson was appointed chief in January to succeed Lee Brown, the city's first black police chief, who left to run New York City's police force. Mrs. Watson said her pregnancy wouldn't affect her ability to act as chief, as she plans to take the minimum time away from the job and will appoint a temporary chief from her command staff. ``I will be only a phone call away,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: France Announces Nuclear Test in South Pacific
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Ministry announced Thursday that France exploded its second nuclear device in a week at the testing site under Mururoa atoll in the South Pacific. The explosion, early Friday South Pacific time, drew immediate fire from Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer of New Zealand, who said France seemed determined to continue testing no matter what it cost in terms of relations with the South Pacific. The blast released a force of less than 12 kilotons, the ministry said in a communique. That is slightly more than half the power of the World War II bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. A kiloton is equal to the explosive force of 1,000 tons of TNT. On Saturday, France made its first announcement of a nuclear explosion in 15 years after detonating a 15-kiloton device. President Francois Mitterrand pledged a new policy of openness last month during a visit to French Polynesia. The world previously learned of French tests from New Zealand, which has monitored France's nuclear program from an observation station in the Cook Islands. Palmer commented on Friday, ``From New Zealand's point of view, the only announcement we want to hear is that they are stopping testing.'' He said, ``They already know that their nuclear tests are rejected by all countries of the region. However, we will continue to make this point unmistakably clear every time they explode one of their nuclear devices.'' Premier Michel Rocard said recently France would reduce the number of nuclear tests each year at Mururoa from eight to six.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Jury Selection Slow; Plea Bargain `Increasingly Unlikely'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to update with 37 now in jury pool, ``In the,'' Please note that a0684 should have been slugged 1st Ld sted 2nd
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson met with Marion Barry Thursday and said later the embattled mayor was ``open to talks'' on a plea bargain agreement on his drug and perjury charges. Meanwhile, jury selection dragged on for a fourth day in U.S. District Court, and it is expected to continue well into next week. Jackson, in a televised interview, said of Barry, ``He is open to talks as opposed to a drawing-the-line situation. ... I am rather convinced the mayor is inclined to ... do something to break the cycle and break the tension.'' At the same time, Barry's spokeswoman, Lurma Rackley, said the mayor had no intention of announcing in the next day or two that he would not seek re-election. She said she asked Barry about reports to that effect, and he told her, ``If you hold your breath, you'll die.'' Negotiations leading to a guilty plea on one or more of the 14 charges Barry faces have stalled, according to sources close to Barry's legal team. ``We're nowhere right now,'' said one source familiar with the negotiations between Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy and U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens. ``It's increasingly unlikely that we will have any agreement soon,'' said the source, who commented only on condition of anonymity. Talk of a possible plea bargain dominated attention at the trial Wednesday after Jackson publicly urged Barry to announce he would not run for a fourth term. Jackson suggested such a statement would nudge prosecutors toward allowing Barry to plead guilty to a drug-possession misdemeanor rather than one of the three perjury felony counts he faces. Pleading guilty to a felony would bar Barry from holding office or running for re-election and would make a jail sentence more likely. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor charges of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged drug use. Meanwhile, Jackson associates said the civil rights leader and former Democratic presidential hopeful has been urging Barry privately for six weeks to abandon his re-election plans and seek a plea bargain agreement. According to sources close to both men, Barry wants Jackson to run for mayor if he steps aside, and Jackson does not want to do so. However, Barry's spokeswoman later denied that the mayor was urging Jackson to succeed him. ``That's totally, totally untrue,'' Ms. Rackley said. Jackson, who moved to Washington last year, flirted with a candidacy before announcing in February he would not run for mayor. Mundy would not comment on the plea bargain issue during a lunch break from the jury selection process of the trial. In court, questioning of prospective jurors continued slowly. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson is going alphabetically through a list of more than 200 people who have filled out questionnaires for the Barry case. Jackson plans to review all 200-plus applications and have lawyers for the two sides question them rather than stopping with a pool of 40 to 45 people as is more customary. The shorter approach for picking a jury pool _ from which a panel of 12 jurors and six alternates would be chosen _ was used in the recent high-profile trials of Oliver North and John Poindexter. Jackson himself used such an approach in the case of former White House aide Michael Deaver. In the Barry case, 37 people have been sent into the jury pool so far. Also on Thursday, the American Civil Liberties Union said it will file a brief with the judge asking him to reject any plea bargain that includes Barry's resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Former Soldier Arrested in Tampa; Accused of Spying
URGENT
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents arrested a former soldier in Tampa, Fla. Thursday on spying charges, FBI headquarters said Thursday night. The arrested man, Roderick James Ramsay, was accused of supplying military secrets of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to a foreign country while serving in 8th Infantry Division headquarters at Bad Kreuznach, West Germany, said the FBI announcement. The case was an outgrowth of the invesigation of Clyde Lee Conrad, a retired U.S. Army sergeant convicted of treason by a West German court earlier this week and sentenced to life in prison, the FBI said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Decry Logging Policies At Kickoff Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators, some dressed as trees, launched Redwood Summer on Thursday with a protest at a lumber-export company, promising to ``put their bodies on the line'' to block cutting of virgin timber. The 50 demonstrators were matched one-for-one by police who are on edge because of a bombing that injured two members of Earth First!, the group organizing the summer of protest. The demonstrators gathered at the Port of Sacramento outside Gene West Inc., which exports logs to China, Korea, and Japan. Speakers, some in tree garb, decried what they said is over-harvesting of timber and cutting of old-growth redwoods. They said logging companies are racing deadlines, including environmental protection measures on California's November ballot and possiblity that logging of redwoods could be curtailed by an endangered-species designation for the spotted owl, which lives among the big trees. ``Over 150 acres of old-growth timber a day are being cut. It's time for us to stop asking and start demanding that they stop it,'' said David Orr, 32, a University of California at Davis employee. ``Earth First! participants are willing to put their bodies on the line to stop the devastation.'' Protesters' varied ranks stretched from students to housewives, and from perennial activists to environmental demonstration newcomers. ``I am not a liberal. I have a job. I am a mainstream American and I am equally concerned about our resources,'' said Edwin Reidel, a 21-year-old college student with trim hair and wearing a suit. ``This is no joke. The time has come for everyone to express their concern.'' Between speakers, demonstrators waved a large American flag and chanted such slogans as, ``Save our forests,'' and, ``No more exports.'' They held hand-fashioned signs that said: ``Logs are jobs. Keep 'em here,'' ``Stop log exports,'' and ``Support sustainable yield.'' A spokesman for the port said Gene West Inc. exports only low-quality white fir and diseased trees, taken from the Sierra Nevada, that would not normally be milled in the United States anyway. Protesters had planned to interfere with loading of logs aboard a ship bound for Japan, but the vessel left Wednesday, port officials said. The environmentalists are planning widespread protests in coming months called Redwood Summer. The Earth First! organizers said they hope to reproduce the environmental equivalent of Freedom Summer, the 1964 voter registration campaign centered in Mississippi that ld to the 1965 Voting Rights Act. That summer was marked by violence, including the murder of three civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnappers Release Photo of Abducted American Engineer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 6-7, `In Illinois...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with father saying $35,000 raised, family has received similar photos. Pickup 8th pvs, `The family...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Raising Ransom, Bjt
LaserPhoto QTO1
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers have released a photograph of an American mining engineer, surrounded in the jungle by armed guards, and are demanding $60,000 ransom for his safe return. Scott Heimdal, 27, was abducted April 28 in a boat near the Colombian border and is believed held in Colombian territory. Members of his family in Peoria, Ill., say the kidnappers, reportedly leftist Colombian guerrillas, are demanding the money by Monday. The manager of the mining company where Heimdal worked said Thursday that the kidnappers and representatives from Heimdal's family have met five times, and he said without elaboration that negotiations were going well. The manager, Jeffrey Fino, showed a color photograph of Heimdal sent by the kidnappers to show he is alive. In the photo, Heimdal is sitting down, encircled by several armed men. He appears relaxed, and in the foreground is a carton of cigarettes and a can of food. U.S. and Ecuadoran officials would not comment on negotiations between the kidnappers and family representatives. In Illinois, his father, Roy Heimdal, said Thursday night the family had received 10 photographs of his son recently, and he speculated that the photo released in Ecuador could have been from the same roll of film. He said about $35,000 of the $60,000 ransom had been raised after the family made a televised plea for help to obtain the money. His wife, Marge Heimdal, said the kidnappers, reportedly members of the pro-Cuban Popular Liberation Army guerrillas, have threatened to ``show us where his body is'' unless they are paid before their Monday deadline. The family said the money will be given to an unidentified intermediary, who will carry the money into the jungles along the Ecuador-Colombia border where their son was kidnapped. ``This has been like a nightmare,'' Mrs. Heimdal said in her home. ``It's not easy to strip your soul in front of the whole country. We're trying to keep our dignity. But we had no other way to save our son than to go public like this.'' A U.S. diplomatic source said Heimdal was in Colombian territory. ``We assume that his life is in danger,'' the source said on condition of anonymity. A senior government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``We must to be very careful. We are talking about a very difficult case. ``Remember that Mr. Heimdal was abducted in Ecuador, near the Ecuadoran-Colombian border, but he was immediately taken into Colombian territory by his captors,'' the official added. Heimdal and four others were traveling by motorboat on the Bermeja River, about six miles from the border, when they were ambushed by armed guerrillas. The guerrillas killed the pilot, injured another in the party and kidnapped Heimdal. Heimdal has worked the past two years at a dredging operation for Iminco Co., a gold-mining company near the border.

DOC.HEAD: Grounded Tanker Spills 260,000 Gallons Of Oil, Crewman Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with crewman pleading innocent, CORRECT name to Gregory Frederick Geoffrey sted Geoffrey Frederick Gregory and hometown to Merkse sted Merskey, in keeping with court papers. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Drug tests...' SUBS 15th graf pvs, `The cargo...' to add detail on vessel's ownership.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NR2; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: An oil tanker ran aground Thursday, spilling 260,000 gallons of heating oil into a busy shipping channel between New Jersey and New York, and the first mate was arrested for substance abuse. It was the fifth major oil spill in the area since January. Football-size globs of oil washed ashore on both sides of the Kill Van Kull waterway, which was closed to ships after the tanker BT Nautilus hit bottom while docking Thursday morning. Bathing beaches on New Jersey's Atlantic shore weren't expected to be affected, officials said. The first mate, identified in court documents as Gregory Frederick Geoffrey, 52, of Merkse, England, pleaded innocent Thursday night to charges of operating a vessel under the influence of alcohol or drugs and negligent discharge of a pollutant without a permit. His attorney, Richard F. X. Regan, said after the evening arraignment, ``It appears that my client is really a scapegoat, at this point in time, for what appears to be an accident.'' Christopher Florentz, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo, said he didn't know if Geoffrey was accused of using alcohol or drugs. Officials didn't immediately disclose what role Geoffrey had in guiding the tanker. Bayonne Municipal Court Judge Frank T. Carpenter III set bail at $50,000 and ordered the ship to surrender Geoffrey's passport. Drug tests were ordered for other ship workers and the harbor pilot who was on board to help steer the ship to dock. Oil leaked for almost five hours from the ship, which was carrying 12 million gallons of heating fuel, said Coast Guard Rear Adm. Richard Rybacki in Boston. Divers found a gash about 30 feet long and 12 to 16 inches wide in one of the ship's tanks, Rybacki said. The tank holds 1.2 million gallons. New York Lt. Gov. Stan Lundine, after a helicopter tour of the area with New York Environmental Conservation Commissioner Thomas Jorling, called the spill serious. ``There are areas on beaches and in coves which are clearly contaminated with this very heavy oil,'' he said. The recent rash of spills in Kill Van Kull and connecting Arthur Kill have brought harsh criticism of the oil industry from environmentalists and state officials. The waterways separate New Jersey from New York's Staten Island, and lie along a heavily industrialized area. New York Attorney General Robert Abrams said his office was conducting civil and criminal investigations into the spill. Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Gene Hoff said booms were strung around the ship to contain the floating oil. Vacuum and skimming equipment were being used to clean up the slick, and up to 300 workers were expected to use rakes, shovels and absorbent material to clean the shoreline. ``It looks like mud, really disgusting,'' said Margaret Capuana of Jersey City, who went to a park at the southern tip of Bayonne to see the crippled tanker. The tanker is owned by Nautilus Motor Tanker of Gibraltar, and operated by Bulk Tanker Management of London. The vessel is registered in Hong Kong. Richard Bartha, a Rutgers University microbiology professor, said the waterways have suffered such environmental destruction in recent months that only birds were likely to suffer serious harm. ``There is little living in the water anymore, because the water quality is so bad,'' he said. Thursday's spill prompted New York and New Jersey members of Congress to ask that House Speaker Thomas Foley add a proposal to require double hulls on oil tankers into an oil spill bill being considered by a House-Senate committee. The waterways have been plagued with major oil spills this year. On Jan. 1-2, 567,000 gallons of oil leaked into the Arthur Kill from a ruptured Exxon underwater pipeline. On Feb. 28, 30,000 gallons of heating oil spilled into the Kill Van Kull from a barge anchored in Bayonne. A day later, nearly 4,000 gallons of heavy crude oil spilled into the Arthur Kill at Exxon's refinery in Linden. About a week later, more than 100,000 gallons of heating oil was dumped in the Arthur Kill near Linden from a barge that exploded and caught fire.

DOC.HEAD: Colombians Protest U.S. Decision to Keep Colombia Out of Accord
DOC.TEXT: Officials, newspapers and businessmen on Thursday protested a U.S. decision to keep Colombia out of an international trade agreement. The decision by Washington came one day after President Bush promised to help the country fight its drug war. The United States on Wednesday decided not to give Colombia preferential treatment under the Subsidies Code of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, GATT. Colombia sends 40 percent of its exports to the United States. Angry Colombians called the decision hostile, since the United States had said it would help the country defeat its violent drug traffickers. On Tuesday, Bush met with President Virgilio Barco in Washington and reiterated the U.S. pledge to aid Colombia economically. The President of the National Association of Exporters, Ricardo Sala Gaitan, on Thursday called the U.S. rejection a ``a slap in the face.'' ``There is a contradiction that can only be called spectacular between the smiles of President Bush in the photographs with President Barco and the attitude of his own government,'' he said in an interview with the RCN radio network. The Subsidies Code would require U.S. companies to prove they had been damaged by Colombian exports before any trade sanctions could be applied. Under the current arrangement, if U.S. companies claim injury, the burden rests on Colombia to prove otherwise. A U.S. embassy spokesman told The Associated Press that U.S. policy is not to admit countries into the Subsidies Code unless there exists a bilateral agreement governing subsidies. ``Every new country has to have a bilateral agreement with us in which they agree to phase out their own export subsidies,'' the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Colombian Development Minister Maria Mercedes de Martinez said in a news conference that 30 countries approved Colombia's request in Geneva to join the Subsidies Code, but that the United States rejected it. Martinez was quoted in the Bogota daily El Espectador as saying, ``the decision cannot be justified when our country is going through serious difficulties which the rest of the world is well aware of.'' El Espectador itself condemned the decision. ``The North American attitude is a real slight by President Bush, who says he supports Colombia's war against the drug cartels, but makes no effort to demonstrate the sincerity of his words,'' it said. Colombian drug lords have been blamed for killing about 300 people since August, when Barco began a U.S.-backed anti-drug crackdown. Colombia has complained that the United States discriminates against its legal exports such as coffee and flowers, without providing enough support to erradicate drugs. During a February anti-drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, Bush promised the leaders of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru to help reduce their peoples' dependence on the lucrative cocaine trade. Bush agreed this could only happen through building stronger economies.

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact, Declaring `Enemy Image' Over, Begins Transformation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS nine grafs for 17-25 bgng `Havel said...' to ADD name of security conference and CLARIFY reference to Kvitsinsky; pickup graf 26 `Havel and...'
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Warsaw Pact on Thursday began transforming their 35-year-old alliance from a military to a political body, declaring the ``enemy image'' of East and West to be a thing of the past. Members of the Kremlin-led alliance also discussed various roles for a united Germany in Europe, said Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Kvitsinsky, but he indicated there was no agreement. The leaders also declared their ``readiness for constructive cooperation'' with archrival NATO. They said they favor the formation of a new, ``all-European security system and the creation of a single Europe of peace and cooperation,'' without artificial barriers and ``ideological hostility.'' To do this, it has become necessary ``to reconsider the character and functions of the Warsaw Treaty,'' its members said in a declaration adopted at the meeting. New proposals on such a transformation will be drawn up before the end of October. ``The prevailing view was that we have to emphasize the political component in the Warsaw Treaty Organization activities,'' Kvitsinsky said at a news conference. Soviet and East European sources familiar with the thinking of government leaders have said that the envisioned new political structure of the Warsaw Pact would be patterned roughly after the NATO secretariat and council in Brussels, although no firm plans have been disclosed. ``We have to broaden the consultative basis of the Warsaw Treaty Organization activities, and perhaps we should go in the direction of curtailing the military structures,'' Kvitsinsky said. Warsaw Pact members include Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland, Romania and the Soviet Union. Yugoslavia and Albania are no longer members of the pact, which has been criticized by some of its members as outdated, given the pro-democratic reforms in Eastern Europe since 1989. Romanian President Ion Iliescu said the view was unanimous at the meeting to move away from military aspects and focus on the political nature of the organization, founded 35 years ago. ``All the participants spoke in favor of developing and adapting the Treaty on the line of the processes under way in Europe now, so that the development of the political character of the Treaty could be emphasized,'' Iliescu told Soviet television. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, arriving in Prague, said the meeting was ``probably the most important in the history of this body'' because it paved the way for the Warsaw Pact to proceed with the transformation of the security order in Europe. Havel said Czechoslovakia presented the draft of the new order for the Warsaw Pact to its members last week and deputy foreign ministers from the nations worked on it through the night Wednesday and Thursday. ``Participants in the meeting are unanimous in their opinion that the ideological enemy image has been overcome by mutual efforts of the East and the West, while the notions of East and West are again acquiring their purely geographical meaning,'' the declaration said. ``Confrontation elements contained in documents of the Warsaw Treaty and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, that were adopted in the past, are no longer in line with the spirit of the times,'' it said. A provisional commission of government representatives of the member nations will work out proposals on transforming the alliance before the end of October, and the Political Consultative Committee _ the group that met in Moscow on Thursday _ will examine them before the end of November, the declaration said. Havel said he proposed that the committee's plans on a new security order in Europe be put before a 35-nation summit in Paris in December. The Conference on European Security and Cooperation is the successor to the one that issued the 1975 Helsinki Final Act. It also called for the ``full implementation of the basic human rights and freedoms.'' Despite statements before the meeting by Hungarian Prime Minister Joszsef Antall that he wants to remove his country from the alliance, Kvitsinsky said ``there wasn't a single statement made relating to a wish to quit the Warsaw Treaty Organization.'' Havel, too, said he stressed that Czechoslovakia remain in the pact in order to oversee its transformation. Kvitsinsky said that all participants said the Warsaw Pact ``has to be adapted to new circumstances.'' He added that the topic of reorganizing the Warsaw Pact's integrated military command also was brought up. The complex structure places Soviet commanders over member armies in the event of war. The Warsaw Pact members also heard a detailed report by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on his Washington summit last week with President Bush. The possibility of a united Germany being a member of both alliances was raised, Kvitsinsky said, along with other scenarios of its political and military status. Havel and Czechoslovak Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier also indicated there was no agreement on future security arrangements for a united Germany. The Soviets oppose NATO membership for a united Germany, and Gorbachev and Bush failed to resolve their differences over the issue last week.

DOC.HEAD: Smuggled Document Focused on American, NATO Troops, Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 2nd pvs, `Former Army...' to UPDATE with FBI arrest of second U.S. soldier, SUBS grafs 12-13, `ABC News...' with details of arrest. Pickup 14th pvs, `Prechtel denied...'
