DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. soldier convicted of spying for the East bloc leaked documents on NATO and American troops in Europe, the chief federal prosecutor's office said Thursday. Former Army Sgt. 1st Class Clyde Lee Conrad was found guilty of high treason and sentenced to life in prison in West Germany on Wednesday after a court in Koblenz found he had passed classified secrets to Hungary and Czechoslovakia for a decade. Late Thursday, the FBI announced that its agents had arrested another former soldier on spying charges in an outgrowth of the Conrad case. A court in the West German state of Rhineland-Palatinate, in which the spying occurred, found the 43-year-old Conrad guilty of providing classified material to the Hungarian and Czechoslovak secret services from 1975 through 1985. It was the first time a foreign resident living in West Germany had been tried for espionage. It estimated he received $1.2 million for his efforts. The native of Sebring, Ohio, had been in charge of the classified document center at the army's 8th Infantry Division in Bad Krueznach, 50 miles west of Frankfurt, during the majority of his time with the unit. A top official in the chief federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe, Alexander Prechtel, said Thursday that Conrad had turned over ``defense strategic papers'' to the Hungarian and Czechoslovak secret services. The documents concerned NATO and American troops in Germany and Europe, Prechtel said, but he would not elaborate. Of the classified documents Conrad leaked, Prechtel said: ``Normally everything goes to the Soviet Union, but we can only prove the way to Czechoslovakia and Hungary, and the rest is speculation.'' Prechtel said authorities in Czechoslovakia and Hungary had not cooperated in the investigation. ``But that's quite normal. Those countries who are involved in the case, they are not asked to cooperate,'' he said. In Tampa, the FBI arrested another soldier in Conrad's unit, Roderick James Ramsey, and accused him of violating espionage laws against gathering or delivering defense information for a foreign government. FBI Director William S. Sessions said the investigation was one of the most complicated of its kind ever undertaken by the bureau, and the information passed on was ``extremely sensitive.'' In reporting Wednesday night that Ramsay had been targeted by the FBI, ABC News said the espionage ring had smuggled computer parts from the United States to the East Bloc through Canada. Prechtel denied that Conrad was involved in smuggling computer parts. He said West Germans had no other investigation pending in connection with the Conrad case but pointed out that the United States had given West Germany the information for Conrad's prosecution. Because Conrad had retired in West Germany with his German wife and son, he had to be prosecuted by German authorities. U.S. authorities in West Germany referred all questions regarding Conrad and possible other investigations to Washington. Conrad's Bonn-based lawyer, Klaus Huemmerich, said he would appeal the judgment. Chief Judge Ferdinand Schuth said Conrad ``endangered the entire defense capability of the West'' and that the former sergeant was motivated by ``pure greed.'' Had war broken out, the judge said, the information passed by Conrad ``could have led to a breakdown in the defenses of the Western Alliance,'' and ``to capitulation and the use of nuclear weapons on German territory.'' Schuth sentenced Conrad to life imprisonment for spying for the Hungarians. He said Conrad was also guilty of spying for Czechoslovakia on a lesser scale, and he sentenced him to four years in prison on that charge. Conrad was arrested Aug. 23, 1988, on suspicion of heading a West German-based international spy ring with Eastern contacts in Sweden and Vienna, Austria. Conrad, who retired after 20 years in the military, served with the Army from 1965 to September 1985 and had lived in West Germany since his discharge. According to court records, Conrad was introduced to the Hungarian secret service in late autumn 1975 by his supervisor in the 8th Infantry Division, former U.S. Army Sgt. 1st Class Zoltan Szabo. Szabo, who was convicted of espionage in Austria in 1989, received a 10-month suspended sentence. He identified for investigators some of the documents the court said Conrad sold to the Hungarians. Two Hungarians, Sandor Kercsik and his brother, Imre, were described by the court as Conrad's main contacts. The two were arrested in 1988 in Sweden and admitted being agents of the Hungarian secret police. They were sentenced to 18 months in prison for possessing NATO defense material. The Kercsik brothers also provided statements to the Rhineland Palatinate state court with evidence implicating Conrad.

DOC.HEAD: New Florida Theme Park Faces Marketing Challenge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT that park opened Thursday. A version moving on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: Universal Studios Florida held a glitzy Hollywood-style inaugural Thursday in a $630 million gamble that it can compete with entertainment giant Walt Disney World on its own turf. The combination film production center and tourist park also is an important test of whether its parent company, MCA Inc., and partner Rank Organization PLC of London can export the same concept to Europe and Japan _ again following in Disney's footsteps. ``We think there's a terrific market out there'' for high-tech theme parks, said MCA Vice President Jay Stein. ``The foreign prospects are excellent.'' Success here would set the pace for a breakout from MCA's basic business of filmmaking into tourist parks, in this country and overseas. Universal Studio Tour in Los Angeles opened in 1964. But the 444-acre Florida complex is a bigger, more sophisticated version, considered a prototype for the future by company officials. Besides the formidable competition posed by Walt Disney World's three attractions just a few miles down the road from Universal, Disney's also got the jump on foreign shores. Euro Disneyland is scheduled to open outside Paris in 1992 and Tokyo Disneyland has been in operation since 1983. MCA has announced plans for a theme park in Japan, in partnership with Nippon Steel. Stein, who headed the creative team that built the Florida park, said an announcement of a site for MCA-Rank's European enterprise could come within a month. Locations near Paris and London are under consideration, MCA officials say. But much depends on whether Universal can get a healthy portion of the 13 million annual visitors to Central Florida. With a daily capacity of 40,000 to 50,000, MCA expects to host from 5 million to 6 million people its first year. Richard P. Simon, an entertainment analyst for Goldman Sachs in New York, said MCA probably needs only about 3{ million visitors a year to break even. ``I think they'll be profitable in the first full year,'' he said. ``Initially the market will not be large enough to accomodate the large jump in capacity. But I think in time it will be.'' The Disney-MGM Studios, which celebrated its first anniversary May 1, racked up 8 million ``visits'' in its first year. Disney records turnstile counts, meaning some guests can be counted more than once during a visit. Disney has been luring tourists to Central Florida for almost two decades and is one of the industry's top merchandising experts. The Magic Kingdom opened in 1971 and Epcot Center began operating in 1982. The two companies have been caught up in a promotional frenzy in recent weeks, spending money lavishly on radio, television and newspaper advertising as well in the travel-trade press. Universal Studios President Steven Lew said Wednesday that MCA-Rank and its partners in the Orlando attraction will spend a total of $150 million this year in advertising and merchandising the $630 million park. Entertainment analysts say Disney is spending at least $50 million to market all three of the Florida parks this fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: `Prin' Opens Starring Eileen Atkins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned.
DOC.TEXT: A wonderful actress named Eileen Atkins is playing the title role in ``Prin,'' which is more an interesting character study than a play. ``Prin,'' by Andrew Davies, opened at off-Broadway's Manhattan Theater Club on Wednesday. Davies' ``Rose'' starred Glenda Jackson on Broadway nearly a decade ago and also was about a teacher. ``Prin'' upgrades its title character to principal of an English teacher-training college specializing in science, dance and physical education. It is to Davies' credit that he maintains suspense in the midst of several different situations. The play starts slowly, in the principal's office, with Prin urging vice principal Dorothy Dibs, played with wan charm by Amy Wright, to mimicry and flights of fancy. It's clear, though they don't say so untill later, that they're lovers. Prin had chosen the younger woman from a dance class. Dorothy would still like to be called Dorothy, but Prin, who plows through life ignoring other people's desires _ even those of someone she loves _ calls Dorothy ``Little Dibs.'' It's clear that Dorothy isn't a committed lesbian and probably is about to leave Prin for a man. It's also clear that the college will go under, merging with either a university or a technical school. Prin might have a formidable personality that could intimidate a board of directors but she doesn't rely on that. It's inconceivable to Prin that the college will fold. Living largely in her imagination and without a single ace in her hand, she simply believes that she'll win through. Early in Act 1, Prin speaks to graduates. ``You are, all of you, excellent.'' She tells them that teachers can show children how to be extraordinary and change the world. It's clear she has devoted her life to that belief. Less admirably, Prin is elitist, really interested only in people with superior minds, the ``prima donnas'' as opposed to the ``job lots.'' Prin's life does crash and crumble, and Atkins brilliantly puts her heartbreak in her face. But Prin's blunt approach to life and her beliefs sustain her. Out of a job, she is seen at the end lecturing to a group whose name she doesn't know. ``You look a pretty rum bunch,'' she tells them. Then, as fervently as she had with the college graduates, she lectures them about the holiness of the heart's affections, the truth of the imagination and the pursuit of the extraordinary. John Curless and John Christopher Jones were good as teachers. Wendy Makkena squirmed nicely as a promiscuous student with low self-esteem. Remak Ramsay played the merger sponsor. He seemed uncomfortable telling Prin he'd always hated her, possibly one too many emotions from the author. John Lee Beatty designed the set. John Tillinger directed.

Lawmakers are threatening to block exports of U.S. high technology to the Soviet Union until it ends its economic blockade of Lithuania. By a 390-24 vote Thursday, the House voted to bar the sale of U.S. computers and telecommunications gear needed to modernize the Soviet economy until Moscow begins negotiating Lithuania's independence ``without economic coercion.'' On a voice vote, the House also agreed to ban high-tech sales to the Soviet Union if it continues to restrict Jewish emigration. ``While the Soviet president put out one hand in requesting aid from the United States, the other hand is wrapped tightly around the neck of Lithuania,'' said Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Pro-choice Republicans won a trio of platform victories at recent state party conventions and expect still more states to part ways with the national GOP's anti-abortion plank this year. Republicans in Maine and New York have adopted pro-choice state platform provisions, and Wisconsin Republicans voted down an anti-abortion plank that would have called for legal protection ``for all human beings, from conception on.'' With the convention season just beginning, more state parties will be taking up platform language or resolutions in coming weeks that depart from the national GOP's platform opposition to abortion. The actions have the indirect blessing of national Republicans, as they test Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater's assertion that the party is a ``big tent'' with room for differing views on abortion.

State medical regulators have joined prosecutors in investigating Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the suicide-machine inventor treading the line separating outsider from outlaw. The Department of Licensing and Regulation launched a probe Wednesday of the 62-year-old retired pathologist who hooked an Alzheimer's victim to the drug-injecting apparatus and let her take her life with the press of a button. ``Our role is to gather the facts and evidence and determine what occurred,'' said Mary MacDowell, director of the department's Health Investigation Division. Evidence of a violation of regulations would be referred to the state Board of Medicine, which could reprimand Kevorkian or lift his license, MacDowell said.

Tens of thousands of immigrants paid millions of dollars to Panamanian officials led by Manuel Noriega to use that nation as an illegal gateway to the United States and Canada, U.S. immigration officials allege. ``They ran the most sophisticated organization we have ever seen. Nobody ever operated an alien-smuggling operation to the extent of Panama,'' said Robert Harris, chief criminal investigator for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami. INS officials have enough evidence against Noriega to indict him, but they and federal prosecutors don't want to interfere with the drug trafficking case against him, Harris said. The office of U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen acknowledged it is investigating the alien-smuggling allegations. But in a statement Wednesday, Lehtinen denied any indictment is now contemplated against the former dictator.

From 3.8 billion miles, the Earth is a blue dot in an ocean of black. ``On that blue dot, that's where everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever lived, lived out their life,'' astronomer Carl Sagan said Wednesday as NASA released an extraordinary photo taken from a vantage point in deep space. Voyager 1, speeding toward the edge of the solar system, looked back in February and snapped photos of six of the nine planets that whirl around the sun. The photograph, actually a mosaic of 64 images taken in a four-hour period, was the last from the spacecraft. The pictures were recorded Feb. 13-14 but were not played back to Earth until late March because deep-space radio receivers were occupied with higher priority tasks.

DOC.HEAD: Beirut's Criminal Justice System Has a Backlog
DOC.TEXT: Because of the shelling, judges seldom hold people in jail awaiting trial, but artillery fire also keeps judges and lawyers away from work, so an accused can wait a long time for his day in court. Murder, burglary and other crimes still are against the law after 15 years of ruinous civil war, but the battle often overruns what remains of the criminal justice system. Months of fighting trapped about 420 prisoners being held on charges of murder, theft and drug trafficking. The showdown between Christian factions led by Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea has taken nearly 1,000 lives and wounded more than 2,500 people since Jan. 30. A lawyer who fled to Moslem west Beirut said judicial authorities were unable to meet to consider dozens of cases of people awaiting prosecution for common crimes. ``They were arrested and jailed, and now their fate depends on the situation,'' said the lawyer. The Palace of Justice, where the meetings normally are held, is on the confrontation line between Geagea's areas of influence and Aoun's terrain. It is subject to constant sniper fire and shelling. ``We have been trying to form a committee, to meet anywhere, in order to take a decision to release the prisoners on bail pending a trial when security conditions permit,'' said the judge, who demanded anonymity like the others interviewed. ``I switched on the TV one night and saw gunmen sniping from my office at the Palace of Justice. We obviously cannot meet there.'' According to the lawyer, some colleagues paid quick visits to the Palace of Justice to hide or remove files, ``but it is not possible to operate normally from there.'' The jails are in the most heavily shelled areas of Roumieh, Baabda and Furn el-Shubbak, all held by Aoun, the judge said. Roumieh prison is the biggest. Aoun's main howitzer batteries are deployed in a wooded valley around it, partially protected from Geagea's fire. ``The prisons are so crowded and in such dangerous areas that, whenever we can meet, we try to release most of the detainees who have committed minor offenses on bail set at a minimal amount,'' the judge said. ``We also have no wards to treat drug addicts, so again we tend to set them free on bail because if we place them in prison, they'll be more corrupted by other prisoners.'' Few jails have bomb shelters and the guards generally flee when shelling starts. About fifty inmates escaped from a prison in Moslem west Beirut last year when artillery fire knocked down cell walls during Aoun's six-month battle with Syrian soldiers and their Moslem allies. Only about 30 were caught. The Christian feud has stopped family visits to prisoners, and telephones went dead months ago. ``The lack of security also means prisoners could receive visitors only during lulls in the fighting,'' the judge said. ``Those who have family and friends in Geagea-controlled areas haven't had visitors since the clashes began.'' The judge said some prisoners who finished their terms might be safer in jail, but were not allowed to stay. ``If they are known to have been Geagea supporters before they were imprisoned, they're in trouble, for the prisons are in an area under Aoun's control,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Books and Authors: The Counterfeit Author
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Open the wallet of Louis B. Jones and you'll find a California driver's license, a slip of yellow paper, scribbled messages and a counterfeit $20 bill. The bill is printed on typing paper, stained by tea. It's dated 1985 and has the signature of then Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker III on the lower right-hand side. You can tell it's fake by scratching it against a hard surface and watching the ink run off. Also, the green is much paler than real currency. No, Jones is not a crook, and he's not playing a board game. Jones is a writer. The fake bill was part of research for his first novel, ``Ordinary Money'' ($18.95, Viking), in which the author imagines the serious conseqences of a little funny money. ``A catalyst was Andre Gide's novel, `The Counterfeiters,''' said the author, a native of Chicago who now lives in Mill Valley, Calif. ``It's about a bunch of children, one of whom runs away from home. Gide seems to think money is the devil. It's about modern, sensible people who don't think the devil exists even though it passes through his fingers every day.'' ``Ordinary Money'' is a morality play complete with fake limbs, real love, near adultery and ever present federal agents. The real, the unreal and the surreal mix like coins in a piggy bank. Wayne Paschke is trying to be sensible, but it's not easy. He knows about bills, real bills, the kind that arrive at the first of the month. A resident of California's Marin County, Wayne's has a wife, a teen-age daughter, another kid on the way and a less-than-promising career painting houses. He's willing to take some chances to make money, even try something a little silly, like selling coins over the telephone. In this practical man's garage sits a wooden crate crammed with $20 bills, printed on paper so authentic that even the Feds think it's real. It's a gift from his best friend Randy Potts, ``a government unto himself'' looking to get rich with the speed of his ill-gotten red Ferrari. The author makes a cameo appearance. Randy has received the money from his boss, a mysterious man who meets with him in parking lots of fast-food restaurants and offers instructions on how to pass the bucks. Jones named the boss ``Auctor.'' ```The Latin name for author is auctor,'' Jones explained. ``The fact that we're both in the business of inventing images was very much on my mind. When I go in a bookstore and see my book next to Thomas Pynchon's, I feel like a counterfeiter.'' Like Wayne, Jones has stumbled a few times himself, writing several unpublished novels, heading for New York to become an author and leaving ``scared, defeated, brokenhearted about my possibilities.'' In ``Ordinary Money,'' Jones writes: ``The old Wayne Paschke would have found Marketrend ridiculous. But exactly when things seemed most absurd, that was the moment when the successful man plunges forward without admitting the possibility of defeat, almost irrationally.'' Jones admits he's also taken some awkward plunges. ``When I was 17 or 18, I got involved with something called `Bestline,' which is something like Amway. Bestline is soap. You studied this book about self-esteem, and go to these meeting and stir a lot of enthusiasm. ``What you're competing for is the Cadillac, a bonus Cadillac. If you get enough points you get a pink Cadillac. I really kind of believed it for two months, like Wayne. It was a happy mistake. I learned by becoming someone else, living with different values. It was a kind of schizophrenic experience.'' Research for ``Ordinary Money'' began in 1985 when Jones set up various bleaches on his kitchen counter, printed specimens on typing paper and trimmed them with a paper cutter. Two years later, he took another plunge. Jones headed for the Bureau of Engraving and Printing in Washington, enduring the occasional eviction by angry security guards as he sought official advice on how to break the bank. On paper, at least, Jones succeeds, writing of computer-driven lasers, argon lasers and flying spot scanners, making the process of counterfeiting seem as simple as selling detergent. In real life, however, the author reports that he can do no better than invent the perfect crime. ``It's unhappy. I hate to be the man who says there's no Mary Poppins,'' said Jones, holding a real bill in his hands. ``But the perfect counterfeit bill is not yet a technological possibility. It almost is.''

DOC.HEAD: Twisting The FHA Insurance Program
DOC.TEXT: One reason why the government's mortgage insurance program could go broke is that in some respects it has been skewed to reward those who don't need it and deny those who do. It is just one of many defects in the nation's public housing program, many of which developed during the tenure of Samuel Pierce Jr., the former secretary of housing and urban development. It is also another chapter in a big book, of how another well-intended government program, one that theoretically could make home-ownership more possible for the poor, becomes twisted in the practical application. That twist has helped produce some incredible losses in the single-family home-mortgage program. The Federal Housing Administration's single-family mortgage programs, for example, lost more than $1 billion in 1988. Critics, to be found everywhere _ in Congress, in the FHA itself, among lenders and among neighborhood action groups _ fear that by the end of the decade the government insurance program could become another S&L debacle. That financial disaster, for those who need reminding, could cost American taxpayers as much as a half-trillion dollars, and some blame for it can be attributed to poor government supervision and regulation. The FHA mortgage insurance program, like government guarantees on deposits in now insolvent savings and loan associations, is also victimized by some lax regulation, bad loans and favoritism toward certain borrowers. Designed with middle-income and low-income homebuyers in mind, it has in some instances become a financing tool for yuppies who, it often turns out, may be poorer risks than the poor. That, at least, is what the figures show. ``Providing 100 percent insurance on loans to yuppies in speculative housing markets is a sure-fire recipe for a new federal bailout, this time of the FHA,'' says Gale Cincotta, chairman of National People's Action. To Cincotta, an authority on community reinvestment and housing _ she was appointed by HUD Secretary Jack Kemp to a commission on affordable housing _ this is but one of many distortions of the Federal Housing Administration program, but a very significant one. Why should 100 percent government-insured loans be going to yuppies with good incomes, and who have the option of obtaining a variety of other loans, rather than to the more needy, who have little or no other choice? That, however, is the situation, and that situation has still another dimension: The bigger loans, such as those that Cincotta says go to the yuppies, often have the highest foreclosure rate. She refers to studies, one by the Mortgage Insurance Companies of American in 1989 and another just completed by the United Guaranty Residential Insurance Corp., that demonstrate this correlation on privately insured mortgages. She maintains that much the same pattern applies to FHA loans, that is, the larger they are the stronger becomes the correlation with foreclosure. And the reverse: The smaller the loan, the smaller the foreclosure ratio. But why should FHA-insured loans go to the more rather than less affluent? Because, she says, while the federal government might lose on them, the lenders and brokers who originate the loans find them more profitable. Many mortgage companies imposed minimum loan amounts on FHA loans, even in violation of the law. They do it simply by refusing to make loans under $25,000 and by adding on points to loans under a certain amount, such as $40,000. NPA demonstrated this by calling the top five Veterans Administration and FHA mortgage lenders in Chicago, Philadelphia, Cleveland and Milwaukee. All employed minimum loan amounts or points for the smallest loans. The reason why is understandable if not defendable: Every origination fee a mortgage banker receives is a percentage of the size of the loan. The larger the loan, the bigger the fee. The FHA sought to encourage smaller loans, such as those to poorer people most in need of FHA help, by raising the annual servicing fee on the smaller loans, but it apparently wasn't enough to turn the tide. ``It's outrageous that federal programs like FHA are being used to discriminate against and rip off lower income and minority home buyers,'' says Cincotta. Cincotta's Chicago-based organization is a foundation-supported coalition of more than 200 housing groups. It is allied with the National Training and Information Center, which develops and teaches ways to preserve neighborhoods.

DOC.HEAD: Cold War Thaw Topic of `Other Summit'
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Meanwhile, back at the other summit, the thawed Cold War is a factor, too. Budget negotiators have their sights on military spending, and want to know how much more it can be cut because of what the diplomats have done. The link between the budget summit and the superpower summit _ said to have marked the end of the Cold War era _ is not as clear and direct as Democratic leaders want to make it, so as to press the case for sharp Pentagon spending cuts. At the budget talks Bush convened with a White House sendoff a month ago, there's no sign of a breakthrough any time soon. Those discussions have settled into a routine that may keep the negotiators at it most of the summer. They haven't yet started bargaining on specific steps to save or raise funds in order to reach the legal limit on this year's deficit, and avoid an election-time slash in federal programs across the board. Such automatic spending cuts have happened before, but this time, the administration says the cuts would be so drastic that voters would feel the impact _ and congressional election candidates might, too. The deficit limit is $64 billion. The budget summit is seeking agreement on steps to get close to that target, with deficit estimates now ranging over $200 billion. So far, most of their time has been spent on technical questions _ basically, on starting points for negotiation. The negotiating teams for Congress and the White House have agreed to meet daily from now on, instead of convening twice a week. They have yet to determine how much money has to be saved and raised in order to meet the legal limit and avoid punishing cuts next fall. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, has just issued a Democratic study contending that overly optimistic administration forecasts mask the real size of deficits over the next five years. ``If the budget agreement is not based on realistic and prudent assumptions, the result will be an empty declaration of victory,'' Hamilton said. Any declaration of victory, hollow or otherwise, is a long way away. This summit and the superpower summit reached something of a common denominator when Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser, talked with the budget bargainers last week. That prompted the question of whether the diplomatic summit had produced accords that would prompt defense spending moves at the budget summit, but the White House wasn't answering. ``We aren't willing to discuss any specifics of the budget negotiations,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the president's press secretary. Cheney wasn't bargaining on the administration's $303.3 billion defense budget, which Democratic critics say is too high for a time of easing international tensions. But he did agree to produce a Pentagon study of what would happen to the defense budget should military force levels be cut by 25 percent over the next five years. He said the Pentagon already is analyzing that option. That study doesn't mean the administration would sign off on such cuts and again, as on the overall question of deficit projections, the starting point for negotiation is not yet settled. Cheney and his Pentagon planners contend that ebbing Cold War tensions and steadily reduced defense spending already are factored in to their budget projections. ``The military budget has declined in real terms since 1985,'' Secretary of the Air Force Donald B. Rice told the Detroit Economic Club last month. ``Based on the president's budget ... defense has already been cut 12 to 13 percent in purchasing power. ``Our internal planning, under Secretary Cheney's guidance, will bring the Department of Defense to a total real decline of 22 percent by 1997,'' he said. Defense outlays at that point would account for their lowest share of federal spending since before Pearl Harbor, even without the cuts Congress is certain to make. By Pentagon count, over the 10 years beginning in 1985, defense budget reductions will total $515 billion. Rice said Pentagon planners began factoring a peace dividend into their projections five years ago. Those arguments don't take with Democratic leaders and with some Republicans in Congress; they think there's much more to be cut out of military spending in the quest for a long-term budget and deficit settlement.

DOC.HEAD: In Barry Case, Say Some Blacks, `Selective Prosecution' Is at Play
DOC.TEXT: Ever since Adam Clayton Powell, the flamboyant playboy-preacher from Harlem, was driven from his House seat in 1967, black leaders have seen a conspiracy at work. For years they've said that the white power structure singles out any black politician who threatens the status quo _ and some who don't _ for relentless investigation and costly prosecution. Washington Mayor Marion Barry Jr., on trial on drug and perjury charges after an elaborate FBI sting, they say, is just the latest victim of ``selective prosecution.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh denies that government prosecutors targeted Barry or that they go after black politicians. ``We follow the evidence wherever it leads, regardless of position, race, party affiliation or other identifying factors,'' Thornburgh said in January. He was responding to Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the NAACP, who pictured Barry as a victim of selective law enforcement. Hooks remains unconvinced. In an interview, he estimated that 80 percent of the black people in Washington share the perception that Barry has been singled out. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens suggested that the government paid extraordinary attention to the Barry case _ after years of rumors that he was using drugs _ because, as mayor, Barry was a role model for the black youth of Washington. In court, Stephens called Barry's arrest ``a personal tragedy for the defendant'' but added: ``Narcotics abuse is also a tragedy for this city. Narcotics abuse is not a victimless crime.'' The issue of whether Barry had been singled out because of his race came to dominate the jury selection process last week at his trial. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson asked prospective jurors if they believe the law is selectively enforced. Many of the blacks said they did. ``It seems like some people are made to go through a little more than others,'' said one, a gospel singer. ``They televised this too much, talked about it too much. ... I think race had a lot to do with it, as far as giving him a hard time.'' The judge asked if a white mayor would have been spared prosecution under similar circumstances. ``Exactly,'' she said. ``The masses of the people out there understand what is going on,'' says Clarence Mitchell III, former Maryland state legislator and one-time colleague with Barry in the 1960s civil rights organization, the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. ``The media can say Barry's lifestyle is not appropriate but the masses of people perceive that if Marion Barry were white we would not be reading anything about him,'' says Mitchell. Mitchell says he, too, became a victim of selective prosecution as he was running in a primary for the nomination to a congressional seat vacated by his uncle, Parren Mitchell. Mitchell lost the nomination. He and his brother, Michael _ scions of a prominent black family and son of civil rights leader Clarence Mitchell Jr. _ were subsequently convicted of taking a bribe to block an investigation by Parren Mitchell's House Small Business Committee. At the sentencing, their mother, Juanita Jackson Mitchell, alluded to their claim that they were victims of an FBI vendetta against black leaders. ``My sons are casualties on the road to freedom,'' she said. Thus, say black leaders, the Mitchells joined a long list of black politicians who had been singled out. On the list: Mayors Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, Coleman Young of Detroit, and Richard Arrington of Birmingham, Ala.; former Mayors Carl Stokes of Cleveland, Kenneth Gibson of Newark, N.J., and Charles Evers of Fayette, Miss.; Reps. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., Harold Ford, D-Tenn., and Louis Stokes, D-Ohio; and former Reps. Shirley Chisholm, D-N.Y. and Charles Diggs, D-Mich. Hooks says, ``If they had accused Barry of stealing millions, creating a slush fund, awarding corrupt contracts, that would be one thing. But a personal habit that is bad, dangerous, lethal, that makes him a bad role model? There are 4 million people out there doing it. If there are 4 million, why did they pick out one and stick on his case for eight years?'' Hooks is careful to say he is not passing judgment on Barry's guilt or innocence. Instead, he draws an analogy: ``If everyone is going 80 miles an hour on the highway, and you're doing 70 and the cops stop you, you've got to wonder.'' ``What I'm trying to say is the perception is there,'' he says, ``and the government has a right to dispel the perception if it isn't true.'' Adds Joann Watson, who heads the National YWCA's Office of Racial Justice: ``We are not supporting _ quote _ `corrupt' politicians.'' Joseph Agne, consultant to the National Council of Churches, says he sees a motive behind selective prosecution: ``This is one way to get around the gains from the Voting Rights Act,'' whose enactment raised the number of black elected officials from the scores to the thousands. But lawyer Richard A. Samp, chief counsel for the conservative Washington Legal Foundation, says prosecutors lack the resources to bring charges against every lawbreaker. He says it makes sense for them to focus first on officeholders. Blacks aren't singled out, he says, but since there is likely to be more corruption at the local level, and ``given that much of the black electoral success to date has been at the local level, it is perhaps not surprising that blacks have been included among the targets of these corruption probes.'' And Louis Michael Seidman, law professor at Georgetown University, points to a 19th century Supreme Court decision that selective prosecution _ of prominent wealthy people on tax charges, for example _ is permissible, as long as it is not based on such things as race or religion. Now that Barry has admitted he used crack cocaine at the Vista Hotel on Jan. 18, his only recourse is to persuade a jury that he was unfairly singled out, says Seidman. ``In reality, that is his defense,'' says Seidman. Barry seemed to be saying as much when he told The Washington Post on May 28, ``I think the prosecutors know that in this town all it takes is one juror saying: `I'm not going to convict Marion Barry, I don't care what you say.''' Mary R. Sawyer, assistant professor of religious studies at Iowa State University in Ames, has been studying the question of selective prosecution for years. ``What is happening to black elected officials today is only marginally different from what happened to black activists in the black power and black civil right eras and to what happened to blacks during Jim Crow segregation days and what happened to blacks during slavery,'' Ms. Sawyer said. ``In each instance, the leaders were singled out, there was a double standard, there were steps taken to intimidate and terminate effective strategies for social change.''

DOC.HEAD: Plan To Escalate Drug War Provokes Debate in Bolivia
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Plans to involve the army in fighting drugs, which the United States supports, have many Bolivians worried that a largely peaceful law-enforcement effort will become a bloody war like the one in Colombia. Proponents say only the military can control the vast, lawless areas where cocaine traffickers now operate with impunity. Few shots have been fired in Bolivia's campaign against narcotics, and bloodshed is rare. A specially trained 600-man police unit, called the Leopards, works closely with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration in pursuing processors and traffickers. Growers of coca, the base of cocaine, are urged to switch crops voluntarily. During a trip to Washington in May, however, President Jaime Paz Zamora agreed to commit about 900 soldiers in two army battalions to the effort, and to increase air force and navy involvement. In return, Bolivia will get $75 million worth of U.S. military equipment and training during 1990-91. Paz Zamora kept the agreement quiet, preferring to emphasize $127 million in economic aid pledged by the United States in the same two-year period, but it was leaked to the La Paz newspaper Presencia. Publication inspired protests from opposition politicians and labor unions. Presencia quoted Jorge Alderrete, a former undersecretary of the interior, as saying: ``The government has put at risk all the country's chances to achieve a peaceful solution to the drug trafficking problem. It will do nothing more than prove an old axiom: Violence begets violence.'' Alderrete is a prominent member of the Revolutionary Nationalist Movement, the main political opposition. Bolivia's army is better known for coups d'etat and corruption than combat skills. A military government that took power in 1980 even worked closely with cocaine traffickers. The army also has a reputation for heavy-handedness. When it is called in to put down strikes, for instance, bloodshed often results. Coca-growing peasants, militant and well organized, have sworn they will resist any any military crackdown. Leading officers of the Leopards also question the switch to a military approach. Maj. Carlos Barriga, Leopard commander for the Beni region, said he would accept whatever help he could get, but that army involvement ``can create big social problems. ... We've had some experiences in the past.'' ``The armed forces is an institution created to defend sovereignty from an exterior threat,'' Barriga said in an interview in Trinidad, capital of the Beni. ``I think the situation is being basically controlled now, without violence.'' The Beni is an expanse of jungles and grasslands about the size of Texas, loaded with clandestine cocaine laboratories. Barriga said Leopard and DEA operations there had ``done a lot of damage'' to the traffickers. He cited the discovery of 18 labs and 10 important drug caches during 1989. Don Ferrarone, DEA attache for Bolivia, said the most pressing need was additional transport and communications equipment so more Leopards could take part in raids. He said only about two dozen could be deployed for an operation by air because of shortages of planes and helicopters. ``The first thing we need to attend to is fully applying the people we have out here,'' he told The Associated Press in Trinidad, where he was directing helicopter and boat raids. ``We're not in a declared war and we have to take a step-by-step approach to applying the military.'' Those who favor military involvement, including U.S. Ambassador Robert Gelbard, say army action is needed ``if Bolivia is going to nip in the bud what is developing into a real national threat.'' Cocaine traffickers operate beyond the law's reach in eastern and northern Bolivia. They are believed to control entire towns that police and U.S. drug agents won't enter for fear of attack by townspeople. ``We have to find ways to cover these areas,'' Gelbard said in an interview in La Paz. ``Bolivia is no longer just a producer of (coca) leaf and paste. It is now is a major producer of cocaine hydrochloride. If the problem is ignored, I'm afraid it really could become another Colombia.'' Gelbard noted that some air force units have been involved in the anti-drug effort for years, flying a dozen Vietnam-era Huey helicopters supplied by the United States. The navy also interdicts drugs on jungle rivers. Some Bolivian critics draw parallels between escalating the drug war and the U.S. involvement in Vietnam, expressing concern about the increasing number of U.S. advisers and trainers in Bolivia. To that argument, Gelbard responds: ``You need advisers and trainers to avoid the problems other countries have had, where charred carcasses of U.S. helicopters lie in the valleys.'' He said U.S. training had produced a corps of Bolivian air force helicopter pilots that was ``the best in Latin America.'' More than 100 U.S. civilian and military officials are involved in the anti-narcotics campaign. Green Beret trainers run a base in the Chapare coca-growing region. U.S. Army, Navy and Air Force advisers work with DEA agents and the Leopards. U.S. border patrol agents and a special Coast Guard unit carry out interdiction operations on roads and rivers. Some U.S. civilian personnel, such as DEA, Coast Guard and border patrol agents, are allowed to take part in raids, but American military personnel are limited to training and advising.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Complain of Slow Payment for Eradicating Coca
With BC-Bolivia-Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: Coca farmers who agreed to switch crops waited hours to sign up for the government eradication program, two months for officials to certify their coca plants had been destroyed and several weeks to be paid. Samuel Zambrana, 61 with seven children, said he was going along with the plan, but ``I have no income now and I cannot get my banana and orange crop out because of bad roads. If the government is going to take coca away from us, we need profitable alternative crops, good roads and a market.'' Since Dec. 1, farmers have destroyed a record 4,500 hectares of coca, more than one-tenth of the 38,250 devoted to growing the crop from which cocaine is made, according to U.S. government figures. A hectare is about 2{ acres. ``We continue to be very pleased with voluntary eradication programs and the commitment which the Bolivian government continues to demonstrate,'' the U.S. Embassy said. Tens of thousands of farmers have left the Chapare coca-producing region because of a sharp drop in prices for the leaf. Farmers receive $2,000 from the Bolivian government for every hectare destroyed. Voluntary eradication was spurred late last year, when Colombia's drug war and increased interdiction in Bolivia disrupted cocaine production and reduced the demand for coca leaves. A 100-pound sack of coca costs about $30 to produce and brought only $10 at the beginning of May, compared with $100 five years ago, but had risen to about $20 by the end of the month. The increase caused concern that cocaine processing operations were resuming in Colombia. Nearly one-third of the world's coca leaves are produced in the Chapare, a lush, tropical region in the heart of Bolivia. At least 300,000 farmers depend on coca cultivation and cocaine production for a livelihood. The government says the industry brings about $600 million a year into the economy. Leaves of the coca bush, which resemble bay leaves, are harvested four times a year, dried and then macerated into paste with kerosene in plastic-covered pits. The paste is refined into cocaine in labs in the Bolivian lowlands, Colombia and Brazil. Bolivia, which has a population of 7.1 million, is South America's poorest country and its largest recipient of U.S. aid.

DOC.HEAD: Everything Is Scarce in Sudanese Refugee Camps
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Aweil is a place where everything is in desperately short supply: food, money, medicine, hope. Especially hope, when survival can depend on whether the train from Muglad arrives. As recently as December, 4,750 families waited in Aweil's refugee camps _ about 30,000 people driven into the town by a seemingly endless civil war. Despair drove most of them back to the countryside, to the risk of death from war, lawlessness or famine. Only a few hundred women, children and old men are in the camps now. ``Most of the families who left had been waiting for six to seven months for the relief train,'' said Mohamed Ali of the local relief committee. ``They saw no ray of hope so they moved out to the villages, where they might find something to eat.'' There is food at Muglad, a relief-distribution center 160 miles north of Aweil at the northern terminus of a rail line. Goods shipped from Khartoum, the capital 450 miles to the northeast, are stockpiled there under Operation Lifeline-Sudan, a relief program coordinated by the United Nations. Operation Lifeline was created after the famine of 1988, which took between 250,000 and 500,000 lives and resulted from a civil war that has raged in the southern part of Africa's largest nation since 1983. Black rebels in the south, which is predominantly Christian and animist, demand greater autonomy from the Arab, Moslem north. The relief project was credited with preventing a recurrence of the 1988 disaster last year, but getting supplies into the area has been difficult. Trains often are weeks or months late in making the 160-mile journey from Muglad to Aweil. Reasons range from the dilapidated track and the danger of land mines or attacks by rebels, renegade soldiers or bandits to bad weather, bureaucracy, inadequate equipment and the reluctance of crews to risk the trip. At the end of May, a 150-car train with 1,500 tons of grain had been waiting at Muglad for six months. ``We have only 400 gallons of edible oil and nothing else,'' said the Rev. Akili Malweth, the local Roman Catholic bishop. ``Our stores are as empty as a hungry man's stomach.'' Four trains have brought supplies to Aweil since Operation Lifeline began in 1989. On the return trip north, each carried thousands of people trying to escape and survive. ``Those who could not move out of the town are the poor, the old, the tuberculosis victims and the children,'' said Mohamed Ali, who also is the local representative of the Sudanese Commission on Relief and Rehabilitation. Nearly all those remaining are women, children and old men. They are housed in two makeshift camps and few have money to buy anything. One camp has nine large huts that accommodate 20 families each and the other is in the school. Alino Kolong, Aweil's education commissioner, said those who lived in the school cleaned it each morning before classes began. The women, and many of the children, try to find work. Refugee women till other people's gardens and carry firewood and water from the center of town to outlying houses in Aweil, which has a normal population of 11,000. ``Women here work in all sorts of jobs,'' said Majack Khawaja, a resident of the town. ``Even building houses, which traditionally has been a man's job, is now being done by women.'' Even if the refugee women can find work, they seldom make enough money to buy food. A cup of tea costs 10 Sudanese pounds, nearly 85 cents, double the daily wage for the best-paying jobs available. ``They cannot afford to buy one sack of sorghum at the unimaginable price of 900 pounds,'' or $75, for the 88-pound bag, Kolong said. Sorghum is the staple food in Sudan. On a recent inspection tour, officials of the U.N. agencies running Operation Lifeline found the refugee families had no materials for cooking and were grinding peanuts in large bowls, making paste so the nuts would go farther. ``All the people here eat is peanuts,'' Mohamed Ali said. ``It's not because they like them; it's because they're cheaper.'' Peanuts sell at one-third the price of sorghum. Although the people of Aweil looked relatively healthy, relief officials said most had chronic tuberculosis or suffered from malaria or other water-borne diseases. Aweil's drugstore had been empty for months. Dr. Samuel Deng, the area's only physician, said the medical charity Doctors Without Borders brought enough supplies for a year in February 1989, but no more had come. The group left Sudan after some of its workers were killed. ``What medicine we have left cannot last for one week, let alone until supplies come in no one knows how long,'' Deng said.

DOC.HEAD: Feeding Center a Tenuous Lifeline for Sudanese Orphans
With BC-Aweil-Camp Despair
DOC.TEXT: Relief workers call the two mud-and-grass huts a feeding center, but for 150 Sudanese war orphans, the lifeline is increasingly tenuous. The children, whose parents and relatives were among hundreds of thousands of civilian victims of civil war and famine, live with hundreds of other refugee women, children and old men at Aweil, in the embattled Bahr el-Ghazal region of southern Sudan. Each orphan has a tag attached to an arm or leg showing when he or she entered the center and detailing medical care. Each has been given a name, a nurse said, because ``everybody has to have a name, you know.'' All the children are members of the predominant southern Dinka tribe. They have nothing outside the feeding center's two crude huts, and inside they sleep on the earth floor. They have food _ cookies, high-protien gruel and milk provided by the Roman Catholic charity Sudanaid _ and most are in relatively good health. Considering the limited expectations of Aweil's children, that makes the orphans of the feeding center luckier than many of their famished and impoverished fellows, at least for now. The Rev. Akili Malweth, the local Catholic bishop, said the center's food was being exhausted rapidly, and ``after that, we will be at the mercy of the train.'' His reference was to a relief train that had been waiting for six months in Muglad, 160 miles away, to bring 1,500 tons of grain. Caretakers like Bishop Malweth try to maintain a semblance of normality for the children of Aweil's camps, but it is difficult. Alino Kolong, the town's education commissioner, said fewer children were attending school. ``Not all families can afford to buy school materials, and many of the children here are orphans,'' he said. A notebook costs 25 Sudanese pounds, about $2, and a pencil 10 pounds, or 85 cents. There is little work for the refugees and none that pays more than 5 pounds a day. Many pupils also stay away from school because ``some of the families cannot afford to buy clothes for their children,'' Kolong said, and ``we can't leave a naked child in the classroom with the others.'' Aweil has a hospital and a doctor. The hospital has only 75 beds in a capacity of 150, and often is virtually empty because many Dinka people prefer witch doctors. ``Sometimes a child is brought here and we hospitalize it,'' Dr. Samuel Deng said. ``After 10 to 12 hours we discover that the child has vanished,'' taken to a traditional healer by its mother. Most of those children die, he said.

DOC.HEAD: THE LANCASHIRE LAD OF MANY LAUGHS
Solo Spotlight on Stan Laurel in Centenary Festivities
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Long before he met Oliver Hardy, Stan Laurel made people laugh all by himself. He was the disaster-prone, stage-struck Lancashire boy, born Stanley Jefferson, who set the stage on fire on the opening night of a home theater. The first time he performed in a real theater, he squashed his father's top hat, then ripped his best frock coat for an encore. Those were the little mishaps on the road to Hollywood, where Stanley Jefferson in 1918 became Stan Laurel, star of 75 movies on his own and co-star with Oliver Hardy 105 more. For Laurel's 100th birthday on June 16, however, all roads lead to 3 Argyle St. in Ulverston, the northern town where Stanley Jefferson was born. The attractions include the birthplace, the balcony in Coronation Hall where Laurel and Hardy greeted townspeople in 1947, the Laurel and Hardy Museum and the companionship of the Sons of the Desert, members of the international Laurel and Hardy fan club. And what will they learn of their hero? ``A difficult one, that,'' said Bill Cubin, curator of the Laurel and Hardy Museum. ``I don't think the surroundings could tell you anything about Stan. His grandfather and grandmother were simple Ulverstonian people.'' Letters written by Laurel and now in the museum's collection reflect happy memories of fishing in the canal, rolling Easter eggs or shopping with Grandma Metcalfe. ``That was a big event for me,'' Laurel recalled in one letter. ``She used to buy me Beer's Treacle Toffee. It sure was good.'' The day after the birthday, a plaque will be dedicated at a more significant spot: North Shields, near the mouth of the River Tyne and clear across the country from Ulverston. In the attic of the family home in North Shields, A.J. Jefferson built a theater for plays written, produced, directed and starring his 9-year-old son, Stanley. John McCabe, an American actor and author of ``The Comedy World of Stan Laurel,'' found much of the story of Laurel's early days in an article written in 1939 by the father, a small-time impresario who operated theaters here and there in Britain. As the senior Jefferson told the tale, Stanley cast himself as the hero in the first of the attic productions and recruited for the villain a boy named Harold, whose principal asset was a bulldog sort of face _ and temperment. On opening night, the boys played a fight scene so intensely that a lamp was knocked over and both boys were burned. One imagines poor Harold spluttering, ``This is a fine mess!'' Harold apparently wrote to Stanley about his disenchantment, and it's unlikely that he was appeased by this reply: ``The fire was all your fault; if you had let go of my throat when you saw my face going all red, we shouldn't have rolled over as far as the lamps. You have lost nothing over the accident. I have lost my theater. ... I am sorry about your eyebrows being burned off, of course, but they will grow again.'' The house is no longer standing, Cubin said, but Laurel devotees can travel north to see the derelict Pickard's Theater in Glasgow, Scotland, where 16-year-old Stanley Jefferson made his professional debut. He was then working for his father at the Metropole Theater, on the business side, but he fibbed to his father about wanting to attend a party and sneaked off to appear at Pickard's. A.J. Jefferson was out strolling that night, wandered into Pickard's and was surprised to find several pieces of his clothing there, and his son performing in them. Stanley didn't notice his father until he was taking his bows, and A.J. recalled the scene: ``Giving a subdued yell of horrified astonishment, he dropped my topper which thereupon rolled toward the footlights. Stan pursued it, tried to grab it and in so doing kicked it accidentally into the orchestra where one of the musicians made a rush to retrieve it and stepped on it, squashing it thoroughly! ``Then Stan made a dash for the exit but his luck was out. As he ran off he came in contact with a steel hook fixed in the wings for a trapeze act and the hook ripped off half the skirt of my beautiful frock coat. Exit ... loud applause!'' Stanley came back for more, playing the vaudeville circuit, and his big break came with Fred Karno's comedy troupe. Soon after young Jefferson joined the troupe, they were rehearsing a show called ``Jimmy the Fearless'' in London. The troupe's star, Charlie Chaplin, decided the show wouldn't work and refused to appear, so Jefferson got the part. The show was a hit, and within a week Chaplin consented to star _ but Jefferson stayed on as Chaplin's understudy and second banana. One of the treasures of the museum in Ulverston is a poster advertising the Karno's troupe's appearance at the William Morris American Music Hall in New York in 1911. Jefferson and Chaplin had star billing. In 1912, the troupe returned to America where Chaplin resigned to make movies for Mack Sennett. Stanley Jefferson became the principal comedian, but the troupe folded a short time later in Philadelphia. Stanley Jefferson decided to stay. In 1917, he signed a contract with Universal Studios and that same year appeared in a short film titled ``Lucky Dog'' with Oliver Hardy. It wasn't until 1926, however, that they became a team in ``45 Minutes From Hollywood.'' It was the birth of one of the greatest comedy teams in film history _ the reedy, hair-scratching Laurel with his childish innocence and mischief, and the tubby tie-twirling Hardy whose cherubic face belied a short temper when his partner got them into ``another fine mess.'' Laurel died in 1965. Hardy, whose 100th birthday is in 1992, died in 1957. Laurel's solo films were highlighted this month in programs in London and New York. The National Film Theater in London has already screened ``Just Rambling Along,'' ``Somewhere in Wrong,'' ``Dr. Pyckle and Mr. Pride'' and ``When Knights Were Cold.'' Another program at the National Film Theater illustrated how Laurel's comedy ideas were recycled in Laurel and Hardy films. ``Smithy,'' a Laurel solo in 1924 about a man who is mistaken for a building contractor and builds a collapsible house, became Laurel and Hardy's ``The Finishing Touch'' four years later. The National Film Theater had advertised a first showing of a recently discovered Laurel and Hardy film _ it would be No. 106 _ but it is still not ready for showing, a theater spokeswoman said. On the birthday, the American Museum of the Moving Image in New York will show five short silents made by Laurel before Hardy: ``Pick and Shovel,'' ``Collars and Cuffs,'' ``West of Hot Dog,'' ``On the Front Page'' and ``Eve's Love Letters.''

DOC.HEAD: Frogs, Salamanders Disappearing Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: Frogs, toads and salamanders are vanishing around the world in a trend biologists say appears linked to the planet's deteriorating environment. From the United States to India, to Japan and Australia, scientists report whole amphibian populations have disappeared or are declining, even in protected reserves. ``There is no consistent pattern,'' says University of Miami biologist Marc Hayes. ``There doesn't seem to be any obvious global cause _ except that almost all seem to be man-made.'' Hayes, who heads the new national Committee on Declining Amphibians, says humans should worry not only because of the loss of animal species, but because amphibians' highly sensitive biology make them the ``canary in the coal mine'' _ an environmental early warning system. Amphibians _ including frogs, toads and salamanders _ were the first land vertebrates. They appeared 400 million years ago, long before dinosaurs, and about 200 million years ago evolved into species similar to present-day varieties. That longevity now seems imperiled. Studies presented at an international conference in February documented a sharp drop worldwide in amphibian populations. Leopard frogs are no longer sighted in Canada. The common European toad has disappeared from regions in Norway. Three species of miniature frogs vanished from Puerto Rico. Salamander populations are shrinking in the Western United States, and Japan reports several frog species are in decline. A recently discovered Australian frog that fascinated biologists because it hatched its young in its stomach apparently went extinct in only one season. The Monte Verde nature reserve in Costa Rica reports all of its amphibian populations have declined, and the golden toad that once carpeted its forests may be extinct. Some causes of the phemomenon are known, and vary from country to country. But cases such as the loss of frogs in Australia or U.S. preserves leave biologists puzzled. ``In some of the areas that are the most protected, frogs are disappearing, and we have no explanation for it,'' Hayes says. ``There are a whole suite of species that have disappeared from very wide ranges in the United States.'' David Wake, a University of California at Berkeley zoologist who chaired the conference in February, says acid raid could be one of the culprits killing off salamanders in the Colorado Rockies. Hayes says ultraviolet light is a known threat to frog's eggs, and increased amounts of the harmful radiation entering through the thinning ozone layer could be destructive. Another hazard for frogs is stocking ponds with bass and other predator fish, especially in areas where the animals evolved with no such enemies, and have no ability to escape them. In the Everglades, Hayes notes, pig frogs were hunted for food almost to extinction in the 1930s, and have never fully recovered. That pattern is being repeated in India and Indonesia. The Monte Verde disappearance could be due to changing weather patterns caused by global warming, he says, or because frogs need many interconnected habitats, and become isolated by roads and other development. Wake says amphibians, which absorb large amounts of water through their skins, are highly susceptible to heavy metals and other toxic material often exhuasted into the air and water. Add widespread pesticide use, logging, dams, habitat destruction and other local factors, and the amphibian population is in trouble. ``They are bio-indicators,'' Wake warns. ``It may not be something that will hurt us directly, but they are telling us about the loss of resiliance of our ecosystem, the loss of diversity.'' The loss of amphibians also has some immediate noticeable effects on man, the scientists say. The poison dart frog has a toxin in its skin that, when refined, has been used successfully on an experimental basis for treating heart conditions, says Hayes. In addition, frogs are a source of food in many parts of the world. Wake says amphibians also are a key part of nature's ecological balance. ``Frog tadpoles consume an enormous about of algae,'' says Wake. ``They keep our streams flowing clear and clean.'' As adults, frogs move onto land, and become the top local predators, consuming enormous amounts of small insects, including mosquitoes. The demise of pig frogs in the Everglades could have a bearing on the unexplained drop in wading birds, which have decreased by up to 90 percent since the beginning of the century, says Hayes. The variety of explanations and theories makes it clear there is no panacea to solve the problem, says Wake. And he adds that no government agency is working on the problem in any case. He has been in contact with several U.S. senators on a project to create a National Institute for the Environment to protect the nation's biological wealth, but says so far, the amphibian problem in the United States is in the hands of over-worked, under-funded state game commissions. Until there is more attention, biologists can only watch the disappearance of amphibian species with alarm. ``When the canary died, the miner left,'' says Wake. ``Now the canary is dying, but we've got to sit here _ where are we going to go?''

DOC.HEAD: Revered Archaeologist Still Under Attack 100 Years After Death
DOC.TEXT: Heinrich Schliemann, the 19th-century German archaeologist credited with discovering the legendary city of Troy, has come under fresh attack a century after his death. More than 200 archaeologists, historians and classicists gathered in Athens to mark Schliemann's death and debate the legacy of the man considered the father of prehistoric Greek archaeology. Schliemann, a grocer's son who became a millionaire, is famous for excavating the ancient cities of Troy and Mycenae, and finding Bronze Age civilizations at the sites whose existence previously was unknown. But some experts have doubted Schliemann's integrity and the reliability of the historical data he left his successors. ``My findings seem to show that Schliemann was a pathological liar,'' David A. Taill, a classics professor at the University of California at Davis, said in an interview. Controversy has surrounded Schliemann's findings since their publication in 1874. His methods, primitive by today's standards, have often been criticized. Still, many historians regard him as a pioneer in archaeological discovery and say purported inaccuracies may be due to hasty documentation. Taill, who spoke at the conference held last month, spent 10 years scouring records of Schliemann's excavations as well as his diaries and letters. The professor said the value of an archaeological find depended on knowing where particular pieces were discovered. Placement often indicates age. ``Once it has been established Schliemann falsified some of his finds, the question is how great is the damage,'' he said. The implications of any faking could be great. For example, his data on the existence of settlements and the position of objects at Troy have helped to determine the age of ruins throughout the Anatolia region in Turkey. Troy is in modern-day Hissarlik, Turkey. Taill and others have challenged Schliemann's most dramatic discovery _ a gold hoard he said was the treasure of legendary King Priam. ``I'm fairly convinced he found some of the items separately and put them together for a big bang at the end,'' Taill said. Taill claimed that Schliemann, in different accounts, changed his description of where he found Priam's treasure. Schliemann's account of finding the treasure with his wife, Sophia, was false, because letters showed she was in Athens at the time, Taill said. Taill's research added new fuel to a debate that has raged for years. Schliemann's excavating techniques have long been debated, with some people saying he destroyed valuable data by working too quickly. Another expert, Edmund F. Bloedow, professor of ancient history at Ottawa University, told conference delegates that differences in Schliemann's accounts could be attributed to ``the inevitable haste in making initial notes and sketches, and transcribing them.'' Professor Manfred Korfmann of Tubingen University in West Germany said Schliemann may have enlarged the King Priam trove with items he bought. But Korfmann, who is excavating at Troy, nonetheless emphasized Schliemann's pioneering of archaeological techniques. Questions about King Priam's hoard may never be resolved. Schliemann said he found the gold, silver and bronze trove in 1873. He gave it to Germany and during World War II it was stored in a Berlin vault. It later vanished. Schliemann is esteemed for using archaeology as a means to reconstruct historical periods. Before him, archaeologists generally dug to find sculptures to enrich private and museum collections. Schliemann's attention to small finds at different levels of the earth resulted in a more accurate method of determining chronologies. ``With the publication of Schliemann's first reports on Troy, archaeology, and prehistoric field archaeology in particular, began to move ahead toward something entirely new,'' Korfmann told the delegates. Taill, to underline his contention that Schliemann's integrity was dubious, listed examples of how the archaeologist had allegedly lied in his personal life. He claimed that Schliemann gained U.S. citizenship in 1869 by lying about the length of his stay in the country. Schliemann also apparently falsified his diary, Taill said. A June 1851 entry gives his graphic, eyewitness account of a major fire in San Francisco. However, the fire was in May, when Schliemann was in Sacramento, Taill said. ``Why would he lie in his own diary?'' he asked. Despite attacks on Schliemann's credibility, scholars admired his skills. Schliemann, who died Dec. 26, 1890, at 68, immersed himself in the poet Homer. Schliemann said he found Troy by following Homer's descriptions of its location. However, historians point out that Hissarlik had already been suggested as the likely site of pre-historic Troy.

DOC.HEAD: New, Safer Breast Implants Being Studied
DOC.TEXT: A breast implant filled with peanut oil could mean safer breast enlargements for thousands of women who have the surgery each year, a radiologist says. Because the oil is transparent, the new implants do not interfere with X-ray mammography for breast cancer the way silicone breast implants can, said Judy Destouet, head of the mammography unit at Washington University's Mallinckrodt Institute of Radiology. ``They appear like the fat in the breast _ you can see through it,'' Destouet said. Destouet and Leroy Young, associate professor of plastic and reconstructive surgery at Washington University School of Medicine, are heading the development of the new implant. The most common implant now is filled with silicone gel, which appears as dense as bone in X-rays and therefore can hamper early detection of breast cancer, Destouet said. Others are filled with saline, or a combination of silicone and saline. ``I think many women need (breast augmentation) for self esteem, and I think that we should have the freedom to do what we want for our bodies,'' Destouet said. ``We hoped to develop a better product that would allow women to augment their breasts but won't take away the benefits of state-of-the-art mammography. We feel that we have something that really can be a safe alternative.'' Breast augmentation is one of the most popular cosmetic surgery procedures available, according to the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons Inc. in Arlington Heights, Ill. Some 72,000 women undergo breast augmentation each year, said spokeswoman Cathleen Coyne. But some doctors disagree that implants interfere with early cancer detection. Studies by Dr. Garry Brody at the University of Southern California followed 3,000 women in the Los Angeles area who have had breast augmentation. ``Thus far, the delay is theoretic only. It's certainly a possibility, but when we look at the statistics, we can't find the delay. Their cancer seems to be picked up at the same stage as the unaugmented population.'' The American Cancer Society estimates that one in 10 women will develop breast cancer in her lifetime. Carolyn Cline, a plastic surgeon and psychologist in San Francisco, said she discourages women with a family history of breast cancer from having the surgery. ``But the average women, I don't feel _ given the improvements in radiological techniques _ that it is a major issue,'' she said. The Washington University researchers have spent the last year or so conducting tests on rats and rabbits to make sure their implants have no adverse effects, such as allergic reactions or extreme scar tissue formation. ``So far our animal studies are very favorable,'' Destouet said. ``There really are no side effects.'' Once the researchers get U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval, the implants will be tested in women. They could be available commercially in about two years. Destouet said the researchers came upon peanut oil as a safe implant filler when they turned to their chemistry books to find which substances would allow X-ray penetration, and which of those substances were not carcinogenic. The implants still use a thin silicone shell to hold the peanut oil. ``We need a better envelope too,'' Destouet said. ``You can't invent everything at the same time.''

DOC.HEAD: Legionnaire's Disease Bacteria Survive By Hiding Inside Amoebas
DOC.TEXT: Scientists discovered how deadly Legionnaire's disease bacteria can survive in chlorinated water, especially hot water tanks in hospitals and other large buildings: The microbes hide inside amoebas. ``Anywhere you have water that is tepid, you may have a problem,'' said John Kuchta, chief microbiologist for the city water department in Pittsburgh. The problem is unlikely in residential hot water tanks, which usually are heated from the bottom, where heat kills the sediment-dwelling microorganisms known as amoebas, Kuchta said recently during the American Society for Microbiology's annual meeting in Anaheim. But Kuchta and fellow microbiologist Jeannine Navratil found both the disease-causing Legionella pneumophila bacteria and the amoebas that hide them when they examined hot water reservoirs at hospitals and universities. Those recirculating-water tanks weren't heated from the bottom, but from the sides. Kuchta said the problem can be solved by superchlorinating water for short periods of time and by increasing water temperature to 150 degrees Fahrenheit, which he acknowledged contradicts efforts to conserve energy and prevent scalding burns. Legionnaire's disease was named after it killed 34 guests staying at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia during a state American Legion convention in 1976. An additional 221 people became ill. The disease subsequently was recognized as a leading cause of pneumonia among hospital patients. It is believed to be spread by inhalation of contaminated water vapor, such as from tainted air conditioning units or, in a recent case, from mist sprayed on produce in a grocery store. The disease apparently isn't transmitted from one person to another. Scientists already knew Legionnaire's bacteria could multiply only after they are engulfed by amoebas, members of a group of single-celled organisms called protozoa. In laboratory studies, the Pittsburgh scientists found the same process allows the bacteria to survive chlorination 10 times stronger than is generally accepted as safe for disinfection of drinking water. In addition to being physically sheltered from chlorine, Legionnaire's bacteria also undergo biochemical changes when growing inside amoebas, making the bacteria even more resistant to chlorination. ``It may be difficult if not impossible to completely prevent legionellae (Legionnaire's and related bacteria) and perhaps other protozoan-borne pathogens from colonizing potable water'' tanks, which can be disinfected only by superchlorination or high temperatures, the scientists wrote. Kuchta said he is mainly concerned about hospitals, where hot water often is 130 degrees or less ``for fear of scalding patients. The bottom line is to make sure it is 150 degrees, at least for a time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Publishes Food Guide
DOC.TEXT: The of Agriculture has issued two publications to help consumers eat well. The fifth and sixth publications in the USDA's ``E U.S. Departmentating Right'' campaign are ``Good Sources of Nutrients'' and ``Calories & Weight: The USDA Pocket Guide.'' The pocket guide includes calorie values for nearly 400 foods, and is a new version of one of the department's most popular publications. ``Good Sources'' is a series of fact sheets that give the top food sources of 16 vitamins and minerals and of fiber. A food is considered a good source of a nutrient if it contributes at least 10 percent of the U.S. Recommended Daily Allowance of the nutrient per serving. Only foods containing moderate amounts of fat and sugar are included, said Sue Ann Ritchko, administrator of the UDSA's Human Nutrition Information Service.
