DOC.HEAD: House Ties High-Tech Exports to End of Lithuania Blockade
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS day of week in 2nd graf; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers are threatening to block exports of U.S. high technology to the Soviet Union until it ends its economic blockade of Lithuania. By a 390-24 vote Wednesday, the House voted to bar the sale of U.S. computers and telecommunications gear needed to modernize the Soviet economy until Moscow begins negotiating Lithuania's independence ``without economic coercion.'' On a voice vote, the House also agreed to ban high-tech sales to the Soviet Union if it continues to restrict Jewish emigration. ``While the Soviet president put out one hand in requesting aid from the United States, the other hand is wrapped tightly around the neck of Lithuania,'' said Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., who sought the Jewish emigration provision, said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had ``played into the hands of Arab extremists'' in remarks at a news conference ending last week's superpower summit. Gorbachev said he was under pressure from Egypt and Syria to start denying exit visas to Soviet Jews if Israel continues to allow them settle in Israeli-occupied territories on the West Bank. Meanwhile Wednesday, the United States and the Soviet Union signed another agreement on sharing food-processing information, particularly how U.S. technology and methods can be incorporated by the Soviets. And Yuri N. Chumakov, the deputy Soviet minister of foreign economic relations, told a gathering of U.S. businessmen that his country will be looking for U.S. loans under a new tentative trade agreement. ``The United States is our greatest food supplier (and) we have been paying with cash,'' Chumakov said. ``We have the right to expect in this hard period to receive certain credits in order to withstand the pressure.'' The House votes on amendments to an administration-opposed bill easing controls on high-tech U.S. exports was the first congressional reaction to the trade accord signed by Bush and Gorbachev last Friday. Moscow is particularly interested in acquiring U.S. telecommunications and computer technology. During last week's summit, for example, the Soviets signed an agreement with International Business Machines Corp. to buy school computers. The Bush-Gorbachev agreement would lower 40-year-old trade barriers between the two countries, but only upon the Supreme Soviet's approval of a law to make it easier for Soviet citizens to emigrate to or visit the West. However, many members of Congress want to condition any change in trade relations with Moscow to its treatment of Lithuania and other breakaway movements within the faltering Soviet empire. Since April 18, the Soviets have cut off supplies of oil, natural gas, other raw materials and medical supplies to Lithuania in response to its declaration of independence a month earlier. ``Although the Soviet Union is moving toward peace and openness, it is not quite there,'' said Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., the author of the measure to forbid high-tech sales to Moscow. ``The Iron Curtain is still present when it comes to Lithuania and other Baltic countries.'' Through other amendments, House members also expressed dissatisfaction with Bush's decision last month to extend Most Favored Nation trade status to China despite the government's violent reaction to the Tiananmen Square uprising a year ago. On a 393-15 vote, the House approved an amendment by Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., that would forbid Bush from approving any more exports of U.S.-built or U.S.-owned satellites to China. The amendment would not affect the export of three such satellites approved last December by Bush. All of the votes were on amendments to a bill reauthorizing U.S. participation in the 17-nation Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Security Controls, which determines which Western high-tech goods are too militarily sensitive to be sold to potential enemies. The overall bill passed 312-86 despite administration veto threats. Similar legislation is pending in the Senate Banking Committee. ``The thrust of the bill is that business is more important than national security,'' said Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill. ``There are military and intelligence aspects to some of these telecommunications exports. We're crazy to hand that stuff to the Soviet Union.'' Supporters, however, maintained that ``cold warrior'' attitudes should no longer dominate U.S. export policies. Rep. Ed Markey, D-Mass., said: ``We should accept our victory. Eastern Europeans are going to spend upwards of $140 billion in the next decade on telecommunications and we should get a chunk of it.'' Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., cited a study by the National Academy of Sciences estimating that the existing controls denied U.S. companies $9.2 billion in exports in 1987 ``with no perceptible increase in national security.'' The bill basically eases export controls on telecommunications equipment, computers and machine tools to the newly democratizing countries of Eastern Europe and, to a lesser extent, the Soviets. U.S. manufacturers have repeatedly complained that the U.S. export controls are effectively shutting out their participation in Eastern Europe's developing economy while Japan, West Germany and South Korea establish toeholds in it.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Air Changing Name, Plans to Focus on Continental
LaserPhoto HT3 of June 6
DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS crowd figure in 7th graf to 200 sted 2,000; uppicks 8th graf pvs: Lorenzo admitted ...
DOC.TEXT: Frank Lorenzo, acknowledging that he controls only one airline today, said his Texas Air Corp. would change its name to Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. Although Texas Air technically still owns Eastern Airlines as well as Continental, a bankruptcy judge in April ordered Lorenzo out of the Eastern cockpit and appointed a trustee to run the strike-bound airline. ``The name change was made to reflect the fact that the principal business of the company is Continental,'' Lorenzo told shareholders at the company's annual meeting Wednesday. The change takes effect Monday. He told reporters later that the change doesn't mean Texas Air has given up completely on Eastern, but he declined to comment when asked whether he believed he would regain control of the carrier. The atmosphere at the shareholder meeting was a stark contrast to the gathering last September, when Eastern was seven months into a bitter labor dispute with its striking unions. Then, about 100 Eastern strikers picketed outside and chanted anti-Lorenzo slogans, while those attending the meeting had to pass through metal detectors. The protestors and detectors were absent this year, and even Lorenzo couldn't resist mentioning that the quiet crowd of more than 200 was unusual for a Texas Air shareholders' meeting. Lorenzo admitted that the ``Eastern Airlines situation has been very difficult for us.'' On April 18, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland acted at the request of Eastern's creditors and turned control of the airline over to trustee Martin Shugrue, a former Continental boss and Lorenzo associate. The move had been sought by the airline's unions since the strike began. ``We don't believe that a trustee was warranted,'' Lorenzo said. But he said he remains concerned about the future of Eastern employees, adding: ``We wish them and the trustee well.'' Lorenzo said negotiations were continuing to determine how much Texas Air and Continental will contribute to bolster Eastern's pension plans. He said he had ``every reason to believe that these negotiations will result in a settlement that is manageable and will not have an adverse impact on our company, its financial health and its future.'' The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., a federal agency, has estimated Eastern has about $830 million in unfunded pension liabilities. Lorenzo brushed aside talk about the possibility of selling Continental, telling shareholders that wasn't a ``priority.'' He said there have been recent financial and operational improvements at Continental. ``We're well-positioned to compete in the service-driven marketplace of today,'' he said. Lorenzo announced at the meeting that shareholders had approved the management-proposed slate of 14 directors, including four new directors representing preferred shareholders. Texas Air had to expand its board after failing to pay dividends to three classes of preferred shareholders for the past 1{ years. The four directors elected to represent the preferred classes are Lindsay E. Fox, Robert Garrett, James A. Lawrence and Gerald Tsai Jr.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stocks prices were higher at midday Thursday, helped by a steady pound and weaker gold prices. The market moved from early lows to peaks at midday. Dealers pointed to a firmer pound against a basket of currencies while gold touched $351.50 an ounce, its lowest level in four years. The brighter tone to the British equities market attracted more institutional buying, which also has helped the market rise, one dealer said. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 19.1 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,377.6, its session peak. Volume was 337.9 million shares at noon, compared with 261.2 million shares at the same time Wednesday.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 465.47 up .51 from the previous day's close.

The stock market edged upward today in a sluggish bid to recover from a two-session setback. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 23.54 points over the past two trading days, rose 3.64 to 2,915.29 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 635 up, 558 down and 565 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 53.74 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said the pullback in prices Tuesday and Wednesday appeared to have attracted some ``catch-up'' buyers who had been awaiting a chance to add to their stockholdings. Investors got some mild encouragement from the bond market, where prices edged upward, putting yields on long-term Treasury bonds in the 8.42 percent-8.46 percent range. Over the past several weeks government bonds have recovered about half the ground they lost as interest rates rose earlier in the year. That has evidently prompted money managers at investing institutions to pump some of their large cash reserves into stocks. Among actively traded blue chips, American Express rose { to 31}; Eastman Kodak gained | to 42{; Philip Morris added ] to 45\, and International Business Machines was unchanged at 120|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .13 to 199.28. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .11 at 364.08.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Resumes Payments On Foreign Debt
DOC.TEXT: Argentina has made a $40 million payment to foreign creditors, the first since foreign debt payments were suspended more than two years ago, government officials said Thursday. Carlos Carballo, undersecretary of economy, confirmed that payments had been renewed following ``arduous'' discussions in New York between Central Bank Vice President Javier Gonzalez Fraga and individual creditor banks. The payment, ministry sources said, is considered ``a gesture of good will'' aimed at aiding Gonzalez Fraga in talks scheduled to began this week with a consortium of private creditors. Argentina, the developing world's third largest debtor, owes a total of $60 billion in loans plus unpaid interest that could reach $8.5 billion by the end of the year. Ministry sources said the government hopes to negotiate an agreement to pay $300 million in overdue interest by the end of the year. The creditors reportedly have sought payment of $500 million. In the event negotiators reach agreement, Argentina would make another interest payment of between $70 million and $80 million, ministry sources said. The 11-month-old government of President Carlos Menem is seeking debt forgiveness, approval for debt capitalization and new loans. Negotiations with a steering committee that represents private banks, which are owed a total of $40 billion, are likely to be difficult. Citibank, for example, reportedly has written off 40 percent of its loans to Argentina as uncollectable and resents having done so. Nevertheless, the International Monetary Fund has indicated it approves of Menem's policy of budget austerity and privatizations, and recently unblocked payment of a $1.7 billion loan granted last October and suspended five months later. Carballo said $240 million of the unblocked funds ``have already entered the country'' and that a new installment of the same amount would be disbursed by early August. Argentina is emerging from two bouts of hyperinflation and is mired in recession. Inflation, which hit 96 percent in March, dropped to 11 percent in April but is expected to be slightly higher for May.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Soviet Automaker Sign Joint Agreement
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. and Volga Auto Works, the largest U.S. and Soviet automakers, signed a $1 billion deal involving the purchase of GM-designed engine parts, the U.S. company said today. The seven-year agreement marks the first automotive deal between a U.S. and a Soviet company since the Great Depression. Ford Motor Co. last year pulled out of joint venture talks with Soviet companies, and Chrysler Corp. has no dealings with Soviet companies. GM will supply fuel injection, emissions control subsystems and other engine components to VAZ for two of its cars sold under the Lada nameplate. The program may be extended to other cars later, the company said. Shipments of the GM parts to VAZ may begin as early as 1992 and will continue through 1997. The first batches of components will be made by GM in the United States and Europe, the company said. U.S. automakers have been looking for business in Eastern Europe as political and economic changes occur. GM already has announced vehicle manufacturing deals in Hungary and East Germany. Last February, GM's Allison Gas Turbine Division announced it had signed a deal to supply up to 100 helicopter engines to the Soviet Union beginning in 1992. The agreement could be worth $50 million to $100 million during the 1990s, officials have said.

DOC.HEAD: New Film Park Debuts in Florida
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs with official opening, editing to conform; picks up 15th graf, They claim ...
DOC.TEXT: The $630 million home-away-from-home for E.T., Ghostbusters, Jaws and King Kong made its official debut today with dozens of Hollywood stars joining Steven Spielberg to ``ride the movies'' at Universal Studios Florida. The combination theme park and film production center features high-tech entertainment on a big scale _ showing visitors how movies are made while letting them in on the action. James Stewart, Charlton Heston, Bill Cosby and Michael J. Fox were among the 50 or so top names parading down a replica of Hollywood Boulevard in limousines to open the festivities. Sidney Sheinberg, president of the park's co-owner, MCA Inc., today called the 444-acre site ``a swampland turned into a dreamland.'' But the park wasn't totally up and running. Technical glitches prevented some of the major rides from operating at a special party for some 4,500 delegates to a travel industry convention Wednesday night. Sheinberg and studio technical officials said ``most everything would be in operation'' today but that problems and delays were expected because of the complexity of the equipment. The park, owned by California-based MCA and London's Rank Organisation PLC, features classic movie-themed rides and ``participatory adventures,'' many of which were conceived and designed by film director Spielberg, Universal's creative consultant. Visitors go soaring with E.T., the Extraterrestrial, survive the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, agonize over an encounter with the great white shark from ``Jaws,'' get buffetted in an aerial tramway by a 3-story-tall King Kong and lose themselves in the live-action Ghostbusters haunting. Universal also has the largest movie and TV sound stage area outside Hollywood, Calif. Production has been under way since 1988, and 13 feature films and 500 television episodes are to go before the cameras this year. Universal is also the new home to Nickelodeon, the children's television network, and the first Hard Rock Cafe in Florida. MCA is trying to grab a share of Florida's booming theme-park industry, a business dominated by entertainment giant Walt Disney World. The Disney-MGM Studios, based on the same concept but about half the size of Universal Studios, completed its first year of operation May 1. It recorded about 8 million visits in its first year, but the turnstile count inflates actual attendance. Universal has a daily capacity of more than 40,000 and expects to draw at least 5 million visitors its first year. MCA Vice President Jay Stein, who headed designing and building of the Florida park, said he was confident of its success in the face of the formidable competition a few miles down the interstate. ``It's a must-see attraction ... I don't think we're going to eclipse Disney overnight. But we are going to bring lots of new business to the area, and lots of repeat business to the area,'' he said. Stein, a tough-talking taskmaster who started in the mailroom at MCA 30 years ago, and his boss, Sheinberg, have had a running feud with Disney Chairman Michael Eisner for years. They claim Eisner copied their idea for a movie-theme park and rushed to build the Disney-MGM Studios before Universal could get its act together. Eisner and other Disney executives downplay any talk of a rivalry and instead tout the benefits of competition. Universal Studios Florida is also an important test of whether MCA and Rank can export the same concept to Europe and Japan. ``We think there's a terrific market out there'' for high-tech theme parks, Stein says. An announcement is expected soon on a similar enterprise to be built either near London or Paris. MCA also has announced plans for a theme park in Japan in partnership with Nippon Steel.

DOC.HEAD: Market Continues Under Spell of Weather
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Weather was key to the market once again as corn futures were strongly higher over concerns about the size of the corn crop. Rain in the southern Midwest could further delay planting, which has been lagging because of soggy fields. ``People are nervous about the weather and what it will do to the size of crops this summer,'' said Jerry Zusel, an analyst with Balfour Maclaine Corp. in Chicago. Soybeans were being helped by the strength of corn. Wheat futures also were higher. Prices were boosted by news the U.S. Agriculture Department has offered the Soviet Union two million metric tons of wheat under the export bonus program. In early trading, wheat was 1\ cents to 1} cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.33\; corn was 2\ cents to 6\ cents higher with July at $2.83{ a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with July at $1.47{ bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $5.97} a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were mostly lower in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle prices were pushed lower by professional and commercial selling. Pork futures were lower on weak cash prices. Live cattle were .17 cent lower to .10 cent higher with June at 75.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent lower to .10 cent higher with August at 85.45 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent to .43 cent lower with June at 65.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to .70 cent higher with July at 66.75 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled higher and pork futures lower in Wednesday's trading.

The stock market headed lower today, resuming its retreat of the past two sessions after a brief attempt to rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 23.54 points over the past two trading days, dropped 10.44 to 2,901.21 by noontime on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 570 up, 749 down and 546 unchanged. Stock traders appeared to drew cautious conclusions from activity in the bond market, where prices were little changed. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds hovered in the 8.43 percent-8.47 percent range. Over the past several weeks government bonds have recovered about half the ground they lost as interest rates rose earlier in the year. That has evidently prompted money managers at investing institutions to pump some of their large cash reserves into stocks. But over the past couple of days uncertainty has evidently increased over whether rates can keep going down. Losers among the blue chips included General Motors, down { at 49]; International Business Machines, down \ at 120]; Exxon, down [ at 47}, and International Paper, down { at 51}. Precious-metals stocks were broadly lower, extending their recent slide. ASA Ltd. fell 1] to 45[; American Barrick Resources } to 16|; Homestake Mining } to 17, and Newmont Gold 1 to 40]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .56 to 198.59. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .71 at 363.48. Volume on the Big Board came to 78.84 million shares at noontime, down from 88.14 million at the same point Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Casino News Conference: Nothing Is For Sale
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's top executive in this casino city today flatly denied the New York developer planned to sell any of his gaming halls in the wake of reports of cash flow problems. ``Let me tell you today there is no `For Sale' sign on the Trump properties,'' said Ed Tracy, president of Trump's three casino complexes and luxury hotel here. ``The properties are not for sale _ not Trump Plaza, Trump Castle or Taj Mahal.'' Trump also operates the Trump Regency, formerly the Atlantis Casino Hotel, as a hotel only. Tracy told a crowded news conference that the Taj Mahal Casino Hotel, the $1 billion complex that opened with much fanfare in April, will reduce its workforce of 7,200 by about 10 percent. But he cautioned that layoffs were routine following the opening of a new gaming hall, and the Boardwalk complex would probably have from 6,000 to 6,200 workers when it completes what is known in the industry as its ``shakedown'' period. ``There's nothing new about this, '' Tracy said, noting that Trump Plaza cut its workforce by 12 percent when it opened in 1985 under Harrah's management. Tracy refused to discuss any legal action involving Trump himself. Bondholders for Trump Plaza and Trump Castle have sued the Manhattan developer in U.S. District Court, contending his promotion of the Taj Mahal has weakened the values of their bonds in the other gaming halls. Tracy also rejected rumors that the properties are for sale because bankers are pressuring Trump to cut back costs and because the bonds used to finance the casinos are plummeting.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Rise

DOC.HEAD: Rate of Business Investment Expected to be Slower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Shorter version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. businesses plan to boost plant and equipment investment in 1990 at the slowest rate in three years, the government said Thursday. The report reflected a sluggish economy and weak product demand. The Commerce Department said a survey completed in May found businesses planning to boost spending on expansion and modernization by 5.5 percent to $500.4 billion. It would be the fourth consecutive yearly increase. But while the spending projection would top the record $474.3 billion set last year, the rate of increase would be the slowest since a 4.2 percent gain in 1987. Investments rose 8.9 percent last year and 9.4 percent in 1988. ``It shows the manufacturing sector is responding negatively to the sluggishness in that area,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``All one is looking for here is that it not be a drag on the economy,'' he added. ``If it were a drag, it would be a heavy burden on the economy given the other negatives such as defense spending and housing.'' Manufacturing and housing have been the sectors of the economy hardest hit by the Federal Reserve's tight-money policy. Also, the federal government has cut back on military spending because of budget constraints. The new estimate is down from the 7.9 percent spending increase in a previous survey completed in March. A survey completed in November indicated a 4.9 percent investment gain this year. All of the figures have been adjusted for inflation. Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said three factors were dampening investment plans _ a soft economy and subsequent sluggish demand, weak profits and cash flows, and high interest rates and tighter restrictions on credit. ``The only thing keeping capital spending going now is the fact a lot of companies realize if they don't modernize and improve productivity and improve the quality of their products, they'll be out of business eventually.'' he said. Replacing aging plants and equipment and expanding facilities helps to boost U.S. productivity, an increasingly important factor in view of the stiff competition American companies face from overseas. The Labor Department reported Monday that American worker productivity had plunged at a 2.7 percent annual rate so far this year, the poorest showing since the 1981-82 recession. Any growth in business spending would help stimulate the economy, now in its eighth year of expansion, and pick up some of the slack from diminished consumer spending. Before adjusting for inflation, the department survey projected a 6.7 percent increase for all businesses this year to $507.2 billion after gains of 10.4 percent last year and 10.5 percent in 1988. It said the investment increase for all industries includes a 3.4 percent gain for manufacturing firms and an 8.7 percent advance for companies engaged in mining, transportation and other non-manufacturing activities. Manufacturers are projecting investment spending this year of $190.9 billion. The anticipated rate of increase is lower than the average for all industries and down from the 4.9 percent projection in April. The manufacturing gain includes a 2.4 percent hike in durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last at least three years _ and a 4.3 percent increase in non-durables.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Leads Surge in Grain, Soybean Prices
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were higher Thursday in trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn futures led the advance, as adverse weather conditions continue to influence the market. There was more rain in the southern Midwest crop areas, increasing the prospects for a smaller than anticipated U.S. corn crop this year, said Susan Leighty, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. There was talk on the floor that as much as 3 to 5 percent of intented corn acreage may not get planted, analysts said. Soybean prices were boosted by the strength of corn futures and concern about planting delays. However, the jump in soybean futures was limited by speculation that should the southern Midwest dry out by mid-June, some of the intended corn acres will be switched to soybeans. Corn needs longer to mature than soybeans. Wheat futures gained on concerns the wet weather has lowered the quality and quantity of the winter crop and is delaying harvesting, Ms. Leighty said. Wheat prices also received a boost from word the U.S. Agriculture Department has targeted the Soviet Union for 2 million metric tons of export bonus wheat. At the close, wheat was 1 cent to 3{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.35 a bushel; corn was 4} cents to 9{ cents higher with July at $2.85\ a bushel; oats were 2} cents to 4 cents higher with July at $1.49\ a bushel; soybeans were 8} cents to 12 cents higher with July at $6.04 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: No. 2 at Federal Reserve Announces Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS slug to conform to digest. SUBS grafs 12-14, beginning `The administration...' with 9 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Johnson and administration as well as possible successors. Picks up 15th graf pvs, `Johnson was ...' Nickname `Manley' in penultimate graf is cq. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Manuel H. Johnson unexpectedly announced his resignation Thursday from the No. 2 job at the Federal Reserve, creating a key opening at an agency often criticized by the Bush administration for keeping interest rates too high. Johnson, 41, said he planned to return to an academic career. The Aug. 3 departure will give President Bush the chance to make another appointment to the seven-member board that directs the nation's monetary policy. The administration at various times in past months has been openly critical of the Fed's efforts to restrain inflation by keeping interest rates high. There was a published report in March quoting an unnamed Bush adviser as saying the president was ``mad as hell'' with Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and would not reappoint him as chairman. Bush later insisted there was ``no bubbling war'' with Greenspan, but left the clear impression he would like to see more aggressive action on the part of the Fed to lower interest rates. Analysts said it was likely that Bush would appoint someone to the Fed who would be more amenable to the administration's pleas for lower interest rates. ``This administration has been jawboning the Fed on and off for some time for a looser monetary policy,'' said Kenneth Guenther of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``They want lower interest rates because they don't want the economy moving into a recession.'' Fed officials have been pursuing a ``soft-landing'' approach for the economy in which interest rates are used to slow growth enough to ease inflationary pressures but not enough to tip the country into a recession. Many analysts believe that approach is working and that the Fed is unlikely to change course even with a new vice chairman appointed by Bush. ``The Fed isn't closely divided now where one vote in either direction would make much of a difference,'' said Lyle Gramley, a former Fed governor and now chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association. The White House would not discuss possible successors, but Deputy White House press secretary Alixe Glen said the administration believed Johnson had ``done a terrific job.'' Bush will may either name someone new to the board and designate that person vice chairman or select one of the other governors as vice chairman while appointing someone to fill Johnson's board term, which runs until Aug. 21, 2000. There was speculation that David Mullins, appointed to the Fed earlier this year, might be considered for the vice chairman's job. Mullins, one of the authors of the savings and loan bailout legislation, had been a top assistant to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Others mentioned as possible candidates for appointment were Wendy Gramm, head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and wife of Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas; John Taylor, a member of the president's Council of Economic Advisers; and Treasury Under Secretary Robert Glauber. ``The administration is likely to choose someone out of the same mold as Mullins,'' said David Jones, author of a book on the Federal Reserve and chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. ``He will be a pro-administration Republican with an academic background.'' Johnson had once been considered a top candidate to become Fed chairman if the administration chose not to reappoint Greenspan next year. Johnson said at a news conference that he fully backed the reappointment of Greenspan and that policy disagreements were not a factor in his decision to step down. While past Fed governors have cited the low pay as a reason for resigning, Johnson said his $82,500 salary was not a factor in his decision. ``The main reason I decided to step down is that I have spent 10 consecutive years in public service,'' he said. ``Ten years is long enough.'' Johnson was appointed to the Fed by President Reagan on Feb. 7, 1986, and was elevated to vice chairman six months later. He said his resignation would be effective at the end of his four-year term as vice chairman. ``I am extremely proud to have played a part in the unprecedented period of sustained economic growth and low inflation that has characterized the decade of the 1980s and continues into the 1990s,'' Johnson said in his letter of resignation. Johnson said he planned to return to George Mason University in Washington's Virginia suburbs and assume the Koch Chair in international economics and become director of the Center for Global Market Studies. He was a professor at the school in 1981 when he was selected to join the economics team assembled by then-Treasury Secretary Donald Regan in Reagan's first term. ``I deeply regret, but understand, Manley Johnson's decision,'' Greenspan said in a statement. ``The vice chairman and I have been an effective team. I'll miss him.'' The Fed, the nation's central bank headquartered in Washington, is run by the board of governors and a nationwide network of 12 district banks. The governors are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate to serve 14-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: Iacocca Staying as Chairman; But for How Long is a Question
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca will stay on as head of the financially struggling automaker after his contract expires in 1991, the company said Thursday. ``There's a battle raging and I'm not going to leave my troops in the field,'' he said in a statement after Chrysler's board meeting in New York. It was unclear how long he would remain as Chrysler's chairman and chief executive officer or how much it would cost the nation's third-biggest automaker to keep him, company spokesman A.C. Liebler said. Keeping Iacocca, 65, appears to be a stopgap move inspired by last week's resignation of Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald, Iacocca's hand-picked successor. ``He has just said that until he and the board determine together that the company can continue to be equally effective without his personal day-to-day involvement, he will stay around,'' Liebler said. ``One other thing is to put a succession plan in place,'' he added. A year ago, Iacocca told Greenwald that the chairmanship ``was yours to lose.'' But on May 31, it was announced Greenwald had resigned to spearhead a three-union bid to buy United Airlines for $4.54 billion. Iacocca, who loves the limelight, has waffled recently on whether he would step down as chairman in December 1991 when his contract expires. Unlike other auto company chairmen, Iacocca regularly appears in television commercials and in print advertising, unabashedly touting Chrysler and the United States. He has written two books, ``Iacocca: An Autobiography,'' of which millions of copies were sold, and ``Talking Straight.'' He once made a guest appearance on the television show ``Miami Vice,'' and markets wine produced at his Italian estate. Even if Greenwald had taken over as chairman, Iacocca had been expected to remain on the company's board of directors and play a large role in the company's future. Some analysts speculated that Iacocca's continued presence might be one reason Greenwald quit. Less than 24 hours after Greenwald's resignation, Chrysler announced that Robert S. Miller, the company's chief financial officer, would take over Greenwald's title and most of his duties. Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz got the rest of the duties, but no new title. The changes prompted immediate speculation that Iacocca might seek a new contract after 1991, since neither Miller, 48, nor Lutz, 58, appeared ready to become chairman in 18 months. The extension of Iacocca's tenure as chairman buys time for Chrysler to groom one of them or find another heir for Iacocca. Greenwald was the highest-ranking of three executives who announced in May they would quit Chrysler. Michael Hammes resigned as vice president for international operations to head up hand tool operations at Black & Decker Corp., the Towson, Md.-based household products manufacturer, and Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman said he will quit sometime this summer. The drain on Chrysler's executive force began last October when the company started a $1.5 billion cost-cutting program that will result in a white-collar work force reduction of more than 2,500 people. Chrysler reported its first-quarter earnings were down 80 percent from last year to $71 million, and analysts have predicted there won't be any upturn until at least the fourth quarter. Chrysler's sales also have taken a dive. Through the first five months of this year, Chrysler's car and truck sales were down nearly 13 percent compared with last year. Iacocca signed a four-year contract with the automaker in 1987. He joined Chrysler in 1979 after being fired as president of Ford Motor Co. by the late Henry Ford II. Iacocca's most lucrative year as chairman was in 1986 when he received $20.5 million in compensation. His average annual compensation since 1985 was $11.5 million. He received $4 million for last year. The company's 1990 proxy statement says Iacocca will receive 191,250 shares of Chrysler stock this coming Nov. 2 and another 63,750 shares after Dec. 8, 1991. At recent prices, the stock would have a combined value of $4.1 million. Iacocca's colossal compensation wasn't the only thing that put the son of Italian immigrants into the news during the last decade. His name has popped up occasionally as a potential Democratic presidential candidate, and he made news when he collided with the Reagan administration over funding for the Statue of Liberty restoration. He is engaged to be married for a third time after a stormy divorce that ended an 18-month marriage to his second wife, Peggy Johnson. Mary Iacocca, his first wife of 26 years, died in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Rally Runs Out of Energy in Oil Pits
DOC.TEXT: Renewed selling stalled a rally in energy futures Thursday and oil prices closed lower. Energy analysts said buyers flocked to oil futures in the early going, building on the momentum begun in Wednesday's session. The recent steep price slide encouraged buyers looking for bargains. But the technical rally ran out steam in later trading once sellers resumed unloading contracts. The contract July delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, closed at $16.67 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, losing 25 cents. That more than wiped out Wednesday's 24-cent gain. Later months also posted declines. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for July delivery, which moved 0.54 cent higher on Wednesday, fell 0.75 cent a gallon to 57.61 cents. Contracts for later delivery ended lower also. The July contract for home heating oil dropped 0.41 cent to 46.90 cents a gallon after gaining 0.20 cent Wednesday. Subsequent months also skidded. James R. Fiedler, an energy broker at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said the technical buying lacked any fundamental support so the rally fizzled. He said an abundance of crude oil continues to weigh on the market. In natural gas trading, the July contract increased to $1.573 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.560 on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Fell $804.8 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 504 money market mutual funds fell $804.8 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline, to $380.73 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $121.1 million increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The funds' assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 241 general purpose funds increased $1.01 billion to $130.30 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds dropped $1.34 billion to $158.28 billion, and assets of 161 institutional funds fell $475.3 million to $92.14 billion. ``Short term interest rates were stable last week, but buoyant stock and bond markets drained some assets out of money market funds and into long-term funds,'' said Jacob Dreyer, chief economist at the institute. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.67 percent from 7.68 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield rose to 7.69 percent from 7.68 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, up from 43 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.20 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained unchanged at 5.06 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.94 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.96 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.14 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.16 percent; 8.15 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.18 percent; and 8.22 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.24 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Plans to Sell 20 TWA Jets
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines Chairman Carl Icahn has disclosed plans to sell 20 Boeing 727s in what union officials called another scare tactic in his bid to gain concessions from pilots. Icahn has promised to modernize TWA's fleet if pilots take 10 percent pay cuts and agree to other concessions that would save $80 million a year. He has threatened to shrink or dismantle the troubled carrier if they refuse. Kent Scott, chairman of the TWA branch of the Air Line Pilots Association, said Wednesday that Icahn may only be trying to get rid of the old, relatively inefficient jets to make room for more modern ones such as European-made Airbuses. ``Of course, he wouldn't let us in on that,'' Scott said. ``He'd make it look like a liquidation to put more pressure on us.'' Thomas Albrecht, an analyst for A.G. Edwards, said he also doubted that the sale of the planes was the beginning of a dismantling of the airline. He said Icahn would probably make no drastic changes as long as he still saw a chance of selling the entire airline to employees or an outside buyer. ``I've got to believe that if he was going to shrink the airline, he wouldn't be doing it now,'' Albrecht said. ``He still wants to keep it attractive.'' The plan to sell the jets was disclosed this week when Icahn sent out solicitations for bids to Avmark, an airline marketing and consulting company. The current plan is different from earlier sales, analysts say. TWA has sold 21 other jets since December in deals that generated about $580 million in proceeds. All but two of those jets were leased back to the airline, however. The current sale of jets is apparently an attempt to eliminate the 727s from the carrier's 210-jet fleet. ``It does not look like a sale-lease-back type of arrangement,'' said Paul Turk, an analyst for Avmark. TWA and other airlines have been selling and leasing back jets to capitalize on a strong market for used aircraft. Used 727s of the type that TWA is selling have been bringing anywhere from $6.5 million to $12 million, Turk said. TWA could replace the 727s by leasing or buying some of the 100 Airbus A320s once destined for Braniff Inc., which went bankrupt last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Given Permission to Pay Salaries, Expenses
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge Thursday authorized Greyhound Lines Inc. to pay salaries and operating expenses after union attorneys made sure the strike-bound bus company's executives would not receive ``golden parachute'' bonuses. A top Greyhound executive said after Thursday's hearing that ``illegal strike-related violence'' forced the company to file Monday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. At the hearing, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Richard S. Schmidt ordered the U.S. Trustee's office to start setting up a single committee of unsecured creditors. He set the next hearing for June 28 in McAllen. Dallas-based Greyhound, the nation's largest bus transportation company, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday to keep buses operating through the peak summer travel season. The company has been hurt financially since a walkout three months ago by its 6,300 bus drivers. ``We have been given the ability to use cash to continue to operate our business in the ordinary course,'' George W. Hanthorn, vice president and general counsel for Greyhound, said after the hearing. He said the judge's order on operating expenses and an order Monday allowing pre-bankruptcy tickets to be honored would keep the buses rolling. Greyhound will have about 3,800 buses on the road at any given time, he said. ``Our customers will not see any change in the business as we have been operating,'' Hanthorn told reporters. Hanthorn blamed strike-related violence for the bankruptcy filing. ``Greyhound has spent literally millions of dollars in legal fees, excess security costs, etcetera, to try to combat the illegal violence that we face during the strike and I attribute it exactly to that,'' he said. Smith Williamson, secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Locals, rejected Hanthorn's contention. ``There's been a comedy of errors by (Greyhound chairman) Fred Currey. He figured the strike would be over in three days and it didn't work,'' Williamson said Thursday. ``Currey has to manufacture some reason why he's in this position now, so he's laying the blame at the feet of the union.'' Since the strike began, there have been dozens of incidents of shooting and rock-throwing at buses. Early in the strike, a picketer was crushed by a bus in California. Attorneys for Greyhound and the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Locals spent part of Thursday morning negotiating how Greyhound intended to pay $2.5 million in salaries and up to $27 million in other employee vacation, medical and workers' compensation benefits. The main sticking point was the $2.5 million in pre-bankruptcy wages and salaries, including paychecks issued but not yet cashed. Negotiators agreed to limit pre-filing wage payments to $2,000 per employee. ``I just didn't want any golden parachutes adopted that would be weighted in favor of Greyhound executives and against the wage earner,'' said union attorney Shelby Jordan. Golden parachutes are contract provisions that grant severance payments to top executives if they lose their jobs in a change of control at their company. Asked whether he intended to seek a trustee to manage Greyhound, Jordan said he had no ``plots or plans'' to ask the bankruptcy court to take any drastic steps, and was waiting to see how Greyhound handled the bankruptcy. Left unresolved is whether the company will have to pay back wages to striking workers in an unfair labor practices claim set to be litigated before the National Labor Relations Board in Washington this fall. Judge Schmidt approved Greyhound's requests to pay $2 million in accumulated COD payments owed to various shipping customers, and to honor pre-filing deposits for charter trips. Court documents indicate Greyhound's largest unsecured creditors are financial services and insurance companies. But a list of debt holders stretches out over 1,800 pages, ranging from junk bond holders to parts and tire suppliers. Schmidt also allowed the company to file a single disclosure statement for all six Greyhound entities involved in the bankruptcy. The courtroom was packed with 18 attorneys for various parties in the case, including Greyhound, the union and creditors. The preliminary order allowing operating expenses lasts until the June 28 hearing. Schmidt also allowed the company to hire the Houston law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges as its lead counsel. An hour before the hearing, Greyhound announced it was withdrawing a tender offer for junk bonds. ``We have withdrawn our tender offer so that we can focus on mapping out a sound debt restructuring plan for the court,'' said J. Michael Doyle, senior vice president and financial officer. On May 21, Greyhound asked holders of $225 million of its junk bonds to sell them back at steep discounts, totaling about $90 million. The company said the move was crucial to avoid the bankruptcy filing. The offer was to expire June 18. Greyhound attorneys said they filed in Brownsville because its Eagle Bus Manufacturing Inc. subsidiary is based in the South Texas city.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Falls, Dollar Mostly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices fell Thursday, briefly reaching their lowest levels in four years as traders lost interest in buying the metal. Meanwhile, the dollar was mostly higher against other major currencies in uninspired trading. Gold, which has slumped in recent months, has become increasingly unattractive to investors. Producer selling also contributed to Tuesday's decline, said David Ryan, chief bullion trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Bullion fell $2.80 to $354.60 a troy ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $353.60 a troy ounce, down $3.15 from late Wednesday. Earlier, prices tumbled overseas with gold falling to a low of about $351.50 in mid-morning London trading. That was the lowest level for the metal in nearly four years. Prices recovered somewhat in Europe as Middle Eastern buyers began to buy heavily as gold reached its lows for the day. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $354.15 a troy ounce from $359.50 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $353 from $358.60 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $5.75 to close at a bid $355.67. Silver fell in London to a late bid price of $5.01 a troy ounce, down from $5.085 late Wednesday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver slipped 1.7 cents to close at $5.013 a troy ounce. The dollar was mixed in lackluster trading. Ronald Holzer, chief foreign exchange dealer, Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said the market was waiting to see what fallout there might be from the upcoming German monetary unification, and was also waiting to see whether the Federal Reserve would adjust its credit policy. The dollar began its day in Tokyo, falling 0.05 yen to a closing 152.55 yen. Later, in London, it also was quoted at 152.55 yen, and in New York, it fell to 152.55 yen from 152.68 late Wednesday. In London, the British pound held steady at $1.6880, but it gained ground against the dollar in New York, rising to $1.6895 from $1.6875 on Wednesday.
