Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6913 West German marks, up from 1.6870; 1.4385 Swiss francs, up from 1.4280; 5.6993 French francs, up from 5.6870; 1.9028 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8980; 1,244.25 Italian lire, up from 1,241.00; and 1.1678 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1723.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: Precious metal futures prices fell Thursday on New York's Commodity Exchange, with gold prices approaching four-year lows. On other markets, energy futures resumed a slide; grain and soybean futures were higher; and livestock and pork futures were mixed. Gold traders reacted to overnight selling by the Japanese and traders in the Middle East by selling. Traders said gold prices approached their lowest levels since mid-1986. ``This is the third time in as many months that the Arabs have sold gold,'' said Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst Jim Steel. Steel said Middle East investors are shifting portfolios out of gold into other financial instruments, including sterling and U.S. treasury bonds, because of rising interest rates. Adding to pressure on gold were fears the Soviet Union again will enter the market and sell gold to pay for imports. Gold settled $2.80 to $3.40 lower with the contract for delivery in June at $354.60 a troy ounce; silver was 1.7 cents to 2.3 cents lower with June at $5.013 a troy ounce. Energy futures, after trading higher for most of the day, finished lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market rose at the start of trading as investors continued to take advantage of low prices, said Randolph Donney, an energy analyst with Merrill Lynch. Reports that Exxon Corp.'s Bayway, N.J., refinery was back in business after a maintenance shutdown triggered a sell-off, he said. Exxon later announced it was resuming product shipments from the plant, but production of finished products would not resume until the end of June. Analysts attributed market nervousness to overproduction by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and to a large build-up of gasoline, distillate and crude oil stocks. West Texas Intermediate crude was 19 cents to 26 cents lower with July at $16.67 a barrel; heating oil was .21 cent to .41 cent lower with July at 46.90 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .60 cent to 1.25 cent lower with July aat 57.61 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures were higher on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn futures led the advance, as adverse weather conditions continue to influence the market. There was more rain in the southern Midwest crop areas, increasing the prospects for a smaller than anticipated U.S. corn crop this year, said Susan Leighty, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Soybean prices were boosted by strong corn futures and concern about planting delays. But the jump in soybean futures was limited by speculation that some intended corn acreage will be switched to soybeans if the southern Midwest dries out by mid-June. Corn takes longer to mature than soybeans. Wheat futures gained on concerns the wet weather has lowered the quality and quantity of the winter crop and is delaying harvesting, Leighty said. Wheat prices also received a boost from word the U.S. Agriculture Department has targeted the Soviet Union for 2 million metric tons of export bonus wheat. Wheat was 1\ cents to 3\ cents higher with July at $3.34} a bushel; corn was 4} cents to 9{ cents higher with July at $2.85{ a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 3 cents higher with July at $1.49\ a bushel; soybeans were 8} cents to 11{ cents higher with July at $6.02} a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .03 cent to .10 cent higher with June at 75.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .53 cent lower with August at 85.10 cents a pound; hogs were .10 cent to 1.23 cents lower with June at 64.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to 1.35 cents higher with July at 67.40 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Government Investigating Norton Deal
DOC.TEXT: The federal government will investigate whether the proposed merger between Norton Co., a U.S. manufacturer with defense contracts, and a French company raises national security concerns, it was announced Thursday. Executives announced the $1.8 billion merger between Norton and France's Compagnie de Saint Gobain this spring, thwarting a hostile bid made by a British company, BTR PLC, for Worcester-based Norton. When BTR was fighting for control of Norton, Massachusetts politicians said they would try to block the bid because Norton's technology should be protected. But when Saint Gobain, one of the world's leading glass makers, came forward to rescue Norton with a friendly tender offer, government officials said the deal might have to come under the same review. With the news of the investigation Thursday, Norton's stock dropped $1.50 a share to $87.87{ in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Norton is a leading manufacturer of abrasives and engineering materials that has defense contracts with the U.S. government. The company, with 1989 sales of $1.5 billion, employs 16,000 people and operates 113 plants worldwide. Tom Ryan, a spokesman for Saint Gobain, said the company learned of the decision to proceed with the investigation from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States. ``We certainly knew it was a possibility,'' Ryan said. ``Our position is there should not be any problems.'' The investigation is scheduled to last 45 days. The $90-per-share tender offer was scheduled to expire Friday, but Saint Gobain has extended it to June 27. So far, 41.4 percent of Norton's outstanding shares of common stock have been tendered. Ryan said many shareholders appear to be waiting a decision from the federal government.

DOC.HEAD: Two Measures Decline
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended May 28, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,258.6 billion from $3,266.4 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,052.6 billion from $4,063.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $803.7 billion from $806.9 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 3.5 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.1 percent, below the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,268.0 billion, a 4.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,065.2 billion, up 1.6 percent, while M1 rose 4.6 percent to an average of $805.7 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $172 million, compared with a decline of $1.157 billion a week earlier. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $442 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $924 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $401 million in the two weeks ended May 30, down from $645 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $305.0 billion in the two-week period ended May 30, down from $306.0 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Louisiana, Texas Plants Release Most Toxic Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: Plants in the petrochemical and industrial belts of Louisiana and Texas release the most toxic industrial chemicals, but pockets of significant toxic pollution exist across the nation, a private group said Thursday. ``Nearly every state in the nation has become a dumping ground for toxic chemicals by the nation's largest manufacturers,'' said Robert Brandon, vice president of Citizen Action. Citizen Action, a Washington-based environmental and consumer group, said that Jefferson Parish and St. Charles Parish in Louisiana and Sedgwick County in Kansas had the largest releases of toxic industrial chemicals in 1988. All three areas have major chemical companies and industrial plants that use large amounts of solvents. The organization used statistics published earlier this year by the Environmental Protection Agency, compiled from annual reports by industrial plants to the agency. According to the EPA, 4.6 billion pounds of toxic chemicals were released by industry into the air, water and into the ground in 1988, the latest year for which data were available. The EPA has said it could not estimate the resulting health risks because it has no information on the extent of human exposure to the chemicals. Citizen Action gave the total as 6.2 billion pounds. The group included 1.6 billion pounds sent away for disposal or to municipal treatment facilities. The EPA does not consider the 1.6 billion pounds to have been released into the environment. Of the total releases cited by Citizen Action, about half of the chemicals were released in 10 states: Louisana, Texas, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Tennessee, Michigan, California, Pennsylvania and Florida. Major toxic polluters, however, were found in many parts of the country. The Eastman Kodak Co., was the second largest source of cancer-causing emissions, the group said. Its complex of plants in Rochester, N.Y., released more than 9.7 million pounds of cancer-causing chemicals. The company in the past has said the releases are not a health hazard. The 3M Corp., a Minneapolis-based manufacturer of a variety of products such as recording tape and sandpaper, led the list of companies releasing chemicals that may be linked to birth defects. It released 53 million pounds of such chemicals, including 16 million pounds from a plant in Hutchinson, Minn., the group said. Rick Renner, a 3M Corp. spokesman, said the company has an extensive pollution control effort underway and the 1988 figures do not reflect new controls as some of the company's factories. ``Our emissions will be down substantially this year,'' he said. Sedgwick County in Kansas, containing Wichita, was the third most polluted county on the list largely because of Vulcan Chemicals, which has a plant there, and the widespread use of solvents at a Boeing Co. plant. Vulcan's releases are mostly through the injection of chemical wastes into deep wells. Industry says such releases are a safe disposal method, but environmentalists say they could threaten groundwater. Southern California ranked high on emissions largely because of a concentration of petrochemical, plastics, aerospace and other industrial plants, the environmental group said. Citizen Action is a Washington-based federation of consumer and environmental groups in 27 states and claims more than 2 million members. Spokesmen for the Chemical Manufacturers Association simply noted that the Citizen Action report was based on data that had been made public previously. The industry group in the past has acknowledged that toxic releases from chemical plants are too high and says its member companies are working to reduce them.

DOC.HEAD: Government Spends More Than Double To Fight Dollar Rise In Feb.-April Period
DOC.TEXT: The government boosted its efforts to stem the dollar's rise against the Japanese yen from February through April, but by the end of the quarter it was market sentiment that actually stopped the climb, the Federal Reserve said Thursday. The Fed and the U.S. Treasury sold $1.78 million in the three months ended April 30, nearly 90 percent of it to buy yen, the Fed said in its quarterly foreign exchange report. The remaining $200 million was used to buy West German marks. In the previous three months, October through January, the government spent $750 million intervening in currency markets, all of it to buy yen. Although purchases more than doubled in the latest quarter, it was ``far, far lower than the earlier three-month period last year,'' Sam Y. Cross, a Fed executive vice president who released the report at a press conference. The government's purchases last year included a record $11.92 billion in yen and marks during the three months ended July 31 and $5.871 billion in the following three months. The dollar rose 10 percent against the yen during the February-April period this year while declining by less than 0.5 percent against the mark. The dollar saw its steepest climb of the period against the yen from late February through early April. The climb subsided as the market awaited the April 7 meeting of financial officials from governments of the so-called Group of Seven leading industrial nations, the Fed said. Also, in April, the market came to view the Bank of Japan's 1 percent increase in its discount rate as sufficient to lessen downward pressure on the yen. Then, the Japanese stock and bond markets began to recoup some of their losses, according to the report. The dollar hit a low for the period of 143.6 yen on Feb. 19, but began to rally after election victories for the Liberal Democratic Party in Japan and predictions that interest rates outside Japan could rise, further weakening the yen. The government sold $650 million to buy yen between February 23 and March 2. Also, fears that German inflation would accelerate due to the pending currency union between East and West Germany strengthened the dollar against the mark. It reached 1.7237 marks on March 1. Between March 5 and March 27, the Treasury sold $830 million to buy yen and sold $200 million for marks. The purchases were made by the U.S. Treasury as the Fed temporarily put its intervention program on hold. The Fed and Treasury normally split the funds used for intervention. The temporary halt in intervention came after some Fed officials said they were concerned that high amounts of purchases like those in 1989 could cause doubts about the Fed's commitment to curbing inflation, according to the report. The government's currency-intervention programs can have the unintended effect of increasing the supply of dollars and some feared inflation could result. Furthermore, the Fed's holdings of foreign currencies were approaching the $21 billion authorized by the Federal Open Market Committee. The Fed decided to stop making purchases until the committee's March 27, meeting where an additional $4 billion in holdings were authorized. Also, the FOMC decided to retain tight-money policies. The government intervened twice more, on March 28 and April 9, selling $50 million for yen each time.

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood Stars Make Up for Glitches at New Florida Park
DOC.TEXT: Jaws failed to terrify boaters and King Kong swung from a bridge only sporadically, but Universal Studios opened its $630 million attraction Thursday to an enthusiastic crowd with 50 Hollywood stars in their eyes. ``Isn't he cute, isn't he short and cute,'' teen-ager Marla Working said of Michael J.Fox, one of the stars brought in for inaugural ceremonies at the combination theme park and film-production center. Even as Universal Studios Florida was being inaugurated, executives of parent companies MCA Inc. and Rank Organisation PLC, were announcing plans for similar theme parks in Europe and Japan and for a second gated attraction on the 444-acre property in Orlando. But few details were available on the future projects. Universal, which will compete with the nearby Disney-MGM Studios for some 13 million annual visitors to Central Florida, experienced opening day glitches with some of its major rides. The six-story tall Kongfrontation sound stage was closed to the general public because the six-ton steel-and-fur monster was able to go through his computer-activated terror routines only in stages. A program that melds all the segments into one smooth, hopefully frightening performance was inoperative, a company spokesman said. A similar problem afflicted the 24-foot killer shark Jaws. Technicians temporarily placed off limits a boat ride across the Amity Lagoon during which passengers are attacked by the computerized razor-toothed shark. A re-creation of a San Francisco earthquake for passengers aboard a subway train was only in partial operation, and actor Charlton Heston _ who starred in the movie ``Earthquake'' _ became the main attraction at that site. ``I think most of our visitors saw all the movie stars as a trade-off for the problems with the rides,'' said company spokesman Joe Curley. ``But we offered full refunds to anyone who was really put out by some of the rides being closed... We had only a few takers.'' Fox and Heston were joined by Bill Cosby, Linda Blair, Jimmy Stewart, Ernest Borgnine, Sissy Spacek and dozens of other stars. MCA President Sid Sheinberg praised park creator Jay Stein for turning ``swampland into dreamland'' and took note of the company's competitor down the road. ``Universal Studios Florida is the beginning of the symbiotic process of filmmaking and tourism in Florida,'' Sheinberg told some 1,500 invited guests to the inaugural ceremonies. Stein said there would be an announcement later this year about the new park's expansion plans, including a second gated attraction, for which tickets could be purchased separately. Sheinberg, who just returned from Europe, said he hoped an announcement could be made in two or three months about the selection of a new theme park site either in Paris or London. ``Personally, I'd like to see it in Britain,'' said Sir Patrick Meaney, Chairman of the Rank Organisation of London. But, he said, ``We are equally supported by both governments.'' Universal also plans a park in Japan with Nippon Steel. Universal Studios Florida has a capacity of about 40,000, but officials have said attendance would be held below 20,000, if necessary, for the first few weeks until the shakedown process for both personnel and the high-tech equipment is completed. Universal hopes to attract about 5 million visitors in its first year, and Stein told reporters that ``somewhere between 3 or 4 million people would put us in the black.''

DOC.HEAD: Wasserstein Perrella To Buy Maybelline Cosmetics From Schering-Plough
DOC.TEXT: Schering-Plough Corp. has agreed to sell its Maybelline cosmetics business for $300 million to an affiliate of the buyout specialists Wasserstein Perella, the companies said Thursday. At the same time, the pharmaceutical giant said it had terminated an earlier agreement to sell Maybelline for the same price to a group made up of Playtex Family Products Corp. and executives from Playtex and Maybelline. Wasserstein's announced purchase of Maybelline, the leading cosmetics manufacturer in the U.S. and Canada, came the same day it completed buying Yardley-Lentheric, a British cosmetics and toiletries business, for $185.4 million. Wasserstein executives characterized the two acquisitions as long-term investments, and said they planned to set up a holding company that would own and run both businesses. ``These companies are absolutely not'' for sale, said Robert B. McKeon, co-president of Wasserstein Perella Management Partners, Inc. An affiliate of its merchant banking arm, Wasserstein Perella Partners LP, made the purchase. A spokesman for MBP Acquisition Corp., the Playtex affiliate, refused to comment on why its April agreement to buy Maybelline fell apart. ``Playtex tried to get a price reduction on the April deal, so Schering-Plough turned to Wasserstein,'' who had earlier expressed an interest in Maybelline, said an executive who declined to be identified. Wasserstein said it is financing the deal without high-yield ``junk'' bonds. ``We're doing this with strictly a healthy dose of equity and bank debt,'' McKeon said. The final details of the financing have yet to be ironed out, but the mix would be about 30 percent equity and 70 percent bank debt, McKeon said. Wasserstein's purchase of Maybelline is contingent on routine government approval of all sales of companies over $100 million. Most of Schering's $300 million in cosmetics sales in 1989 were generated by Maybelline, a Schering spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Paramount Chairman Testifies About Boesky Pursuit
DOC.TEXT: Martin S. Davis, chairman of Paramount Communications Inc., testified Thursday that Ivan Boesky in 1985 doggedly pursued a leveraged buyout of Paramount's predecessor, Gulf & Western Industries Inc., and threatened a takeover fight. Despite repeated rejections, Boesky ``did not accept no as an answer,'' Davis said at the federal securities fraud trial of former Boesky associate John A. Mulheren Jr. ``The more we said no, the more he asked us to think about it, so in order to facilitate his leaving, we said we'd think about it,'' Davis testified under questioning from Assistant U.S. Attorney E. Scott Gilbert. Mulheren, 40, is accused of inflating the stock price of Gulf & Western to $45 in October 1985 by purchasing 75,000 shares to help Boesky make more money in selling his stake back to the company. Boesky, who previously testified at the trial, paid $100 million in penalties and pleaded guilty to one felony to settle the biggest insider trading case ever. In exchange, he gave government investigators incriminating information about several associates, including Mulheren. Davis said he first met with Boesky on Sept. 5, 1985, amid rumors and media reports that Boesky and others were contemplating a takeover of Gulf & Western after it sold off its manufacturing and textile holdings for $1 billion in cash. At the meeting, attended and arranged by investor Carl Icahn, Davis said Boesky told him he held 4.9 percent of Gulf & Western's stock and proposed that Davis agree to a leveraged buyout at $50 per share. When Davis rejected the proposal as ``ridiculously low,'' Boesky said he would increase his holdings to 9.9 percent and then demand two seats on the company's board. Davis, then chairman of Gulf & Western, said his response to Boeksy's proposal was ``an emphatic no.'' He said Icahn also held 4.9 percent of the company's stock, but told him he was not a party to Boesky's proposal. At a second meeting, on Oct. 1, 1985, Davis said Boesky continued to persist in his leveraged buyout proposal, telling Davis he could personally earn $100 million to $200 million. Davis testified he told Boesky he had no interest in doing business with him, especially in a plan that he thought would disenfranchise shareholders. Boesky then offered to sell back his holdings in Gulf & Western at $45 per share, which was higher than its trading price on the New York Stock Exchange, Davis said. David testified that he said he would only buy back the stock at the market price. Davis said he had a telephone conversation with Boesky on Oct. 16, 1985, the night before Gulf & Western bought back all 6.7 million of Boesky's and Icahn's shares in the company. He said that during that conversation, Boesky reiterated his buyback offer of $45 per share, but that Davis rejected it because the stock closed that day at just above $44. The buyback took place on Oct. 17, when the price of the shares rose to $45, Davis said. Prosecutors claim Mulheren aided Boesky in boosting the price of the stock by purchasing 75,000 shares on Oct. 17. Davis also testified that Mulheren, at an Oct. 3, 1985, meeting, offered help in monitoring Boesky's activities in connection with Gulf & Western. Davis said he made some uncomplimentary statements about Boesky and that Mulheren ``certainly didn't disagree.'' In a later telephone conversation that took place before the buyback, Davis said Mulheren told him he didn't believe Boesky owned any Gulf & Western Securities. Davis said Mulheren never told him about his own purchase of the Gulf & Western stock. In addition to stock manipulation, Mulheren is charged with concealing ownership of other stocks to help Boesky cheat on taxes and evade federal securities laws.

DOC.HEAD: ConAgra To Buy Beatrice Co.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `ConAgra, an ...' to RECAST and INSERTS 1 graf after 15th graf, `Four years ...' to UPDATE with return for buyout investors; picks up 16th graf, `For the ...'
DOC.TEXT: ConAgra Inc. has agreed to buy Beatrice Co. for $1.34 billion in cash and stock in a deal that puts several of the nation's leading food brands on the same corporate shelf, the two companies announced Thursday. ``This is a major league acquisition,'' said Stephen Carnes, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. The deal completes the divestiture of Beatrice by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which bought the company _ then a huge foods and consumer products conglomerate _ in a $6.1 billion leveraged buyout in 1986. Since then, Beatrice has sold off most of its businesses but still retains such well-known food brands as Hunt's, Wesson, Manwich, Peter Pan, Snack Pak, Swiss Miss, La Choy, Swift Premium, Butterball, Eckrich, and Reddi-Wip. ConAgra, an Omaha-based company with annual sales of more than $15 billion, has a stable of brand names in the frozen food market as well as selling unbranded products such as animal feed and fertilizer. ``This is clearly a major strategic opportunity for ConAgra,'' said Charles M. Harper, ConAgra chairman and chief executive officer. ``One of ConAgra's most important long-term objectives has been to establish a strong sales and distribution system to the shelf-stable section of the grocery store,'' he said. ``Beatrice will fulfill that objective.'' Expansion-minded ConAgra last year lost a bidding war for poultry processor Holly Farms Corp., which was acquired by Tyson Foods Inc. in a $1.4 billion deal. ConAgra did pocket $50 million in termination fees and other expenses. The company sells food products under such brands as Healthy Choice, Banquet, Armour Classics, Morton, Chun King and Kid's Cuisine frozen foods; Armour processed meats and Country Pride chicken products. Under terms of the ConAgra-Beatrice agreement, ConAgra would buy Beatrice for $11.50 a share from Kohlberg Kravis partnerships and management investors. Beatrice would have 123.44 million shares outstanding assuming the exercise of warrants for its shares. The purchase transaction consists of approximately $626 million in cash, net of warrant proceeds, $355 million in ConAgra common stock and $355 million in two series of ConAgra preferred stock _ a total of $1.34 billion, the companies said. The deal, which is subject to approval by federal regulators, was announced after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where ConAgra's stock rose 75 cents to $32 a share. ``We believe Beatrice offers long-term value to ConAgra and our stockholders,'' Harper said. ``We are also optimistic about near-term earnings prospects.'' Henry Kravis, a founding partner of Kohlberg Kravis, ``We are very excited about the combination of ConAgra Inc. and Beatrice Company. ``Four years ago, together with new management of Beatrice, we began the process of reshaping Beatrice from a diverse conglomerate into a focused and more profitable food company,'' he said. ``Today's announcement marks the successful completion of this process.'' KKR said investors who put $420 million of equity into the Beatrice buyout reaped a total of about $2.2 billion from the selloff of its businesses, representing a compound annual rate of return of more than 50 percent. For the fiscal year ending Feb. 28, Beatrice reported earnings of $12 million on sales of $4.26 billion. The company reported it had trimmed its long-term debt to $987 million from $1.252 billion a year earlier. ConAgra had sales in excess of $15 billion for the fiscal year that ended May 27. Its earnings statement is expected to be released later this month. Beatrice was one of the nation's biggest food and consumer products conglomerates, owning product lines that included Coca-Cola bottlers, Hunt-Wesson foods, Swift-Eckrich meats, Stiffel lamps, Samsonite luggage, Tropicana juices, Max Factor cosmetics and the Avis car rental agency. The 1986 buyout led by Kohlberg Kravis at the time was the biggest leveraged buyout ever, and one of the largest non-oil company takeovers of all time. After the deal, Beatrice began selling most of its businesses to pay off the buyout debt and generate a return for investors who put up money for the deal. Avis was sold to a group led by its employees; Tropicana to Seagram Co. Ltd.; Beatrice's international food businesses to the investment firm TLC International; and a score of other companies to a group led by former Beatrice Chairman Donald P. Kelly.

DOC.HEAD: Hitachi Announces Development of 64-Megabit Memory Chip
DOC.TEXT: Hitachi Ltd., a leading Japanese electric machinery maker, said it has produced the first prototype of a 64-megabit memory chip. The company said the development of the dynamic random access memory chip puts it in the lead in the race to produce future generations of memory chips, which are used in products ranging from computers to compact disc players. The tiny circuits etched in the semiconductor chip are only 0.3 microns, or millionths of a meter, wide. The chip can hold about 64 million binary units of information, enough to hold the equivalent of 512 English newspaper pages or one hour of music recorded on compact discs, Hitachi spokesman Takafumi Ichinose said Thursday. ``That should lead to the development of a variety of new products,'' he said. Hitachi expects to begin marketing the chip in 1995, he said. Each generation of memory chips is generally replaced by a new generation with four times as much capacity every three years. The most advanced DRAM chips currently being marketed have a capacity of four megabits.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Trial Date in Mammoth Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: Defendants in the securities case against American Continental Corp. and its Lincoln Savings and Loan unit have until next April 1 to decide if they will testify at the trial, a federal judge ruled Thursday. The ruling came despite the protests of a lawyer for New York financier Michael R. Milken, who claimed Milken's own legal situation would make it impossible for him to decide whether to testify in that time frame. U.S. District Judge Richard M. Bilby, chief judge for the Arizona District, also set a Sept. 30, 1991, trial date and said he would hear the case in Tucson. The judge disposed of a series of motions, heard an update on the case's 32 million-document depository, and ordered an attorney for the federal Office of Thrift Supervision to ferret out OTS employees who may have abused attorney-client privilege in denying documents to American Continental lawyers. American Continental, which bought Lincoln in February 1984, triggered a rash of suits and countersuits when it filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of federal Bankruptcy Code on April 13, 1989. The next day, the forerunner of the OTS took control of Lincoln. Not long after, about 23,000 investors claimed that officers of the holding company or Lincoln misled them into buying more than $200 million in junk bonds by passing them off as sound investments. The class action was filed in federal court in Los Angeles. It has been transferred to Bilby's court and combined with the bankruptcy filing and a Resolution Trust Corp. racketeering suit against American Continental chairman Charles Keating Jr. and other American Continental insiders under the blanket term of Multi District Litigation. In addition, Keating, who has maintained that federal regulators caused the $2 billion Lincoln failure by taking over a healthy thrift, has filed two suits in U.S. District Court in Washington. One seeks to set aside the conservatorship of Lincoln; the other is a $300 million personal-damages suit against federal officials. Bilby said he would investigate the allegation of Michael Kennedy, an American Continental attorney, that the OTS had withheld documents that the company needs in its suit by claiming the files were privileged. Kennedy said non-lawyers, who do not have the right to claim a professional privilege, have classified the documents as privileged. ``I want you to tell me, sooner rather than later, who did it,'' Bilby told OTS attorney Donald Wall. Bilby set an April 1 deadline for defendants to decide if they will invoke the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. He said anyone indicted from now until mid-February would have 45 days after indictment to make the same decision. Milken is a defendant in the class-action suit through his defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert investment-banking firm, which underwrote many of American Continental's and Lincoln's securities. Milken pleaded guilty in April to six felony counts and paid a record $600 million fine. He is to be sentenced Oct. 1. Because of his legal problems, Milken is not in a position to meet the April 1 deadline to decide if he will testify at the trial, argued David L. Kornblau, a New York lawyer for Milken. Kornblau also argued that Milken was a peripheral figure in the Keating case, prompting Bilby to quip, ``If he has such a small part in this case, this (decision) can't be any problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Signs $5 Million Phone Deal for Hungary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. has signed a $5 million contract to provide cellular telephones to Hungary, the company said. Motorola said Wednesday the deal makes it the first company to supply mobile phones in Eastern Europe. Motorola's British subsidiary said it would deliver the phone equipment over the next two years to Hungarian Radiotelephone Ltd., a joint venture between Hungarian Telecommunications, previously Magyar Posta, and U S West International. The joint venture currently is installing a cellular network in Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Reportedly Chooses Motorola Design for New Cellular System
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese government has chosen American technology as the technical standard for a new generation of digital cellular telephones, a newspaper reported. The decision, made Wednesday but due to be announced formally on Thursday, may make it easier for American companies to supply equipment in Japan, The New York Times said in an early edition of Thursday's paper. Current Japanese equipment isn't compatible with U.S. equipment, the newspaper said. Japan's Ministry of Post and Telecommunications selected a key digital cellular phone component designed by Motorola Inc., the company's vice president for digital product operations, Morton Stern, was quoted as saying. Motorola was selected in a close contest over competing designs offered by Japanese, European and American companies, a Japanese embassy official in Washington, who asked not to be identified, was quoted as saying. Although Motorola's standard was chosen, the design must be published and licensed to other companies free of charge under Japan's rules of competition, the newspaper said. The equipment will be used to convert Japan's cellular telephone system from analog transmission to digital transmission, which is capable of carrying a greater number of calls.
